summary:
According to an FBI affidavit, photographs on Rasha Abual-Ragheb’s phone placed her inside the Capitol building on the day of the attack. A Capitol Police officer who looked at the photograph confirmed to authorities that it was taken on the Senate side of the Capitol building.

According to the affidavit, a Facebook page the FBI has confirmed belonged to Abual-Ragheb in November 2020 showed her participating in Facebook and Telegram group chats with members of the New Jersey chapter of the American Patriot 3%, a far-right anti-government militia movement.

In one of those chats, a user whom the FBI believes was Abual-Ragheb said that a civil war was coming and that people needed to show support and rise up and fight for the Constitution. 

During an FBI interview, Abual-Ragheb allegedly told agents she was born in Lebanon and fled to Jordan when she was a child to escape the civil war there. She told agents she had been in the U.S. for 21 years and was a Trump supporter, attended his rallies and was blocked from Facebook and Twitter for some of her pro-Trump postings.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Abual-Ragheb pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 11/23/2021 to 36 months probation, the first 2 months as Home Detention; 60 hours community service; $10 assessment; $500 restitution

summary:
Daniel Adams went to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with his cousin Cody Connell. According to an FBI affidavit, video evidence places them squarely in the thick of the melee outside the Capitol building. At the beginning of one video, according to the affidavit, Adams repeatedly says to the crowds around him, “Let’s go. Are you ready to push?”  The affidavit cites another video that captures Adams struggling directly with officers. He and other members of the crowd push to make their way up the Capitol stairs. The video ends with a loud thud and cuts to Adams holding his head and swearing.

Adams has a criminal record going back to 2007, when he was found guilty and sentenced for “deadly conduct” in Chambers, County, Texas. He had an assault charge dismissed in 2020.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Adams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: Esyededeea Aesfyza, also known as Esyedepa Aefyga, was arrested on a curfew violation in Washington, D.C. There was a District-wide curfew that began at 6 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, and ended the next day at 6 a.m. According to court documents, a D.C. police officer saw Aesfyza and a handful of other individuals near the Peace Monument in Washington around 7:15 pm. They were asked to disperse three times, the court document said, and when they didn’t, officers placed them under arrest.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Dismissed - Nolle-Prosequi on 10/1/2021

summary:
According to court documents, Zachary Alam was allegedly part of the group on Jan. 6, 2021, that attempted to get inside the Speaker's Lobby, a group which included Ashli Babbitt, the woman who was shot and killed by U.S. Capitol Police.

In videos of the incident, there are police officers guarding the door to the Speaker's Lobby. In the video, the person the FBI has identified as Alam can be seen "repeatedly punching the glass panels of the doors immediately behind the officers, causing the glass to splinter," according to court documents. In the video, he allegedly pushes against one of the officers and shouts "f*** the blue" into their faces. The officers eventually move to the side, and Alam allegedly takes a helmet from another rioter and shatters the window that was already splintered and another one to the right. Babbitt was shot trying to climb through one of the shattered panes. 

Alam later told a relative that he was sorry for what he had done at the Capitol but was not going to turn himself in because "he did not want to go to jail again," according to court documents.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property Exceeding $1,000; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Alam pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Christopher Alberts was allegedly part of a crowd that D.C. Metropolitan Police officers tried to move off the Capitol grounds on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021. Metropolitan Police were trying to clear the streets by a 6 p.m. District-wide curfew. It was about 7 p.m. when officers encountered Alberts.

The arresting officer said in a statement to the court that Alberts was slow to respond to orders to leave when he noticed Alberts appeared to have a handgun strapped to his hip. “While pushing Alberts toward the line, I tapped the bulge with my baton and felt a hard object that I immediately recognized to be a firearm,” the officer said in his statement.

When the gun was discovered, the officer said. Alberts tried to flee. It is a crime to carry or have a dangerous weapon on Capitol grounds. 

According to court documents, Alberts was carrying a Taurus G2C 9mm handgun with one round in the chamber and a full 12-round magazine. He had an extra magazine in his pocket and was also carrying a gas mask and a first aid kit. 

Alberts told the officers that the gun was for personal protection and that he didn’t intend to use the firearm to harm anyone.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Ground with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Carrying a Pistol Without a License Outside Home or Place of Business; Possession of a Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device
case_updates: Alberts pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, Tommy Allan was arrested on charges of violent entry or disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building or grounds and theft of government property. Recordings of the riot, both from media and security cameras, show Allan taking government documents from a desk in the Senate chamber while carrying a Capitol flagpole. A law enforcement officer was able to stop the Rocklin, Calif., native from stealing the flag, but he left the premises with the papers, according to court documents.

Prosecutors allege that in a video posted on Facebook, Allan was heard saying the documents he took were from Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell's desk. He can also be heard saying that one of the papers he took was “a letter from Trump” and was “signed by Trump,” according to the complaint.  When someone off-camera asks him why he took the documents, Allan responds that he is a “taxpayer.”

A tipster who contacted the FBI alleged that Allan shared a Facebook post “that said the next step of the Insurrection was to get rid of Justice Roberts.”  According to prosecutors, another tipster reported that Allan took down his Facebook page and destroyed the documents he took from the Capitol in his backyard.
charges: Corruptly Altering, Destroying, Mutilating, or Concealing a Record, Document, or Other Object [cellphone and Facebook account]; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property [US flag and Senate documents]; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Allan pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 12/8/2022

summary:
Wilmar Alvarado talked with Fox 26 Houston after the U.S. Capitol attack and before boarding a flight back home to Texas. He confirmed he participated in what he called "protests" because he believes there was election fraud. In that same interview, Alvarado claimed he was pushed toward officers by the crowd, telling them, “I’m not part of this. I’m trying to get out.”   

According to the criminal complaint, Alvarado called the FBI and voluntarily confirmed that he was the individual pictured in FBI posters. He said he traveled to Washington alone and did not assault any officers. Alvarado also claimed he never went inside the Capitol building. But federal agents say a YouTube video by a user named "Status Coup" tells a different story. 

The video, titled "UNBELIEVABLE Footage | Trump Supporters Battle Cops Inside the Capitol," allegedly shows Alvarado alongside other rioters trying to "violently battle their way through a line of police officers" guarding an entrance to the Capitol, according to the complaint. 

Alvarado is a native of El Salvador and is the owner of a Salvadoran bakery-restaurant in Pasadena, Texas.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Montano Alvarado pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: Michael Amos was arrested for breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. D.C. Superior Court documents show Amos was charged with unlawful entry. Amos pleaded not guilty.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Diversion Successfully completed. Case Dismissed - Nolle Diversion January 25, 2022

summary:
Federal investigators say Stephen Ayres and two unidentified friends filmed a video in their hotel room to “share what really happened” at the Capitol building and posted it on YouTube following the riot. 

According to an FBI affidavit, at some point during the video, Ayres’ male friend claimed that “Antifa breached” the Capitol and that police “escorted” them into the building. He stated it was a “staged Antifa setup” coordinated by media, police and the mayor of Washington, D.C. In response, Ayers agreed that the entire incident was “definitely planned out,” according to the FBI report.

Court documents also cite a witness who contacted the authorities after allegedly watching a livestream Ayers broadcasted from his Facebook account. According to the witness, Ayers was acting “like he was at war.” The witness also said that at some point during the streaming video, Ayres stated that the incident at the Capitol was “just the beginning” and that there was “more to come next week.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ayres pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 9/13/2022

summary:
Stephen Baker recorded live footage under the alias “Stephen Ignoramus” during the protests at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Some media outlets have used his footage in news reports. 

Once inside, Baker is allegedly heard on tape saying: “All right, what’s up, y’all? How you guys doin’? Super-intense. Welcome, I am Stephen. I’m a livestreamer and a musician. We’re having fun, huh? Repent and believe in Jesus.” 

Baker also makes multiple references to members from the far-right groups The Red Elephants and Oath Keepers, identifying some of them by name, during his livestream. 

According to court documents, the FBI identified a profile page of a Washington, D.C., music store featuring Baker, on which he describes himself as a “multi-instrumentalist, composer, and business owner who studied music at Western Michigan University, before moving to the D.C. area.” The profile further states that Baker operates a recording/rehearsal studio in Hyattsville, Md., and that he has performed at venues including the 9:30 Club, the Howard Theatre, the Black Cat and Rock & Roll Hotel. 

Baker is also seen on video saying, “I was inside for like an hour, dude. I was one of like the last 10 people in there. ... I’m on Instagram and YouTube. I’m Stephen Ignoramus. I don’t matter though — this s*** is history.” 

A witness who was interviewed by the FBI stated that they’ve known Baker for about 10 years and were alarmed by the content of those videos, which included, according to the witness, the “advancement of conspiracy theories and mockery of minority groups.”
charges: Unlawful Entry in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baker pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 5/13/2022 to 24 months probation; 9 days intermittent incarceration; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
An FBI tip led investigators to a video that allegedly shows Dawn Bancroft, a gym owner, entering the Capitol building through a broken window as part of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. 

According to court documents, federal investigators reviewed a video in which Bancroft allegedly said, “We were looking for Nancy to shoot her in the friggin’ brain but we didn’t find her.” Investigators believe Bancroft was referring to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. 

In an interview with an FBI special agent, Bancroft confirmed that she climbed through a broken window to get inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 and knew she was entering restricted grounds.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bancroft pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/21/22 to 60 days incarceration, 3 years probation, 100 hours community service, $500 restitution, $10 special assessment

summary:
When Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt was fatally shot by police inside the U.S. Capitol, she fell backward onto Thomas Baranyi, according to court documents. 

In an interview with a Washington, D.C., television station, Baranyi, wearing a blue New York Giants sweatshirt and a backwards baseball hat, shows the camera blood on his hands and says: “It was a joke to them until we got inside and then all of a sudden, guns came out, but I mean, we’re at a point now, it can’t be allowed to stand. We have to do something. People have to do something, because this could be you or your kids."

In the TV interview, which is also detailed in the court documents, Baranyi says, “We tore through the scaffolding, through flash bangs and tear gas, and blitzed our way in through all the chambers just trying to get into Congress or whoever we could get in to and tell them that we need some kind of investigation into this.”

In July 2020, Baranyi enlisted in the Marine Corps, but according to the Marines, he "was separated prior to completing entry level training."

Baranyi served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Albania from January 2018 until March 2020, according to the Peace Corps.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baranyi pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/17/2022 to 90 days incarceration; 1 year of supervised release; $25 special assessment; $500 in restitution; 60 hours of community service

summary:
Richard Barnett, who goes by the nickname "Bigo," gained notoriety in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection after he was photographed sitting in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office with his feet propped on a desk. 

In a recorded interview with media outlets that same day, Barnett, who was wearing a plaid jacket without a shirt underneath, is seen holding an envelope addressed to Rep. Billy Long and with a digital signature from Speaker Pelosi, according to court documents. In the interview, Barnett says: “I did not steal it. I bled on it because they were Macing me... I put a quarter on her desk." He also left a note on the speaker's desk, according to court documents, which read “Nancy, Bigo was here, you b****.”

According to The Washington Post, Barnett has criticized Pelosi for considering the term “white nationalist” to be derogatory, allegedly posting on Facebook: "I am white. There is no denying that. I am a nationalist. I put my nation first. So that makes me a white nationalist."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property (an envelope which has a value of less than $1,000)
case_updates: Barnett pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
Robert Bauer traveled to Washington, D.C., from Kentucky with his wife, Jenna, to go to the Jan. 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally, according to court documents. They attended the rally with Bauer's cousin Edward Hemenway, who is also charged in connection with the Capitol insurrection.

In his speech, Trump told the crowd: "We're going to walk down to the Capitol, and we're going to cheer on our brave senators and congressmen and women and we're probably not going to be cheering so much for some of them." According to Bauer's statement to the FBI, the crowd began moving to the Capitol, and Bauer, along with Hemenway and his wife, marched there, too. Bauer reiterated to the FBI that he marched to the Capitol "because President Trump said to do so."

Bauer told the FBI that he entered the Capitol building with a crowd of others, while his wife stayed outside. He said he didn't think he had done anything wrong and had no intention of fighting anyone. After he entered the building, Bauer remembered meeting a police officer. According to Bauer in the court documents, the officer shook his hand and told him, "It's your house now." Bauer said he thought the officer was acting out of fear.

Bauer explained to the FBI that "people in the crowd were angry about pedophiles, the news cycle, and losing their businesses during the lockdown."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct at the Grounds and in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bauer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/14/2021 to 45 days of incarceration; 60 hours of community service; special assessment of $10.00; and restitution in the amount of $500.00.

summary:
According to court documents, Damon Beckley appears in a video taken during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. In the video, Beckley says that Mike Pence has the blood of the woman shot by U.S. Capitol Police on his hands. That woman was later identified to be Ashli Babbitt, who eventually died. In the video, Beckley, from Louisville, Ky., adds: "We're not putting up with this tyrannical rule. If we're going to come back here and start a revolution and take all of these traitors out, which is what should be done, then we will!"
 
On Dec. 10, 2020, Beckley registered a limited liability company called DC Under Siege with the Kentucky Secretary of State, according to state records and local news reports.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Beckley pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Andrew Bennett posted four videos to Facebook from outside and inside the Capitol building, according to court documents. He is seen in the videos wearing a baseball hat with a motto on it associated with the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group. 

In one video, he appears to yell "no destruction," but in another video, he allegedly chants "break it down" with the crowd, in reference to the door to the Speaker's Lobby, where U.S. Capitol Police later shot Ashli Babbitt, court documents indicate.  

Before the insurrection, Bennett "posted and shared conspiracy theorist material" on Facebook, according to the FBI. Court documents state that the FBI investigated Bennett's ties to the Proud Boys. "The FBI found that while Bennett attempted to contact a Maryland chapter of the Proud Boys about becoming a member," the documents state, "it did not find that Bennett is a member of or associate of any organized chapter of the Proud Boys."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bennett pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/1/2021 to 24 months Probation; 80 hours of community service; Special Assessment in the amount of $10; and $500 restitution

summary:
Victoria Bergeson is a registered nurse in Connecticut, according to state records. 

On Jan. 6, 2021, D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser ordered a 6 p.m. curfew in the district until the next morning. At around 7:15 p.m., Bergeson and a group of nearly two dozen others were arrested in the 100 block of First Street NW, near the U.S. Capitol building, after Metropolitan Police and Capitol Police issued multiple warnings to disperse. 

“People assume she’s part of that crazed mob,” Bergeson’s attorney told the Connecticut Post a few days after the riot. “She was never even close to the building ... I don’t think they can prove she knew she was on Capitol grounds.”
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 1/17/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Bryan Betancur is a self-professed white supremacist, according to court documents. 

The FBI affidavit for Betancur outlines a long list of violent statements he has allegedly made, including his professed desire to carry out a school shooting, run people over with a car, kill people in a church and be a "lone wolf killer." He has voiced support, according to the FBI, for the man convicted of killing Heather Heyer with his car during the 2017 Unite The Right rally in Charlottesville, Va. Betancur has reportedly said he has changed his mind about wanting to hurt people, according to the FBI.  

Betancur has previously been convicted of fourth-degree burglarly. He received permission from his parole officer's supervisor to leave Maryland on Jan. 6, 2021, in order to distribute Bibles with an organization, according to court documents. 

Betancur's court-ordered GPS monitoring device showed him in the vicinity of the Capitol for around three hours that afternoon, according to the FBI. Betancur also posted images of himself at the Capitol on social media, including a photo of himself holding a Confederate flag and another where he is wearing a Proud Boys shirt and flashing the “OK” hand signal, a white supremacist gesture that stands for "white power."

On Jan. 8, 2021, he called his parole officer and said he was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 and was paranoid about photographs people had taken of him. He later recanted that he was inside the Capitol, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Betancur pleaded Guilty to one charge, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentenced on 8/10/2022 to 4 months of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $500 restitution and $25 special assessment.

summary:
Joseph Randall Biggs is a member and an organizer of the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group, according to court documents. Biggs and other organizers encouraged members of their group to travel to Washington, D.C., for the Jan. 6, 2021, rally. On Dec. 29, 2020, Biggs posted a message on Parler, allegedly aimed at "antifa" according to the FBI: “We will be blending in as one of you. You won’t see us. You’ll even think we are you . . .We are going to smell like you, move like you, and look like you. The only thing we’ll do that’s us is think like us! Jan 6th is gonna be epic.”

Biggs served as a staff sergeant in the Army Reserve from 2004 to 2007 and in the active Army from 2007 to 2012. He deployed to Iraq from November 2005 until October 2006 and to Afghanistan from December 2007 to February 2009, according to the Army. He was awarded multiple decorations for his service, including the Purple Heart, the Army confirmed.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts)
case_updates: Biggs pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On the day of the Capitol insurrection, Craig Bingert, wearing a camouflage jacket and a beanie with the word "America" scrawled across it, was depicted on video grabbing a metal barricade outside the Capitol and pushing it toward the police officers blocking the mob's way, according to court documents. 

After the police barrier was broken, Bingert was later shown on video waving an American flag as the crowd chanted "f*** the police," according to court documents. 

Bingert was a cadet with the Pennsylvania State Police Academy for four days in September 2015 and resigned on his own accord, according to the academy.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Obstructing, or Impeding Passage Through or Within, the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings; Engaging in an Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Bingert pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Gina Bisignano is the owner of Gina's Eyelashes and Skincare in Beverly Hills, Calif. 

On Dec. 19, 2020, President Donald Trump tweeted: “Big protest in D.C. on January 6th. Be there, will be wild!” Bisignano replied to the tweet: "I'll be there." 

Bisignano ultimately felt compelled to go by Trump, according to an interview with The Beverly Hills Courier.  “Trump said, patriots, go to D.C.,” she told The Courier. “If enough patriots got together to rightfully assemble and put pressure, chant and cheer like we do, they would think, ‘Okay, we the people - we the people are speaking.’”

On Jan. 6, 2021, Bisignano was shown on video just outside the Capitol using a megaphone to speak to the rioters, according to court documents. She says, "Everybody, we need gas masks…we need weapons...we need strong, angry patriots to help our boys."

In another video, Bisignano says: “We the people are not going to take it any more...  You are not going to take away our votes. And our freedom, and I thank God for it. This is 1776, and we the people will never give up. We will never let our country go to the globalists. George Soros, you can go to hell.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bisignano pleaded Guilty to six charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building.

summary:
Joshua Black was photographed as part of a group of rioters who made it inside the Senate chamber. In the photos, he is wearing a camouflage jacket and yellow gloves and seems to be bleeding from his left cheek, according to court documents. 

Two days after the Capitol attack, he uploaded a video to YouTube detailing his account of the insurrection. "There was a glass door, and it said ‘U.S. Senate’ on it. I said I need to get in there," Black says in the video, which is detailed in the court documents, "So I was about to break the glass, and I thought, 'No, this is our house — we don’t act like that.' I was tempted to, I’m not gonna lie. 'Cause I’m pretty upset, you know? They stole my country.” Once inside the chamber, he says, he "praised the name of Jesus on the Senate floor."

More than 24 hours after the insurrection, then-President Donald Trump condemned the Capitol riot and called it a "heinous attack," in a video on social media. Black, in his own video, mentions seeing Trump's denunciation. "I guess the hopes of getting a pardon are out the window,” Black says.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Black pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: David Blair allegedly struck a Metropolitan Police Department officer with a lacrosse stick on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, on the west lawn of the U.S. Capitol building. Before he did so, he allegedly told officers to "quit being scared." When one officer pushed Blair with his baton, Blair said "what's up, motherf***er, what's up, what's up, b****?" according to footage from a body camera on the officer. According to court documents, Blair then thrust the lacrosse stick, which had a Confederate flag taped to it, at the officer's chest. Once handcuffed, Blair said, "I understand, what I did, the one motherf***er swung at me so I kinda switched ... so I apologize. We're done though." Blair also explained that he had a knife on him because he was "worried about Antifa and other people trying to jump me," according to court documents. Law enforcement later searched Blair's home and found a notebook with notes that seemed to be about Jan. 6 in it, including a note that simply said "Wasn't there for violence / or to overthrow." Blair is currently charged with a misdemeanor in D.C. Superior Court, but the federal government intends to dismiss that case in favor of federal charges, according to a criminal complaint.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Disorderly Conduct on Grounds or in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings (Federal); Assaulting a Law Enforcement Officer (DC)
case_updates: Blair pleaded Guilty to one federal charge: Civil Disorder. The other charges are dismissed. His DC charge was disposed of by nolle prosequi on March 11, 2021. Sentenced 7/13/2022 to 5 months incarceration; 18 months of supervised release; $100 special assessment; $2,000 restitution

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Matthew Bledsoe posted several videos and photos on his Instagram account showing the crowd approaching the Capitol, scaling its walls and eventually entering the building itself, according to court documents. In one video, Bledsoe trains the camera on a door to the Capitol and says, “In the Capitol. This is our house. We pay for this s***. Where’s those pieces of s*** at?” 

Bledsoe's wife also posted on Facebook soon after the riot: “Matt was inside the Capitol, he was one of the first. They yelled and screamed, that’s about it," she wrote, according to court documents. “My husband is a Patriot solider [sic]."

Bledsoe is the owner of Primetime Movers in Memphis, Tenn., according to business filings with the Tennessee secretary of state and local news reports.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bledsoe pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. At trial on 7/21/2022, a jury found him guilty on all charges. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 10/21/2022

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, James Bonet posted photos of himself to Facebook smoking marijuana in the Capitol building.

In an affidavit contained in court records, Bonet is identified as a shift manager at an unidentified business in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. His co-workers tipped off the FBI after they saw Bonet share a photo of himself smoking inside the Capitol Building. One of his co-workers said that Bonet “openly talks about government conspiracy theories at work” and regularly tries to persuade them “to subscribe to these theories including the conspiracy theory that the 2020 Presidential Election was ‘stolen’,” according to the court documents.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bonet pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/9/2022 to 90 Days Incarceration Followed By 1 Year Of Supervised Release; Special Assessment Of $25.00;  Restitution Of $500; 200 hours of community service

summary:
Larry Rendall Brock was among the group of rioters who made it to the Senate floor. In photographs, he can be seen in a "military-style helmet, tactical vest and holding flex-cuffs in his right hand," according to court documents. One witness who called the FBI was Brock's ex-wife, who had been married to him for 18 years and recognized him from the photos. She said, "I just know that when I saw this was happening, I was afraid he would be there."

In fact, it seems Brock was expecting a moment like Jan. 6, 2021, according to social media posts detailed in his court documents. On Dec. 24, 2020, he posted on Facebook that he had purchased body armor and a helmet "for the civil war that is coming." On Jan. 1, he wrote, "I suspect that this is what will happen on the 6th. The castle will be stormed. The question is what then?" On Jan. 6, he posted again: "Patriots on the Capitol," "Patriots storming," and "Men with guns need to shoot there [sic] way in," according to court documents. 

Brock was a lieutenant colonel and an A-10 pilot in the Air Force, serving on active duty from 1989 to 1998, according to the Air Force. He retired from the Air Force Reserves in 2014. 

“The President asked for his supporters to be there to attend, and I felt like it was important, because of how much I love this country, to actually be there,” Brock told The New Yorker in an interview. He also told the magazine that once he was at the Capitol building, he assumed he was allowed to enter.  

In 2018, Brock was fired from CAE SimuFlite Inc. because of "threatening and discriminatory speech," including saying to other employees that he "not killed anyone for a while," according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Captiol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Brock pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Jere Brower was with a group of people outside of the Capitol building around 7:15 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, after the city had imposed a 6 p.m. curfew. 

Brower told NPR in an interview that he came to Washington to support the president’s protests and says he believes that the election was stolen. He said he never entered the Capitol building during the rioting (and prosecutors have not alleged that he did) and said he condemned the violence that occurred that day.

A spokesperson for the U.S. Army confirmed that Brower had previously served, stating, "Pvt. Jere Dement Brower served as a Medical specialist in the Army from November 1996 to February 2001."

In 2000, when Brower was 24 years old, The Spokesman-Review newspaper and The Associated Press reported that Brower had been involved with the neo-Nazi group the Aryan Nations in Idaho.

Brower declined to discuss his experience with the Aryan Nations on the record.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Jury Trial scheduled for 3/13/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Terry Brown was among the few alleged rioters arrested while the Jan. 6, 2021, chaos at the Capitol building was happening. 

Near the atrium of the House of Representatives, around 3 p.m., Capitol Police Officers ordered the crowd to leave the building. "The crowd did not comply, and instead responded by shouting and cursing at the Capitol Police Officers," prosecutors allege. 

A group of people inside the building were then arrested; that included Brown.

According to local news reports, Brown is an Army veteran and a retired public safety officer.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brown pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/1/2021 to 36 Months of Probation with the first month as Home Detention; $500.00 Restitution; Special Assessment of $10.00; 60 hours community service

summary:
U.S. Navy veteran Thomas Caldwell was indicted on federal conspiracy and other charges in connection with the Capitol riot. 

Federal prosecutors allege Caldwell is affiliated with the far-right Oath Keepers militia and say he was involved in planning and coordinating the breach of the U.S. Capitol, with at least two other individuals who are also indicted on conspiracy charges. That coordinating, prosecutors say, includes an attempt to reach out to the Three Percenters militia group in the days leading up to the insurrection to "discuss plans to transport weapons across the Potomac by boat." 

According to court documents, on Jan. 1, 2021, Caldwell replied to a Facebook comment, writing, "I swore to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies foreign and domestic. I did the former, I have done the latter peacefully but they have morphed into pure evil even blatantly rigging an election and paying off the political caste. We must smite them now and drive them down."

On Jan. 6, as a crowd descended on the U.S. Capitol, Caldwell allegedly sent a Faceook message, writing, "We are surging forward. Doors breached." Minutes later, Caldwell wrote, "Inside."

Federal investigators found that while Caldwell was at the Capitol, he received a message from an unnamed individual who said, “All members are in the tunnels under capital [sic] seal them in. Turn on gas.”

Later that evening, after the National Guard secured the Capitol building, investigators believe Caldwell sent a Facebook message to another rioter also facing conspiracy charges. “We need to do this at the local level," he said. "Lets [sic] storm the capitol in Ohio. Tell me when!” 

In a motion for his release from detention, Caldwell's lawyer revealed that after he retired from the armed forces Caldwell served as an FBI section chief from 2009-2010 and has held a top-secret security clearance since 1979. The court filing also indicates Caldwell formed and operated a consulting firm that has done business for the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Coast Guard and the Army Personnel Command. 

Prosecutors opposed the motion, citing, among other things, a search of Caldwell's residence in Virginia, where federal investigators allegedly found a document labeled "Death List." 

"Handwritten on the document was the name of an election official from another state," said prosecutors. They have not identified that official.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Caldwell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
A couple of months before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, the FBI National Threat Operations Center received a tip. According to court documents, the caller said William Calhoun Jr., a Georgia attorney, was making threats on social media and encouraging people to storm Washington, D.C., and peacefully protest while openly carrying firearms. The caller read some of the messages, including one that allegedly said, "We are going to kill every last communist who stands in Trump's way." 

Federal investigators believe Calhoun was part of the first group of rioters who breached the Capitol building, based on photographs and posts they found on Calhoun's Facebook page. In one post he said, "Patriots have taken the Capitol Building. We overran multiple police barricades and swarmed the building. We busted through – thousands of us swarmed in.” He also said he was "among the first" who "kicked in Nancy Pelosi’s office door and pushed down the hall toward her inner sanctum.”

The judge presiding over the case said Calhoun was "seduced by a dangerous and violent ideology," citing his social media threats to "wage a civil war against Democrats, communists, the Deep State, and BLM-Antifa."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Calhoun pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to court documents, Samuel Camargo posted photographs, videos and messages on his social media channels that show him on Capitol grounds. Federal investigators highlight one video in which Camargo allegedly used his mobile phone to record his struggle with the U.S. Capitol Police over opening a door to the Capitol building. Another post allegedly shows Camargo holding a metal object with a caption that says: “got some memorabilia, did it myself.”

Camargo admitted he attended the protests in an interview with a federal investigator, but he allegedly grew uncooperative and questioned the agent's loyalty to the Constitution, according to court documents. 

When Florida law enforcement officials attempted to arrest Camargo at his home in Broward County, Fla., he was not there. Investigators found him the following day in Washington, D.C., and took him into custody.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Camargo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal investigators were tipped off to Mathew Capsel's involvement in the Capitol breach by two individuals who flagged his social media posts about the riot. 

Charging documents say a video Capsel posted shows him fighting against National Guardsmen attempting to hold the line with riot shields. In another video posted to TikTok, Capsel is seen allegedly fighting against National Guardsmen until he is pepper-sprayed and charging against a lined group of National Guardsman, running into their protective shields. 

Some of Capsel's social media accounts are under the name Mateo Q or feature the letter Q in some prominent fashion, according to court documents. It is not clear whether that is a reference or embrace of the QAnon conspiracy claims.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Capsel pleaded Not Guilty to both charges.

summary:
Jacob Chansley, also known as Jacob Angeli, is a U.S. Navy veteran and a follower of the QAnon conspiracy, which claims that Satan-worshipping pedophiles are running a global child sex-trafficking ring and plotting against former President Donald Trump.

According to court documents, Chansley told federal agents he participated in the insurrection with other "patriots" from Arizona, at the request of the president that all "patriots" come to D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021. 

Chansley confessed to federal agents that he was the man photographed in Vice President Pence's chair on the Senate dais with his face painted, wearing a horned headdress. He left a note on the Senate chamber dais that said, "It's only a matter of time, justice is coming." He said he was glad he sat in the vice president's chair because Vice President Pence is "a child-trafficking traitor."

Through his lawyer, Chansley recently expressed regret for storming the building and said he was disappointed with former President Donald Trump.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chansley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. The other charges were dropped. Sentenced 11/17/2021 to 41 months in prison with credit for time served; 36 month term of supervised release; $100 special assessment; $2,000 restitution

summary:
According to court documents, Albert Ciarpelli told federal agents that he learned of the Jan. 6, 2021, Trump rally from television ads. He told investigators he did not meet up with anyone in Washington, D.C., for the rally and did not socialize much with others who attended.

Ciarpelli, who manages rental and income properties in New York, told federal agents he considered his time in the U.S. Capitol to be a “little adventure.” He said he took a picture of a painting of President Andrew Jackson, whom he said he admires and that he left the Capitol after about 15 minutes “when he got the feeling that he should not be there and decided to leave.”

Thinking back on what occurred that day, Ciarpelli said, according to court records, that he was out of his mind and had never done anything like that before.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: According to court documents, Daniel Clavijo was arrested for a curfew violation in Washington, D.C. On Jan. 6, 2021, there was a District-wide curfew that began at 6 p.m. and ended at 6 a.m. the next day. Records say a Metropolitan Police officer warned Clavijo and other individuals near the Peace Monument in Washington around 7:15 p.m. They were asked to disperse three times, according to the records, and when they didn’t, officers placed them under arrest.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Guilty plea on Sept. 13, 2021. Clavijo entered a Deferred Prosecution Agreement.  Diversion Status Hearing scheduled for 8/05/2022. Defendant failed to complete the diversion conditions. Status hearing 8/22/2022

summary:
U.S. Capitol Police responded to two separate reports of a possible explosive device on Jan. 6., 2021, near the National Republican Club and the Democratic National Committee headquarters. Both sites are less than a mile from the U.S. Capitol. During a canine sweep, officers came across a red truck and noticed what appeared to be a firearm on the passenger seat. According to court records, the truck is registered to Lonnie Leroy Coffman. He was not with his car at the time. 

In a search of Coffman's truck, officers allegedly found an assault rifle, rifle magazines with ammunition, 11 mason jars containing an unknown liquid, cloth rags and lighters. A preliminary test by Capitol Police Hazardous Material Team determined the liquid was an igniting substance. 

When Coffman tried to return to his truck later that evening, he crossed paths with officers. After asking Coffman for a description of his car and his name, Coffman allegedly asked officers whether they had located the bombs.  

According to court documents, Coffman told law enforcement that the mason jars contained "melted Styrofoam and gasoline," an explosive mixture that has the effect of napalm, according to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. 

Coffman was indicted on 17 weapons charges. The U.S. Capitol Police does not attribute the explosive devices at the National Republican Club and the Democratic National Committee Headquarters to Coffman.

Coffman is a retired veteran, according to court records.
charges: Possession of an Unregistered Firearm [11 Molotov cocktails]; Carrying a Pistol Without a License (outside home or place of business) [9mm Smith & Wesson handgun, .22 caliber North American arms revolver, 9mm Hi-Point handgun]; Carrying a Rifle or Shotgun (Outside Home or Place of Business) [Windham Weaponry rifle, Hatfield Gun Company SAS shotgun]; Possession of a Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device; Unlawful Possession of Ammunition [.22 caliber rounds, 9mm rounds, 5.56 x 45mm rounds, .223 caliber rounds, shotgun shells]
case_updates: Coffman pleaded Guilty to two charges: Possession of an Unregistered Firearm [11 Molotov cocktails]; Carrying a Pistol Without a License. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/1/2022 to incarceration of 46 months on Count 1 and 15 months on Count 2 with credit for time served; 36 months supervised release on Count 1 and 36 months on Count 2; $200 special assessment

summary: Tara Coleman was arrested for a curfew violation in Washington, D.C. There was a District-wide curfew that began at 6 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, and ended the next day at 6 a.m. According to court documents, a D.C. police officer saw Coleman and a handful of other people out around 7:15 p.m., in violation of the curfew order. According to D.C. Superior Court documents, Coleman and others were asked to disperse three times, and when they didn’t, officers placed them under arrest.
charges: Unlawful entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Guilty plea on Sept. 2, 2021. Sentenced to 40 hours community service; $50 fine; 18 months probation

summary:
Josiah Colt was allegedly photographed hanging from the Senate balcony on Jan. 6, 2021, and also sitting in the vice president’s chair. He was initially identified by relatives, according to the FBI. 

He admitted that he was involved in the rioting on the Capitol and apologized for his role in what went on, in a statement to a local Boise, Idaho, station. “I love America, I love the people, I didn’t hurt anyone and I didn’t cause any damage in the Chamber,” he said in a statement given to CBS2 News. “I got caught up in the moment and when I saw the door to the Chamber open, I walked in, hopped down and sat on the chair.” He said he helped someone who was injured get to safety and then he left. 

He was arrested in Idaho on Jan. 12, 2021, according to a criminal complaint.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Colt pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. The other charges are dismissed. He has agreed to cooperate with authorities and sentencing will occur at a later date.

summary:
According to federal court documents, Cody Connell stormed the Capitol building with his cousin Daniel Page Adams on Jan. 6, 2021. He told someone on social media, according to the court files, that “4 of us breached the cops blockage and us same 4 breached the Capitol.” 

Just a day earlier, Connell reposted a message saying, “Join President Donald J. Trump at the Save America March.” He added the comment, “Definitely gonna be an experience.” 

An unknown individual, according to court documents, also sent authorities a screenshot of what appears to be a Facebook exchange between Connell and an individual on Jan. 7, 2021, in which Connell writes, “I have more videos of us breaching the Capitol but not gonna post them. We will be back and it will be a lot worse than yesterday.”

According to court documents, Connell had communicated with at least two other people in Texas about purchasing long-rifle firearms, ammunition and body armor for a second trip to Washington that Connell was planning for the week of Jan.18, 2021.
 
According to a witness interviewed by the FBI, Connell said he was not returning to Louisiana unless he was in a body bag. Authorities said in court filings that they understood that to mean that Connell intended to be in D.C. “to cause violence that may result in the end of his life.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Connell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Nolan Cooke told police that he went to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, because he wanted to be heard. Photographs of him, with long brown hair and wearing a Trump hat, were posted on Instagram. One reads: “I wouldn’t want anyone other than you with me to take on the revolution.” It was followed by a heart and a kiss emoji. The FBI confirmed that Cooke is the person in the photographs.

Cooke voluntarily agreed to be interviewed by law enforcement in Texas and said that he drove to Washington on Jan. 5 with a relative and his girlfriend after seeing a posting on Twitter for a Trump rally there on Jan. 6.

Cooke told officials that he had brought several firearms with him on the trip but that he left the weapons in the car. 

Cooke said he was at the front of the crowd and pushed past police officers to get to the Capitol building and used a flagpole to bang on a window, but he denied that he went inside.
charges: Civil Disorder
case_updates: Cooke pleaded Guilty to the single charge: Civil Disorder. Sentenced 6/10/2022 to 12 months and 1 day incarceration; 3 years supervised release; $2,000 in restitution; $100 special assessment

summary:
Matthew Council was part of a larger group that broke into the Senate wing of the Capitol building and was pushing against officers trying to keep an emergency door closed, according to federal court documents. The door was eventually breached, and officers who were there said Council was among those who pushed through.
 
“All during this time he was continually yelling at police officers that were trying to contain the scene,” the statement of facts reads. In the melee, Council pushed a Capitol Police officer. He was pepper-sprayed and detained. While in custody, but before he was advised of his Miranda rights, Council “expressed remorse about pushing the officer and indicated that he did not intend to injure her.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Council pleaded Guilty to all six charges. Sentencing set for 11/1/2022

summary:
Gracyn Courtright, a senior at the University of Kentucky studying mathematical economics, posted photographs of herself in Washington outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Under one photograph of herself, she wrote: “can’t wait to tell my grandkids I was here!”

Court documents say she was wearing a hat that was so distinctive, it allowed investigators to track her throughout the Capitol. She was seen entering the building through a door near the West Senate Stairs at 2:42 p.m. About 15 minutes later, cameras caught her on the second floor, near the Senate chamber, carrying a “Members Only” sign. A law enforcement officer took the sign away from her a few moments later, just before she left the building.

The FBI was provided with screenshots of a direct message between Courtright and a friend on Instagram. It included a video of Courtright chanting as she went through the halls of the Capitol. Her friend asked whether she was there, and Courtright responded by saying that she walked into “the chamber like the Senate where desks are.” 

“It wasn’t violent like the news said, I took pictures all in the building,” the message began. “I never saw the violence i guess I was lucky. The cops like let’s (sic) us walk in.”

Shortly before her Instagram account was deactivated around Jan. 7, she wrote below a selfie: “Infamy is just as good as fame. Either way I end up more known. XOXO.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property (less than $1,000) [a sign]
case_updates: Courtright pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/17/2021 to 30 days in jail, followed by 12 months of Supervised Release; 60 hours community service; $500 restitution; and Special Assessment of $25.00

summary:
A witness who came forward told the FBI he traveled by car with two other men to Washington, D.C., and checked in at the Holiday Inn National Airport in Arlington, Va. He became ill during the drive and was not able to attend any of the events, but the two other passengers — Dalton Crase and Troy Williams — allegedly did. 

According to court documents, the FBI later interviewed Crase and Williams, who both admitted to attending Donald Trump’s speech and to have subsequently walked to the Capitol building and entered on two occasions. They also provided photographs and videos they took inside.

Crase allegedly told FBI agents: “Even though we didn’t participate in violence, I think it was dumb that we went in. … I was breaking the law by being in the Capitol building, but it didn’t register with me. ... Even me, I didn’t do anything violent, but I went into the building, so I did trespass.” According to court documents, Williams told FBI agents, “I wasn’t doing anything wrong or inciteful. … We were a part of something. There’s cops here, they tried to stop us, they are not letting us in, but not fighting us.”

Williams also allegedly said he “rationalized with himself at one point asking himself what the legal way would be to get into the Capitol building,” because they were told by other men in the crowd that this could be a felony. Crase told the FBI that “if he was ever allowed back, he would get a 'pass' the next time.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Crase pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/13/2022 to 3 years probation; 60 days home detention/locations monitoring; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution; 60 hours community service

summary: The Justice Department has indicted Donovan Crowl on conspiracy and other charges. According to court documents, Crowl, a U.S. Marine veteran, is a member of the Ohio State Regular Militia, a group with links to the far-right Oath Keepers militia. Federal prosecutors allege that in December 2020, Crowl attended a training camp in North Carolina. In a review of Crowl's Facebook posts, federal investigators found a message he sent on Jan. 4, 2021, that said, "Sorry Brother, been busy planning for this week. ... We are enroute to DC right now for a few days on an Oathkeepers Op." Two days later, prosecutors say Crowl and another individual also indicted on conspiracy charges -- Jessica Watkins -- were in full battle gear at the Capitol when they joined other members of the Oath Keepers and "moved in an organized and practiced fashion up the steps" of the Capitol. According to charging documents, Crowl and Watkins forcibly entered the Capitol building, pushing past at least one law enforcemnt officer, and made it into the Capitol Rotunda. In a recorded video, Crowl allegedly said, "We took on the Capitol! We overran the Capitol!" Federal prosecutors say Crowl returned to Ohio after the attack on the Capitol, but once the media idenfitied him, he traveled to Virginia to stay with another alleged rioter facing conspiracy charges -- Thomas Caldwell. According to the indictment, "Caldwell directed Crowl to conceal his travel and invited him to hide evidence of his involvement in the Capitol incursion, writing, 'No need to call me again. Will expect you even if you're running late.'" On Jan. 17, 2021, Crowl was arrested in Ohio along with Jessica Watkins. They turned themselves in, according to the Urbana Police Department.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Crowl pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Jenny Cudd allegedly livestreamed on Facebook from the Capitol. According to court documents, Cudd stated: “I was here today on January 6th when the new revolution started at the Capitol,” she said. "F*** yes, I am proud of my actions, I f***ing charged the Capitol today with patriots today."

"We did break down Nancy Pelosi’s office door, and somebody stole her gavel, and I took a picture sitting in the chair flipping off the camera and that was on Fox News,” she added during her live social media stream. 

Cudd is charged with offenses that don’t include destruction of property, despite her statement. 

In November 2019, Cudd ran for mayor of Midland, Texas, but lost in the elections, coming in third, according to the Midland Country Summary Results Report. Her campaign slogan was “Midland Deserves Better.”

Cudd is the owner of Becky’s Flowers, a local flower shop. The Houston Chronicle reported that in 2020, Cudd was part of protests in Midland against “business closures and potential mask mandates.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Cudd pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced on 3/23/2022 to 2 Months Probation; $25 Special Assessment; $5,000 Fine;  Restitution of $500

summary:
According to court documents, Michael Curzio was with a group of rioters inside the Capitol building who did not comply with police orders to leave. He also allegedly wore a gas mask inside the Capitol. After the Capitol riot, Curzio allegedly said, "Our point was made yesterday. I have no regrets about anything.” 

Curzio's defense attorney stated in one court filing that, "Mr. Curzio concedes he was on the Capitol grounds and building to protest along with hundreds of other protesters and was merely following the directions of then-President Trump, who has billed himself as the country’s chief law enforcement officer." The defense attorney argued that Curzio was unable to follow law enforcement's orders to leave the Capitol, because of the large crowd of demonstrators, but prosecutors have disputed that claim.

Records show he had earlier served eight years in prison for attempted first-degree murder. He was released in 2019. According to federal prosecutors, "Curzio was a member in a violent white-supremacist prison gang, the Unforgiven, while he served time in the Florida corrections system. Curzio bears tattoos with Nazi imagery." Prosecutors argued in court documents that Curzio has a "longstanding, if not ongoing, devotion to the Unforgiven’s extremist, racist ideology and violent reputation."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Curzio pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 7/12/2021 to 6 months of incarceration; $500 restitution; and a $10 Special Assessment

summary: According to a federal complaint, Michael Daughtry told Pelham police he participated in the insurrection and was one of the first people to force his way past the barricades surrounding the perimeter. "We was the first ones over the fence. Everybody followed us," he said. A federal investigator reviewed Daughtry's Facebook posts and highlighted one from November 2020 that was an apparent advertisement for a business Daughtry operated from his home known as "Crazy Coon's Armory." The post said, "Anyone needing an AR15 and some extra ammo before the election, I've got a couple left in stock. ... It may be your last chance if the election don't go right tomorrow! Let me know if you're interested!" On Jan. 4, 2021, two days before the insurrection, Daughtry posted on Facebook: "About 25,000 people at the Trump rally tonight, now we're headed to Washington DC where they're expecting 4 Million people. Looks like we may have to walk about 5 miles to get there from what we were told at the rally but it'll be worth it to be able to yell crap at Pelosi and the rest of the idiots." The day of the insurrection, Daughtry posted another message on Facebook that said, "We just tore down the fence and stormed the Capital [sic]." According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Daughtry is a former police officer.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Daughtry pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentenced 6/9/2022 to 36 months probation, 60 days home detention w/monitoring; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment; 60 hours community service

summary:
Nick DeCarlo was indicted by a federal grand jury for conspiracy to obstruct Congress.

A few days after the insurrection, DeCarlo told the LA Times he was inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. DeCarlo said he was there as a journalist with another rioter, but according to the federal complaint, DeCarlo "is not listed as a credentialed reporter with the House Periodical Press Gallery or the U.S. Senate Press Gallery, the organizations that credential Congressional correspondents."

Federal investigators found photos of DeCarlo inside the Capitol building posing in front of a door with the words "Murder The Media" scrawled on it. In that photo, DeCarlo is wearing a shirt and hat with the same words. Over the course of their investigation, federal agents learned that DeCarlo purports to be an employee of "MT Media News," which stands for Murder the Media News. 

Photographs of DeCarlo from Jan. 6 that are in the criminal complaint show him posing next to Nicholas Ochs, a leader and founder of the Hawaii chapter of the Proud Boys, which is considered an extremist group by the government. Ochs was also indicted on conspiracy charges.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: DeCarlo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal prosecutors allege that Nathaniel DeGrave had been planning to attend the pro-Trump rallies on Jan. 6, 2021, for at least several days. In response to Donald Trump's Facebook message calling for a "StopTheSteal" protest, DeGrave posted, "We're ready Mr President!!" 

When he made it to Washington from his home in Las Vegas, DeGrave, who goes by Nate, allegedly appeared in a video where he said, "We are out here protecting the country, if s**t goes down, if Pence does what we think he is going to do. Then we are here to defend this city, defend any city in this country. Let antifa try us. We are here. We are ready. I say bring it. We are not silent anymore." 

By 2:40 p.m. on Jan. 6, prosecutors say, DeGrave had entered the Capitol building wearing "black tactical gear, including what appears to be body armor, a helmet, and a mask/face shield." Surveillance footage allegedly shows DeGrave getting into a "shoving match" with officers from the U.S. Capitol Police, putting up his fists and pounding his chest. 

DeGrave was arrested on Jan. 28, 2021.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: DeGrave pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers.

summary:
Jonathan Doll was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside the Capitol for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse.

Doll told a local news station he didn’t support the storming of the U.S. Capitol building by pro-Trump rioters. 

“Surrounding the Capitol is one thing, but going in and invading their workspace, that's wrong," Doll told the station. “But we needed to be there.”
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Doll entered into a deferred prosecution agreement on June 11, 2021. Under that agreement, Doll must complete community service, must not violate any laws, and can only enter Washington, DC in order to confer with his lawyer. If he abides by that agreement for six months, the charges will be dismissed. Diversion Successfully Completed, Case Dismissed - Nolle-Diversion

summary:
According to court documents, a tip directed federal investigators to Karl Dresch's Facebook account. There they found a post from early January that said he was preparing to go to “DC” and was “prepared for chemical attacks and what not.” He also called on others to go. “NO EXCUSES! NO RETREAT! NO SURRENDER! TAKE THE STREETS! TAKE BACK OUR COUNTRY! 1/6/2021=7/4/1776,” he wrote in a Facebook post.

Photographs and messages from Dresch's Facebook account on Jan. 6, 2021, suggest he got inside the Capitol building. 

According to news reports, Dresch is a felon who was involved in a 2013 high-speed chase with police. Dresch was barred from possessing firearms or ammunition, which is what FBI agents allegedly found in a recent search of his home.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Dresch pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 8/4/2021 to Time Served (6 months) with no term of supervised release imposed. Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution in the amount of $500.00 was imposed.

summary:
Stacy Ebanks was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, while she was in a parking lot outside the Capitol. The charges say she violated the District of Columbia’s curfew order and ignored police officers’ orders to disperse.  

Ebanks operates a senior home care business in Maryland.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Diversion Status Hearing scheduled for 8/05/2022. Diversion Successfully Completed by the Defendant and case dismissed by the Government as agreed.

summary:
Hunter Ehmke was part of the crowd confronting police and overturning barricades outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The documents say Ehmke found a window that led into the Capitol office building and beat on it with his fist until it shattered. An officer knocked Ehmke over with his shield, the two fell to the ground, and Ehmke was handcuffed.

The police officers in the area, however, were quickly overwhelmed by the crowd, the court filing says, and someone in the crowd told the officer who had Ehmke in custody that he would not be able to leave with him. Given the menace growing within the crowd, the officers took Ehmke’s driver’s license and released him. He was arrested in California a week later. 

The Architect of the Capitol has estimated that the cost to replace the broken window is $2,821.
charges: Destruction of Government Property; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ehmke pleaded Guilty to one charge: Destruction of Government Property. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/13/2022 to 4 months incarceration; 36 months of supervised release; $2,821 restitution; $100 special assessment

summary:
“I took off when I felt pepper spray in my throat! Lol,” read a Facebook post from Valerie Ehrke. She included a video showing a group of people entering the U.S. Capitol building at a little after 2 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021. “We made it inside, right before they shoved us all out,” the caption on the video said. 

According to court documents, that same profile page showed a flaming “Q” and a map that law enforcement associates with QAnon, a far-right conspiracy theory.
 
FBI agents interviewed Ehrke, and she confirmed that she had traveled to Washington, D.C., attended a rally for then-President Donald Trump and heard him speak. But she said his telling the crowd to go to the Capitol didn’t inspire her to do so. Instead, according to details of her interview in court documents, she told the FBI she went back to her hotel room, turned on the TV, saw a news story about the march to the Capitol and wanted to be part of it all. 

She told the FBI, according to court documents, that she got about 15 feet inside the Capitol before someone grabbed her and pushed her outside.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
