case_updates: Ehrke pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 9/17/2021 to 3 years probation; $500 restitution; $10 assessment fee; and 120 hours of community service

summary:
Lisa Eisenhart is a nurse from Georgia who went to Washington, D.C., with her son, Eric Gavelek Munchel.

Munchel is alleged to be one of the people photographed on a balcony inside the Senate chamber while wearing tactical gear and holding zip ties. Eisenhart was allegedly there too, wearing a bulletproof vest.

According to federal court documents, Eisenhart rented a room for the two of them at the Grand Hyatt hotel in Washington on Jan. 4 and checked out three days later. 

Hotel video surveillance, the court documents say, establishes that she and her son left the hotel together a little over an hour before the pro-Trump mob breached the Capitol barricades. The hotel surveillance video shows her son, Munchel, in his tactical gear, according to the criminal complaint.

Video from inside the Capitol allegedly shows Eisenhart and her son holding flex-cuffs, pursuing two Capitol Police officers and searching for members of Congress with the crowd, allegedly shouting, “Anybody home?” or “Treason!” 

She allegedly told her son as they were leaving the building, according to the criminal complaint, to get rid of the flex-cuffs, saying, “Don’t carry the zip ties. Just get 'em out … of our hands.” 

On Jan. 10, the London newspaper The Times published an article that quoted both Eisenhart and her son. She said the two had gone into the Capitol as “observers,” and the article quoted Eisenhart as saying that “this country was founded on revolution. I’d rather die a 57-year-old woman than live under oppression. I’d rather die and would rather fight.” The article is included in the criminal complaint against her. 

Eisenhart was arrested in Nashville, Tenn. She has been ordered detained and transported to D.C., according to the Justice Department.
charges: Conspiracy to Commit Obstruction; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Eisenhart pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Andrew Ericson took at least two photos of himself inside the U.S. Capitol and posted them to his Snapchat account, according to court documents. He also allegedly livestreamed himself entering and walking around the building and taking a beer out of a refrigerator in what appears to be House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, according to court documents.  

According to local news reports, Ericson's father, Stuart Ericson, is a former Oklahoma state representative.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ericson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 20 days of intermittent confinement (serving the sentence on consecutive weekends); 24 months of probation; $10.00 Special Assessment; $500 in restitution.

summary:
The night before the Capitol siege, Derrick Evans, who was elected to the West Virginia House in November, posted a photo that appeared to show passengers on a bus. "Two bus loads of Patriots from WV, KY, and Ohio are loaded up and heading to DC. #StopTheSteal," read the caption.  

The next day, according to court documents, Evans posted a video of crowds at the National Mall. "They're making an announcement right now saying if Pence betrays us, you better get your mind right because we're storming that building," he says in the video. "I'm just the messenger, so don't be hating on me. I'm just telling you what I'm hearing on the ground."

Later that day, as rioters swarmed the Capitol building, Evans allegedly started livestreaming a video that shows him egging on a crowd trying to enter the building. "There we go! Open the door!" he's heard saying. Minutes later, Evans shouts, "We're in, we're in, we're in. ... Let's go — keep it moving, baby!" 

In the days leading up to the Capitol attack, Evans talked about his plans to travel to Washington in a couple of Facebook posts. "A STORM IS COMING ... AND THERE IS NOTHING THE LEFT CAN DO TO STOP IT!" he posted on Dec. 31. In another post, he shared a tweet by then-President Donald Trump that said, "Just happened to have found another 4000 ballots from Fulton County" — a reference to the baseless claim of election fraud. "This is why we are going to DC. #StopTheSteal," Evans said in the caption. 

Evans resigned after the Justice Department announced its charges against him.
charges: Impeding, Obstructing or Interfering with Law Enforcement During a Civil Disorder
case_updates: Evans pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 6/22/2022 to three months in jail, three years of supervised release, $2,000 fine, $2,000 restitution; $100 special assessment

summary:
Scott Fairlamb, a gym owner from New Jersey, is accused of shoving an officer and punching the officer in the head on Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021. Videos from that day allegedly show Fairlamb standing on scaffolding and carrying a baton while saying, "What do patriots do? We f***in' disarm them and then we storm the f***in' Capitol."

He's charged with assaulting an officer, civil disorder, unlawful entry of a restricted building while armed with a dangerous or deadly weapon, and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Columbia.

Last year, Fairlamb, who was struggling to keep his gym afloat because of pandemic lockdowns, protested and defied the governor's coronavirus restrictions. “He has overstepped his boundaries, and it’s time for these gyms, that are, that are essential to open up,” he told CBS New York at the time.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Fairlamb pleaded Guilty to two felony charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced 11/10/2021 to 41 months incarceration with credit for time served; 26 months supervised release; $200 special assessment; $2,000 fine

summary:
Thomas Fee, a recently retired firefighter, was part of the mob that breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. 

When Fee allegedly sent a selfie and a video from inside the Capitol to his girlfriend's brother, who is a special agent with the State Department, the agent then turned them over to an FBI Joint Terrorism Task Force. Fee also wrote in a text message that he was “at the tip of the spear.” It is not clear from the complaint whether Fee knew at the time that his girlfriend's brother was a special agent.

According to multiple news reports, Fee was suspended as a volunteer firefighter in 2004 for allegedly yelling out racial slurs at a Black doctor who walked past the firehouse.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fee pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 4/1/2022 to 24 months probation; 50 hours community service; $500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
According to court documents, Brandon Fellows was allegedly part of a group that stormed into the Capitol and Oregon Sen. Jeff Merkley's office.

In an interview with CNN on Jan. 6, 2021, Fellows said, “Cops are very cool. They were like, 'Hey guys, have a good night.' Some of them, which is crazy, it’s really weird, you can see that some of them were on our side.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fellows pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
The day before the Capitol attack, Samuel Fisher, a self-professed dating coach who is also known as Brad Holiday, allegedly described three possible scenarios for how Jan. 6, 2021, could play out. 

"Trump has an Ace card up his sleeve. He plays it. The Deep State is arrested and hanged on the White House lawn for the High Treason. ... Trump fails, Biden gets installed. ... Patriots are ineffective and we live under the rule of the elite pedophiles and chinese communist party. ... Trump fails, Biden gets installed. ... Patriots show up in the millions with guns. They execute all treasonous members of government and rebuild."

The criminal complaint does not explicitly say that Fisher subscribes to any extremist ideology, but notions of a "deep state" and a vast child sex-trafficking ring are tenets of the QAnon conspiracy theory. 

According to court documents, federal investigators believe Fisher was in possession of multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest when he was in Washington. 

On Jan. 6, Fisher received a Facebook message asking whether D.C. allows open carry. "Not at all," he responded and followed up with a photograph of a couple of firearms. The same day, he wrote, “I’m Going To the parking garage super early,” “Leaving s*** in there maybe except pistol” and “if it kicks off I got a Vest and My Rifle.”

The day after the Capitol attack, when Fisher was asked on Facebook whether he made it to the "frontlines" of the Capitol breach, he allegedly responded, “i was there ... it was awesome” / “it was dangerous and violent” / “people died ... but it was f***ing great if you ask me ... i got tear gassed and pepper sprayed” / “seeing cops literally run ... was the coolest thing ive ever seen in my life” / “cant divulge too much here” / “but f*** the dc police” / “in all seriousness and get ready ... get in shape and see if you can find someone that knows medical/veteran w/ combat experience.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building
case_updates: Fisher pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 10/7/2022

summary:
Cindy Fitchett was among the few alleged rioters who was arrested while the chaos at the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, was ongoing.

Near the atrium of the House of Representatives, around 3:00 pm, Capitol Police Officers ordered the crowd to leave the building. "The crowd did not comply, and instead responded by shouting and cursing at the Capitol Police Officers," prosecutors allege.

A group of people inside the building were then arrested, including Fitchett.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fitchett pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/9/2021 to 36 months of probation with one month home detention; 60 hours community service; restitution of $500.00; Special Assessment of $10.

summary:
David Fitzgerald, a tattoo artist from Roselle, Ill., was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside the Capitol for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's 6 p.m. curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse.

When he returned to his home in Illinois on Jan. 8, he talked to CBS Chicago. He said he didn't like what he saw in D.C. but had no regrets.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Fitzgerald pleaded Guilty on 5/11/2022. Sentenced to 1 year of supervised probation; $50 Crime Victims Compensation Fund

summary:
Federal prosecutors have called Michael Foy “one of the most violent of the Capitol rioters” and have said that evidence shows him “brutally assaulting law enforcement officers” with both a hockey stick and a “sharpened pole” during the riot. Prosecutors allege that Foy was captured on bystander video, as well as on police body camera footage, as he used a hockey stick to hit an officer who was defending an outer door to the Capitol. In all, Foy allegedly hit officers at least 10 times, including officers who had already been knocked to the ground. When federal agents arrested Foy on Jan. 21, 2021, they say he still had the hockey stick, along with at least one photo on his phone of destruction from inside the Capitol. 

Foy had previously been seen at a pro-Trump protest in Detroit in November, when people demonstrated against the counting of ballots.

Foy served in the Marine Corps from 2015 to 2019 as an engineer equipment mechanic, a Marine Corps spokesperson told NPR. He reached the rank of sergeant, according to the spokesperson, and did not deploy as part of his service. 

Both prosecutors and Foy’s defense attorney have said that he has serious mental illness, including substance abuse problems, post-traumatic stress disorder and suicidal thoughts. Foy’s attorney argued that he should be allowed to live with his mother while his case is pending, given the fact that suicide is the leading cause of death in America’s jails. A federal judge ruled that Foy posed a danger to others and must remain in custody.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Foy pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Jacob Fracker appeared in photos from inside the Capitol during the rioting and later posted on Facebook, “Lol to anyone who’s possibly concerned about the picture of me going around. ... Sorry I hate freedom?”

“I can protest for what I believe in and still support your protest for what you believe in,” Fracker wrote in the Facebook post, which prosecutors entered as evidence against him. He added: “After all, I fought for your right to do it.”

Fracker served as a Marine infantry rifleman from 2010 to 2014 and deployed to Afghanistan twice. He later joined the Virginia National Guard, according to widespread news reports.

Most recently, he had worked as a police officer in Rocky Mount, Va. On Jan. 26, 2021, the Rocky Mount Police Department announced it had fired Fracker and another officer who allegedly joined the mob that stormed the Capitol.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Fracker pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 8/16/22 to 12 months of probation, the first 59 days on home detention, 120 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution; assessment of $100

summary: Thomas Gallagher was among the relatively few alleged rioters arrested during the chaos at the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Near the atrium of the House of Representatives, around 3 p.m., Capitol Police officers ordered the crowd to leave the building. "The crowd did not comply, and instead responded by shouting and cursing at the Capitol Police Officers," prosecutors allege. A group of people inside the building was then arrested, including Gallagher.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gallagher pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed.  Sentenced 11/4/2021 to 24 Months of Probation (with Conditions); Restitution of $500.00; Special Assessment of $10; 60 hours of community service

summary:
Federal prosecutors allege that Gabriel Garcia joined the storming of the Capitol and posted videos of himself on Facebook Live getting into an “aggressive confrontation” with police officers inside the Capitol. 

Video shows Garcia yelling, “You f***ing traitors” at Capitol Police, prosecutors allege, and saying, “Storm this s***!” to the growing mob.

At one point in the video, he says, “Free Enrique,” which prosecutors say is a reference to Henry “Enrique” Tarrio, a leader of the right-wing extremist group the Proud Boys. (Two days before the Capitol insurrection, Tarrio was arrested in Washington, D.C., for allegedly burning a church’s Black Lives Matter banner, as well as allegedly carrying high-capacity ammunition magazines, which is illegal in D.C.)

Garcia served as an air defense artillery officer in the U.S. Army, Florida Army National Guard and U.S. Army Reserve from February 2002 to March 2017. He deployed to Iraq from August 2009 to July 2010. He reached the rank of captain during his service, and prosecutors say another rioter at the Capitol referred to Garcia as “El Capitan.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Garcia pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Chris Georgia was charged with violating the District of Columbia's curfew on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021. Three days after his arrest and charge, he died by suicide, according to the Office of the Fulton County Medical Examiner.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Georgia's charge was disposed - prosecution abated due to defendant's death

summary:
Christina Gerding was allegedly part of the crowd that made it inside the U.S. Capitol rotunda on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. In the days following the siege, the FBI received tips about a widely circulated photograph that shows her posing in front of a painting of the Declaration of Independence with another individual believed to be Jason Gerding, who is also facing charges. 

Jason Gerding's Twitter account shows an alleged embrace of QAnon, a conspiracy theory that claims Satan-worshipping pedophiles are running a global child sex-trafficking ring and plotting against Donald Trump. It is not clear whether Christina Gerding is also a follower.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gerding pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Jason Gerding posted a photograph to what federal investigators believe is his Twitter account. According to a criminal complaint, the photo shows Gerding inside the Capitol rotunda posing in front of a painting of the Declaration of Independence with the caption "Quincy Made it Inside," a reference to his hometown. 

Other tweets from that account in the days leading up to the Capitol siege show Gerding's alleged embrace of QAnon, the outrageous conspiracy theory that claims Satan-worshipping pedophiles are running a global child sex-trafficking ring and plotting against Donald Trump. Screenshots of the account in court documents show a "Q" background banner and a profile picture of Trump. In one tweet dated Dec. 21, 2020, Gerding asks "Anons" if they know of a good place to stay in Washington, D.C., for the rally. Several days later, Gerding tweeted, "So much disinformation coming out I don't know what is real what is fake. I trust the plan.... I'll be in DC Jan 6th, but my head is starting to hurt."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gerding pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Robert Gieswein "appears to be affiliated with the radical militia group known as the Three Percenters" and also runs a paramilitary training group called the Woodland Wild Dogs. Court records also indicate he believes the "Rothschilds" have taken over the U.S. government, which is a common anti-Semitic trope, and said that political leaders need to be "imprisoned" for "destroying our country."

On the day of the insurrection, Gieswein allegedly used a baseball bat and some sort of unidentified "irritant spray" to assault police officers protecting the Capitol. He encouraged rioters to break a window on the outside of the Capitol building, the government alleges, and then climbed through the broken window to join the storming of the Capitol.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, Or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon
case_updates: Gieswein pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On the far-right Internet, Anthime Gionet is among the most well-known of the alleged Capitol rioters. Gionet goes by the handle "Baked Alaska" on social media and has widely been described as an Internet "troll." The Anti-Defamation League says that Gionet has promoted "white supremacist and anti-Semitic ideologies" and attacked Muslims. (“Everyone on the right can agree that they don’t like Islam — is that correct?” he said at one rally.) He has also frequently been associated with the "alt-right" and appeared at rallies with the right-wing extremist group the Proud Boys. In 2017, Gionet took part in the Charlottesville, Va., Unite the Right rally promoted by white supremacist groups, in which one woman was killed. 

One reason for Gionet's notoriety is his use of livestreaming video. That video has now become evidence for federal prosecutors. 

On Jan. 6, 2021, Gionet allegedly livestreamed himself from inside the Capitol building, saying, “Occupy the Capitol. Let’s go. We ain’t leaving this b****." When officers ordered Gionet to leave the building, he responded, "You’re a f***ing oath-breaker, you piece of s***.”

Gionet was later arrested in Texas.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gionet pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentencing set for 1/12/2023

summary: Earl Glosser was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside the Capitol for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 10/03/2022

summary:
Simone Gold is a physician based in Beverly Hills, Calif., who is affiliated with the group America's Frontline Doctors. That group has advocated for several positions that have been widely criticized by public health experts and scientists — arguing against the use of masks to combat the coronavirus, for instance, and for the use of the drug hydroxychloroquine. 

Based on images from social media, as well as surveillance footage, federal prosecutors allege that Gold joined the group of people who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and that she carried a bullhorn.

Days after the rioting, Gold spoke to The Washington Post and said that she traveled to Washington for a "Rally for Health Freedom." 

She told the Post that she did enter the Capitol building but insisted that everyone she saw inside was "peaceful."

“I can certainly speak to the place that I was, and it most emphatically was not a riot,” she told the Post. However, Gold said, “I do regret being there."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gold pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/16/2022 to 60 days incarceration; 12 months of supervised release; $9,500 fine; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Daniel Goodwyn "is a self-proclaimed member of the Proud Boys," the right-wing extremist group. He has also been associated with Anthime Gionet, better known as "Baked Alaska," who is a prominent figure on the far-right Internet. After the 2020 presidential election, Goodwyn urged people to protest at state capitols and quoted Donald Trump's statement from a presidential debate that the Proud Boys should "stand back and stand by."

"Await orders from our Commander In Chief," he posted on Nov. 7, 2020, according to federal court records.

On Jan. 6, 2021, Goodwyn allegedly entered the Capitol building. Prosecutors allege that he called police officers defending the Capitol from the mob "oath-breakers" and later claimed on Instagram, "I didn’t break or take anything but I went inside for a couple of minutes.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Goodwyn pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Much of the government's case against Vaughn Gordon relies on Gordon's own videos and photos that he posted during the rioting, according to court records, as well as statements to the media. Prosecutors say Gordon posted multiple selfies from inside the Capitol on Facebook with the caption, “Live inside the Congress building. It was worth the tear gas." 

Gordon later spoke about the riot at a protest in his home state of Louisiana and gave an interview to The Advocate newspaper. "It was chaos. It was mayhem. It was surreal," he told The Advocate.

He insisted, however, that "the rampant destruction and the violence that they’re talking about us is not true."

He was arrested a few days later.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gordon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Soon after the attack on the Capitol, the FBI released several photos of people who allegedly joined in the rioting and asked the public for help in identifying them. One of the people sought by investigators, according to court documents, was wearing a blue jacket and black sunglasses and at one point used a Taser while "pushing himself through the crowd of violent individuals towards the police line that was protecting the entrance to the U.S. Capitol building."

The use of a Taser was significant because a Capitol Police officer told investigators that he had been shocked by a Taser on the back of his neck during the violence and had to be hospitalized after having a heart attack.

The "Be on the Lookout" posters led the FBI to Vitali GossJankowski. 

GossJankowski turned himself in to police after seeing the poster, the records indicate, and told FBI agents in an interview, that "he found [the Taser] on the ground when he was walking up towards the U.S. Capitol." He said he never entered the Capitol building itself.

GossJankowski allegedly told the FBI that "he did not use his Taser" on the injured officer, but "if he touched him, he touched his helmet and it was merely to help him." Local media reports indicate that GossJankowski is a student at Gallaudet University in Washington, D.C.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: GossJankowski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Jeffrey Grace flew with his son to Washington, D.C., to sightsee and attend the rally for Donald Trump, according to court records. Grace told FBI agents, who interviewed him outside his residence on Jan. 21, 2021, that he got separated from his son after the Trump rally and later entered the Capitol building from the north side.

He also told the FBI that he saw “an individual carrying what appeared to be a metal pipe, asked him to give him the pipe, and when the individual refused, Grace took it from him and placed it behind a wooden object in the Rotunda.” Grace also said that “the door he previously entered was closed, with police officers blocking it, so he followed a group of people and climbed out a broken window.”

Grace allegedly appears in photographs behind the man carrying a lectern inside the rotunda. According to court documents, Grace told the FBI that he was not a member of any groups advocating violence but that he “knew people who were members of the following groups: Three Percenters, Proud Boys, and 1% Outlaw Motorcycle Gang.” Grace was arrested on Feb. 4, 2021, in western Washington state.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grace pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Lance Grames was among a group of people arrested outside the Capitol building on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order. The government has not alleged that he ever joined the storming of the Capitol. 

Grames served in the U.S. Air Force from 1997 to 2007 and reached the rank of senior airman, a Defense Department spokesperson told NPR. He most recently worked as a systems technician at Fort Meade in Maryland. 

The Sanford Herald, of Sanford, N.C., reported that Grames has been a vocal Trump supporter and also a critic of North Carolina’s restrictions related to COVID-19. Grames told a county commission meeting that he was “assaulted” at a Family Dollar for not wearing a mask.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Deferred Prosecution Agreement with Community Service Filed. Diversion Status Hearing scheduled 8/05/2022. Matter was continued to allow time for the defendant to complete diversion conditions. Hearing set for 8/19/2022

summary:
Weeks before the Capitol riot, Kenneth Grayson allegedly messaged someone, "IF TRUMP TELLS US TO STORM THE F***IN CAPITAL IMA DO THAT THEN!"

Federal prosecutors say Grayson can be seen in footage from inside the Capitol building — including in a livestream on Grayson's own Facebook page — wearing a black jacket with a large yellow "Q." 

Investigators say they believe Grayson has expressed support for QAnon, the pro-Trump conspiracy theory, and they have also cited photographs of Grayson with a leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys, as well as the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones.

As part of the case against Grayson, the government has also cited messages he allegedly sent around the time of pro-Trump rallies in November and December 2020. "I was beating commies with a flag pole I picked up," Grayson allegedly messaged someone after one such rally. "I left one unconscious so I did my little part and got the f*** out before I got arrested."

Federal prosecutors have not charged Grayson with any violent crimes. Still, during a federal court hearing in Grayson's case, an FBI agent testified that Grayson expressed no remorse for his alleged role in the Capitol rioting and that he expressed a "feeling or need to kill, and that included current President Joe Biden.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grayson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal prosecutors say they first learned about Christopher Grider's alleged involvement in the Capitol riot because he gave an interview to a local TV station in Texas. "The president asked people to come and show their support. I feel like it’s the least that we can do. It’s kind of why I came from central Texas all the way to D.C.,” Grider told KWTX. Grider said he witnessed the police shooting of Ashli Babbitt, who was killed by a Capitol Police officer while trying to climb through a broken window inside the Capitol. 

Prosecutors allege that Grider handed his helmet to another rioter, who used the helmet to break the glass window that Babbitt then tried to climb through. Grider also allegedly "attempted to push open the doors and then kick the doors in an attempt to breach the entrance leading to House Chamber where members of Congress were located." 

Grider was arrested in Austin, Texas, on Jan. 21, 2021, and was indicted on multiple charges, including destruction of government property, on Jan. 26, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grider pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Couy Griffin is a county commissioner in New Mexico, as well as the founder of the group Cowboys for Trump. According to federal prosecutors, Griffin spoke to the growing crowd outside the Capitol with a bullhorn and entered into restricted areas by the steps of the Capitol. He has not been charged with entering the Capitol building. 

Griffin has repeatedly questioned the results of the 2020 presidential election and has been a staunch ally of Donald Trump. He has been photographed with Trump inside the Oval Office. At times, Griffin has used violent rhetoric — for example, stating that "the only good Democrat is a dead Democrat." (He later said that he meant no physical harm to Democrats.) The day after the Capitol insurrection, according to court documents, he also said he planned to return to Washington, D.C., and said, "we could have a 2nd Amendment rally on those same steps that we had that rally yesterday. You know, and if we do, then it's gonna be a sad day, because there's gonna be blood running out of that building."

FBI agents interviewed Griffin about his actions on Jan. 6, and the agents said in a memo that "Griffin was proud of the turnout and commented that seeing the 'patriots' claiming control of the Capitol 'by God it felt pretty damn good.' "

Griffin was arrested on Jan. 17, 2021, and faces charges of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. 

Griffin's attorney has highlighted the fact that his charge relates only to his alleged presence in restricted areas outside the Capitol.

"The only conviction in his criminal history is a DUI almost 25 year ago," his attorney stated in one court filing. "He is a part of a large and loving family, including a sister and brothers and seven-year-old son, who are deeply concerned for his welfare, familiar with his case, and steeped in respect for law enforcement."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Griffin pleaded Not Guilty to both charges. A Bench Trial was held on March 21 and 22, 2022. Griffin was found Guilty of one count, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and Not Guilty of the second count, Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentenced on 6/17/2022 to 14 days incarceration (credit for time already served); 1 year supervised release; 60 hours community service; $3,000 fine; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary:
The federal government alleges that Jack Griffith can be seen in photos and videos from inside the Capitol building during the rioting on Jan. 6. After the riot, prosecutors say, Griffith posted on Facebook, "I even helped stormed [sic] the capitol today, but it only made things worse." 

In that same post, he said, "The New World Order beat us," an apparent reference to a popular conspiracy theory. He added, "Why, God? Why? WHY HAVE YOU FORSAKEN US? Unless...Trump still has a plan?"

The FBI arrested Griffith in Tennessee on Jan. 16, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Griffith pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/28/2021 to 36 months Probation which includes 90 days of home confinement (an additional 14 days was added due to probation violations); $10.00 special assessment; restitution in the amount of $500

summary:
Brian Gunderson, an ex-varsity football player, was identified by the superintendent of Byram Hills High School and multiple individuals of the community near Armonk, N.Y., according to the FBI. The identification came after community members saw photos and videos circulating in the media of an individual wearing a Byram Hills varsity letterman jacket. The North Castle township police chief informed the FBI and identified that the individual wearing the varsity jacket was Gunderson, based on the two-digit number on the jacket’s arm.

In an FBI interview, Gunderson allegedly admitted to being the person wearing the jacket. He claimed that he was pushed into the Capitol by the crowd but remained in there for about 10 minutes, prosecutors said. However, according to the affidavit, following the riot, Gunderson sent a text that read, “We all stormed the us capitol [sic] and tried to take over the government. We failed but f*** it.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gundersen pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
About a week after the Capitol insurrection, prosecutors say, Timothy Hale-Cusanelli started talking to someone about what happened that day and what he did. 

What Hale-Cusanelli likely did not realize, however, was that he was speaking with a confidential informant from the Naval Criminal Investigative Service, who was recording their conversation as part of a federal criminal investigation.

The confidential source told federal agents that Hale-Cusanelli is “an avowed white supremacist and Nazi sympathizer.” And in the recorded conversation, Hale-Cusanelli allegedly admitted to traveling from New Jersey to join the storming of the Capitol. He told the informant that if additional people had joined the mob, they could have taken over the Capitol.

Hale-Cusanelli later allegedly told FBI agents that he watched Donald Trump’s speech before going to the Capitol and “believed there was a strong chance, President Trump would be with them.”

Hale-Cusanelli is currently enlisted in the Army Reserve, where he serves as a sergeant in the 174th Infantry Brigade, the Army confirmed to NPR. He is a human resources specialist and has served since 2009. The Army says Hale-Cusanelli has not deployed as part of his military service. 

Court records state that he also works as a contractor at a naval weapons station, where he has a “secret” security clearance.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hale-Cusanelli was found Guilty of all charges. He is to be sentenced on Sept. 16, 2022.

summary:
Federal prosecutors say Peter Harding spoke extensively on video about joining the Capitol rioting. "We did what we needed to do. We made our point … and we got out," Harding said, according to a government affidavit filed in court. Harding was also allegedly seen inside the Capitol yelling "America first!" during a video livestream by Anthime Gionet, also known as "Baked Alaska." 

At one point, prosecutors allege, Harding held a lighter to a pile of camera equipment outside the Capitol while people chanted, "CNN sucks." 

Harding spoke to The Buffalo News and confirmed that he had used the lighter but said, "That was a symbolic gesture. Nothing burned." 

One of Harding's attorneys, Jason DiPasquale, has said, "Mr. Harding believes that the evidence, as the case goes on, will bear out that his intention in being there was to protest peacefully and that his actions were peaceful in nature and not violent while in there."
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary:
Alex Harkrider is part of Rescue the Universe, an organization that rescues people affected by hurricanes and tropical storms across the Gulf Coast. A witness who reported Harkrider to the FBI claims he and his friend Ryan Nichols were "planning a civil war," according to federal documents. The criminal complaint alleges Harkrider carried a baton as he and the crowd forced themselves inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021.

"We're in. 2 people killed already. We need all the patriots of this country to rally the f*** up and fight for our freedom or it's gone forever. Give us liberty, or give us death. We won't stand for it," Harkrider captioned photos of himself inside the Capitol building that he posted on Snapchat, according to court documents. 

Harkrider is a veteran, having attained the rank of lance corporal with the Marines Corps through his service from 2008 to 2012. He was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and then Afghanistan from 2010 to 2011. In a detention order dated Jan. 22, Judge K. Nicole Mitchell of the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas noted Harkrider's correspondence "discussing bringing firearms to the Capitol, evidence that the defendant did bring a weapon with him onto the Capitol grounds, and video evidence of the defendant entering the Capitol building." She added that Harkrider's "mental health history and past abuse of alcohol also support detention."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Harkrider pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
"It has come to my attention that there was someone who looks like me at the Capitol," Andrew Hatley, a truck driver from South Carolina, wrote on Facebook shortly after Jan. 6, 2021, according to the FBI complaint. "I'd like to set the record straight. I don't have that kind of motivation for lost causes. I just don't care enough anymore; certainly not enough for all that."

According to court documents, FBI agents claim Hatley's cellphone had been broadcasting his location at the Capitol building during the riot through Life360, a geolocation app that can share a person's location with other users of the app. When he was reached on the phone by the FBI, court documents state, Hatley said that "he was not sure how much he should say without legal counsel because he could be in a great deal of trouble."

He was arrested on Jan. 19, 2021, in Eloy, Ariz.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hatley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/16/2021 to 36 months probation; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500.

summary:
Stephanie Hazelton stood by an arched tunnel during the Capitol riot, waving people forward into the building, shouting, "We need more men ... not women" and calling for more helmets, according to the FBI's criminal complaint.

Also known as Ayla Wolf, Hazelton is an anti-vaccine activist who has previously tangled with New Jersey State Police. At a court hearing on Jan. 28, 2021, attorneys noted a case is still pending against her in Mercer County, N.J., for organizing a protest of more than 100 people on April 28, 2020, in violation of the governor's executive orders restricting public gatherings because of COVID-19.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Hazelton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Edward Hemenway, a trucker from Winchester, Va., attended the Stop the Steal rally on Jan. 6, 2021, with his cousin Robert Bauer and Bauer's wife. He told the FBI that he didn't know what was going to happen but had heard crazy things on social media. At the rally, Hemenway said, then-President Donald Trump said “something about taking Pennsylvania Avenue,” so Hemenway and Bauer followed the street down to the U.S. Capitol. Bauer's wife peeled off at some point along the way to return to their hotel, according to court documents. Hemenway said that the force of the crowd pushed them into the Capitol building but that neither of them tried to turn back. Inside the Capitol, he apologized to a police officer, who replied, "It's your house now, man," and gave Hemenway a half-hug.

Hemenway explained to FBI agents that he entered the Capitol out of “curiosity” and “stupidity," claiming he didn't know Congress was in session but that he did know Congress was certifying the Electoral College votes. The criminal complaint claims Hemenway "said that he knows being inside the U.S. Capitol under those circumstances was wrong."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct at the Grounds and in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hemenway pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/13/2021 to 45 days of incarceration; 60 hours of community service; $10 assessment fee; restitution in the amount of $500.00.

summary:
Prosecutors claim photos and videos taken on Jan. 6, 2021, show Emily Hernandez inside and outside the U.S. Capitol building, holding aloft a fragment of a wooden sign bearing the name and title of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Capitol officials estimated it will cost $870 to replace this nameplate, taken from above Pelosi's office door.

Hernandez's attorney told KMOV in St. Louis that Hernandez was "swept into the mass delirium of that event" and would just like to deal with the consequences and move on.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Hernandez pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 4/11/2022 to 30 days incarceration, one year of supervised release, 80 hours of community service, $500 restitution, $25 special assessment

summary: On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, Jacob Hiles posted a picture of himself on Facebook in sunglasses, a camouflage MAGA hat and a "F*** Antifa" sweatshirt with the caption, "Feelin cute … might start a revolution later, IDK." Later that day, he allegedly joined the mob that stormed the Capitol building and posted, "After being tear gassed for an hour, we entered the capitol, thousands of us." He added that he saw the police shoot a woman, later identified as Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt, and wrote, "I watched the American government attack it's [sic] own people today." Hiles said he did not witness any property damage or violence, allegedly posting, “While under the rotunda, I never saw anyone touch or vandalize anything and I distinctly heard several people saying ‘look but don’t touch.’ ” Hiles is a charter boat captain with Matador Sportfishing in Virginia Beach, Va., according to the company's website. He was arrested on Jan. 19, 2021, in Norfolk, Va.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hiles pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 12/6/2021 to 24 months of probation; 60 hours community service; Special Assessment of $10.00; and Restitution in the amount of $500.00.

summary: Yuji Hiraiwa was among 10 individuals arrested at about 7:15 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, just outside the Capitol building. D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser declared a public emergency with a curfew beginning at 6 p.m. that day, and District of Columbia police claim the group ignored three police warnings to disperse. They were charged with curfew violation and unlawful entry on federal ground.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Defendant entered into a Deferred Prosecution agreement. Case Dismissed-Nolle-Diversion 3/4/2022

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Jerod Wade Hughes and his brother, Joshua Calvin Hughes, watched as other rioters broke windows outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and that they then climbed inside. Jerod Wade Hughes allegedly then broke the lock on a door to allow more people inside. 

Both Hughes brothers were later seen in footage of the confrontation with Capitol Police officer Eugene Goodman, according to court documents, and joined with other rioters who followed Goodman and refused to follow orders to leave the building. Later, prosecutors say, they and other rioters entered the Senate Chamber, where they "sat in Senators’ chairs, opened Senators’ desks, and reviewed sensitive material stored therein."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hughes pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 11/22/2022

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Joshua Calvin Hughes and his brother, Jerod Wade Hughes, watched as other rioters broke windows outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and that they then climbed inside. 

Both Hughes brothers were later seen in footage of the confrontation with Capitol Police officer Eugene Goodman, according to court documents, and joined with other rioters who followed Goodman and refused to follow orders to leave the building. Later, prosecutors say, they and other rioters entered the Senate Chamber, where they "sat in Senators’ chairs, opened Senators’ desks, and reviewed sensitive material stored therein."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hughes pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 11/22/2022

summary:
Prosecutors allege Jason Hyland helped arrange a private plane — which he called a "Patriot Flight" — to take himself and others to Washington, D.C., for the rallies on Jan. 6, 2021.

Hyland later entered the Capitol building during the rioting, prosecutors allege, and can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the building. 

Federal agents interviewed Hyland, and he allegedly said that it appeared people were being actively let into the Capitol by law enforcement. 

Hyland said he asked a Capitol Police officer if he could go inside the Capitol, and the officer allegedly replied, "Everyone else is."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hyland pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/9/2022 to 7 days incarceration; $10 special assessment; $500 in restitution;  $4,000 fine

summary:
Suzanne Ianni, according to court documents, is active with the far-right group Super Happy Fun America, which advocates for "straight pride." The group also planned a parade in 2019 featuring a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys. Ianni is also a member of Town Meeting in Natick, Mass., a local government organization, according to WBUR. 

Super Happy Fun America supported Donald Trump's baseless accusations of widespread voter fraud and tweeted in early January that it was sending multiple buses to "the January 6th rally in support of the President and election integrity." 

Ianni helped organize those buses, according to federal prosecutors, and was later photographed inside the Capitol during the rioting.
charges: Entering or Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ianni pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
At age 20 at the time of the riot, Emanuel Jackson is among the youngest defendants in the Capitol riot cases. He has been accused of using a metal baseball bat to repeatedly hit police officers defending the Capitol from the mob just outside the building, as the officers blocked the blows with plexiglass shields. In a video from Jan. 6, 2021, he is heard saying, “I am fighting for America — we have been taken over by globalists and the Chinese. … I am fighting for America." 

Jackson later turned himself in to police and told investigators that he went to the Capitol to "halt the counting of the electoral votes and prevent the Electoral College from certifying the results of the presidential election."

Jackson's attorney described him as "recently homeless" and said in a court filing that he "has been diagnosed with several mental health conditions that limit his ability to perform the most basic daily functions." Both the government and Jackson's attorney say he has no criminal history as an adult. His lawyer also wrote in a Jan. 22, 2021, court filing that "the nature and circumstances of this offense must be viewed through the lens of an event inspired by the President of the United States."
charges: Obstructing or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building
case_updates: Jackson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal prosecutors say Douglas Austin Jensen can be seen in one of the most widely viewed videos of the rioting at the Capitol: one of him following a Capitol Police officer up a flight of stairs, trailed by a crowd of Trump supporters.

According to court documents, Jensen is "an adherent of QAnon" — the far-right conspiracy theory — and was wearing a "Q" shirt when he joined the storming of the Capitol. 

Jensen allegedly disregarded the police officer's orders to stop and put his hands up, and instead he "led the crowd toward the officer in a menacing manner, causing the officer to retreat and repeat his commands," which Jensen continued to ignore.

On Jan. 8, 2021, two days after the riot, Jensen turned himself in to police in Des Moines, Iowa and allegedly told investigators that he wore the "Q" shirt hoping that it would be photographed so that "Q" would "get the credit.”

On Jan. 11, 2021, a grand jury indicted Jensen on multiple charges related to his alleged role in the insurrection. According to TV station KCCI, Jensen also lost his job as a laborer with an Iowa masonry company in the wake of the riots.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Jensen pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Adam Johnson, prosecutors allege, is the man whom a photographer captured widely smiling and waving while carrying House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's lectern. He became known on social media as "podium guy."

A person who knew Johnson through a mutual friend allegedly identified Johnson to the FBI after seeing his photo.

The day after the riots, Capitol staff found the lectern in a corridor inside the Capitol building.

One of Johnson's attorneys, Dan Eckhart, told reporters that the photo of Johnson carrying the lectern presents a serious problem for his client's defense. 

"I don’t know how else to explain that, but, yeah, that would be a problem,” Eckhart said. “I'm not a magician."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building
case_updates: Johnson pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 2/25/2022 to 75 days of incarceration with credit for time served; Supervised Release for a period of 1 year; special assessment of $25; restitution of $500; fine of $5,000; 200 hours of community service

summary: Andrew Johnson was arrested outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, for allegedly violating the curfew order imposed by the mayor of Washington, D.C. The government has not alleged that he entered the Capitol building at any point during the riot.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Jury Trial scheduled for 3/13/2023

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Chad Jones joined the group of rioters who tried to breach an area of the Capitol along with rioter Ashli Babbitt. 

Jones allegedly used a "long, wood flagpole" to strike out a door's glass panel near the Speaker's Lobby as the mob shouted, "Break it down!" and "Let's f***ing go!" Soon after, Babbitt tried to climb through one of the doors' broken windows and was shot and killed.

Two days after the riot, a person identified as a "family member" of Jones contacted the FBI and said they recognized him from photos and videos of the scene. The family member also allegedly told the FBI that Jones had attended a previous Trump rally in Washington, D.C., and saw on Facebook that Jones had been planning to go to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. 

Jones was arrested on Jan. 16, 2021, in Kentucky.
charges: Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property Exceeding  $1,000; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol
case_updates: Jones pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Klete Keller is among the most prominent defendants charged in connection with the rioting at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Keller is a retired athlete who won five Olympic medals — including two gold medals — for swimming. 

Soon after the rioting, photos emerged of Keller allegedly joining the mob inside the Capitol while wearing a jacket labeled "USA," with a red and white patch for the U.S. Olympic Team. Keller is 6 feet, 6 inches tall, and investigators said his height helped identify him among the large crowd. 

After Keller was charged, USA Swimming issued a statement condemning Keller's alleged actions. "Mr. Keller's actions in no way represent the values or mission of USA Swimming," the statement reads. "And while once a swimmer at the highest levels of our sport — representing the country and democracy he so willfully attacked — Mr. Keller has not been a member of this organization since 2008."

Keller also resigned from his position with a commercial real estate company, The Los Angeles Times reported. One of Keller's former coaches told The New York Times that Keller had apologized for joining the rioting.  “He kept repeating, ‘You’ve done so much for me, and I let you down,’ " coach Mark Schubert told the newspaper. "He kept saying over and over, ‘I didn’t mean for any of this to happen.’ ”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Keller pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding.

summary:
According to the FBI, prior to the riot, Christopher Kelly was in contact with multiple people about his plans to travel to Washington, D.C., between Jan. 5 and Jan. 7 of 2021. “I’ll be with ex NYPD and some proud boys,” he allegedly said in a message. “This will be the most historic event of my life.” Court documents say Kelly’s brother is a retired New York Police Department officer. The Wall Street Journal reported that following the FBI’s report, the NYPD’s Internal Affairs Bureau started investigating a member of the department in connection with the Capitol riot.  

In addition, Kelly sent multiple Facebook messages in which he claimed to be inside the Capitol during the riot, according to the court documents. In one message, he sent a photo of the Capitol building and followed it with, “Taking this back by force now, no more bs,” according to the prosecutors. “MAGA is here full on. Capitol building is breached,” Kelly allegedly wrote in another message. “F*** these snakes. Out of OUR HOUSE!”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Aiding and Abetting; Unlawful Entry to Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct
case_updates: All charges against Christopher Kelly were dismissed on June 2. The Department of Justice stated in a court filing that, "upon reflection of the facts currently known to the government," dismissing the case "serves the interests of justice," but did not elaborate further.

summary:
Federal prosecutors allege that Kash Lee Kelly posted a picture of himself on Facebook from inside the Capitol during the rioting. He added this caption, according to court documents: "The day we let the Traitors who constantly push the divide in OUR country know that we are done playing their games. All ppl of all colors came together today and I couldn’t be more proud to be an AMERICAN." 

Screenshots of that Facebook post and others reached "law enforcement agents who have known Kelly for several years," prosecutors say. 

That appears to be a reference to an earlier federal criminal case against Kelly.

In 2017, Kelly pleaded guilty to drug charges related to his involvement with the gang known as the Latin Kings. At a plea hearing, Kelly testified, "I started selling marijuana because we didn't have anything. I started selling marijuana to make sure that my sister and I had food and to pay the light bill and stuff like that." He said that he joined the Latin Kings in 2006, when he was a teenager, and regularly sold marijuana with the gang until about 2009. Prosecutors described Kelly as an "enforcer" with the gang, and Kelly testified that, at one point, he committed a "home invasion" to try to "rob" people who he thought had marijuana. 

Kelly had not yet been sentenced in that case, and his alleged actions in the Capitol riot may now affect the outcome.

Kelly has been a vocal Trump supporter and shared debunked conspiracy theories about widespread voter fraud during the 2020 election. After the rioting, he appeared in YouTube videos and appeared to be unapologetic about his actions on Jan. 6, 2021, saying they were "very patriotic."
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kelly pleaded Not Guilty to the charge

summary:
Soon after the Capitol riot, Leo Christopher Kelly gave a video interview to LifeSiteNews, a news site founded by an anti-abortion group. Federal prosecutors now cite that interview in their criminal case against Kelly.

Kelly told LifeSiteNews that he came to Washington, D.C., from Iowa by himself, watched the president's speech and then walked over to the Capitol. "I wanted to see what was going on," he said.

Kelly said he saw the crowd pushing into the Capitol and thought to himself, "This is a moment in U.S. history that, like, it's not unlike the days of the beginning of the country." And he said he decided to enter the Capitol too, in part because he got "swept up in a movement." 

"It's not the logical mind that's working anymore. You're just reacting to things," he said, adding that he was frustrated that Donald Trump's claims of voter fraud had been repeatedly rejected in court. "At some point, there's enough illegal behavior and there's enough crimes against the Constitution being committed by the elected officials that what are you supposed to do?" he said. "None of my institutions are working." 

Kelly said he was inside the Capitol for between 30 and 60 minutes, describing the scene as "absolute chaos." He said he entered the Senate floor and then joined other rioters in saying a prayer. 

In the interview, Kelly expressed uncertainty about consequences for entering the Capitol, saying, "God will judge us for what we did."

Kelly was arrested on Jan. 18, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kelly pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Joshua Knowles was arrested alongside nine others for allegedly violating the curfew imposed by Washington, D.C., Mayor Muriel Bowser on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, police issued at least three warnings for the individuals to disperse and go indoors, but they did not obey the warnings. This resulted in their arrest.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 10/03/2022

summary:
FBI agents tracked down Edward Lang through a tip from an alleged childhood friend and by scouring his social media posts. According to charging documents, Lang posted photos and videos of himself at the Capitol on Jan. 6 and boasted about his participation. "I was the leader of Liberty today," said one of Lang's captions. "Arrest me. You are on the wrong side of history."

According to court records, photos allegedly of Lang on Jan. 6, 2021, show him at times wielding a shield and a bat. Lang allegedly "raised the shield above his head and thrusted it in the direction of the law enforcement officers" and "swung, thrusted, and/or jabbed the bat at law enforcement officers multiple times."

The following day, on Instagram, Lang said, "Pepper spray really does wonders for your complexion #1776.”

Federal investigators also found a post in which Lang allegedly discussed what would follow the attack on the Capitol with another social media user. Lang said, “Guns…That’s it. One word. The First Amendment didn’t work, we pull out the Second. We’re all civilized people and we love going to work and praying to God on Sundays and having nice family barbeques…and that was every single person there. No one wants to take this and and die for our rights, but dying for our rights is the only option that any person with a logical brain sees right now. This is it.”

According to multiple news reports, Lang's father, Ned Lang, is a former council member in Tusten, N.Y.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Lang pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
William Leary was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, in the 100 block of First Street NW, near the U.S. Capitol building, for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order, despite at least three warnings from Metropolitan Police Department officers to disperse, according to court documents. 

In an interview with The Associated Press, Leary said he believes the 2020 presidential election was stolen from Donald Trump, said he went to D.C. to show his support and denied going inside the Capitol.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Jury Trial scheduled for 3/13/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Mark Leffingwell repeatedly punched a U.S. Capitol Police officer while attempting to push into the Capitol building, according to court documents. The officer claims Leffingwell spontaneously apologized for striking out as he was being taken to the Capitol Police headquarters.

Leffingwell is an Iraq War veteran who suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder and a traumatic brain injury, according to attorney Mark Carroll, who represented Leffingwell at his arraignment hearing on Jan. 29, 2021. "This whole incident is an anomaly in his life. He's served his country valiantly," Carroll said. Leffingwell told the judge he is on a full-disability pension but still works part time at a packaging factory.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building
case_updates: Leffingwell pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/10/2022 to 6 months incarceration; 2 years supervised release; 200 hours community service; $2,000 restitution; $100 special assessment

summary:
Jacob Lewis owns a fitness business in Victorville, Calif., and is known locally as a face of the anti-coronavirus restriction movement there. According to numerous local media reports, he refused to keep his gym closed after California Gov. Gavin Newsom ordered nonessential businesses to shutter in order to try to tamp down the spread of the coronavirus.

When he reopened the gym in May, Lewis raised an American flag out front and set up a cardboard cutout of the Constitution for customers to pose next to for selfies. Now, according to court documents, he stands accused of breaching the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

The court documents say he told a friend back in December 2020 to “watch what happens to the Capitol on the 6th.”

On Jan.15, 2021, law enforcement officials sat down with Lewis in Victorville, and he said he’d traveled to D.C. to attend the rally and had walked to the Capitol and went inside, according to court documents. But he said he was “escorted” by the police.
 
U.S. Capitol Police video captured someone who officials believe was Lewis breaching the Senate Wing door, walking through the Hall of Columns and the crypt and then exiting a short time later. There is no evidence, the court documents said, that Lewis was escorted in any way.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lewis pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/14/2022 to 24 months probation; $3,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: Kevin Loftus was photographed carrying an American flag in the rotunda of the U.S. Capitol building. Court documents claim he posted these pictures to Facebook saying that he was "one of 700 inside" and that "some of us are in it to win it." He later posted a New York Post article to his Facebook profile, noting, "i am wanted by the FBI for illegal entry." Former Wisconsin state Sen. David Zien described Loftus as a patriotic and commendable veteran to WQOW. He claimed Loftus did not act maliciously within the Capitol building. "The crowd was so wrapped up in the magic of the moment, they were pushing, and he couldn't have turned back if he would have wanted to," Zien told WQOW. Loftus told NPR in an interview that he signed up for a membership with the The Oath Keepers in 2016, and participated in one event with the extremist group. He said he stopped paying dues to the Oath Keepers in 2019 and disavowed the group. In his interview with NPR, Loftus discussed his Army service in the 1990s.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Loftus pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The remaining charges were dismissed. Sentenced 3/15/22 to three years of probation; 60 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
Court documents claim Joshua Lollar, of Spring, Texas, tangled with officers during an unsuccessful attempt to pass through police lines deeper into the Capitol building. Prosecutors claim Lollar streamed footage of the Capitol riot live on Facebook, writing, “Sorry they are jamming the phones so I can’t do much about a live stream or uploading. I’ll do my best, it’s about to get spicy boi!”

At a hearing, he told a judge he was unemployed, with 78 cents in his bank account. Army representatives confirmed to NPR that Lollar served as an infantryman in the U.S. Army from January 2002 to November 2009 and completed one combat deployment to Iraq from 2003 to 2004.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Aiding and Abetting; Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lollar pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Two days after the riot at the Capitol, prosecutors allege, John Lolos boarded a Delta flight departing from Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. After Lolos repeatedly yelled, "Trump 2020!" on board, the flight crew decided to turn back and escort Lolos off the flight, court records indicate. 

About 45 minutes later, a police officer at the airport recognized Lolos from photographs of the Capitol riot — Lolos was also allegedly wearing the same shirt as in the photos — and called up additional help from police and FBI personnel, who then arrested Lolos. When law enforcement searched Lolos' possessions, prosecutors say, they found the same pro-Trump flag that Lolos appeared to have in photos of the Capitol riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
