case_updates: Lolos pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/19/2021 to 14 days incarceration; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary:
Robert Lyon and Dustin Thompson, who is also facing charges related to the Capitol riot, drove to D.C. together for the pro-Trump rally, according to court documents. 

At around 6 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, two U.S. Capitol Police officers came across Lyon and Thompson sitting on a sidewalk near the Capitol and waiting for an Uber, according to court documents. They were asked to leave the area, and as they were leaving, Thompson grabbed a coat rack that was later confirmed to be from inside the Capitol, according to court records. The officers asked Thompson to put it down, which he did. But Thompson then allegedly fled. Lyon stayed behind and cooperated. 

On Jan. 11, 2021, Lyon was interviewed by FBI agents at his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was confronted by FBI agents with a text message he allegedly sent to Thompson saying, "We need to get the f*** out with this trophy." Lyon insisted he had not been inside the Capitol, though security footage from inside the Capitol and detailed in the court documents appears to show otherwise.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lyon pleaded Guilty to two charges: Theft of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentencing continued to 9/22/2022

summary:
Before the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, Kevin Lyons posted on Instagram that he was heading to Washington, D.C., from his home in Chicago. "I refuse to tell my children that I sat back and did nothing," Lyons allegedly posted. "I am heading to DC to STOP THE STEAL!" Later, prosecutors say, that same Instagram account posted a photo of a plaque from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office with the caption, "WHOS [sic] HOUSE?!?!? OUR HOUSE!!"

Two days after the rioting, on Jan. 8, 2021, FBI agents interviewed Lyons in Chicago. When agents showed Lyons the Instagram post of Pelosi's office, he allegedly replied, "Wow, you are pretty good. That was up for only an hour." Prosecutors say that Lyons then provided additional photos and videos from inside the Capitol to the FBI and told agents that he entered Pelosi's office but did not cause any damage. 

Fox 32 Chicago reported that Lyons works for a heating and cooling company and that his manager referred to him as an "upstanding employee." 

Lyons was arrested on Jan. 13, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Lyons pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal investigators say they learned about Dominick Madden's alleged involvement in the Capitol riot through an article in the New York Post that identified Madden as a New York City sanitation worker. 

Madden can allegedly be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol during the riot. Prosecutors say they also obtained evidence that Madden traveled to the Washington, D.C., region from license plate readers. Madden, prosecutors allege, was wearing a "Q" sweatshirt on the day of the rioting, suggesting that he's an adherent of the far-right conspiracy theory QAnon. The New York Post reported that he also shouted, “When we go one, we go all!" — a QAnon slogan. 

According to court documents, Madden later told investigators with the New York City Department of Sanitation that he was "out on sick leave" on Jan. 6 and "admitted to being out of the house without authorization during this time frame." 

Madden was arrested on Jan. 21, 2021, in New York.

New York's Daily News reported that Madden has since resigned from his job with the Sanitation Department.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Madden pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary:
Kristina Malimon and her mother were arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside the Capitol for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse.

Malimon is the vice chair of the Young Republicans of Oregon. Her bio on the organization's website says she is also an ambassador to Turning Point USA and Liberty University's Falkirk Center.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 10/03/2022 in DC Superior Court

summary: Yevgeniya Malimon and her daughter were arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside the Capitol for allegedly violating the District of Columbia's curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 10/03/2022 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Anthony Mariotto, who goes by Tony, summed it up in a smiling Facebook photo taken from the balcony of the Senate gallery on Jan. 6, 2021. “I’m in,” it said. “And there are just a few This is our house.” The post was sent to authorities by a private citizen who said they had known Mariotto for about a year.

According to court documents, the FBI found Mariotto in Georgia 10 days after the breach of the Capitol building and interviewed him over the phone. Mariotto said that he and his wife had listened to Donald Trump’s speech and then followed the crowd to the Capitol.

Mariotto allegedly told the agent that he thought he “was being part of history” and walked through the Capitol chanting, “USA.”  He conceded he knew he was not allowed to be there, the court documents said. 

Mariotto voluntarily met with an agent and gave him his phone, and the agent found the selfie that the private citizen had sent to authorities.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mariotto pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/17/2021 to 3 years probation; $5,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 250 hours community service

summary:
According to court documents, a tipster who recorded a video Felipe Marquez posted on Snapchat turned over the evidence to federal investigators.

The video is a compilation of clips allegedly showing Marquez driving from Florida to Washington, a scene from an outdoor rally near the Washington Monument, a crowd on the U.S. Capitol grounds, people climbing over a stone rail/fence and eventually a scene inside a conference room that federal investigators believe is in the office of Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Ore.

Marquez spoke with CBS Miami after the riot. “I went on the 6th to D.C. to protest against communism and prostitution,” Marquez said. "This is like a Rosa Parks, like Martin Luther King moment for me." 

Marquez said he learned about the event in Washington from the remarks of the president.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Marquez pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 18 months Probation with conditions; $25 special assessment; imposition of a fine waived; restitution in the amount of $500

summary:
Zachary Martin was first identified by the FBI from a tip submitted to the agency that alerted agents to video streams allegedly uploaded by Martin to Facebook. The videos allegedly show Martin, who goes by Zac, in front of a painting of former New York Rep. Shirley Chisholm that is located inside the Capitol building. Martin later deleted his account, according to court documents. Subsequently, multiple witnesses apoke to the FBI and allegedly confirmed his presence at the Capitol. 

Martin was arrested on Jan. 28, 2021, in Missouri.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Martin pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/17/2022 to 3 years probation; $500 restitution; $1,000 fine and $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: According to court documents, Ryan Mason was charged with entering or attempting to enter the U.S. Capitol grounds and violation of a curfew against the will of the Capitol Police.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Mason entered into a deferred prosecution agreement on June 11, 2021. Under that agreement, Mason must complete community service, must not violate any laws, and can only enter Washington, DC in order to confer with his lawyer. If he abides by that agreement for six months, the charges will be dismissed.  On 12/13/2021, Nolle Diversion successfully completed, case dismissed.

summary:
Social media posts allegedly by Matthew Mazzocco place him at and inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021.

A Facebook photo in court documents shows Mazzocco, a mortgage loan officer, right outside the Capitol building with the caption,"The Capital [sic] is ours!" In a video, Mazzocco appears to be looking out a window, where the back of a police line in the exterior plaza of the Capitol building is visible. At one point, Mazzocco is allegedly seen and heard telling rioters not to take or destroy anything, and that they were probably going to get in trouble for what they were doing.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mazzocco pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. He was sentenced 10/4/2021 to 45 days of incarceration; 60 hours of community service; $10 assessment fee; $500 restitution

summary:
In the days following the riot, an old friend of Justin McAuliffe's sent photos of the certified public accountant inside the U.S. Capitol building to the FBI, according to court documents. The photos were allegedly taken from McAuliffe’s Facebook account, which was deleted after Jan. 6, 2021. The court documents also show screenshots of a Facebook message sent by McAuliffe. “Yeah, I was in one of the offices,” the Bellmore, N.Y., resident allegedly admitted. “Some people were smoking a joint in the room.” 

A tip also led the FBI to a Telegram account associated with McAuliffe's cellphone number. Prosecutors claim the display picture associated with McAuliffe’s account showed him sitting in an office at the Capitol.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McAuliffe pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/28/2022 to 3 years probation; 60 days home detention/location monitoring; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
A federal grand jury has indicted Patrick McCaughey III on nine counts. Federal investigators say that McCaughey was in the front line of rioters and that he used a police riot shield to pin Officer Daniel Hodges between the shield and a door. In a widely circulated video, Officer Hodges is seen crying out in pain. Another rioter ripped off Officer Hodges’ gas mask exposing his bloodied mouth.

Investigators identified McCaughey with the help of a tip from someone who knew him and from his appearance and voice in several different videos, according to court documents. 

“Even after days of seeing so many shocking and horrific scenes from the siege on the U.S. Capitol, the savage beating of D.C. Metropolitan Police Officer Hodges stands out for the perpetrator’s blatant disregard for human life,” said Steven M. D’Antuono, assistant director in charge of the FBI Washington Field Office. “Patrick McCaughey’s actions were violent, barbaric, and completely out of control.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: McCaughey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: According to court documents, Mauricio Mendez has been charged in D.C.’s Superior Court with entering or attempting to enter the U.S. Capitol Grounds and violation of a curfew, against the will of the Capitol Police.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 1/17/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Cleveland Meredith Jr. is facing criminal charges from both Washington, D.C., authorities and the federal government. 

Washington, D.C., police arrested Meredith for allegedly assaulting a man in a traffic-related incident in Washington on Jan. 7, 2021, the day after the rioting. 

In an interview with law enforcement from his room at a Holiday Inn in Washington, Meredith allegedly told FBI agents that he traveled to the area for the "Stop The Steal" rally, but arrived too late. 

While agents interviewed him, prosecutors say, they discovered that Meredith sent text messages about bringing a "sh** ton" of armor piercing ammunition with him, and said he considered "putting a bullet" in House Speaker Nancy's Pelosi's "noggin on Live TV."  In another text, Meredith allegedly wrote, “I’m gonna run that C*** Pelosi over while she chews on her gums” and threatened Washington Mayor Muriel Bowser, writing, “I may wander over to the Mayor’s office and put a 5.56 in her skull." Agents then searched Meredith's trailer and allegedly found, "a Glock 19, nine millimeter pistol, a Tavor X95 assault rifle and approximately hundreds of rounds of ammunition."

In addition to the allegation of assault, Meredith is now facing charges related to his alleged threats to public officials, as well as weapons charges. 

11 Alive News in Atlanta reported that Meredith’s family had previously alerted his local police department, "because they were concerned about his behavior and ties to QAnon." According to court documents, Meredith texted someone on Jan. 7, "Calm before the STORM," which is a phrase commonly cited by QAnon adherents.
charges: Interstate Communication of Threats; Possession of Unregistered Firearms; Possession of Unregistered Ammunition; Possession of Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Devices
case_updates: Meredith pleaded Guilty to one charge: Interstate Communication of Threats. Sentenced 12/14/2021 to 28 months in prison with credit for time served; 36 months of supervised release; $100 special assessment

summary:
Federal prosecutors say that in the days ahead of the Capitol riot, Garret Miller posted on Facebook about his plans to go to Washington, D.C. 

“I am about to drive across the country for this trump s***," Miller posted, according to an affidavit filed in federal court. "Some crazy s*** going to happen this week. Dollar might collapse ... civil war could start."

On the day of the riot, Miller allegedly tweeted a 14-second video from inside the Capitol, and later posted a selfie on Facebook from the rotunda in the Capitol.

According to the government, one of Miller's Facebook friends commented on the selfie, “bro you got in?! Nice!” Miller replied, “just wanted to incriminate myself a little lol.”

Miller also allegedly tweeted on Jan. 6, 2021, that "next time we bring the guns," and replied to a tweet from Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez with, "Assassinate AOC."

Days after the riot, Miller also allegedly posted about the U.S. Capitol Police officer who shot and killed Ashli Babbitt. 

"We going to get a hold of [the USCP officer] and hug his neck with a nice rope," Miller allegedly wrote on Instagram. 

Miller was arrested in Texas on Jan. 20, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder (2 counts); Obstruction of an Official Proceeding (charge was dismissed); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Interstate Threats to Injure or Kidnap; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Miller pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Matthew Miller is accused of discharging a fire extinguisher on the steps leading to an entrance to the Capitol building. The FBI said he also used a section of the crowd control barriers as a ladder to scale the walls of the west side of the Capitol plaza and assisted other rioters with scaling Capitol walls.

According to images the FBI collected, Miller was dressed in a black cowboy hat and a Washington Capitals red, white and blue jersey. He also allegedly had a Gadsden flag -- a symbol for the Tea Party, Second Amendment advocates and organizations opposing government overreach -- tied around his neck.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Miller pleaded Guilty to two charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. On 5/23/22 Miller was sentenced to 33 months incarceration, 24 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution, $200 special assessment; 100 hours community service

summary:
Jordan Mink allegedly used a baseball bat to shatter windows at the U.S. Capitol building, according to charging documents. 

After reviewing video footage and photogaphs, investigators believe Mink entered the Capitol building through that broken window and started removing property from inside the building, handing items over to the crowd outside.

In a review of his social media accounts, a federal investigator found that on Nov. 3, 2020 – Election Day – Mink posted a selfie on Instagram holding a gun with a sticker that says, “I Voted," and a caption that read, “The ballot is stronger than the bullet – Abraham Lincoln. “Well … my magazines will be fully loaded just in case it’s not.”

The judge presiding over Mink's case has ordered Mink to stay in custody until his trial.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers
case_updates: Mink pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
“I came up the stairs where the scaffolding was,” David Mish Jr. told a detective with the Washington Metropolitan Police, according to court documents. “I was with a group of guys… [E]verybody was yelling ‘breach the building.’” 

Mish had contacted the Washington, D.C., police on Jan. 7, 2021, according to court documents, so he could provide information on the fatal shooting of Ashli Babbitt, the woman shot by police in the early moments of the siege on the Capitol building. The court documents don’t provide detail on what he told the officer about that shooting.
 
Mish did tell the detective, according to court documents, that he had gone into the Capitol but that “I didn’t break anything.” Indeed, video surveillance footage captures Mish outside the Speaker’s Lobby in the Capitol building, according to court documents. He was wearing a black sweater, blue jeans and a Blue Lives Matter T-shirt and a hat with the American flag on it.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mish pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/18/2021 to 30 days incarceration; restitution of $500.00; and $10.00 Special Assessment.

summary:
Faculty and fellow students from the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan recognized Nicolas Moncada in Instagram and Twitter posts from both inside and outside the Capitol building on Jan 6, 2021. 

According to court documents, one photograph was captioned: “Outside Pelosi’s office.”
 
In response to a video Moncada allegedly posted, someone asked him what was going on. Moncada, allegedly responded, “Storming the Capitol Building.” An image of the exchange is in court documents. In another, Moncada says he’s in the “Building where Senate & House are conducting Electoral Vote Count.”
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Buildings or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary:
Professional hunting and river guide Patrick Montgomery allegedly posted photographs on Facebook inside the Senate chambers of the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. 

A tipster who knew Montgomery saw a post and asked if it was him, according to court documents. Montgomery said it was. “You have been reported to the police in D.C. as well as the FBI,” the tipster wrote, the court documents say. “Im [sic] so deeply covered by the best Federal Defense lawyers in the country in case you chicken sh** cry boys don’t want it [sic] takes to defend our freedom from these corrupt politicians,” Montgomery responded, according to court documents. 

Montgomery told the tipster that he “didn’t storm the castle violently. My group was let in peacefully by the police we were talking to with respect. We came a[n]d left peacefully before the anarchist and Antifa showed up breaking sh** and being hoodlums.”

Someone who told authorities she went to high school with Montgomery said he posted something on his Facebook page on Jan. 5, 2021, that said he was heading to Washington, D.C., and said he was “figuring out what we do next moving forward.” 

On Jan. 7, the day after the riot, a tipster told the FBI that Montgomery had deleted his Facebook and Instagram accounts, according to court documents.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Montgomery pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
“The election was stolen,” Aaron Mostofsky told a New York Post reporter in a video interview from the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. He was draped head to toe in fur pelts and was wearing a bulletproof vest that read “Police” on the front.

“We were cheated,” he told the reporter, echoing Trump’s baseless claims of election fraud. “I don’t think 75 million people voted for Trump, Mostofsky told the reporter. “I think it was close to 85 million people.” 

Authorities matched Mostofsky’s driver’s license photo to the image in the video, according to court documents. Public media reports have also determined that he is the son of a Brooklyn judge.

An FBI review of social media accounts belonging to Mostofsky allegedly found videos and posts that placed Mostofsky inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. 

He was also captured in another photograph carrying a U.S. Capitol Police shield and wearing a Capitol police officer’s bulletproof vest. A message was sent to Mostofsky regarding the photo that read: “Your famous.” Mostofsky allegedly responded with: “IK unfortunately.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mostofsky pleaded Guilty to three charges: Civil Disorder, Theft of Government Property and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced to 8 months incarceration; 12 months supervised release; 200 hours community service; $2,000 restitution; $150 special assessment

summary:
Eric Munchel "was dressed for combat" on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Photographs allegedly show him inside the Senate gallery wearing combat boots, a tactical vest with a Punisher logo on it and black camouflaged pants, holding zip-tie handcuffs with a taser on his hip. He became known on social media after the riot as "zip tie guy."

Munchel, a server at a bar/restaurant in Nashville, also had a cell phone allegedly mounted to his chest with the camera facing forward. Federal prosecutors say video from that phone shows Munchel stashed away weapons at some unknown location just outside the U.S. Capitol building right before he joined the mob that stormed the building. 

In a search of his home several days later, federal agents allegedly found approximately 15 firearms, including assault rifles, a sniper rifle, other rifles, shotguns and pistols, as well as hundreds of rounds of ammunition.

Court documents say agents also found a video on Munchel's phone from Jan. 6 that allegedly show him crossing paths and bumping fists with a member of the far-right, pro-Trump Oath Keepers militia, as one of them says, “There’s 65 more of us coming.”

Munchel allegedly took part in the insurrection with his mother, Lisa Eisenhart, and both are now face charges of conspiracy. Munchel's lawyer has argued her client participated in the  insurrection only because former President Donald Trump said the election was rigged.
charges: Conspiracy to Commit Obstruction; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Munchel pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On Dec. 20, 2020, Henry Muntzer, known as Hank, posted a meme on Facebook that depicted "President Trump's encouragement to attend a January 6, 2020 'wild' rally," according to court documents. In his Facebook post, he wrote: “I will be going to Washington DC. Anyone that would like to join me let me know." Two days later, he posted again, offering to pay for some of the travel expenses for anyone who couldn't afford to go. Later, Muntzer posted that he and other "patriots" had rented a house and offered it to anyone who needed a place to stay, according to court documents. 

On Jan. 6, 2021, Muntzer posted at least two videos on Facebook from inside the Capitol, according to court documents. In one post, he said, "We sent the message that we are not going to take it, we want our country back."

Muntzer is the owner of an appliance store in Dillon, Mont. According to the Dillon Tribune, Muntzer's business is known around the city for a "QAnon-supporting mural" that covers the building.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Muntzer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
Marsha Murphy was arrested and accused of trespassing on Capitol grounds and violating the Jan. 6, 2021, curfew in Washington.

Murphy runs an ammunition sales business in Oklahoma.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: On 12/13/2021, Charge Disposed - Pled Guilty and Sentencing Deferred. Deferred Sentencing Review scheduled 3/17/2023

summary:
It was just a couple of years ago that Ryan Nichols appeared on The Ellen DeGeneres Show after a video of him rescuing animals after Hurricane Florence went viral. Nichols was also mentioned in an NPR piece for his rescues at the time. Now, the U.S. Marine veteran is facing multiple charges for participating in the Capitol riot. 

According to court documents, photographs and video of Nichols allegedly show him standing on the ledge of a broken window at the Capitol building holding a bullhorn and crowbar, yelling into a bullhorn at the crowd, "If you have a weapon, you need to get your weapon!" and also yelling, "This is the second revolution right here folks! ... This is not a peaceful protest." At one point, Nichols allegedly took a large aerosol canister from someone in the crowd and spraying an unknown substance in the direction of the entrance, where officers were trying to hold back the mob. 

According to court documents, Nichols openly talked about his plans to travel to Washington on Facebook ahead of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. "By Bullet or Ballot, Restoration of the Republic is Coming," he said in one post on Dec. 24, 2020.  A few days later, Nichols posted, "Pence better do the right thing, or we're going to MAKE you do the right thing."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Nichols pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Ethan Nordean, also known as Rufio Panman, is a member of the Proud Boys, according to court records. Nordean is the “sergeant of arms” of the Seattle chapter of the organization. 

Pictures and videos show Nordean was allegedly "among those who entered the Capitol building after rioters forced entry and pushed past officers,” according to court records.

Social media posts by Nordean show that prior to Jan. 6, 2021, he and other Proud Boys members were planning to organize a group that would attempt “to overwhelm police barricades” and enter the Capitol building.

On Jan. 8, 2021, according to court records, Nordean posted on Parler: "if you feel bad for the police, you are part of the problem.” The picture accompanying the post was of a police officer using pepper spray on a rioter.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts)
case_updates: Nordean pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Nicholas Ochs was a decorated Marine. He left the service in 2018. According to interviews he gave to the media, Ochs is the leader and founder of a Hawaii chapter of the Proud Boys. His right forearm says as much -- it has a tattoo that reads “Proud Boy.” 

According to court documents, Ochs forwarded a Nov. 16, 2020, tweet from President Trump declaring: “I WON THE ELECTION!” Ochs said that “leftists” won’t do anything when “he just keeps being president.” 

“Hello from the Capitol lol,” he posted on his Twitter account on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. “We didn’t have to break in,” he told CNN. “I just walked in and filmed.” 

Ochs ran as a Republican for a seat in the Hawaii House of Representatives last year, on a platform that included, among other things, objecting to the restrictive way Hawaii’s state leaders were dealing with the pandemic. 

He was initially charged with acts during civil disorder and entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. A superseding indictment accuses him of conspiring with others to plan, raise money and travel to Washington to disrupt Congress, posting images and video of the incursion in real time, and defacing the U.S. Capitol’s Memorial Door with the words “MURDER THE MEDIA,” the name of the Proud Boys' social media video collective.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Ochs pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
The government alleges that multiple people sent in tips that Christopher Ortiz had posted video on Instagram from inside the Capitol during the rioting. 

Ortiz allegedly exchanged messages with one person about his actions on Jan. 6, 2021, saying he went to the Capitol because he is "vehemently against CCP influence in our government." ("CCP" appears to be a reference to the Chinese Communist Party.) 

"I didn’t break or vandalize or steal," he wrote, according to court documents. "I walked through and out."

“I’d storm the Capitol for you any day," he allegedly wrote. 

Those messages were then shared with the FBI, and Ortiz was arrested on Jan. 27, 2021, in New York state.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ortiz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/9/2022 to 12 months of Probation; 60 days location monitoring/home confinement; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500; 100 hours community service

summary:
Robert Packer, allegedly seen in videos wearing a "Camp Auschwitz" sweatshirt at the Capitol riot, is facing federal charges of unlawfully entering a restricted area and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.

According to the criminal complaint, a witness who often saw Packer at his store in Newport News, Va., wearing that sweatshirt tipped off the FBI.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Packer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charge is dismissed. Sentencing continued to 8/25/2022

summary: According to court documents, John Parker was charged with entering or attempting to enter the U.S. Capitol grounds and violation of a curfew against the will of the Capitol Police.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Jury Trial scheduled for 3/13/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
William Pepe, an alleged member of the Proud Boys, was indicted on conspiracy and other charges in connection with the Capitol riot. 

According to charging documents, Pepe, a New York MTA worker, called in sick so he could travel to Washington.

Federal prosecutors allege he met up with other members of the Proud Boys near Capitol grounds, where they chanted "f*** antifa" and "we love Trump." Court documents also say they toppled metal barriers set up by the Capitol Police and assaulted officers who were trying to control access to the Capitol grounds.
charges: Conspiracy; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Pepe pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to court documents, Matthew Perna posted an 8-minute video on his Facebook account on Jan. 6, 2021. It was shot inside a hotel room, and in it, Perna and a woman sitting next to him describe what they had just seen and done at the Capitol. About two minutes in, Perna allegedly says, “Steve and I, we walked right into the Capitol Building.”
 
Perna was No. 73 on an FBI bulletin of suspects, and when friends and acquaintances saw an image of Perna on the list, they called the FBI. 

According to court documents, acquaintances told the FBI that Perna followed QAnon and had recently purchased a handgun.

On Jan. 14, 2021, agents interviewed Perna at his home and he said, according to the documents, that he had attended the Trump rally on Jan. 6 and marched with the others to the Capitol. He said he and a friend had climbed to the top of the steps of the Capitol and were surprised to find the door open. He told agents, according to the documents, that he was pushed into the building by the crowd and had not intended to go inside. 

According to the court filing, Perna initially said he was only inside for five or 10 minutes. He later admitted, it said, to becoming frustrated and “using a metal pole, tapped on a window of the Capitol building.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Perna pleaded Guilty to all charges. The Mercer County Coroner's office confirmed that Perna committed suicide at his residence on Feb. 25, 2022.The prosecution of Perna is ABATED due to his death.

summary: According to a criminal complaint, Rachael Lynn Pert was at the riot with her boyfriend, Dana Joe Winn. Pert, an assistant manager at a Circle K, was identified by one of her co-workers, according to the FBI. Prosecutors say her co-worker told the FBI that Pert took time off from work to attend the rally. According to court documents, in a video recovered from Winn’s Facebook account, he can be heard saying, “We’re headed to D.C. because us as American patriots, we're tired of all this s---. It's time to take a stand.... America needs to wake up," while Pert sits next to him. He also adds that they brought flagpoles “to hit Antifa in the head if need be.” In an interview with the FBI, Pert allegedly admitted to entering the Capitol and identified herself in a picture that was taken inside the building on Jan. 6, 2021. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Pert is a U.S. Navy veteran.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pert pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/20/2021 to 24 Months Probation; 100 hours community service;  $25.00 Special Assessment; $500 restitution

summary:
According to charging documents, Dominic Pezzola, of Rochester, N.Y., ripped away a Capitol Police officer’s riot shield and used it to smash a window at the U.S. Capitol. A viral video appears to show him doing so. 

The indictment against him alleges that he is a member of the Proud Boys and that he engaged in a conspiracy to obstruct, influence, impede and interfere with law enforcement officials trying to protect the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. 

Court documents say that a video posted to social media appears to show Pezzola smoking a cigar in the Capitol building, and in it, he says, “I knew we could take this mother****** over [if we] just tried hard enough.” 

A witness came forward, according to court documents, and told authorities that Pezzola is known as “Spaz” and that they recognized him as the person who used the shield to break the window. 

The witness said other members of his group talked about things they had done that day, and they said that anyone they got their hands on they would have killed, including Nancy Pelosi. The witness also allegedly told the FBI that they said they would have killed Vice President Pence if given the chance.

The witness also told the FBI, according to the court documents, that the group said they would be returning for the presidential Inauguration on Jan. 20, 2021, and they plan to kill every single “m-fer” they can. In a later interview, the witness said the group had no definitive date for a return but had said they would be back.

Pezzola served in the Marine Corps Reserves from 1998 to 2005.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts); Robbery of Personal Property of the United States
case_updates: Pezzola pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Until very recently, Tam Dinh Pham, of Richmond, Texas, was an 18-year-employee of the Houston Police Department. That changed after the FBI recovered deleted photographs from his phone that showed he was inside the Capitol Rotunda on Jan. 6, 2021.  

Court documents say Pham told FBI agents that he went to Washington, D.C., on a business trip with his wife and a friend and that they went to the Trump rally to “see history.” He allegedly followed the crowd to the Capitol, court documents say, went around downed barricades and entered the building. He took pictures of himself in front of some of the art in the Capitol. He has been charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.

His attorney, Nicole DeBorde, told NPR that Pham is a quiet man with a strong Buddhist faith who feels a great deal of shame for what happened. He also, she said, believes Joe Biden won the election. He has since resigned from the Houston Police Department.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pham pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 45 days in jail; $500 in restitution; $10 assessment; $1,000 fine

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, Daniel Phipps was identified when the FBI received a tip from a Fort Worth Police analyst who was monitoring social media to locate local residents who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Phipps allegedly commented on a Facebook post about a bus that was planning to travel to D.C. for the protest. Further investigation revealed a Facebook photo of Phipps inside the Capitol building with an American flag draped over his shoulder. 

“Everyone talks about being a patriot until its time to do patriot s---,” he allegedly wrote in another Facebook post, according to court documents. “I went to DC. I helped take the Hill. I helped other patriots prevent Antifa from damaging anything. I exercised my 1st amendment right to take grievances to our representatives. It was a (mostly peaceful) political protest.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Physical Contact; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Phipps pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Christine Priola was photographed in the Senate chamber on Jan. 6, 2021, holding a sign under her arm that read “The Children Cry Out for Justice” while she helped someone sitting in Vice President Pence’s chair take a selfie, according to court documents.

Court documents say she was wearing a red winter coat and distinctive pants that had the word “Trump” emblazoned on the leg. 

Photographs and videos later recovered by law enforcement officials after a search of her home helped place Priola in the Capitol on Jan. 6 in that red coat and distinctive pants, according to charging documents.

Priola had been an occupational therapist with the Cleveland Metropolitan School District. She resigned just a day after the breach on the Capitol. Her resignation letter said she was stepping down because she didn’t want to take a coronavirus vaccine in order to return to in-person learning. She said she had decided to dedicate her life to exposing human trafficking and pedophilia “in our government” -- something that QAnon followers are intent on doing, though there is no suggestion in the charging documents that she follows the group.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Priola pleaded Guilty to the charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 10/28/2022

summary:
Joshua Pruitt was initially arrested for breaking a citywide curfew in Washington, D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021. Police had asked a group on the Capitol Grounds to disperse, and when Pruitt and others didn’t comply, court documents say, he was arrested.

It was only while he was being processed that D.C. police noticed that he appeared to be a person pictured entering the Capitol on a Washington Post website.

Pruitt was read his Miranda rights, waived them and spoke to investigators, telling them that he was indeed the person in the photograph and that he had gone into the Capitol, but didn’t engage in any unlawful activity. Rather, the court documents say he told investigators, he was trying to de-escalate the situation inside.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Pruitt pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 8/29/2022

summary: Nazeer Qaim was arrested the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, and has been charged with entering or attempting to enter the U.S. Capitol grounds and violation of a curfew against the will of the Capitol Police.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Qaim entered into a deferred prosecution agreement on June 11, 2021. Under that agreement, Qaim must complete community service, must not violate any laws, and can only enter Washington, DC in order to confer with his lawyer. If he abides by that agreement for six months, the charges will be dismissed. On 12/13/2021, Nolle Diversion successfully completed, case dismissed.

summary:
“We The People have spoken and we are pissed,” reads the Facebook post accompanying a photo of a man in ski goggles and a gas mask on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. “No antifa, no BLM… We The People took the Capitol… Democratic tyranny WILL NOT STAND! WE HAVE SPOKEN!!” The post ended with six American flags and hashtags with March for Trump and Stop the Steal. Authorities later identified, from other photos, the man in the goggles as Blake Austin Reed. 

A tipster provided a screenshot of Reed’s Facebook account, according to court documents, and it had a series of photographs of the events leading up to the breach of the Capitol. Prominently featured in the photographs: Reed with those ski goggles and a purple and yellow respirator.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Reed pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/14/2022 to 36 months probation with 42 days intermittent confinement and 90 days home detention; fine of $2,500; restitution of $500; special assessment of $25

summary:
Weeks before the U.S. Capitol siege, 18-year-old Jackson Reffitt contacted the FBI, according to a phone interview he did with the New York Times. He wanted to put his father on its radar. 

Not long after that call, Guy Reffitt allegedly turned up in Washington, D.C., where investigators believe he was sprayed with some kind of chemical irritant for getting so close to the police line protecting the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. 

According to court documents, Reffitt allegedly told his family when he got home that he was at the Capitol during the breach and went to Washington to protect the country. He also allegedly said he took his gun with him, and told his kid: "If you turn me in, you're a traitor. And you know what happens to traitors. Traitors get shot."

Reffitt is allegedly a member of the a far-right Three Percenters militia, according to his wife.
charges: Transporting a Firearm in Furtherance of a Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Firearm; Obstructing Officers During a Civil Disorder; Obstruction of Justice – Hindering Communication Through Force or Threat of Physical Force
case_updates: Reffitt pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Jury trial from 2/28/22 to 3/8/2022. Found guilty on all five felony charges. Sentenced on 8/1/2022 to 87 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 in restitution; $500 special assessment

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, Jordan Revlett was identified as one of the Capitol rioters when the FBI received a tip with screenshots from Revlett’s Snapchat account. The screenshots, which display Revlett’s screen name, allegedly place him in the Capitol building during the riot and show what happened at the building from Revlett’s perspective.

According to an FBI affidavit, video surveillance from the Capitol building also shows Revlett entering the premises. During an FBI interview, Revlett allegedly admitted to entering and roaming around the Capitol building. He also stated that “he did not see any signs that would have restricted his entry and a police officer was standing behind the door he entered, who did not try to stop his entry.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Revlett pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 7/7/2022 to 14 days incarceration, 1 year probation, a $10 Special Assessment, Restitution of $500; 80 hours of community service

summary:
Jorge Riley allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., from Sacramento, Calif. Court documents indicate that on Jan. 6, 2021,  Riley — dressed in a black leather jacket, wearing white feathers in his braided hair and donning face paint — appears on multiple social media posts entering the Capitol. 

“I’m here to see what my President called me to DC for. Hello from Sacramento!!!” reads one of his Facebook posts.  According to court documents, between Jan. 6 and Jan. 8, Riley posted more than “150 messages, photographs, and videos on his public Facebook account, detailing his actions.” 

“We breached over there I think. We broke windows, we went into the door, we pushed our way in, and then we just kept going further and further … we went into, there was like a corridor building … We pushed our way to Nancy Pelosi’s office … and then we were sitting in there yelling “f*** you Nancy Pelosi,” he said in one of the videos. 

Riley served as the corresponding secretary for the State Board of the California Republican Assembly and was president of the Sacramento chapter. He resigned after the organization was made aware of his alleged participation during the riots on Jan. 6.
charges: Obstructing of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Riley pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Jesus Rivera uploaded a five-minute video to his Facebook account on Jan. 6, 2021, and did a few Facebook Live broadcasts showing him moving toward the Capitol surrounded by protesters, according to court documents. In one of the videos, the documents say, Rivera told viewers exactly what he intended to do: “Hey guys, if you are on here, share this live because I am about to take my a** to the middle of the… capitol and see what’s going on, where they are trying to jump in.”

Numerous media accounts say Rivera was a vocal Trump supporter and, among other things, started a page called Chicano Patriot on Facebook and was photographed with a “Latinos for Trump” hat. He even turned his Trump support into a business, something he called “We the People 1776.” They traveled the country, press reports said, holding small Trump rallies. 

Rivera served in the Marine Corps from 2002 to 2012 and was deployed for six months during Operation Iraqi Freedom from 2004 to 2005.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rivera pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Bench trial held June 14 and 15, 2022. Rivera was found guilty on all charges. Sentencing set for 11/3/2022

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Thomas Robertson, an off-duty police officer in the Rocky Mount Police Department in Virginia, allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., with a colleague. According to court documents, both men were photographed in the Capitol building “making an obscene gesture in front of the John Stark statue.” Gen. John Stark was a Revolutionary War leader.

A U.S. Army spokesperson confirmed to NPR that Robertson served as a military policeman in the U.S. Army Reserve and the Virginia Army National Guard from March 2006 until August 2009. He also deployed to Kuwait and Iraq from September 2007 until May 2008.

Court documents also describe Robertson as saying on social media that “The right IN ONE DAY took the f***ing U.S. Capitol. Keep poking us.” He also said he is “proud” of the pictures he posted on Instagram and wrote on a Facebook post that he was “willing to put skin in the game.”

The Rocky Mount Police Department terminated Robertson's employment, effective Jan. 26, 2021, according to an official statement.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Tampering with a Document or a Proceeding (cell phone)
case_updates: Robertson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Jury Trial held  4/4/2022-4/11/2022 before Judge Christopher Cooper. Robertson found Guilty on all charges. Sentenced 8/11/2022 to 87 months incarceration; 36 months supervised release; $2,000 restitution; a special assessment of $510

summary:
Nicholas Rodean is allegedly seen in multiple images inside the Capitol carrying a large “Trump is my president” flag. 

According to court documents, Rodean was photographed wearing his work badge around his neck on Jan. 6, 2021. The company he worked for, Navistar Direct Marketing, terminated him after the incident, according to The Associated Press. 

Court documents also say Rodean previously worked at a restaurant in Frederick, Md., on weekends.
charges: Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rodean pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. He was found Guilty of all charges in a Bench Trial on 7/12/2022.  Sentencing set for 10/21/2022

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Eliel Rosa can be seen, according to court documents, alongside Jenny Louise Cudd inside the Capitol. Two days later, Rosa was interviewed by the FBI and allegedly admitted entering the U.S. Capitol as part of the breach. 

In November 2019, Cudd ran for mayor of Midland, Texas, but came in third, according to the Midland County summary results report. Her campaign slogan was “Midland Deserves Better.” 

Rosa is an immigrant from Brazil and the founder of Nehemiah School of Government -- “a ministry aimed at educating Americans and inspiring immigrants to reestablish America as the Shining City on a Hill.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rosa pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dropped. Sentenced 10/12/2021 to 12 months of probation; 100 hours of community service; $10 assessment fee; $500 in restitution

summary:
David Ross served as an infantryman in the Massachusetts Army National Guard until he left the service in September 2013, according to a National Guard spokesperson.

According to court records, Ross is charged with unlawful entry and violating the District’s curfew.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Jury Trial scheduled for 3/13/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Bradley Rukstales traveled to Washington, D.C. to attend the rally. 

On his Twitter page, Rukstales wrote an apology: “In a moment of extremely poor judgment following the Jan. 6, 2021, rally in Washington, I followed hundreds of others through an open set of doors to the Capitol building to see what was taking place inside. I was arrested for the first time in my life and charged with unlawful entry. ... My decision to enter the Capitol was wrong, and I am deeply regretful to have done so.” 

Rukstales was the president and CEO of Cogensia, a marketing firm in Schaumburg, Ill. 

On Jan. 8, 2021, his company posted the following statement: “Cogensia President and CEO Brad Rukstales has been terminated by the company's Board of Directors effective immediately.”

He is also a Republican donor, having contributed to various candidates including former Sen. Kelly Loeffler and former President Donald Trump, as well as the Republican National Committee.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rukstales pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/12/2021 to 30 days incarceration; Special Assessment of $10; and $500 restitution

summary:
Jennifer Ryan, a real estate broker, traveled on a private plane from Trinity Aviation in Denton, Texas, on Jan. 5, 2021, to attend the rally in Washington, D.C., according to court documents. 

On her personal Twitter page, she allegedly posted a picture of herself next to a broken window of the Capitol building with the following caption: “Window at The capital [sic]. And if the news doesn’t stop lying about us we’re going to come after their studios next…” 

“We are going to f***ing go in here. Life or death, it doesn’t matter. Here we go,” Ryan said during a livestream from her Facebook page, according to court documents, as she was approaching the stairs of the building. The video was later deleted, according to the FBI. 

"I do not feel a sense of shame or guilt from my heart from what I was doing. I thought I was following my President. I would like a pardon,” Ryan said after the incident in an interview with a local CBS affiliate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ryan pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/4/2021 to 60 days incarceration; a $10 Special Assessment; Restitution in the amount of $500; and a $1000 fine.

summary:
Federal prosecutors have alleged that Jeffrey Sabol punched and dragged a Capitol Police officer down stairs outside the Capitol during the rioting. Sabol was wearing a black helmet, tan jacket and green backpack, prosecutors say, and can be seen in several videos of the melee. 

On Jan. 11, 2021, five days after the rioting, police in New City, N.Y., pulled Jeffrey Sabol over because he was driving erratically, according to court documents. 

He was "found covered in blood, suffering from severe lacerations to both thighs and arms," prosecutors say, which Sabol told officers were self-inflicted wounds. He also told police he was "fighting tyranny in the DC Capital."

Once in custody, federal investigators showed Sabol video of the fighting outside the Capitol. Sabol "acknowledged that the video seemed to depict him throwing punches at the police officer," prosecutors say, but Sabol claimed he was just "patting him on the back." Sabol allegedly told investigators that he picked up the officer's baton at one point, and claimed he used it to protect the officer, but later said "he could not recall if he hit the police officer with the baton because he was in a fit of rage and the details are cloudy."

Prosecutors claim that Sabol had bought a plane ticket and was attempting to flee to Switzerland before he was arrested.

The Denver Post reported that Sabol's lawyer said Sabol had been steadily employed for decades as a geophysicist and had the support of family. But a federal judge denied his request for release, referring to the charges against Sabol as "very disturbing."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Robbery in a Federal Enclave; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sabol pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Mark Sahady is the vice president of an anti-LGBTQ organization called Super Happy Fun America, or SHFA. According to their website, the organization is “committed to creating spaces for people of all identities to embrace the vibrancy of the straight community.”

Prior to Jan. 6, 2021, Sahady posted statements on Twitter questioning the legitimacy of the election. According to court documents, the day before the attack on the Capitol, he posted a group picture of himself and other members inside a bus, with the caption: “Bus 1 of 11 coming to Washington DC. See you there!” The buses were organized by Sahady’s organization. Previously, he had also written: “SHFA will be in DC once again on January 6th to get wild.”

A U.S. Army spokesperson confirmed to NPR that Sahady, whose rank is Captain, has served in the U.S. Army Reserve from 2004 until the present. He deployed to Afghanistan in 2011 and 2012. 

Court documents show pictures of a man alleged to be Sahady inside the Capitol building. He has been accused of knowingly entering and remaining in the Capitol without lawful authority and also for using “loud, threatening or abusive language.”

According to court documents, in December, Sahady posted about Jan. 6, 2021, stating that “it is important that millions of Americans show up in DC on January 6 to support the legitimate President, Donald Trump, and show Democrats what they will be facing if they continue to try and steal the Presidency.”
charges: Entering or Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sahady pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
The government has accused Ryan Samsel of assaulting a Capitol Police officer outside of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Around 12:50 p.m., prosecutors say, a group of people including Samsel approached a barricade outside of the Capitol and started pushing it, knocking an officer to the ground. The officer hit her head on a set of stairs and fell unconscious, the documents indicate. At that point, Samsel picked her up and said, "We don't have to hurt you, why are you standing in our way?"

The officer later collapsed, blacked out and was diagnosed with a concussion at a local hospital. 

After the incident at the barricade, prosecutors say, Samsel continued to move toward the crowds by the Capitol and "attempted to pull a riot shield from a uniformed U.S. Capitol Police Officer."

Samsel is currently wanted by police in Riverside, N.J., for allegedly committing assault, federal prosecutors noted.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Samsel pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Ronald "Ronnie" Sandlin had planned to attend the pro-Trump rally in Washington, D.C., for at least a week, federal prosecutors say. In late December, he allegedly posted on Facebook, "I’m going to be there to show support for our president and to do my part to stop the steal and stand behind Trump when he decides to cross the rubicon."

As the hours ticked down toward the attack on the Capitol, his rhetoric turned increasingly violent, the court records indicate. 

“Freedom is paid for with blood," Sandlin said several times on video, according to federal prosecutors. "I think it is time to take the Capitol and I don’t say that lightly."

Sandlin allegedly entered the Capitol building during the riot and was seen on video smoking inside the Capitol, saying: "We made history guys. People are smoking weed in here."

Prosecutors also allege that "Sandlin assaulted police officers on two separate occasions in two different locations in the Capitol that day." 

In one incident, "he attempted to rip an officer’s helmet off as the officer tried to hold back the mob trying to rush into the Capitol through one of its entrances," according to court documents. He also allegedly, "engaged in a shoving match with an officer attempting to lock and secure a set of doors inside the Capitol."

Sandlin was arrested in Nevada on Jan. 28, 2021.

"The defendant was a spoke in the wheel that caused the historic events of January 6, 2021, and he is thus a danger to our society and a threat to the peaceful functioning of our community," prosecutors wrote.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Sandlin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Robert Sanford, a retired firefighter, allegedly struck three U.S. Capitol police officers with a fire extinguisher. Court documents state that “the fire extinguisher struck one officer, who was wearing a helmet, in the head; then, the fire extinguisher ricochets striking a second officer, who was not wearing a helmet, in the head; and ricochets a third time and strikes a third officer, wearing a helmet, in the head.”

According to court documents, Sanford allegedly told a tipster he had traveled to Washington, D.C. by bus with a group. He also said he went to the White House, listened to former President Trump's speech and then followed the president's instructions to go to the Capitol. 

A press statement from the office of Mayor Thaddeus Kirkland of Chester, Pa., describes Sanford as a member of the Chester Fire Department from January 1994 until his retirement in February 2020. The statement also cites that “while Robert Sanford adorned a hat with a Fire Department logo, he is not a current employee of the city of Chester” and that “city officials are aware that a former Chester Firefighter allegedly attended and participated in the insurrection that took place in our nation’s capital."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sanford pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Diana Santos-Smith allegedly climbed through a broken window and got inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. 

In an interview with federal investigators, Santos-Smith said she did not physically enter the Capitol building but then reversed herself when agents showed her video the FBI received through a tip. 

In that same interview, Santos-Smith said she and another rioter went to the Capitol to protest and did not have plans to storm the Capitol. In charging documents, Santos-Smith said when they arrived at the Capitol, she heard people say "they're letting us in" and interpreted that to mean protesters were being allowed to enter the Capitol. When they saw others in the crowd entering the Capitol through a broken widow, they followed despite knowing they shouldn't have been there.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Santos-Smith pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/21/2022 to 20 days incarceration, 3 years probation; 100 hours community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
Federal investigators believe Jon Schaffer sprayed U.S. Capitol Police with "bear spray" as he and other rioters forced their way into the Capitol building. 

Photographs from that day allegedly show Schaffer wearing a tactical vest with a baseball cap that read "Oath Keepers Lifetime Member." The Oath Keepers is a far-right militia that is known to target and recruit law enforcement and military personnel. 

According to court documents, Schaffer traveled to Washington, D.C., with other Oath Keepers shortly after the 2020 election to participate in the "Million MAGA March." In an interview that day, he was asked if he expected the protests to be violent. "If somebody wants to bring violence, I think there’s a lot of us here that are ready for it," he said. "We don’t want that, but if they bring it we’re going to respond to that, trust me.” 

Schaffer is the front man for the heavy metal band "Iced Earth," and according to court documents "has long held far-right extremist views." He has referred to himself as an "anarchist" and called the government a "criminal enterprise."

Schaffer was originally charged with 6 counts: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disrupting the Orderly Conduct of Government Business; Knowingly Engages in an Act of Physical Violence Against Any Person or Property in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Engage in an Act of Physical Violence in a Capitol Building; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in a Capitol Building. Those charges were dropped as part of a plea agreement and he pleaded guilty to two lesser charges.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon
case_updates: Schaffer pleaded Guilty to: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon.

summary:
Prosecutors allege that Katherine Schwab was part of a group of five people who took a private plane -- dubbed a "Patriot Flight" -- from Texas to Washington, D.C., to join the planned pro-Trump protests.

Schwab can allegedly be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors say she also posted on Facebook about illegally entering the Capitol: "the national guard was in there and didn’t move an inch. They sat back. They didn’t fight against us at all," Schwab allegedly posted, "because there was no need to. After the girl was shot and killed that’s when we raised hell.”

Federal investigators interviewed Schwab, who claimed, according to court records, that she "did not see any violence or anyone destroying anything," though, "she observed the door to the Capitol building had been destroyed." She allegedly told investigators that she left the Capitol because she was being crushed by the large crowd.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds
case_updates:
Schwab pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a
Restricted Building. Sentencing set for 12/9/2022

summary:
Peter Schwartz was arrested Feb. 4, 2021, in Uniontown, Pa. An FBI affidavit claims video filmed on Jan. 6 shows him spraying mace directly at U.S. Capitol Police and carrying a wooden baton. A witness told the FBI that Schwartz is a traveling welder from Owensboro, Ky., who had been released from prison because of COVID-19 and should have been at a rehabilitation facility on Jan. 6 instead of at the Capitol riot.

“All the violence from the left was terrorism. What happened yesterday was the opening of a war," wrote Schwartz on his Facebook profile on Jan. 7, according to the FBI affidavit. "I was there and whether people will acknowledge it or not, we are now at war. It would be wise to be ready!”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weaponand Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Schwartz pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
The FBI was tipped off to Hunter Seefried by his coworker, who said Seefried bragged about being in the Capitol with his father on Jan. 6, 2021.
