Investigators reviewed a video on Twitter that shows Hunter Seefried punching out glass in a window in the Capitol complex after others in the crowd broke it with a wooden 2x4. Once Seefried allegedly cleared the window, the crowd, including the Seefrieds, climbed through and entered the Capitol building.

Both father and son confirmed participating in the breach with federal investigators and both are facing federal charges. The older Seefried was captured in one of the more memorable photographs from that day, carrying the Confederate battle flag inside the Capitol building.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with Physical Violence Against Property; Destruction of Government Property; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
case_updates: Hunter Seefried was convicted in a Bench trial on charges 1-5 and acquitted on charges 6-8. Sentencing set for 9/23/2022

summary:
Kevin Seefried was the man photographed carrying a Confederate battle flag inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to federal investigators. He was there that day with his son, Hunter Seefried, who is also facing charges. In interviews with investigators, both confirmed participating in the breach of the Capitol. The elder Seefried also said he brought the Confederate flag from his home where it is usually displayed outside.

Investigators reviewed a video on Twitter that shows Hunter Seefried punching out glass in a window in the Capitol complex after others in the crowd broke it with a wooden 2x4. Seefried told agents that his son was asked by another individual in the crowd to help clear the window because he was wearing gloves. Once the window was cleared, the crowd, including the Seefrieds, entered the Capitol building.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kevin Seefried was convicted in a Bench trial on all charges. Sentencing set for 9/16/2022

summary:
Five days after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, the FBI put out “Be On the Lookout” bulletins with pictures of suspected rioters whom the FBI was seeking. One of them was Barton Wade Shively.

According to court records, three days after the bulletin was posted a witness contacted the FBI identifying Shively, who later that day contacted law enforcement himself and surrendered. 

Shively allegedly admitted to voluntarily traveling to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, and confronting law enforcement officers. “I got caught up in the moment,” he told the agents. He said he struck officers several times and physically pushed the police line. Shively was eventually maced by the officers in the altercations.

A Marine Corps spokesperson confirmed to NPR that Shively served as a Marine from 1985 until 1989.

According to an interview he gave CNN on the day of the protest, he said: “The Supreme Court is not helping us. What are we supposed to do?”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Shively pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal prosecutors say they learned of Dennis Sidorski's alleged role in the riots at the Capitol after multiple people sent in tips, saying they recognized him from videos taken inside the building. 

One of the tipsters, prosecutors say, previously worked with Sidorski in Washington, D.C.

Sidorski was allegedly seen inside the Capitol wearing a black sweatshirt with "AMERICAN SUPREMACIST" written on it.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sidorski pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building.

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, federal investigators believe Mark Simon, a "far-right activist," allegedly recorded a video on Jan. 6, 2021, that shows numerous individuals pushing their way into the U.S. Capitol while law enforcement officials attempted to remove individuals from inside the building. In the video, captioned “Peacefully Storming the Capitol…#StopTheSteal,” Simon can allegedly be heard saying, “In the Capitol baby, yeah!”  Other Facebook photos allegedly show Simon and an unidentified woman also posing around the Capitol grounds. 

Simon described his experience to Epoch Times, a right-wing newspaper. Simon told the newspaper that he attended the rally in support of President Trump, explaining that the crowd was made up of “frustrated patriots” who “just wanted to be heard.” “If the patriots wanted to get in there and cause damage or burn the Capitol down or get Congress or hurt anybody, they would have got hurt,” he said. “They had full control of the place. Cops had no control throughout the day. We could have gone wherever we wanted at any time, and it was not done. They were restrained.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Simon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/7/2021 to 35 days incarceration; Special Assessment of $10.00; Restitution in the amount of $500.00

summary:
James Sinclair was smoking outside the J.W. Marriott Hotel in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, after the imposed curfew, according to court documents. Police allegedly issued two warnings before placing him under arrest. The arrest yielded "black metal knuckles," which resulted in Sinclair being charged with “possession of a prohibited weapon.” Court documents also indicate Sinclair traveled to Washington with his wife from Philadelphia to attend the Trump rally.

According to court documents, Sinclair said the brass knuckles were bought online as a keychain and that he brought them to Washington for protection. According to the Philadelphia Inquirer, Sinclair posted the following quote on Jan. 6: “It’s 1776, the American people have ears and eyes. We will not accept this fraudulent election.”
charges: Possession of a Prohibited Weapon (metal knuckles)
case_updates: Sinclair entered into a diversion agreement with prosecutors on June 9, 2021. Under that agreement, Sinclair must stay away from Washington, DC, except to meet with his attorney or pretrial services, and must not violate the law. If he abides by that agreement for six months, the charge will be dismissed. 12/10/2021, Case Disposed - Nolle Diversion

summary:
A tipster sent the FBI screenshots of the messages Jeffrey Smith sent from the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, including: “I’m a Patriot" and "I stormed the capital [sic]." Smith went on to write, according to court documents, that he stormed the Capitol “To send a message that Americans are[n’] t going to take a fraudulent election.”

Smith also allegedly wrote to the tipster, according to court documents, that there was “no way in hell I was going to drive 38 hours from San Diego and not walk right through the front of the capital [sic] building.”

When FBI agents contacted Smith days later, according to court documents, he admitted to attending a speech by President Trump in Washington, D.C., with his girlfriend and that when he approached the Capitol the scene was “chaotic.” 

He allegedly told the agent that he stayed inside the Capitol for about half an hour and, according to court documents, he admitted he had deleted his Instagram account after he began receiving threats related to his role in the events of Jan. 6.

Smith served in the Army from January 2010 until he was honorably discharged in January 2015 with the rank of Sergeant, according to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court.
charges: Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building
case_updates: Smith pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced to 90 days of incarceration; probation of 2 years; special assessment of $10; Restitution of $500; Community service of 200 hours

summary:
On the day of the Capitol attack, Troy Smocks allegedly posted on Parler, “Today, January 6th, 2021, We Patriots by the millions have arrived in Washington, DC, carrying banners of support for the greatest President the World has ever known. But if we must… Many of us will return on January 19th, 2021, carrying our weapons in support of Our nation’s resolve, to which the world will never forget. We will come in numbers that no standing army or police agency can match. However, the police are NOT our enemy, unless they choose to be! All who will not stand with the American Patriots…or cannot stand with us, then, that would be a good time for you to take a few vacation days. -The American Patriot.” 

Investigators believe the post to have been viewed by other Parler users at least 60,926 times.

The day after the attack, Smocks posted on Parler: “So over the next 24 hours, I would say lets get our personal affairs in order. Prepare our weapons, and then go get’em. Lets hunt these cowards down like the Traitors that each of them are ... the cowards ran as We took the Capital. They have it back now, only because We left. It wasn’t the building that We wanted ... it was them!”

According to court documents, Smocks allegedly made a flight reservation to depart the United States for a foreign country on Jan. 15, 2021, but was taken into custody before he could leave.
charges: Threats in Interstate Communications - Contained a threat to kidnap and injure law enforcement officers using a social media service and a threat to kidnap and injure politicians and executives in the technology industry
case_updates: Smocks pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 10/21/2021 to 14 months of incarceration; 36 months of supervised release and a special assessment of $100.00

summary:
The day after the insurrection at the Capitol, a tipster called the FBI and allegedly named the first person who entered the building through a broken window: Michael Sparks. 

On Dec. 30, 2020, prosecutors allege, Sparks replied to Trump's social media message of “JANUARY SIXTH, SEE YOU IN DC!,” by saying, “I’ll be there.” 

On Jan. 6, 2021, Sparks, prosecutors say, can be seen in multiple photos and videos from inside the Capitol as part of a group of people moving toward the Capitol Police "in a menacing manner."

At one point, a Capitol Police officer tells Sparks and the group to "Leave now!" according to court records. Sparks responds to the officer, "We’re standing here for you as well," followed by “This is our America! This is our America!”

After the rioting, Sparks allegedly posted on Facebook, "A new dawn is coming. Be ready. Just pray and trust in the lord," and that he had "give[n] up on democracy and I believe we have lost it for quite some time."

Sparks was arrested Jan. 19, 2021, in Kentucky, where he lives.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sparks pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, a few different livestreams Christopher Spencer allegedly posted on his Facebook page show him in various places inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Federal investigators believe he was in the Crypt and then roamed the halls, shouting, "Stop the Steal!" and asking "Where's Nancy's office?"
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Spencer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
On the day of the Capitol attack, members of the mob grabbed a Metropolitan Police officer who was guarding a Capitol building entrance and dragged him down the stairs of the building. An FBI affidavit says the mob forced the officer to the ground and beat him with various objects. 

Federal investigators believe Peter Stager is one of the individuals who assaulted the officer. A video allegedly shows Stager striking the officer repeatedly with a flagpole while the officer lays face-down on the steps of the Capitol building. 

In another video, Stager is allegedly heard saying, "Everybody in there is a treasonous traitor. Death is the only remedy for what's in the building," which investigators believe is a reference to the Capitol building and the lawmakers inside.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Stager pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Court documents indicate that Patrick Stedman is a “dating and relationship strategist.” His Twitter page, under the name “Pat Stedman,” has nearly 26,000 followers. According to court documents, Stedman frequently posts on political topics and has a post of a live stream video called “COVID/CABAL.” 

In December, Stedman allegedly told his followers he is “assembling a team” to travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. Further social media posts show him traveling on a train to Washington.

During the riots at the Capitol, according to court documents, he also posted an image with the following caption: “Backwards hat (Antifa) right where they were breaking into the main area of Congress.” In a different post from the same day he wrote: “I can tell you having been in the Capitol these videos the MSM [mainstream media] is showing of fights between cops and protestors are unlike any of the dynamics I saw. Does this look like a 'tense' scene to you?”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stedman pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
“I’m trying to figure out how I could be there all day and miss all this violence and destruction I’m seeing on TV,” Melody Steele-Smith wrote on her Facebook page about the events of Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. “I think photos for the news were staged.”

One of the photos Steele-Smith herself took appeared to show her inside House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office, according to court documents. Under the caption, “Nancy’s Office,” there is a collage of images -- a framed photo of Pelosi hanging on a wall, a coin rack on top of a cabinet and in one, in a partial reflection, what looked to be a white fuzzy headband and light hair that investigators said was consistent with selfies that Steele-Smith took of herself on Jan. 6. A review of online footage and photos of the speaker’s office by law enforcement officials confirms the posted photos appear to be her office, the documents said.

A relative of Steele-Smith identified her to authorities, according to court documents. Surveillance cameras in the Capitol appear to place Steele-Smith inside the building as well.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Steele-Smith pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
Michael Stepakoff, a rabbi at a messianic synagogue, allegedly entered the Capitol building as part of the Jan. 6, 2021, breach. 

Stepakoff was captured on surveillance footage taking photos with his cellphone after entering the building, according to court documents.

Federal investigators also reviewed his Facebook page and found several photos of crowds outside the Capitol, along with a selfie of Stepakoff wearing a hat and jacket similar to what is in the security video.

“Epic and historical moment,” read the caption.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stepakoff pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/20/2022 to 12 months of Probation with 60 days location monitoring; fine of $742; Special Assessment $10; Restitution of $500; 60 hours community service

summary:
Justin Stoll allegedly attended the Jan. 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol. But his charges are not directly related to his presence there. 

Stoll, a social media personality who goes by the name Th3RealHuckleberry, lives in the Southern District of Ohio. According to his website, Th3RealHuckleberry is a social media content creator who “produces content in the political, comedic and general hot topic news areas, but he is most well-known for his clapbacks.” 

According to court documents, Stoll can be heard on his social media posts from that day saying, “D.C.’s a war zone. ... You ain’t got enough cops, baby! We are at war at the Capitol. ... We have taken the Capitol. This is our country.” 

After Stoll allegedly posted this content on YouTube, he received responses from other online users that he should be arrested. This allegedly prompted Stoll to respond: “If you ever in your f***ing existence did something to jeopardize taking me away from my family, you will absolutely meet your maker. You can play that for the D.A. in court, I don’t care. If you ever jeopardize me from being with my family, you will absolutely meet your mother f***ing maker, and I will be the one to arrange the meeting.” 

The court documents describes his demeanor in the video as “serious and aggressive."

An Army spokesperson confirmed to NPR that Stoll served in the Army between September 1998 and December 2000 and his rank was a private.
charges: Transmission in Interstate Commerce of a Threat to Injure
case_updates: Stoll pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentencing held on 7/27/202 in Cincinnati before Judge Susan J. Dlott: 24 months probation; $100 special assessment

summary:
Brandon Straka is a self-described “former liberal” and the founder of the “WalkAway Campaign,” a movement that encourages and supports those on the left to walk away from the Democratic Party, according to an FBI affidavit.  

Following a tip the FBI received about Straka’s alleged involvement in the Jan. 6 riot, federal investigators reviewed Straka's social media channels and found an hour-long video he posted of himself the day after the attack on the Capitol. He allegedly talked about how he ended up at the U.S. Capitol, saw "nothing being broken" and "nobody committing any acts of violence" or "vandalism." 

The FBI received tips from the public with screenshots showing Straka's alleged Twitter activity on Jan. 6. In one tweet, Straka wrote, “I arrived at the Capitol a few hours ago as Patriots were storming from all sides,” according to court documents. “It was not Antifa at the Capitol,” he allegedly wrote in another tweet. “It was freedom loving Patriots who were DESPERATE to fight for the final hope of our Republic because literally nobody cares about them. Everyone else can denounce them. I will not.”

Witnesses also shared a video with the FBI, which allegedly showed Straka on the “cusp” of entering the U.S. Capitol and encouraging the crowd to take the Capitol police officers' shield as he yelled, “Take it away from him. Take the shield.”
charges: Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Straka pleaded Guilty to the single charge.  Sentenced 1/24/2022 to 36 months of probation; 90 days location monitoring/home confinement; $5,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours community service

summary:
Federal prosecutors say that they received "many" tips regarding John Herbert Strand's alleged participation in the rioting at the Capitol.  “An old acquaintance was posting pictures of himself taking over the capitol yesterday. He was calling for a revolution on his social media accounts," one witness told the FBI. 

Strand tweeted a photo of himself outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with the message: "I am incredibly proud to be a patriot today, to stand up tall in defense of liberty & the Constitution, to support Trump & #MAGAforever, & to send the message: WE ARE NEVER CONCEDING A STOLEN ELECTION.” He was also allegedly seen in footage from inside the Capitol.

Strand allegedly went to the Capitol along with Simone Gold, a California physician. Both Strand and Gold work with the group America's Frontline Doctors. The group has argued against using masks to combat the coronavirus and spread dubious claims about vaccines, according to FactCheck.org.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Strand pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Kevin Strong, a Federal Aviation Administration employee, had been on the FBI's radar before the Jan. 6 Capitol attack. 

The FBI started investigating Strong on Dec. 30, 2020, after a witness told them Strong had been showing signs of "behavioral changes over the last few months including stockpiling items and telling others to get ready for Marshal Law, rioting, and protesting," according to court documents. 

The witness also said that Strong hung a flag at his home that said "WW1WGA," which is a QAnon slogan that stands for "Where We Go One, We Go All." 

Strong confessed to agents he was in the U.S. Capitol rotunda as part of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
case_updates: Strong pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/7/2022 to 24 months of probation, including 30 days of home detention; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours community service

summary:
Marissa Suarez, a probationary corrections officer, used "an emergency holiday" to travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, according to federal investigators. 

Video footage allegedly shows Suarez inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6. Text messages allegedly sent from Suarez's phone also suggest she was among the mob that breached the Capitol. "Sooo we’ve stormed Capitol Hill lol,” she wrote.

The next day, Suarez sent a series of text messages describing the scene inside the U.S. Capitol: 

- "When we found out pence f***ed us, we all stormed the Capitol building and everyone forced entry and started breaking s***... it was a like a scene out of a movie."
- "S*** was crazy inside.. everything was broken. People were flipping out."
- "The smoke alarms were going off bc everyone was smoking pot and then people started drinking."
- "The cops were spraying people when we went in so we were coughing like crazy shortly after that lol"
- "This is one of the antifa f***s we found ... I actually saw a kid getting ready to throw a jack daniels bottle with some s*** in at the cops and I started flipping out on him and then I informed some of the military guys and they handled him."

According to court documents, Suarez stormed the Capitol with another individual -- Patricia Todisco -- who is facing similar charges.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Suarez pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/12/2022 to 36 months of probation; $500 Restitution; $2,000 fine; $10 special assessment; 60 hours community service

summary:
John Sullivan is the head of an organization called Insurgence USA. According to the organization’s website, its mission is “to provide the truth” and give “unedited raw footage, photos, and news of the insurrection here in America," Sullivan has attended and recorded both BLM protests and pro-Trump rallies. 

Sullivan told FBI agents that he was in Washington, D.C., to attend and film the “Stop the Steal” march on Jan. 6, 2021, and claimed to be “an activist and journalist that filmed protests and riots.” According to court documents, he also said that he had been “present at the shooting of a woman" and that "he had filmed the incident.” As footage shows, Sullivan recorded the fatal shooting of Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt.

Sullivan allegedly wore a bulletproof vest and gas mask. “We accomplished this s***. We did this together. F*** yeah! We are all a part of this history,” “Let’s burn this s*** down,” he said according to his video footage reviewed by the FBI. As part of the same video, he allegedly also tells officers: “There are too many people, you gotta stand down, the people out there that tried to do that s***, they got hurt, I saw it, I’m caring about you.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Sullivan pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Douglas Sweet was among the relatively few alleged rioters arrested during the chaos at the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. 

Near the atrium of the House of Representatives, around 3 p.m., Capitol Police officers ordered the crowd to leave the building. "The crowd did not comply, and instead responded by shouting and cursing at the Capitol Police Officers," prosecutors allege. 

A group of people inside the building were then arrested, including Sweet.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sweet pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/9/2021 to 36 months of probation with one month home detention; restitution of $500.00; Special Assessment of $10; 60 hours community service

summary:
Anthony Tammaro was arrested on the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, outside of the Capitol for allegedly violating the city's curfew order and ignoring police officers' orders to disperse. 

According to his now-private Facebook profile, Tammaro works at Goodwill Industries of North Central Pennsylvania.
charges: Unlawful Entry (Public Property)
case_updates: Non-Jury Trial scheduled for 1/17/2023 in DC Superior Court

summary:
Dustin Thompson and Robert Lyon, who is also facing charges related to the Capitol riot, drove to Washington, D.C., together for the pro-Trump rally, according to court documents.

Earlier in the day, Thompson had sent a photo and a video to Lyon, according to court documents. In the photo, he is posing outside the Capitol with a coat rack that was later confirmed to be from inside the Capitol. In the video, he appears to be in a "ransacked office" and yells "Wooooo! 'Merica Hey! This is our house!"

Later that evening, two U.S. Capitol Police officers came across Thompson and Lyon sitting on a sidewalk near the Capitol and asked them to leave. When Thompson tried to leave with the coat rack, the officers asked him to put it down. He did, but then fled and was able to get away, according to court records. Thompson and Lyon drove back to Ohio the next day.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Thompson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Found Guilty by Jury Trial on 4/14/2022 of all charges. Sentencing scheduled for 9/23/2022

summary:
Videos show Patricia Todisco participated in demonstrations outside of the U.S. Capitol building and inside once the crowd had forced its way in, according to a criminal complaint. 

In one recording, Todisco is allegedly seen walking through the Capitol building and into the Senate wing, where a crowd is standing around a pile of overturned furniture, chanting “U-S-A” and taunting the police. In another video, she appears to walk out of the office of Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Ore.

According the court documents, Todisco stormed the Capitol with another rioter who is also facing similar charges.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Todisco pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/12/2022 to 36 months of probation, $500 Restitution, $2,000 fine; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: According to a criminal complaint, Eric Torrens was arrested after a tipster identified him from a photo that aired on a local news broadcast. In a video filmed by another individual charged in relation to the riot, Torrens can allegedly be seen outside an exterior door of the Capitol saying, “We’re going in," according to an FBI affidavit.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Torrens pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/29/2021 to 36 months probation with home detention condition (90 days location monitoring); $10.00 special assessment; and $500.00 restitution.

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, Israel Tutrow allegedly attended the rally in Washington, D.C., with a friend who was also charged and arrested for his activities in relation to the Jan. 6, 2021, riot.

Tutrow was identified by a witness who attended the same high school as him, according to an FBI affidavit. 

According to court documents, photographs that were circulating in the media and social media show both Tutrow and Wagner inside the Capitol building during the riot. In one photo, Tutrow can be seen, with facial hair and facial tattoos, exiting the Capitol while wearing a black beanie with "TRUMP" written on it.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tutrow pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/21/2021 to 36 months of Probation; Special Assessment of $10.00; Restitution in the amount of $500.00; 90 days location monitoring/home detention

summary:
According to court documents, Chance Uptmore and his father went to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, as part of a five-day birthday celebration. 

In an interview with the FBI, Uptmore allegedly volunteered that he and his father had attended the Trump rally on Jan. 6 and then were on the Capitol grounds when the breach of the Capitol occurred. 

Chance Uptmore allegedly told authorities that his father had told him not to go into the building, but he went in anyway, and his father followed him in. The two were seen in numerous photographs and on CNN, the court documents say.

A tipster provided the FBI with a screenshot that Chance Uptmore had allegedly posted to his Facebook account. In it, he described what he experienced inside the Capitol building that day. “If you saw it first hand you would have a different perspective,” he wrote, according to court documents. “The cops were saying Stuff like ‘we stand with you’ ‘thanks for being here’ ‘you made your point now leave calmly.’ "
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Uptmore pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 10/25/2022

summary:
James Uptmore, also known as Sonny, had told his son, Chance, not to go into the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. But his son went in anyway, and James Uptmore followed him in.

Chance told authorities later, according to court documents, that he got caught up in the crowd and going in seemed like a once in a lifetime event. The pair took videos inside the building on their phones, which they allegedly shared with law enforcement officials. The videos were still on their phones, court documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Uptmore pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/16/2022

summary:
Multiple witnesses have allegedly come forward identifying Hector Vargas Santos as a member of the mob inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. 

“WE THE PEOPLE TOOK OVER THE U.S. CAPITOL. #HOLDTHELINE” read one of his online posts from Jan. 6, according to court records. In a separate video post, he allegedly said: “We took over this motherf***er ... we took over this f***ing Capitol, tell them.” 

Court records also indicate Vargas may have set up a GoFundMe account in order to travel to Washington. A post on Twitter reads: "As we’re getting close to Jan 6th there are way more true American Patriots interested in coming to fight the good fight in Washington DC. With your donations we can help them get down there to fight for our democracy. Please donate n share.” 

A spokesperson for the Marine Corps confirmed to NPR that Vargas served as a field radio operator in the U.S. Marines between 2011 and 2015.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vargas Santos pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, an FBI tipster claimed William Vogel was “very vocal” about being at the rally in Washington, D.C., according to the FBI. Court documents indicate Vogel was identified as a rioter after law enforcement received videos he shot and narrated while he was inside the Capitol building. According to an FBI affidavit, in Snapchat videos, Vogel can be seen walking around the Capitol building while law enforcement is seen retreating from the rioters. 

According to court documents, Vogel’s Facebook account, which was verified through phone records, was used to send photos that showed him participating in the riot. He also shared a video taken from the top of the west front steps of the Capitol building, according to the FBI.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vogel pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, Joshua Wagner allegedly attended the pro-Trump rally with his friend Israel Tutrow, who is also facing charges in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, riot.

Three days after the Capitol attack, Wagner identified himself to law enforcement as one of the people featured in an FBI poster. According to court documents, photographs that were circulating in the media and social media show both Wagner and Tutrow inside the Capitol during the riot. In one photo, Wagner is seen wearing  glasses and a red beanie with “TRUMP” written on it in white lettering. 

Wagner was also identified by a witness who attended the same high school as him, according to the affidavit.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wagner pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 2/11/2022 to 30 days incarceration; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary:
Federal prosecutors say Jessica Watkins, a U.S. Army veteran, was among the "most extreme insurgents" who took part in the attack on the Capitol attack.

According to court documents, Watkins, who is a member of the Ohio State Regular Militia and the Oath Keepers, sent text messages to a number of individuals in November who were interested in joining the militia. Watkins allegedly told them the militia had a weeklong "Basic Training class coming up in the beginning of January," and told one recruit, "I need you fighting fit by innaugeration [sic]." She reportedly told another individual, "It's a military style basic, here in Ohio with a Marine Drill Sergeant running it. An hour north of Columbus Ohio."

In the days leading up to the Capitol attack, Watkins was allegedly in regular communication with other militia members. "We plan on going to DC on the 6th," Watkins said in a Dec. 29 text to another individual also facing conspiracy charges. "Trump wants all able bodied Patriots to come." 

On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say, Watkins joined other individuals affiliated with the Oath Keepers and "moved in an organized and practiced fashion up the steps" of the Capitol. 

Federal investigators claim that once Watkins entered the Capitol building, she and others also facing conspiracy charges communicated on Zello, a walkie-talkie-like app, using a channel named "Stop the Steal J6." At one point, Watkins allegedly said, "We have a good group. We have about 30-40 of us. We are sticking together and sticking to the plan."

When FBI searched Watkins' home they found personal protection equipment and communication devices, a mini drone, pepper spray, cellphones, numerous firearms, homemade weapons and instructions for making explosives.

In court filings arguing for her release, Watkins' lawyer said she attended the Jan. 6 rally "to provide security to the speakers at the rally, to provide escort for the legislators and others to march to the Capitol as directed by the then President," and added that Watkins was given a VIP pass that day. 

Watkins' lawyer also mentioned in the motion that she is a small business owner, voted for former President Barack Obama, served in Afghanistan as an Army ranger, and was forced out of the military after her sexual orientation was discovered. "As a transgender female, she is at risk of harsh treatment in custody," he said.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Watkins pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to a criminal complaint, William Watson traveled to Washington, D.C., to "support the patriots, support Trump, support freedom. ... I guess the overriding thing for why we were there that day is because they were certifying the fraudulent election that day, and so we, to protest that." 

Watson said he was following a schedule that conspiracy theorist Alex Jones promoted for Jan. 6,2021,  which, according to Watson, directed people to meet at the Ellipse at 9 a.m. and the U.S. Capitol at 1 p.m., around the time of the certification. 

In an interview with the FBI, Watson initially denied commiting any acts of violence, trespassing, vandalism or other “criminal activity." He then said he entered the Capitol building through a broken window and approached a police officer. "I went straight up to the first cop and literally got on my knees and was like, 'Listen, I want to be peaceful here ... I want to help you get these people peaceful so that we can have a conversation.' " 

Watson said he had a can of mace and a pocketknife on him at the time he breached the building.

According to court documents, Watson was out on bond from a summer drug trafficking case and violated the conditions by participating in the Capitol breach. He was charged in July with possession of controlled substances and drug trafficking of LSD and marijuana, felonies under Alabama law.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Watson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to charging documents, Bradley Weeks allegedly shot video from a Capitol terrace on Jan. 6, 2021, first of the crowd on the Capitol lawn and then of himself, as he says, “We’ve reached the steps. We’ve had to climb scaffolding. We’ve had to climb ladders. We’ve had to break things to get through, but we’ve gotten through. We’ve gotten through, and we are going to take back the Capitol! We’re taking back our country! This is our 1776! This is where it’s gonna happen! This is where tyranny will fall! This is where America will rise! Look at this, America! Look at this!”

Federal investigators obtained screenshots of Weeks' Facebook page from an unnamed informant showing him inside the Capitol building. 

A week after the attack on the Capitol, The Baker County Press, a local paper in his hometown, wrote an article about him. One line read, "During the uproar, Brad Weeks said in a direct message to The Press he inhaled some tear gas after scaling the wall outside the Capitol Building before going inside but was otherwise alright." Federal investigators obtained messages between the reporter and Weeks as further evidence suggesting Weeks entered the Capitol building.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Weeks pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Andrew Williams, a firefighter-paramedic who was photographed and filmed allegedly inside the Capitol building, pleaded not guilty to the federal charges against him.

Court documents cite a couple of videos that appear to be recorded on Jan. 6, 2021, in which Williams allegedly says, "We're storming the Capitol! Yeah baby!" and "How are they going to arrest every single person?” A photograph of Williams inside the Capitol shows him underneath an archway, wearing a Trump hat and pointing to a sign that reads "Speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi."

Williams' lawyer told local news stations that "the president and Capitol police encouraged despicable behavior" and insisted Williams "took part in none of it."
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 2/9/2022 to 24 months of probation; $500 of restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary:
According to court documents, the authorities have a host of video evidence against Riley June Williams. Among other things, she was filmed by an ITV news crew inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The footage shows her yelling, “Upstairs, upstairs, upstairs” while she was physically directing people up a staircase. 

The charging documents say that the staircase led to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. Williams’ mother allegedly confirmed to authorities that the woman in the images is her daughter. Authorities also matched the image to Williams’ driver’s license, the court documents say.

Williams, who worked at a social services organization called Keystone Human Services before her arrest, also appears to have filmed and then shared a video of someone lifting a laptop off a desk in Pelosi’s office. Underneath the post she allegedly shared on the social media site Discord, she wrote: “STOLE S*** FROM NANCY POLESI.” 

There were a number of other posts, riddled with typographical errors, the court documents say authorities have linked to Williams. One read: "I TOOK HER GRAVEL HAMMWR TBING." Another read: "I DOMT CARE I TOOK NANCY POLESIS HARD DRIVES I DONT CARE KILL ME."

The FBI and charging documents did not provide any additional information on the whereabouts of the Pelosi laptop -- which, according to the speaker’s office, was only used for presentations. Court documents say Williams’ mother told authorities that her daughter had taken a sudden interest in President Trump’s politics and “far right message boards.” 

In a video obtained by the investigative research group Bellingcat, Riley is purportedly seen giving a Nazi salute while wearing baseball cap embossed with the Nazi black sun symbol. The video is believed to have been shot and posted sometime in the weeks leading up to the Jan. 6 attack. Williams' lawyer says it was a joke intended to mock Nazis.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
A witness allegedly told the FBI that he traveled by car with two other men to Washington, D.C., and checked in at the Holiday Inn National Airport in Arlington, Va. He became ill during the drive and was not able to attend any of the events, but the two others -- Dalton Crase and Troy Williams -- allegedly did. 

According to court documents, the FBI later interviewed Crase and Williams, who admitted to attending the president's speech and to have subsequently walked to the Capitol building and entered on two occasions. They also provided photographs and videos they took inside.

Crase allegedly told FBI agents: “Even though we didn’t participate in violence, I think it was dumb that we went in. ... I was breaking the law by being in the Capitol building but it didn’t register with me. ... Even me, I didn’t do anything violent, but I went into the building, so I did trespass.” According to court documents, Williams told FBI agents that “I wasn’t doing anything wrong or inciteful. ... We were a part of something, there’s cops here, they tried to stop us, they are not letting us in, but not fighting us.”

Williams also allegedly said he “rationalized with himself at one point asking himself what the legal way would be to get into the Capitol building,” because they were told by other men in the crowd that this could be a felony. Crase told the FBI “if he was ever allowed back, he would get a 'pass' the next time.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced 1/13/2022 to 3 years probation; 60 days home detention/location monitoring; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution; 60 hours community service

summary: According to a criminal complaint, Dana Winn is accused of storming the Capitol with his girlfriend, Rachael Lynn Pert. The couple was identified by one of Pert’s co-workers, said the FBI. In a video recovered from Winn’s Facebook account, he can be heard allegedly saying, “We’re headed to D.C. because us as American patriots, we're tired of all this s***. It's time to take a stand.... America needs to wake up," according to the court documents. He also adds that they brought flagpoles “to hit Antifa in the head if need be.” In an interview with the FBI, Winn allegedly admitted to entering the Capitol and identified himself in a picture that was taken inside the building on Jan. 6, 2021. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Winn is a U.S. Navy veteran.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Winn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/20/2021 to 12 Months Probation; 10 days location monitoring; $25 Special Assessment; $500 restitution; 100 hours of community service

summary:
Photographs, videos and posts from Andrew Wrigley's Facebook page suggest he was part of the massive crowd on U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. 

"At the protest in DC. I went inside the capitol building and got tear gassed," Wrigley said in one post. 

His social media accounts have since been deleted or suspended.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wrigley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/2/2021 to 18 months of probation in Pennsylvania; community service; a $2,000 fine; $500 in restitution; 60 hours community service; $10 special assessment

summary: In the days after the Capitol riot, the woman later identified by authorities as Rachel Powell simply became known on the Internet as "bullhorn lady." In photographs and videos from Jan. 6, 2021, Powell is seen wearing a light pink hat and using a bullhorn to give "very detailed instructions about the layout of the Capitol building," court documents say. In one video, she allegedly urges others to "coordinate together" to take the building. The FBI also identified Powell in photos and videos using a large pipe, with the help of another person, to break a window leading into the Capitol. Powell eventually crawled through a breached window to go inside the building, court documents indicate. According to The New Yorker, Powell is a mother of eight who sells cheese at her local farmers market in western Pennsylvania. “Listen, if somebody doesn’t help and direct people, then do more people die?” she told the magazine about the accusations against her. “That’s all I’m going to say about that. I can’t say anymore. I need to talk to an attorney.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Powell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Mark Aungst traveled to Washington, D.C., from Lewisburg, Pa., for the Jan. 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally with a busload of 55 other people, one witness told law enforcement. The bus was supposed to return to Pennsylvania shortly after the rally, but Aungst and another passenger — Tammy Bronsburg, who is also facing charges — delayed its return by an hour, according to court documents. On the trip back, others on the bus allegedly overheard Aungst bragging about being inside the Capitol after the rally. The FBI also identified Aungst in security footage from inside the Capitol building. Aungst died by suicide after entering a plea of guilty.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Aungst pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He died by suicide prior to his sentencing hearing and the case was dismissed.

summary:
Tammy Bronsburg, also known as Tammy Butry, had a rough start to her day on Jan. 6, 2021. She was waiting for her bus to President Donald Trump’s rally at a McDonald’s parking lot in Williamsport, Pa., but the 55-person charter bus was waiting for her at a McDonald’s over 20 miles away. That’s according to testimony provided to the FBI from the retired law enforcement officer who organized the trip to Washington. 

According to the criminal complaint, that same witness said Bronsburg calls herself the “pissed-off patriot.” He added that the entire group had to wait again for Bronsburg at the end of the day, after the Capitol attack, because she and another person who was charged in connection with the riot, Mark Aungst, returned to the bus an hour after their agreed-upon meeting time.

On the return trip to Pennsylvania, other passengers told the FBI that Aungst was sharing photos of himself and Bronsburg he took inside the Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bronsburg pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/27/2022

summary:
“Jeez, man. You wore your company jacket into the middle of the insurrection?” That’s what Troy Faulkner's friend wrote on social media after the Jan. 6, 2021, rampage, according to court documents. Faulkner owns a painting business, and his khaki company jacket with “Faulkner Painting” and a phone number on the back can be seen in videos taken inside the Capitol. 

The person in the jacket, later identified by authorities as Faulkner, can be seen jumping up on a ledge and kicking in a shuttered window outside the Capitol and shattering it, to the crowd’s delight. Rioters slipped through the opening to get into the building. The video clip was still available on Facebook as of early February. 

A week after the siege, according to court documents, Faulkner allegedly called an FBI hotline and turned himself in. He gave his date of birth and his cell number, which matched the one on the back of the jacket. A local Whitehall Ohio police officer told the FBI that he had arrested Faulkner in the past. Local court documents from Franklin County say Faulkner pleaded guilty to carrying a concealed weapon. He was ordered to serve 14 months in prison in 2015.

According to court documents, authorities found a text message from Faulkner in which he said police were antagonizing the crowd that day. “I believe it was all a set up for the Trump people,” he allegedly wrote. “I know I shouldn’t have kicked in the window. I was upset and wasn’t thinking rationally.”
charges: Destruction of Government Property; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Faulkner pleaded Guilty to one charge: Destruction of Government Property. Sentencing set for 10/14/2022

summary:
Kyle Fitzsimons was seen in surveillance footage pushing and grabbing officers who were holding a police line and trying to stop rioters from entering the Capitol building, according to court documents. After being struck in the head by a Metropolitan Police Department officers’ baton, Fitzsimons allegedly charged the line and swung at officers, according to images captured on an MPD body camera.

The next day, Fitzsimons, an employee at the Hannaford Supermarket in York, Maine, called into a town meeting and said he was present at the rally and the riot in Washington, according to a tipster and a Youtube video of the meeting. He added that he believes Trump is a lion leading an army of lambs through “lawfare.” Fitzsimons also said he was at the Capitol for peace but was “sucked into” the crowd and pushed into the police line. He was treated at a hospital where he received six stitches after getting hit by a police baton, according to court papers.

In an interview he gave to The Rochester Voice following the riot, Fitzsimons said, “The speeches from the morning were overtly preaching the election was not over, there was a path to victory through decertification, there was a plan to delay the certification by the House and Senate and then state legislatures would convene and (certify) the right result.” He added that as the rally ended, the crowd was asked by President Donald Trump to walk to the Capitol to “give our Republicans, the weak ones ... the kind of pride and boldness that they need to take back our country.”

According to multiple news reports, Fitzsimons has a history of intimidating lawmakers and making racist speeches at public hearings. In 2018, at a state legislative hearing on a bill to fund a job-training and education center for immigrants, he spoke of "being replaced."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Fitzsimons pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. A bench trial is held from 8/16/2022-8/19/2022.

summary:
When Brian McCreary returned home from Washington, D.C., he sent one of his co-workers at Domino’s Pizza videos from the riot at the Capitol, including footage of confrontations with police officers he recorded, according to court documents. The videos also included the breaching of a door and the sound of a gunshot heard off-camera.

In interviews with the FBI, four of McCreary’s co-workers confirmed his identity and recognized him in a photograph with Jacob Chansley, the so-called "QAnon shaman" who stormed the Capitol with a painted face and horned headdress. They also said McCreary expressed political beliefs at work, including “the belief that there was widespread voter fraud in the 2020 Presidential Election" and said McCreary told a co-worker that he “raided” the Capitol. 

McCreary later voluntarily provided a statement to the FBI regarding his participation in the Capitol breach. He said that he understood that going into the building “might not have been legal” but that “he made a personal choice at that point.” In an interview with local news, McCreary, who has since lost his job, said he's worried about the consequences of possible jail time. “The thought of losing my daughter is regularly overwhelming,” he said. “I have never cried as much as I have the past weekend.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disordelry and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disordelry Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McCreary pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/1/2022 to 36 months of Probation with 42 days intermittent confinement and 2 months of home detention; special assessment of $25; a fine of $2,500; restitution of $500

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that William Merry Jr. can be seen in news footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, standing alongside Emily Hernandez, who has been identified as his niece and also faces federal charges related to the riot. In that footage, Merry allegedly held a broken piece of a wooden sign that read “Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi," which apparently was taken from outside Pelosi's office. Merry was arrested on Feb. 4, 2021, in Missouri. According to The Associated Press, Merry's attorney said, "He believes he had a right to attend a rally and voice his political beliefs like we all do, but he does not in any way, shape or form condone any type of violence or property destruction or any type of insurrection of the government.”
charges: Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Merry pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 4/11/2022 to 45 days in jail, nine months of supervised release, including 80 hours community service, $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary:
When reporters from a St. Louis television station asked Paul Westover in mid-January if he was a man seen in videos from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, he said he was “not going to say anything about that” and hung up, according to a criminal complaint. Ten days later, FBI agents say, a distinctive yellow hat featuring the St. Louis Blues’ hockey team logo helped them identify Westover as one of the rioters waving a broken fragment of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s nameplate in the videos. 

Facebook provided video to the FBI from Westover’s deactivated account. The video was allegedly filmed by Westover as he breached police barricades with the crowd and charged past retreating officers, according to the complaint. 

Westover is president and founder of Search Ingenuity, a technological staffing company, according to screenshots from his company’s now-deactivated website. His biography describes Westover as a “huge family person” who “strives to run a firm that focuses on integrity and will never be one to compromise his own for a deal.”
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Westover pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced on 4/11/2022 to 45 days incarceration; $10 Special Assessment, and Restitution of $500

summary:
Jason Riddle, a veteran of the U.S. Army Reserve, spoke to a local NBC station in Boston days after the Capitol insurrection and, as cited in court papers, admitted that he joined the riot that day. 

“I had to see it,” he told NBC Boston, saying that he had no regrets about his actions that day. FBI agents later obtained a warrant to search Riddle's address in New Hampshire, and he gave a voluntary interview to agents about his alleged role in the rioting. 

Riddle "admitted that he walked into an office and found an open bottle of wine on or in a refrigerator and poured himself a glass," prosecutors allege. (Riddle told reporters that he "chugged" the wine.) He also allegedly told agents that he took an old book titled "Senate Procedure" from inside the Capitol, and he "sold the book to an unknown male individual for $40."

After the rioting, Riddle said he did a "delete frenzy" of his photos and videos from his trip to Washington, D.C., according to court papers. 

Riddle has been identified as a former mail carrier for the U.S. Postal Service. NBC Boston reported that he resigned from the USPS after the riot. A spokesperson for the U.S. Army said, "Pvt. Jason Riddle served in the Army Reserve as a Motor Transport Operator from Jan. 2011 to June 2016." He did not have any combat deployments, the Army said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Theft of Government Property; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Riddle pleaded Guilty to two charges: Theft of Government Property and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/4/2022 on the first charge to 90 days of incarceration; $254 restitution and $25 special assessment.  Sentenced on the other charge to 3 years of probation; $500 restitution and $10 special assessment; plus 60 hours of community service

summary:
When FBI agents interviewed Benjamin Torre at his home in Georgia more than two weeks after the insurrection, he allegedly admitted he was inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. He said he drove to Washington, D.C., with his family two days earlier and went to the Trump rally not as part of any particular group but because he was a “patriot.” 

Torre allegedly told the FBI that he saw people break the window on the door of the Capitol with a cane, and then someone reached through the broken window to open the door. Torre said he climbed through a window to get into the Capitol and just walked around and went into a couple of offices. 

In one of the videos taken of Torre from one of the Senate offices, the person recording Torre is allegedly heard saying, according to court documents, “This is insane.” Torre replied, “This is f***ing wild man.” Then, according to the documents, he turned to the camera and continued, “This is crazy. I’ve never seen anything like this before in my life. Goddang, dude. I’ve been here so many times in my life, but never like this. Never like this.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Torre pleaded Guilty to one charge:  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/7/2022 to 12 months of probation, including two months of home detention; 60 hours of community service; $1,113 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
A look through Bruno Cua’s social media posts in the runup and aftermath to Jan. 6, 2021, paint a portrait of a young man inspired by President Donald Trump. “President Trump is calling us to FIGHT!” he allegedly wrote on Parler days before the siege on the Capitol, according to court documents. “He knows this is the only way to save our great country, show up #January6th. It’s time to take our freedom back the old fashioned way.”

The FBI allegedly received two tips identifying Cua as the man in a New Yorker video who stood in the Senate chamber on Jan. 6. He wore a dark sweatshirt, a jean jacket, a red “Make America Great Again” hat and gray gloves, according to court documents, and his clothing helped authorities identify his movements and actions throughout the Capitol that day. Surveillance video inside the Capitol allegedly showed him in the same clothes wielding a baton and trying various office doors. 

In a criminal complaint, federal prosecutors cite a Jan. 6 Instagram post in which Cua allegedly wrote,”Yes, we physically fought our way in.” Another post read: “Yes, for everyone asking I stormed the [Capitol] with hundreds of thousands of patriots. I’ll do a whole video explaining what happened, this is history. What happened was unbelievable.”

Another tipster, according to court documents, told authorities that Cua had been talking about going to Washington on his Parler account for days and “actively encouraged the events on the sixth for 11 days leading up to the domestic terrorist attack,” the complaint said. 

Cua, who is believed to be the youngest person so far to be charged with storming the Capitol, allegedly assaulted a federal officer. Once inside the Senate chamber, The New Yorker video allegedly shows Cua responding to someone who ordered someone else not to sit in the vice president’s chair. He can be heard saying, “They can steal an election, but we can’t sit in their chairs?”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cua pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Dubbed "#axehole" on Twitter, William Chrestman was identified by law enforcement in photographs and videos from Jan. 6, 2021, wearing camouflage pants and a green tactical vest and carrying "what appeared to be a wooden club or axe handle" with a blue flag wrapped around it, according to court documents.

Chrestman can be seen on video marching closely and chanting with a group led by Proud Boys organizers Joseph Biggs and Ethan Nordean, who are also facing charges. According to law enforcement, strips of orange tape on some of Chrestman's belongings help link him to several others and is allegedly a sign that the group was strategically working together. Shortly after 1 p.m., the group toppled a police barricade and approached a line of U.S. Capitol Police officers, where Chrestman yells at an officer: "You shoot and I'll take your f****** a** out!" according to court documents. In another video detailed by the FBI, Chrestman turns to face the mob and yells, "Do you want your house back?" The crowd responded "Yes!" and Chrestman yelled back "Take it!" Later, Chrestman is seen in Capitol security footage in a tunnel underneath the building, using his wooden club or ax handle to prevent a metal barrier from closing, which the FBI says would have secured certain areas of the Capitol if closed. He and others are charged with conspiracy, one of the more serious allegations faced by those who breached the Capitol. 

Chrestman's attorneys argued in a legal filing that he and other Proud Boys believed they were following Donald Trump's lead when they breached the Capitol. "The mob was given explicit permission and encouragement by the former President to do what they did," they argued. His attorneys also identified him as an "Army veteran" and a "union sheet metal worker."
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Threatening a Federal Officer; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Carrying a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, that is, a wooden axe handle
case_updates: Chrestman pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Christopher Kuehne, a U.S. Marine veteran, is believed to have ties to the Kansas City chapter of the Proud Boys. 

According to court documents, Kuehne and four others wore orange tape on their clothing and helmets so they could easily identify each other on Jan. 6, 2021. The group was seen in footage marching toward the Capitol with a larger Proud Boys group. 

Once inside, surveillance footage allegedly shows Kuehne using a podium to prevent a metal barrier door from closing. The group moved in close proximity with one another, coordinating with gestures and dismantling metal barriers. 

A military spokesperson confirmed to NPR that Kuehne served in the Marines from 1993 until 2013. He deployed twice as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom and he was awarded several medals for his service, including the Purple Heart.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Kuehne pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
FBI agents believe video footage depicts Louis Colon marching among a crowd of people identified as Proud Boys on Jan. 6, 2021. A criminal complaint alleges Colon arrived at the Capitol wearing tactical gear, a helmet and gloves. Photos show a piece of orange tape was affixed to his helmet, matching headgear worn by several other people charged with conspiracy.

The complaint accuses Colon and others of deliberately attempting to stop Capitol Police from lowering metal barricades in tunnels underneath the building that would block off the invading crowd. Documents say Christopher Kuehne, another man charged with conspiracy, placed a podium under a barrier and motioned to Colon, who grabbed a chair and stuck it under another nearby barrier to stop it from blocking the rioters' path into the Capitol.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Colon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of Law Enforcement during Civil Disorder

summary:
Federal prosecutors say Cory Konold traveled to Washington, D.C., along with his sister, Felicia Konold. They were allegedly part of a group of Proud Boys, the far-right extremist group, that joined in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Both Konolds allegedly led confrontations with Capitol Police guarding the Capitol and "used their hands and bodies in an effort to disrupt or dismantle the metal barriers that officers were using to control the crowd."

They can then be seen in footage from inside the Capitol, prosecutors say. 

Both Konolds now face charges of conspiracy related to the attack on the Capitol.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Konold pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Federal prosecutors say Felicia Konold traveled to Washington, D.C., along with her brother, Cory Konold. They were allegedly part of a group of Proud Boys, the far-right extremist group, that joined in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Both Konolds allegedly led confrontations with Capitol Police guarding the Capitol and "used their hands and bodies in an effort to disrupt or dismantle the metal barriers that officers were using to control the crowd." 

They can then be seen in footage from inside the Capitol, prosecutors say. At one point, metal barriers were activated inside the building to try to seal off parts of the Capitol from the mob. Felicia Konold allegedly blocked the barriers from coming down, allowing more attackers to enter. Later, a Snapchat account believed to be associated with Felicia Konold featured videos describing how she was inducted into a Kansas City chapter of the Proud Boys, court papers indicate.

Both Konolds now face charges of conspiracy related to the attack on the Capitol.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Konold pleaded Not Guilty to all charges
