summary: At least three people who know Steve Maldonado, also known as Emilio Maldonado, called the FBI to turn him in. One of those people had recognized Maldonado in news coverage of the Jan. 6, 2021, storming of the Capitol. Another had received videos allegedly sent by Maldonado from inside the Capitol, including one from the Senate chamber, court documents indicate. In a Feb. 3, 2021, interview with the FBI, Maldonado admitted to entering the Capitol. He was arrested in Orlando, Fla., on Feb. 10, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Maldonado pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, two people took videos of what they saw posted on Adam Honeycutt's Facebook page on Jan. 6, 2021, in case Honeycutt took the photos and videos down. A few days later, the FBI was reviewing those and other photographs and videos posted by Honeycutt, including pictures of a broken furniture leg with a sticker on it that read "U.S. SENATE SERGEANT AT ARMS" and multiple videos taken from inside and outside the Capitol building. In one video reviewed by law enforcement that appears to be from inside the Capitol, Honeycutt turns the camera on himself and says, "Well, made it in." On Jan. 10, 2021, Honeycutt posted on Facebook: "I was not part of the violence. I just documented history. Hell, I was at the food truck when the s*** hit the fan." According to local news reports, Honeycutt is a bail bondsman in Northeast Florida.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Honeycutt pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced on 5/11/2022 to 90 days of Incarceration to run consecutively with term currently serving in Florida case; Restitution of $500 and Special Assessment of $10

summary: According to court documents, James Mels showed the FBI photos he had taken inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and told officers that after briefly praying, he entered the building to present his copy of the U.S. Constitution and "have his voice heard." He told the FBI that he had traveled to Washington with 11 other "like-minded patriots" that he had met online. He said he believed the election had been "fraudulently decided," according to the FBI.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mels pleaded Guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 10/20/2022

summary:
A family member identified Eduardo Alvear Gonzalez in YouTube videos where he was allegedly seen standing inside the Capitol building.

According to an FBI affidavit, in a Zoom video that Gonzalez allegedly recorded and posted the day after the Capitol riot, he can be seen sharing his laptop screen and narrating multiple photos and videos of himself and others inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In parts of the broadcast, he is depicted showing a folder on his computer named “Captiol [sic] Storming,” which appears to have around 50 photos and videos saved to it, the FBI said.

In a video he showed, Gonzalez is allegedly seen breaking into the Capitol with other rioters while saying, “We’re taking our country back.” He narrates that other rioters were looking for “doors to break in” and that law enforcement was probably told to “stand down, do not f*** with them, you guys will get hurt.” According to the complaint, as Gonzalez keeps narrating photos, he can be heard saying, “This is footage from my camera. This is me there, I’m speaking from firsthand experience” and “I’m showing everyone how I barged into the Capitol.” In the broadcast, Gonzalez also allegedly explains that he smoked marijuana inside the Capitol and that he gave the additional “joints” he had on him to fellow rioters.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Alvear Gonzalez pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/3/2022 to 24 months of probation; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution; $1,000 fine; 200 hours of community service

summary:
Taylor Johnatakis turned himself in to the FBI on Feb. 11, 2021, after a grand jury in Washington, D.C., returned an eight-count indictment against him. Public court documents do not yet reveal what exactly Johnatakis did on Jan. 6, but he is accused of obstructing an official proceeding, assaulting or impeding federal officers, remaining in a restricted building, and engaging in violent and disorderly acts in the Capitol or on its grounds.

According to local news reports, his attorney said Johnatakis is not a member or supporter of any white supremacist or hate group.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Johnatakis pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two weeks after Jan. 6, 2021, a tipster called the FBI to say that Russell Peterson's mother, Shelly Peterson, had posted on Facebook that her son had stormed the Capitol and "sat in Pelosi's chair," according to court documents. Russell Peterson also livestreamed at least two videos from inside the building, prosecutors allege. He was arrested Feb. 12, 2021, in western Pennsylvania.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Peterson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/1/2021 to 30 days incarceration; Special Assessment of $10.00; Restitution of  $500.00

summary:
An acquaintance of John Andries called the FBI after recognizing him in news coverage of the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol insurrection. In surveillance videos from the U.S. Capitol Police, Andries can be seen climbing through a broken window and later in a group that confronted Capitol Police officers, court documents say. 

Court documents say Andries served in the military but do not specify when, where or in which branch.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Andries pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing is set for 1/10/2023

summary:
Leo Brent Bozell IV is the son of a prominent conservative activist and media critic, and allegedly took part in the rioting at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

In an affidavit filed in the case, an FBI special agent stated that Bozell can be seen in footage inside the Capitol, including for a period of time on the floor of the U.S. Senate. At one point, Bozell allegedly went to the Senate gallery and "moved a camera so that the camera was pointing down to the ground of the balcony area. This was done as protesters began to enter the main floor of the U.S. Senate. By pointing the camera to the ground, the camera was unable to record protesters entering the main floor of the U.S. Senate Chamber."

Bozell is the son of Leo Brent Bozell III, the founder and president of the nonprofit Media Research Center, which describes its mission as working "to expose and neutralize the propaganda arm of the Left: the national news media." The organization runs the NewsBusters website, which frequently accuses mainstream media organizations — including NPR — of liberal bias.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bozell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Multiple people called the FBI after Christy Clark posted images on Facebook from inside and outside of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, one photograph shows the Capitol rotunda and was captioned: "I stopped and took a second to pray before I took this pic. It was overwhelming to say the least." She also sent a private message on Facebook to a relative saying, "All good, we were inside," and later clarified that she meant they were inside the Capitol, according to court documents. Clark is facing charges alongside her husband, Matthew Clark.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Clark pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 10/14/2022

summary: Matthew Clark was identified by law enforcement through multiple posts about Jan. 6, 2021, on his Facebook page. In one, he wrote, "Capital building has been breached!" and in another, he wrote that the National Mall was "full of PATRIOTS," according to court documents. Clark is also allegedly seen, alongside his wife Christy Clark, in security footage from inside the Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Clark pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 10/14/2022

summary:
Michael Lopatic Sr. has been accused of attacking and repeatedly punching a police officer in the head, as well as stealing the body camera of another police officer and destroying it, according to court documents. Prior to Jan. 6, 2021, Lopatic posted threatening messages on social media against election officials and expressed an intention to gather at the Capitol and “fight.” 
According to FBI agents, Lopatic also posted multiple photos of dead pheasants on social media. One of the captions read: “I got a double today. The dog flushed them up together. Full choke. Two shots, two kills. Both head shots. I got a rooster and a hen. I named them Joe and Kamala,” a reference to the president and vice president, according to court documents.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Theft in a Federal Enclave; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Lopatic pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Michael Quick surrendered to the FBI after a warrant was issued for his arrest. He told agents that he traveled to Washington, D.C., with his brother to attend the “Stop The Steal” rally and eventually entered the Capitol building through a broken window. Quick also said he was inside for about 15 minutes and that he was not aware he was trespassing because “he thought the police were letting people in,” according to court documents. Quick told FBI agents that he wanted to show his support for an investigation into election fraud. Quick served the in the U.S. Army from 1997 to 1999. He had no deployments and held the rank of private first class, a U.S. Army spokesperson told NPR.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restriced Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Quick pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/17/2022 to 24 months of probation, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary:
Stephen Quick told FBI agents that he was “ashamed" of what he had done by entering the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, after attending the “Stop The Steal” rally in Washington, D.C.
He surrendered to the FBI together with his brother, who also traveled with him, and recalled that “a change came over the crowd” as they approached the Capitol after the rally, according to court documents. Quick told agents he was inside for about 10 minutes.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restriced Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Quick pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/17/2022 to 24 months of probation, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: The FBI received a tip that Greg Rubenacker posted videos on Snapchat from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. "Holy s***! This is history! We took the Capitol!" Rubenacker allegedly said in one video. Federal prosecutors say Rubenacker appears to be smoking marijuana inside the Capitol rotunda in one video posted to Snapchat and states, "Smoke out the Capitol, baby." NBC New York reported that Rubenacker is a DJ based on Long Island. He was arrested on Feb. 9, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rubenacker pleaded Guilty to all charges. He was sentenced on 5/26/22 to 41 months incarceration; 36 months of supervised release; restitution of $2000; and a special assessment of $415

summary: Virginia Marie Spencer, also known as Jenny Spencer, allegedly participated in the Capitol rioting along with her husband, Christopher Spencer. The Spencers, federal prosecutors say, spoke to FBI agents and said they decided to travel to Washington, D.C., along with a caravan organized by a "twitter personality" who goes by the name Dr. ENoCH. (The Detroit Free Press describes Dr. ENoCH as a "QAnon conspiracy theorist who says he's from Michigan.") Jenny Spencer, who was wearing a sweatshirt with the logo "F*** Gun Control," allegedly told the FBI agents that they decided to go to the Capitol after then-President Trump said protesters would be marching there in his speech. Christopher Spencer told agents they were in the Capitol building for less than "15 minutes," according to the FBI. Investigators allege that they found surveillance footage and other video of the Spencers inside the building for more than 20 minutes on Jan. 6, 2021. In the videos, prosecutors say, Christopher Spencer can be heard yelling at Capitol Police, "F***ing traitor!" and encouraging other rioters to kick down a door.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Spencer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 1/7/2022 to 3 months incarceration; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: FBI investigators discovered Paul Spigelmyer's alleged role in the Capitol rioting through his posts and messages on Facebook. Spigelmyer allegedly sent a photo from inside the Capitol to a Facebook friend, along with the message "the moment we stormed the doors." In a series of Facebook posts cited by federal prosecutors, Spigelmyer said, "What happened at the capital [sic] yesterday should and must continue till this election fraud is stopped," and, “The capital [sic] building needs to be burnt down it doesn’t belong to the people that work there." Spigelmyer, prosecutors say, can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Spigelmyer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 10/28/2022

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Ryan Zink posted at least three videos to his Facebook page, according to prosecutors. In one, he turns the camera on himself and says, "We knocked down the gates! We're storming the Capitol! You can't stop us!" He adds, "We're about to bum-rush this s***!" In a later post, he said he "broke down the doors" and "pushed Congress out of session." The next day, he posted on Facebook: "I went and fought for what I believe in. ... History was made and I'm a part of it." On Jan. 8, 2021, he wrote in a private Facebook message, "I'm afraid the time for rioting is over better clean those guns and invest in some level 4 armor," according to court documents. 

Zink is a musician and the owner of Pressure Clean Oil, Gas and Wind in Lubbock, Texas, according to court documents. Local news reports also say he is a student at Texas Tech University. Zink is the son of Jeff Zink, who is running for Congress in Arizona's 7th District. Jeff Zink was also near the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 but maintains that he did not go inside, according to The Arizona Republic.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Zink pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Christian Secor is identified in federal court documents as a student at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the founder of the campus group America First Bruins. Federal prosecutors say that is a reference to the America First podcast hosted by Nick Fuentes, a prominent white supremacist. (The court records do not use Fuentes' name but appear to reference him as "a public figure known for making racist statements and denying the Holocaust.") 

Secor, prosecutors say, also posted on the video-streaming platform DLive under the name "Scuffed Elliot Rodger," an apparent reference to the man who killed six people in Isla Vista, Calif., in 2014. 

The FBI learned of Secor's alleged involvement in the Jan. 6 insurrection when it received tips from at least 11 witnesses. One of those witnesses allegedly told investigators that Secor is a self-described fascist who "openly posted calls for America to become a whites-only nation." During the Capitol riot, Secor can allegedly be seen on video sitting in the chair of the Senate presiding officer, where Vice President Mike Pence had been seated just hours earlier. In one video, prosecutors allege, Secor was seen among "a group of rioters attempting to push through a doorway that is blocked by no less than three police officers" and "breaking through a police line."

After the rioting, one witness told the FBI that Secor moved back in with his mother in Costa Mesa, Calif., and then "got rid of his phone and car and bragged that he would not be caught for his involvement at the U.S. Capitol." The FBI conducted surveillance of Secor in late January, according to court documents, and he was arrested on Feb. 16, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Secor pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 10/7/2022

summary:
Daniel Egtvedt engaged in multiple altercations with law enforcement on Jan. 6, 2021, as officers attempted to restrain him from going farther into the Capitol building, according to court documents. Egtvedt was allegedly seen on various security cameras gripping, pushing and shoving police officers, as well as screaming “shoot me” at one of the officers.
The FBI also obtained a video of Egtvedt in which he screams that he was tear-gassed in the altercations. “Everybody, if you’re seeing this, come down here now. We’re not backing away. This is our house,” he said. He also said that members of Congress should “grow a spine or f***ing resign!”
The Daily Beast reported that Egtvedt has visited the White House twice and has posted on his social media accounts several old photographs in which he's posing with Lara Trump, then-Vice President Mike Pence and Rep. Dan Crenshaw.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Building
case_updates: Egtvedt pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI received tips from "multiple concerned citizens" who said they recognized Jonathan Mellis, nicknamed "Cowboy Screech" on the Internet for his thick black-rimmed glasses and white cowboy hat, at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Mellis posted several selfies and other photographs on Facebook of the crowd on the western steps of the Capitol, with the caption "Storming the Castle. The world heard US!!! Finally not ignored," according to court documents. As he got closer to the building itself, Mellis is allegedly seen on footage from a Metropolitan Police Department body camera "repeatedly striking and making stabbing movements towards the officers" using a large stick. According to court documents, Mellis appears to be "attempting to strike the officers’ necks between their helmets and body-armor where they are not protected." According to court documents, Mellis later wrote on Facebook, "Don't you dare try to tell that people are blaming this on antifa and BLM. We proudly take responsibility for storming the Castle."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mellis pleaded not guilty to all charges

summary:
According to court documents, Graydon Young emailed a membership application to the Florida chapter of the far-right Oath Keepers militia on Dec. 3, 2020, with a message that read, “looking to get involved in helping.” Two weeks later, Young allegedly promoted the Oath Keepers on Facebook, saying “recruiting is under way. DM me if you want more info.” The court documents further state that Young reached out to a Florida company that provides combat training to express interest in an “Ultimate Training Munitions” class.
On Jan. 6, Young and several other individuals affiliated with the Oath Keepers allegedly “maneuvered in an organized and practiced fashion” to forcibly enter the Capitol, causing “significant damage” to the doors they breached, according to court documents.
The indictment states that Young deleted his Facebook account on Jan. 8, 2021, prompting a count of tampering with documents or proceedings.

At Young’s initial appearance on Feb. 16, 2021, his attorney said Young had “no history of violence” and that he and his wife “have strong ties to the community” as business owners.

Young is a U.S. Army veteran and a Navy reservist, according to court documents.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Young pleaded guilty to Conspiracy and Obstruction of An Official Proceeding and, as part of a plea agreement, agreed to cooperate with the government's investigation, including providing testimony at trial and submitting to interviews with law enforcement.

summary:
Federal prosecutors allege that Kelly Meggs and his wife stormed the Capitol with a group of Oath Keepers, a far-right militia. Investigators searched phone records, social media profiles, credit card records, and publicly available photos and videos to connect both Meggs with the storming of the Capitol. On Dec. 22, 2020, Kelly Meggs allegedly messaged someone on Facebook: "Trump said It's gonna be wild!!!!!!! It's gonna be wild!!!!!!! He wants us to make it WILD that's what he's saying. He called us all to the Capitol and wants us to make it wild!!!" In another message that month, he allegedly wrote that "we will have at least 50-100 OK there. (The government says that "OK" is a reference to the Oath Keepers.) The government also suspects Kelly Meggs planned with other Oath Keepers in the run-up to the insurrection. 

According to court documents, Meggs used a credit card to pay for hotel rooms for the group in the Washington, D.C., area. On the day of the insurrection, prosecutors allege, both Meggs "prepared themselves for battle" by wearing military-style gear. They then allegedly joined with other members of the Oath Keepers to form a military-style "stack" formation as they stormed the Capitol.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Meggs pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Connie Meggs and her husband stormed the Capitol with a group of Oath Keepers, a far-right pro-Trump militia. On the day of the insurrection, both Meggs allegedly "prepared themselves for battle" by wearing military-style gear. They then joined other members of the Oath Keepers to form a military-style "stack" formation as they stormed the Capitol, according to court documents. One witness told the FBI that they were acquainted with Connie Meggs and that she works at a thrift shop in Florida. The witness also claimed to investigators that they had seen Meggs wearing clothing with "Oath Keepers" written on it months before the insurrection.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Meggs pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Laura Steele allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., with her brother, where they eventually met up with several other individuals affiliated with the far-right Oath Keepers militia.  According to court documents, the group was involved in trainings to teach and learn paramilitary combat tactics in advance of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection and also used social media and apps to recruit individuals. Federal prosecutors say they brought paramilitary gear to Washington, changed into tactical uniforms featuring the Oath Keepers insignia and moved together in a military-style “stack” formation toward the Capitol, where they pushed past at least one officer, entered the Capitol rotunda and communicated using a walkie-talkie-like app. According to the FBI, Steele emailed a membership application to the Florida chapter of the Oath Keepers just a few days before the Capitol attack. "My brother, Graydon Young told me to send the application to you so I can be verified for the Events this coming Tuesday and Wednesday," she allegedly wrote in the email. Steele was formerly a policer officer with the High Point Police Department in High Point, N.C., the department confirmed to NPR.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Steele pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to court documents, Sandra Parker was part of a group of militia members who spent months planning and training for the Jan. 6, 2021, siege on the Capitol. Parker, a retiree, allegedly joined the Oath Keepers, a far-right militia group, and was allegedly seen moving around the Capitol that day wearing combat gear including communications devices, reinforced vests, helmets and goggles. The criminal complaint says the group moved toward the Capitol that day in a practiced, tactical formation known as a “stack," sticking together by keeping a hand on the back of the person in front of them.
Parker is named as part of a larger indictment that included several other alleged members of the Oath Keepers, including her 70-year-old husband, Bennie. 
According to court documents, Sandra Parker paid for two rooms for two people at the Comfort Inn Ballston from Jan. 5-7 and traveled with others to Washington, D.C. 
The Oath Keepers are known for recruiting former military, law enforcement, and emergency workers and are described by the FBI as a group that believes  “the federal government has been corrupted by a shadowy conspiracy that is trying to strip American citizens of their rights.” Parker is alleged to have joined the group with her husband shortly before the Jan. 6 siege.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Parker pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
Bennie Parker allegedly exchanged text messages with an alleged leader of the far-right Oath Keepers militia named Jessica Watkins right after Christmas. “I may have to see what it takes to join your militia, ours is about gone,” he wrote, according to court documents. In the days that followed, Watkins and Parker discussed uniforms, gear and the weapons they would bring to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, the court documents say. 
“Pack Khaki/Tan pants. Weapons are ok now as well. Sorry for the confusion. We are packing the car and heading your way shortly,” Watkins allegedly wrote. Parker responded that he and his wife didn’t have khakis so they would wear jeans. And then he checked one more time, “So I can bring my gun?”
According to court documents, surveillance video from a hotel in Arlington, Va., shows Bennie and Sandra Parker, Watkins and others named in the indictment together prior to the attack. Sandra Parker is alleged to have breached the Capitol. Her husband is thought to have facilitated communication between members of the group from outside. 
A few days after the insurrection, according to the court documents, Watkins told Bennie Parker that she had been tracking the FBI's "wanted list" of suspects and believed “they’re only interested in people who destroyed things. I wouldn’t worry about them coming after us.”
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Parker pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary:
A day after the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, according to court documents, Joseph Fischer had an exchange with another Facebook user: “Well, I may need a job. … Word got out that I was at the rally… lol.” 

Fischer was worried because he was a patrolman at the North Cornwall Township Police Department in Pennsylvania before he allegedly breached the Capitol with the hordes after the Trump rally. 

Fischer caught it all in a three-minute video that appears to show him entering the Capitol and, among other things, yelling, “Charge.” 

A Washington Metropolitan Police officer inside the Capitol building apparently recorded the scene on his body camera. According to court documents, the video shows a scuffle, and at least one police officer can be seen on the ground. Someone on the video is shouting, “let him up … let him up,” and then the individual says, “I am a cop. I am a cop, too.” Officials believe that individual was Fischer.

Fischer wrote in a Facebook exchange a short time later that the police chief at work had had a word with him. “I told him if that is the price I have to pay to voice my freedom and liberties which I was born with and thusly taken away then then [sic] there must be the price. I told him I have no regrets. … Sometimes doing the right thing no matter how small is more important than ones own security.”

The North Cornwall Police Department issued a statement saying Fischer had been suspended without pay.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fischer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Phillip Bromley, a nurse anesthetist from Alabama, was just outside the Speaker's Lobby in the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, when he said, according to court documents, that he witnessed a U.S. Capitol Police officer shoot Ashli Babbitt, a 35-year-old Air Force veteran and Trump supporter. In a video posted to Parler, court documents say that Bromley said he was reminding SWAT officers “of their oath” when “a gunshot went off.” Bromley allegedly said in the video that it “did not look like a survivable wound” and then described what Babbitt was wearing and then added, “They shot her and she is dead.” According to court documents, he concluded the narrative by saying, “My name is Phillip Bromley.” Bromley’s account of what took place was just one of three videos that allegedly placed him inside the Capitol just outside the Speaker's Lobby during the insurrection. According to court documents, other people in the mob posted videos that placed someone who looked like Bromley there, and surveillance video from the Capitol appeared to do that, too. Officials matched Bromley’s Alabama driver’s license picture with stills from the video. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Bromley served in the U.S. Army Reserves from 1993 until 1999 and was also in the National Guard as a medic from 2002 until 2006.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bromley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/29/2022 to 90 days incarceration; 1 year of supervised release; $2,000 restitution; $2,000 fine; $25 special assessment

summary:
Mariposa Castro uploaded several videos on Facebook that showed her both inside and outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. In one, Castro narrated, "I'm going in, I'm going in the Capitol. We're in! We're inside the Capitol house." She continued posting videos throughout the day. In another one, an unidentified person says that "traitors will be shot" and mentions former Vice President Mike Pence. Castro then adds: "We're coming. ... This is war."

Castro ran a yoga studio and tea lounge in California's Bay Area but is no longer involved with the business, according to local news reports. She is reportedly “well-known in the community for her counter-protest activities," according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Castro pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/23/2022 to 45 days of incarceration; Special Assessment of $10; fine of $5,000 dollars

summary: Federal prosecutors say Glenn Croy took a photo and videos of himself inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, which he then sent to another person on Facebook. In one message, he allegedly wrote, "I was there" and sent a photo of himself in front of a bust of Abraham Lincoln. Prosecutors say Croy is also visible in footage from a police officer's body camera during the riot. According to the government, Croy was active on Twitter. And in December 2020, when Republican Rep. Lauren Boebert of Colorado tweeted, “Who is going to be in DC on January 6th to stand with President Donald Trump?” he allegedly replied: “fellow Coloradan we will be there."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Croy pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed.  Sentenced 11/5/2021 to 36 months probation with special conditions that include 14 days in a residential reentry center and 90 days location monitoring (home detention); $10.00 special assessment; and $500 in restitution

summary: A witness turned Paul Hodgkins into the FBI after seeing a selfie of Hodgkins from the Senate floor, which he had posted on the social media site Parler. According to court documents, another video published by The New Yorker also shows Hodgkins holding a large Trump flag and standing alongside others as they shout and pray inside the Senate chamber. In security footage from the building, Hodgkins can also be seen on the Senate floor with protective goggles around his neck and putting on what appears to be white latex gloves, according to court documents. In an interview with the FBI, Hodgkins said he traveled to Washington alone on a bus from Florida.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hodgkins pleaded Guilty to: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; the other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 7/19/2021 to eight months in prison and 24 months of supervised release; $100 special assessment; and $2,000 restitution.

summary: Two days before the Capitol riot, Terry Lindsey allegedly posted on Facebook, "Going to D.C. anyone I know going give me a shout out." Federal prosecutors say that Lindsey then joined the rioters in storming the Capitol, and posted a photo of himself inside the building along with the caption, "Notice how peaceful we were inside the Capitol. Don’t believe the news we didn’t start s***.” (The government alleges Lindsey was standing next to another defendant in that photo, Glenn Croy.) He is also allegedly visible in footage from a police body camera. Later, on Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say Lindsey posted a message on Facebook in which he said people who "don't like" what happened in the Capitol that day were "brainwashed." According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Lindsey enlisted in the U.S. Army twice. According to the sentencing memo, he was discharged from service “under other than honorable conditions.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lindsey pleaded Guilty to three charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced on 7/15/2022 to 5 months incarceration; 3 years probation; 60 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $45 special assessment

summary:
Not much is known yet about Verden Nalley's case in connection with the Capitol riot. 

He was released on $10,000 bond on Feb. 19, 2021, and instructed to return to his home in Georgia. He’s not to leave his residence except for work or religious, medical, educational or other similar purposes, and he agreed to GPS monitoring. 

He was arrested on Feb. 16, 2021, according to the Atlanta Bureau of the FBI. Court documents show he was charged alongside William McCall Calhoun Jr., another suspect in the riot from Georgia. 

This summary will be updated with more information as it becomes available.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Nalley pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 3/10/2022 to 2 years of probation, $500 restitution; $25 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary:
“First ones in,” Zachary Wilson allegedly wrote on Facebook as he posted photos and videos from inside Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi’s office on Jan. 6, 2021. When a friend wrote he could be sent to jail, Wilson quickly responded, “I didn’t do anything wrong,” according to a criminal complaint. 
Wilson told FBI agents he entered the U.S. Capitol building because he wanted his “voice to be heard” as a strong supporter of former President Donald Trump, according to the complaint. 
It also states Wilson told agents that he had deleted the Facebook videos and deactivated his accounts since Jan. 6 and that he did not destroy any property while inside the Capitol building.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/27/2022 to 24 months probation; 45 days home detention; 60 hours community service; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Thomas Webster is identified in court documents as a U.S. Marine Corps veteran and as a retired New York City Police Department officer. In police body camera footage from Jan. 6, 2021, Webster is allegedly seen at a police barricade yelling at an officer: “You f***ing piece of s***. You f***ing Commie motherf***ers," while carrying a large metal flagpole with a Marine Corps flag attached to it. Soon after, Webster allegedly shoves the barricade and "raises the metal flagpole above his head and forcefully swings downward, striking the metal barricade directly," according to a criminal complaint. Webster allegedly strikes the officer several times with the flagpole and tackles the officer to the ground, where he tries to remove the officer's face shield and gas mask. In a later interview, the officer reported that they were unable to breathe during the assault, court documents indicate. The FBI used Facebook photos, a passport photo and the help of an administrator at Webster's children's school to link him to the attack, according to court records.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence within the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Webster pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Convicted on all charges in a jury trial held 4/25/2022-5/2/2022. Sentencing is set for 9/2/2022

summary:
According to court records, open source videos from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show several people who the FBI has assessed as members of the far-right group Proud Boys marching toward the Capitol. Videos show Ryan Keith Ashlock marching with this group.

In one video, the same group, led by Proud Boys organizers Joseph Biggs and Ethan Nordean, is seen marching toward the entrance of the Capitol, according to the affidavit. Images from the riot and FBI statements link Ashlock to the Kansas City Proud Boys. He can be seen wearing a green tactical vest with orange tape affixed to the front, a gray respirator, yellow goggles and gray kneepads, according to photos captured outside the Capitol.

According to the FBI, U.S. Capitol Police footage also shows Ashlock and several confirmed Proud Boys members trying to pass the barricades and officers guarding the Capitol entrance. Individuals are not only seen moving together but also gesturing to one another while moving together on the Capitol grounds, said the FBI. As the group tried to enter the building, Ashlock allegedly pushed on the barricades and law enforcement but got repelled by officers when they used pepper spray.

In an interview with the FBI, Ashlock identified himself in photos taken during the Jan. 6 riot but explained that he left the grounds after being pepper sprayed by officers, according to the affidavit.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds (2 counts)
case_updates: Ashlock pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: Lewis Cantwell, the co-owner of a tea shop in downtown Sylva, N.C., told Smoky Mountain News that he was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, filming and "didn't go there with any intention to hurt anyone or storm the Capitol.”  According to The Sylva Herald, in social media posts written days after the insurrection, Cantwell allegedly said, "People got mad when [P]ence didn’t do what they wanted, so Trump supporters stormed that building, not Antifa, not BLM, not undercover feds,” and added “I talked to people up front. Most were veterans and small business owners.” A spokesperson for the U.S. Army confirmed that Cantwell served from 2005-2007.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building and Ground; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cantwell pleaded Guilty to one count: Civil Disorder. The other charges are dismissed. Sentencing set for 9/22/2022

summary:
Raechel Genco was identified after her boyfriend, Ryan Stephen Samsel, was arrested for reportedly knocking down barricades that injured an officer. According to court documents, during the arrest of Samsel, police realized that the couple traveled to Washington, D.C., together.

Photos show Genco in Washington with her boyfriend, according to the FBI. Genco was identified following Samsel as he walked toward the barricades guarded by law enforcement. Even though Samsel told the FBI that Genco did not pass any barriers, photos place her in the restricted parts of the Capitol, records say.
charges: Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Genco pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentencing set for 9/27/2022

summary:
According to court records, Philip Grillo was identified after two tipsters spotted him in footage that aired on CNN.  Video footage showed Grillo with a megaphone in hand climbing into the Capitol through a broken window, according to the FBI. 

Inside the building, Grillo and others were captured on surveillance footage in a physical confrontation with uniformed officers, according to an affidavit. The video allegedly shows Grillo and others pushing against the officers who were barricading the exterior doors to prevent the rest of the crowd from entering the building. A video taken outside the Capitol also showed Grillo with a crowd shouting "fight for Trump."

Photos show Grillo was wearing a Knights of Columbus embroidered jacket when he stormed the Capitol. Grillo is a Republican state committeeman for the 24th Assembly District in Queens, N.Y., according to the Queens County GOP website. News reports say he identifies himself as "The Republican Messiah" on his Facebook profile.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grillo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Derek Jancart was identified by a former co-worker after he posted a photo on Facebook showing a group of rioters inside the Capitol. Jancart captioned the post “We’re In,” according to the FBI. Jancart was also captured by a Metropolitan Police Department officer's body-worn camera and Capitol building security camera footage as he was inside the Capitol. Later, another tipster contacted the FBI and informed the bureau that Jancart texted a family member while he was inside the Capitol, according to an affidavit. Based on the tips the FBI received, Jancart was taken into custody at his residence in Ohio on Feb. 23, 2021. According to court documents, Jancart is a veteran of the U.S. Air Force.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Jancart pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 9/29/2021 to 45 days in jail; $10 assessment; and $500 restitution.

summary:
An ex-girlfriend reported Richard Michetti to the FBI after he sent a text message from the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, calling her a “moron,” according to court documents. Michetti allegedly sent a stream of messages and videos to the woman at about 2:45 p.m. the day of the riot, showing protesters carrying flags both inside and outside the Capitol.

“If you can’t see the election was stolen you’re a moron,” court documents say Michetti wrote to the woman at about 4:30 p.m. “Trump won but they won’t audit the votes.” Michetti continued this prolonged text message exchange with his ex-girlfriend into the evening, writing just after 6 p.m., “I understand your point but what I'm saying is [ex-girlfriend's name] the election was rigged and everyone knows it. All's we wanted was an investigation.” 

FBI documents say Michetti's ex-girlfriend identified him in photos and security camera footage that agents collected from the Capitol on Jan. 6.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Michetti pleaded Guilty to one charge: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting. Sentencing set  for 9/6/2022

summary:
The FBI says body camera footage and videos posted to social media show the owner of a used car dealership in western Kentucky, Clayton Ray Mullins, assaulting a U.S. Capitol Police officer on Jan. 6, 2021. FBI agents claim the assault occurred seconds after members of the crowd begged that same officer to help their friend, Rosanne Boyland, who lay injured and dying on the steps just outside an entrance to the Capitol.
The criminal complaint accuses Mullins and others of grabbing the officer’s leg, which eventually led to the officer getting dragged down that set of stairs. The officer reported that the crowd stripped him of his helmet, baton and cellphone while also kicking him, striking him with flagpoles and macing him. He later received two staples at the hospital to close a head laceration. 
Court documents also claim that Mullins was part of a group of rioters who had pushed bicycle racks that were being used as barricades out of the way before spraying police with pepper spray and rushing toward them earlier in the afternoon. 
Mullins was identified in FBI photos by a bank employee who has known him for 30 years.
A court document filed March 2, 2021, states that Mullins has no previous criminal history, but it calls him a “violent instigator” whose record of traffic-related citations demonstrates “disregard for the safety of others” and “a general failure to abide by rules and regulations.”
charges: Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mullins pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A witness told FBI agents that Joseph Padilla, also known as Jose Padilla, has “recently been immersed in the alt-right and had a ‘Q-Anon mentality.’” The criminal complaint claims Padilla approached police barricades during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot wearing a scuba mask. “Push! Push! F***ing push!” Padilla yelled as officers stripped off his mask and struck him with batons to stop him. The complaint states that Padilla later threw a flagpole at officers who were being attacked by rioters on steps leading into the U.S. Capitol.  “I was beaten unconscious twice, sprayed more times than I care to count, received strikes from batons that should have been lethal … except that God was on my side,” Padilla later wrote on pro-Trump website thedonald.win, according to the FBI. The criminal complaint also claims Padilla posted to Facebook on Jan. 7 to dispute rumors that antifa masterminded the riot. “It was not Antifa,” Padilla wrote. “They were Patriots who were trying to Restore the Republic after being attacked by the cops, who struck first.” Padilla served in the Tennessee Army National Guard from July 2002 until October 2012. He attained the rank of sergeant, a National Guard spokesperson confirmed.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Padilla pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Michael Anthony Pope met his brother William Pope the day before the U.S. Capitol riot in Philadelphia. They were planning to camp at several parks along the Atlantic Seaboard before returning home, according to the FBI.
The criminal complaint says surveillance footage shows the brothers in various areas of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. It also states that Michael Pope entered an elevator and refused police requests to leave at one point.
William Pope later told FBI agents that they canceled their vacation plans after seeing the gravity of the Jan. 6 riots. They instead drove to Pittsburgh through West Virginia so Michael could catch a flight back to Idaho. Michael Pope was arrested Feb. 12 in Sandpoint, Idaho.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pope pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
William Pope, a former candidate for Topeka City Council and current Ph.D. student at Kansas State University, turned himself in to the FBI on Jan. 12, 2021.
“I did not damage any property or engage in any violence,” Pope wrote on the FBI’s Internet tip system. “I am loyal to the United States and was only there to exercise my freedom of speech. I left the building voluntarily.”
A criminal complaint states that video footage depicts Pope and his brother Michael Pope in the hallway outside Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi’s office. William Pope was striking an office door with a flagpole and attempting to batter the door open with his shoulder, the documents claim. 
Capitol Police officers told the FBI they recalled William Pope “due to his large size and his passive resistance.” They say Pope blocked officers from closing doors to stop other rioters from entering the Capitol and that Pope tensed up and refused to move when officers attempted to physically push him from the building.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pope pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say they charged James Rahm after he put up posts about storming the Capitol on Facebook, which tipsters then shared with investigators. Rahm can also allegedly be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Rahm allegedly posted on Facebook that he entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office during the riot and claimed he urinated inside. He also allegedly said in a video from inside the Capitol, "We’re taking our f****** house back. We’re here. Time to find some brass and kick some frickin’ a**." According to court papers, Rahm claimed he had been pepper sprayed during the riot. He also allegedly replied to another commenter on Facebook, "do not believe the media there were no anarchist no antifa just patriots trying to take our country back."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rahm pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Soon after the Capitol riot, the FBI issued a "be on the lookout" bulletin with a series of pictures of suspects in the Capitol riot. The Office of the State’s Attorney for Harford
County, Md., then told the FBI that it used facial recognition software to identify one of the people in the photos as Robert Reeder of Maryland, according to federal court records. Later, on Jan. 19, 2021, Reeder contacted federal law enforcement through an attorney and provided photos and videos from in and around the Capitol during the riot. According to the affidavit, Reeder recorded "an assault on a Capitol Police Officer" and also filmed himself apparently telling an officer, "You need to retreat!” At another point in the video, the affidavit states, Reeder spoke directly to the camera and said, "I was in there for over half an hour. I got gassed several times inside the Capitol, many times outside the Capitol. Got shot with pepper balls. It was f****** nuts. We had to do...ah...battle with the Police inside. It was crazy...absolutely insane.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Reeder pleaded Guilty to one count: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/8/2021 to 3 months in jail; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Days before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Alexander Sheppard updated his Facebook status. “Millions of us will be in Washington D.C. on January 6th to protest the RIGGED election and the acts of WAR that China committed on our country," it said, according to court documents. "I’ll see you there!” In photographs and videos from Jan. 6, Sheppard can allegedly be seen roaming inside the Capitol with others. When FBI investigators attempted to interview Sheppard in the weeks following the riot, he said he wanted a lawyer before answering questions, but did say, according to an FBI affidavit, that he had driven from Ohio to Washington, D.C., to protest the “rigged election.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sheppard pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say Tristan Stevens, a computer engineering student at the University of West Florida, clashed with police at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In video surveillance footage, Stevens can be seen among a crowd of rioters using police shields and police riot batons to combat police officers, according to a criminal complaint. At one point, he allegedly grabbed one of the shields that was being passed around and pushed his way to the front of the line of rioters, where he tried to take a baton from an officer.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Stevens pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
"I was probably one of the first 100 in there," read a message posted by Lori Vinson on social media, according to court documents. "In there" being the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, where Vinson, together with her husband, entered the building and spent approximately 40 minutes inside before exiting from the back. 
"People have asked are you sorry that you done that, absolutely I am not, I am not sorry for that, I would do it again tomorrow," Vinson told a local Fox News channel. Vinson also told FBI agents she did not meet any resistance while entering and was not asked by any police officers to leave. Vinson was fired from her job as a registered nurse afterward.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vinson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/22/2021 to five years of probation, fined $5,000; $500 in restitution, $10 special assessment; 120 hours of community service

summary: Thomas Vinson told FBI agents that on Jan. 6, 2021, he and his wife went to the Capitol as a “peaceful bunch of people there to express their views to Congress.” He also added that he did not take or damage any property but mainly chanted after entering the building. According to his wife, they stayed inside for about 40 minutes, unaware that they were not allowed to be there. In a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, a federal prosecutor wrote: "The defendant also served in the U.S. Air Force from 1984 to 1988. While laudable, his military service renders his decision to storm a protected government building during a Constitutional proceeding all the more shocking – and egregious."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vinson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/22/2021 to five years of probation, fined $5,000; $500 in restitution; $10 special assessment; 120 hours of community service.

summary: Luke Coffee was identified in photos and videos of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack by several people, including a college classmate who is now a special agent with the FBI, according to court documents. Coffee told investigators that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Dallas on Jan. 4. On the day of the attack, Coffee is allegedly seen assaulting police officers with a crutch among a mob of other people trying to enter the U.S. Capitol, according to police body camera footage. According to Texas Monthly, Coffee, a director and actor who appeared in the television show Friday Night Lights, stayed at an upscale resort in Texas after the insurrection to "clear his head" after images of him at the Capitol began to circulate on Twitter. Coffee told the magazine that a few months into the pandemic, he discovered QAnon and felt like he was "found."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Coffee pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: John Steven Anderson attempted to enter the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, through a tunnel to a lower level of the building, according to court documents. As he got closer to the door, Anderson is seen on officer body camera footage holding a police shield, which he later released at the request of an officer, according to court documents. The officer warned Anderson that he would "spray" him if he did not release the shield, according to court documents. It is unclear whether that happened, but Anderson is later seen sitting down among the crowd. When asked to get up, Anderson stands up and is heard saying he has “asthma,” he “can’t breathe” and "possibly that he was collapsing," according to court documents. Police then brought him inside the building, where he was escorted to an EMT and later arrested. He died Sept. 21, 2021, at Baptist Hospital South in Jacksonville, Fla., according to an obituary published by the St. John’s Family Funeral Home and his lawyer.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Anderson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. He died Sept. 21 at Baptist Hospital South in Jacksonville, Florida, according to an obituary published by the St. John’s Family Funeral Home and his lawyer.

summary:
According to court documents, Jeremy Groseclose was identified by two online tipsters who informed the FBI that he had several social media posts about being in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Groseclose was also captured by Capitol building surveillance video, according to the affidavit. In the surveillance video, he can be seen recording law enforcement officers as they had a physical struggle with another rioter. Groseclose was also captured impeding law enforcement from securing the building against rioters, said the FBI. Surveillance videos allegedly show him trying to prevent officers from closing a room off by placing chairs, trash cans and other objects under the overhead door.

Groseclose was arrested Feb. 25, 2021, at his home in Virginia.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Groseclose pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
James Horning told a friend on Facebook that he attended the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol so he could smoke weed in government buildings, participate in anarchy and intimidate Congress, according to screenshots of his Facebook profile included in the criminal complaint. He also posted to Facebook that he was “damn proud” to have been there.
The FBI says surveillance footage depicts a man matching Horning’s description entering the Capitol at about 2:45 p.m. and wandering throughout the building.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Horning pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In a series of text messages sent to a family member, William Norwood III said he assaulted and stole gear from police officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to court documents. The day before the attack, Norwood also allegedly said that he planned to dress in all black so he would "look just like ANTIFA," adding that he would "get away with anything." After the riots, Norwood followed up: "It worked... I got away with things that others were shot or arrested for." Federal investigators say at one point on Jan. 6, Norwood sent a selfie of himself wearing what appears to be a U.S. Capitol Police tactical vest underneath a camouflage jacket. In interviews with investigators, Norwood allegedly denied assaulting officers and claimed his text messages were just meant to make him "sound tough."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Norwood pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Andrew Hernandez was identified by a manager at his workplace after a photo of him wearing a shirt and hat bearing the company’s name and logo during the Capitol riot was published on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. After being confronted by the company’s management, Hernandez was subsequently terminated for misrepresenting the company in illegal activities, according to court documents. 
Hernandez was also seen in Capitol security camera footage carrying a flag with a GoPro camera zip-tied to the flagpole, according to the FBI. In the footage he can allegedly be seen with a group of rioters violently pushing their way into the building.

A review of his social media accounts suggests that Hernandez adheres to multiple ideologies, including Q-Anon, health and science-related conspiracies, financial conspiracies and various conspiracies associated with U.S. political figures, according to the FBI. In a Twitter post, days before the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Hernandez wrote, “Happy New Year to You and your Family Courageous Mr. President. You are the Greatest President These United States of American Has Had! We the People are Honored to Stand with You, Fight and Defeat this [hidden] ENEMY Once and For All. For God and Country We Fight!”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hernandez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
In late January, Anna Morgan-Lloyd went to the Greene County, Ind., Sheriff's Department to try to obtain a firearm permit. Once there, according to federal prosecutors, an employee of the department recognized Morgan-Lloyd from Facebook posts, where she said she stormed the Capitol. At that point, federal investigators got involved. 

Searches of Morgan-Lloyd's Facebook profile allegedly uncovered multiple posts from her and another defendant, Dona Bissey, in which they described breaching the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. "I’m here. Best day ever," Morgan-Lloyd allegedly wrote. "We stormed the capitol building." In one post, Bissey allegedly stated that she and Morgan-Lloyd were among the first 100 to 200 people to breach the Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Morgan-Lloyd pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, and the other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 6/23/2021 to 36 months of probation; 120 hours of community service; $10 special assessment and $500 of restitution.

summary:
Dona Bissey allegedly breached the Capitol along with another woman from Indiana, Anna Morgan-Lloyd. Both women posted photos and comments about their actions on Jan. 6, 2021, according to federal prosecutors. 

“Best f***ing day ever!! I’ll never forget. We got into the Capitol Building,” Bissey wrote in one post cited in court documents. In another post, Bissey wrote, "I can tell you even though windows and doors were busted, the Police stood with arms crossed. No force. Some even opened doors and fences. Seen it with my own eyes.” 

Bissey is the owner of a salon, according to a witness who spoke with federal agents. That witness told investigators that Bissey "regularly spoke supportively of QAnon and other conspiracy theories."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bissey pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/12/2021 to 14 days of incarceration; 60 hours of community service; $10 special assessment; restitution of $500

summary: According to the FBI, Danielle Doyle can be seen on surveillance video entering the Capitol through a broken window and walking around. Two witnesses came forward identifying Doyle as a former co-worker, according to court documents. The Oklahoma City Thunder NBA team confirmed to local media that Doyle was a former employee who worked as an account manager for the team until December of last year. “She’s not charged with damaging anything in the Capitol or causing harm to anyone…She’s a fabulous young lady passionate about politics,” said Irven Box, Doyle’s attorney, in an interview he gave to The Oklahoman. A judge set her bond at $10,000.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
