case_updates: Doyle pleaded Guilty to one count: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 10/1/2021 to 2 months Probation; a $3,000.00 Fine; $10 special assessment; and $500 restitution.

summary: “There’s got to be something we can use against these f***ing scumbags,” Christopher Moynihan can be heard saying on a video captured inside the Senate floor of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to the court documents. Moynihan can be seen reviewing and taking pictures on his cellphone of official congressional documents that are “believed to detail the objections and votes of certain congressional members on the certification of electoral results.” The video also shows him standing on the dais inside the Senate chamber. According to FBI agents, two witnesses who reached out to the agency identified Moynihan and confirmed his identity.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stipulated Bench Trial/Plea Agreement Hearing held on 8/23/2022 finds Moynihan Guilty as to one count: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Moynihan also enters a Plea of Guilty as to the remaining counts.  Sentencing set for 12/20/2022

summary:
The Department of Justice says a "close contact" of Bryan Wayne Ivey contacted investigators in late January after recognizing him in photos from the Capitol riot, wearing a brown jacket, brown hat and sunglasses. The witness allegedly told investigators that Ivey also admitted entering the Capitol that day. 

Federal prosecutors say Ivey can also be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as he "attempts to assist others in entering the building."

The FBI arrested Ivey on March 4, 2021, in Cookeville, Tenn.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ivey pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced to 36 months of Probation; 60 days location monitoring/home detention; $10 special assessment; $500 in restitution.

summary: Elias Costianes posted videos of himself breaching the U.S. Capitol on Snapchat, federal prosecutors allege. Costianes uploaded video from inside an elevator reserved for senators and inside the Senate chamber, according to federal investigators. In one video described in court documents, Costianes watched as rioters tried to push open a door blocked by law enforcement and said "open the f****** doors!" and "let's go!" Eventually, the mob overran the officers. Costianes was arrested Feb. 12, 2021, and was indicted by a grand jury March 3, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of Congress and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Costianes pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal investigators believe Federico Klein, a former State Department aide, assaulted police officers with a riot shield and attempted to take items from officers in and around the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, Klein held top-secret security clearance at the time. In various body camera footage, Klein is allegedly seen fighting officers and trying to breach a police line to enter the Capitol. At one point, an officer sprayed a chemical irritant that forced Klein to move away. Investigators say Klein also incited the mob. Video footage allegedly shows Klein calling on the crowd behind him to send "fresh people" to help break through the police line multiple times. Other videos from that day also place Klein at a scene right outside the Capitol building where a police officer had been dragged into the crowd. As other officers tried to recover their colleague, they urged rioters to move. Klein is allegedly seen and heard responding, "No way." Klein worked on Donald Trump's presidential campaign in 2016 and started working at the State Department shortly after Trump's inauguration in 2017, according to a financial disclosure report. A State Department spokesperson said Klein served as a special assistant in the Bureau of Western Hemisphere Affairs. A former colleague told Politico he was later transferred to the office that handles Freedom of Information Act requests. Klein resigned from the State Department on Jan. 19, 2021. According to a court document arguing in favor of Klein's pre-trial detention, Klein has a military history, though it did not specify which branch or other details.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Klein pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: It was "common knowledge" among Larry Stackhouse's co-workers that he attended the Jan. 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally in Washington, D.C., according to court documents. A tipster told the FBI that he had been reprimanded for putting up pro-Trump signs at work in the past and had called out of work on Jan. 5 and 6. He was later seen in security footage inside the U.S. Capitol during the riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stackhouse pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/17/2022 to 36 months of Probation; 14 days intermittent confinement; 90 days home confinement; $10.00 special assessment; restitution of $500.00

summary: Shane Jenkins began tweeting about election fraud and referring to then-President-elect Joe Biden as a "cheater" shortly after the 2020 presidential election, according to Jenkins' Twitter account, which is referenced in court documents. On Dec. 21, 2020, he wrote "Booked my flight and room for the January 6th rally in DC!!! I’m stoked!!!" and later echoed Trump's promise of a "wild" rally. On Jan. 18, 2021, a person reached out to the FBI saying they had been doing Internet research and had identified Jenkins, who has a tattoo below his right eye, in videos from the Jan. 6 riot. According to the tipster, he is seen in one video smashing a window into the U.S. Capitol with a crowbar. Law enforcement later found a video in which they identified Jenkins smashing a window with a hatchet. It is unclear if the hatchet and crowbar are from two separate incidents. Jenkins is also seen in security footage and police body camera videos throwing several items at police officers, including "a pole, a desk drawer, some type of pipe/metal rod, and a flagpole," court documents indicate.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Theft of Government Property; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Jenkins pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two family friends and a close relative turned Jackson Kostolsky in to the FBI after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to court documents. In an interview with the FBI, Kostolsky admitted being inside the U.S. Capitol but said he entered through an open door and was quickly pushed back out by riot police. This later appeared to be confirmed through security footage obtained by law enforcement, where Jackson is seen inside the Capitol in a distinctive leopard-print vest for about 10 seconds, court documents indicate.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kostolsky pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/11/2022 to 3 years probation; 30 days location monitoring/home detention; $10 special assessment; and $500 restitution

summary: Two family members identified Grayson Sherrill to the FBI as being inside the U.S. Capitol during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021. The FBI also identified Sherrill in security footage from the building and in a photograph taken by photojournalist Saul Loeb in which Sherrill poses inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 in a "Keep America Great" sweatshirt next to a statue of Dwight D. Eisenhower. In the photo, he also appears to be "carrying a long, cylindrical-shaped object, approximately two to three feet long in his left hand," according to court documents.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sherrill pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Seven separate tipsters told the FBI that Eric Gene Barber, a former city councilman, was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. 
A Parkersburg, W.Va., newspaper quoted Barber in an article published a day after the Capitol riot, claiming he looked through the Capitol windows during the chaos but never went inside.
However, the FBI identified a man they believe to be Barber wearing a green, combat-style helmet and military field jacket in photos inside the building. A video shows the man saying “They’re giving us the building” as he and a crowd of people try to enter an unidentified room and then proceed deeper into the building, according to the complaint.
The complaint also alleges that surveillance footage shows Barber taking selfies in the Capitol rotunda before riffling through a pile of equipment C-SPAN’s media crew abandoned in Statuary Hall when they evacuated the building. The complaint alleges that Barber unplugged and stole a portable power station (used to charge an iPad) worth about $52.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; (DC): Theft II
case_updates: Barber pleaded Guilty to two charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; and Theft II (DC charge). Sentenced on 6/14/2022 to 45 days incarceration; 24 months of probation; $552.95 restitution ($52.95 to C-SPAN); $60 special assessment

summary:
Nicholes Lentz is a former police officer and a U.S. Marine Corps veteran who told FBI agents he drove overnight from his home in Florida to show support for former President Donald Trump’s rally on Jan. 6, 2021. Lentz told FBI agents he followed the crowd toward the U.S. Capitol after Trump’s speech, remaining inside the building for about two hours, according to a criminal complaint.
“The people give the power, and we’re here to take it back,” Lentz said in a video posted to his Facebook profile that FBI agents believe he filmed inside the U.S. Capitol Crypt. “We’re not here to hurt any cops of course. I love my boys in blue.”
Lentz told FBI agents he “felt obligated to help control the crowd,” so he said he joined elbow to elbow with a group of firefighters and first responders to help with crowd control at one point. 
In 2017, Lentz was featured on ABC News for saving a mother and her 4-month-old baby from Hurricane Irma’s floodwaters.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building
case_updates: Lentz pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced on 5/10/2022 to 36 months probation; 30 days location monitoring; 100 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary:
Joseph Barnes is a broker with JLL Austin, a commercial real estate company in Texas.
Multiple witnesses who saw a video of the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot from London-based news organization ITV News identified Barnes as a man yelling “This is our house! This is our country!” while gesturing at the floor of the Capitol building, according to a criminal complaint. 
Barnes also appears to be an artist with an affinity for sketching flags, according to a storefront featured on his LinkedIn page that encourages customers to “indulge your patriotism.” The page features artwork of American, Texan and Gadsden (“Don’t Tread on Me”) flags for sale.
“A society that puts equality before freedom will get neither,” Barnes wrote to caption a photo of himself pointing an assault-style rifle at the camera on a Facebook page featuring his artwork, according to the criminal complaint.
charges: Obstruction of Justice/Congress; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Barnes died on June 12, 2021 in a motorcycle crash in Austin, Texas. Accordingly, the government's motion for abatement is granted and the indictment against Mr. Barnes is hereby dismissed.

summary:
A couple of weeks after the insurrection, Isaac Steve Sturgeon got on a flight to Kenya with a return ticket set for April 5, 2021. But a little over a month after he got there, Kenyan authorities ordered him to return to the U.S., where an arrest warrant had been issued for his involvement in the Jan. 6 storming of the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. He was arrested at John F. Kennedy International airport in New York. 

According to body camera footage from police on Jan. 6, Sturgeon and a group of others "picked up a metal police barricade and shoved" it into officers with the Metropolitan Police Department. 

Sturgeon is the owner of a landscaping business in Dillon, Mont., who hoped to join the National Guard, according to local news reports.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Obstructing, or Impeding Passage Through or Within, the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings; Engaging in an Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Sturgeon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 25, 2021, Matthew Mark Wood called the FBI to identify himself in one of the wanted photographs the bureau had released. Wood told the FBI that he was inside the U.S. Capitol building and inside House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, though he said he was pushed toward a window and entered the building only to avoid being trampled, according to court documents. An FBI review of videos from the riot indicate Wood was inside the building for a little more than an hour. On Jan. 6, Wood posted twice on his since-deactivated Facebook account. "Our election was stolen. The system is against us. I stood up to our tyrannical government," he wrote. "We sent those politicians running. We sent a resounding message to Washington."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wood pleaded Guilty to all charges. Sentencing set for 9/23/2022

summary:
Roberto Minuta is the owner of a tattoo shop in New York called Casa di Dolore. Federal prosecutors say that when Minuta refused to comply with public health orders to close his shop during the COVID-19 pandemic, he was named a "lifetime" member of the anti-government extremist group known as the Oath Keepers. The court documents cite an interview with Minuta about his shop by Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the Oath Keepers. 

Multiple media outlets, including The New York Times, reported that Minuta was among a group of Oath Keepers who provided protection for Roger Stone, the former adviser to former President Donald Trump, in the hours leading up to the insurrection. The New York Times' report is now cited in the Justice Department's case against Minuta. Minuta allegedly appeared alongside other members of the militia in Washington, wearing tactical gear, including "ballistic goggles," and may have also carried bear spray. Minuta "aggressively taunted and berated law enforcement officers guarding the Capitol," the government alleges, before eventually breaching the Capitol himself. About a week after the Capitol riot, Minuta deleted his Facebook account.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Minuta pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
The statement of facts from the FBI about what 56-year-old Anthony Alfred Griffith did on Jan. 6 runs 13 pages. It details how Griffith, an Oklahoma electrician, allegedly joined the crowd that stormed the Capitol building alongside his employee, Jerry Ryals. Griffith allegedly told the FBI in an interview that the doors to the U.S. Capitol were open by the time he got there — so he just walked in. 

Surveillance footage taken from inside the Capitol shows Griffith and Ryals both inside the building, and leaving together about an hour later.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Griffith pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Jerry Ryals, an apprentice electrician from Oklahoma, traveled to Washington to attend the Trump rally with his boss, Anthony Alfred Griffith, and a friend, according to court documents. 

One witness provided authorities with a video Ryals allegedly sent in the days after the breach. It was shot from outside the building and, according to court documents, a male voice says, “We definitely have enough people to overthrow this bitch. They don’t stand a f***ing chance. We got the f***ing doors open up there I guess. We’re working our way in slowly but surely.”

Ryals also allegedly posted photographs and videos of himself with the crowd inside, standing by a statue of George Washington wearing a Trump hat and a smile. 

When FBI agents interviewed Ryals at his home less than two weeks later, Ryals allegedly admitted that he, his boss, and another individual attended the rally and marched to the Capitol afterward. He told agents that he was pushed up through the doors and into the hallways inside the Capitol building by the crowd, according to court documents. He also allegedly admitted to going into one of the offices. He allegedly told agents he spent about an hour inside the building.

A day after the storming of the Capitol, Ryals allegedly posted a photograph of himself just outside the Capitol building “Where we go one we go all,” the post began, citing one of the slogans associated with QAnon, a far-right conspiracy group. “We reclaimed our Capitol. … The media labeled us as ‘barbarians,’ yet every person I talked to today was a good hearted Christian, who all said they’ve never really gone to any rally, protest or anything like what we did.”
charges: Civil Disorder
case_updates: Ryals pleaded Guilty to Civil Disorder. Sentencing set for 10/18/2022

summary: According to court documents, Jared Adams posted an Instagram story that showed the inside of the U.S. Capitol building. The story included "close-up video of individuals breaking into the Capitol" and statements like: “We stormed the Capitol building and the senate today! I can tell my grandchildren I was there!” Another video from Adams' story showed people walking toward the Capitol, and someone can be heard saying "the Capitol police better have enough pepper spray," according to court documents. Later, an FBI review of Google location records indicated Adams was inside the Capitol building for nearly 2 hours.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Adams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
A tipster alerted federal authorities to Facebook posts from Ronnie B. Presley, of Bethpage, Tenn. In one of them, allegedly posted on Jan. 6, 2021, a video with audio shows him speaking on a cellphone. “I stand on the top step of the Capitol,” it allegedly begins. “Yeah, I can hear you. Do you see me? I am on the top step of the f----ing Capitol.” 

Another post allegedly shows Presley with a crowd around the scaffolding just outside the Capitol building. He can allegedly be heard yelling, “Stands is where we need to go. Do it!” The FBI says the post was taking place as people were starting to climb the scaffolding.

Another post, a short time later, allegedly captured Presley saying, “I’m the guy who got you into this building. Don’t take my word for it. Watch the video.” Presley then allegedly posted an image to make his point: he is standing with a group of people in front of a Capitol doorway with a broken window. In the image, Presley looks like he’s grabbing the top portion of a U.S. Capitol Police officer’s riot shield.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Presley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder.

summary: The Justice Department's case against Troy Sargent began after the government received tips from multiple members of the public who allegedly told the FBI that they recognized Sargent from photos and videos from the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. One witness allegedly told investigators that Sargent is known for participating in rallies in the Pittsfield, Mass., area, and that he posted on Facebook ahead of the Jan. 6 Trump rally: "I ain't missing this." Federal prosecutors say that Sargent is visible in footage from police body cameras on Jan. 6. At one point, according to court documents, Sargent "appears to throw a punch with his right hand at a police officer, inadvertently strikes another member of the crowd, and then retreats back into the crowd." At another point, "Sargent approaches the front of the crowd of rioters, confronts the line of police officers attempting to hold the crowd back, and physically engages with one of the officers with his right hand while holding what appears to be a cell phone in his left hand."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sargent pleaded Guilty to all six charges.  Sentencing set for 10/3/2022.

summary:
Joshua James is the owner of American Pro Hydro Services, a cleaning company in Arab, Ala., and is a veteran of the U.S. Army. James served as an infantryman from January 2006 to June 2008, an Army spokesperson told NPR, and he deployed to Iraq from March 2007 to June 2007. On Jan. 5 and Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege, James joined with a group of Oath Keepers, the far-right anti-government militia, in providing security for speakers at the Stop the Steal rally in Washington, D.C., and also later stormed the Capitol. The New York Times reported that James was among a group of Oath Keepers who guarded former Trump adviser Roger Stone, and that story is cited in court documents. 

James allegedly communicated with multiple members of the Oath Keepers in the runup to the Jan. 6 insurrection and was seen in photos and videos from that day in and around the Capitol wearing "military-style attire and gear, including apparel emblazoned with a patch related to the Oath Keepers Militia."
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: James pleaded Guilty to two charges: Seditious Conspiracy and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding

summary:
“We took the building. They couldn’t stop us. And now they know we can do it again and we will f***ing do it again,” said Andrew Griswold in a video obtained by the FBI, according to court documents. “Pelosi, Schumer, all you mofos, back off, this is our country, we are willing to do whatever it takes to keep it. Don’t mess with us…We showed 'em today. We took it. They ran. And hid,” he added.

A witness, who told the FBI she grew up with Griswold and saw him frequently, identified Griswold based on multiple images and footage taken outside and inside the Capitol building, including the Senate Chamber.
charges: Civil Disorder
case_updates: Griswold pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 7/13/22 to 75 days incarceration; two years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution; $100 special assessment

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Dale "DJ" Shalvey can be seen in videos from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, including videos he apparently took himself and shared with a witness via cellphone. On the day of the riot, Shalvey was wearing "tactical, Army-green clothing, a helmet, and gear," according to court documents, and filmed himself walking through a Capitol hallway yelling, "f*** yeah!" Shalvey allegedly joined a group of rioters who took and examined documents from senators' desks inside the Senate Chamber. At one point, Shalvey apparently misunderstood a document about Sen. Ted Cruz's plan to object to the certification of the Electoral College votes. “He was going to sell us out all along,” Shalvey said of Cruz, according to a video of the scene cited by federal prosecutors. "Another unidentified co-conspirator then stated, 'No, that’s a good thing. That’s a good thing,' " court documents state, at which point Shalvey seemed to acknowledge his misunderstanding.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting Certain Officers or Employees; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Personal Property Within Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; False Statements; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Shalvey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Kenneth Harrelson, a U.S. Army veteran, is accused in an FBI affidavit of conspiring with several other individuals, all of whom are affiliated with the Oath Keepers and are facing federal charges for allegedly coordinating to storm the Capitol. The FBI says Harrelson can be seen in a video from Jan. 6, 2021, inside the Rotunda of the Capitol with alleged Oath Keepers and others who forcibly entered the building in a military-style "stack" formation. According to court documents, Harrelson can also be seen in photos from later in the day with people affiliated with the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol, including Kelly Meggs, Graydon Young and Laura Steele—all of whom are also facing conspiracy charges. The FBI says it obtained call records indicating that Meggs and Harrelson spoke by phone in December and on Jan. 4, two days before the attack on the Capitol. Investigators also obtained records from GoToMeeting, an online site used for video conference calls. The affidavit says an individual using a mobile device with the same IP address as Harrelson's phone organized a meeting titled "dc planning call" on Jan. 3, 2021. In addition to that, the same user organized some 30 meetings affiliated with the Oath Keepers between Sept. 30, 2020, and Jan. 3, 2021.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Harrelson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Howard Adams was identified by a tipster after he was spotted in a TV news segment running into the Capitol building, according to court documents. Adams’ alleged presence in the Capitol was also confirmed through Capitol Police cameras located inside the building, said the FBI. In the surveillance footage, Adams can be seen walking inside the Capitol Rotunda carrying a flagpole with a U.S. flag attached to it. 

Adams can also be seen confronting officers and pushing through a police line, according to an FBI affidavit. In one instance, a group of police officers try to get the rioters to leave the rotunda. Instead of complying, Adams can apprarently be seen raising his flag and moving toward the officers, until he is directly in front of one. In a statement he gave to the FBI, Adams said he was just “standing there” when he was pepper-sprayed in his eyes, even though video evidence indicates he intentionally moved toward the officers moments before, according to court documents.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Grounds or in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Adams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
In an interview with the FBI, Jeffery Witcher said he was present at the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot with his friend Richard Franklin Barnard III, whom he met while serving in the U.S. Marine Corps. According to the court documents, photos and videos recovered from Witcher’s phone place both men inside the Capitol building that day. In one of the photos, Barnard is wearing a USMC hat.

During an interview with the FBI, Barnard admitted to entering the Capitol building with his friend for approximately 20 minutes. Barnard claimed that when the crowd began to push against the police officers in the building, he and some other individuals shielded the officers with their bodies while the crowd moved past. He said he left the building right after that incident.

Barnard stated he deleted the videos and photos on his phone when his wife informed him that people had died during the riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol
case_updates: Barnard pleaded Guilty to one count of: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The remaining charges were dismissed. Sentenced 2/4/2022 to 12 months of Probation and 1 month of home confinement on electronic monitoring; Special Assessment: $10.00; Restitution $500.00; 60 hours of community service

summary:
According to court documents, Antionne Brodnax, who goes by his rapper name "Bugzie the Don," was identified after he was seen in a CNN livestream on Jan. 6, 2021. According to an FBI affidavit, open source searches also led investigators to the now-deleted social media account @bugziethedon, which apparently showed Brodnax walking around and inside the U.S. Capitol building.

Tipsters also provided several photos of Brodnax posing in front of and inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. In one photo, Brodnax can be seen sitting on a U.S. Capitol Police SWAT truck, and in another he is sitting on the statue of Norman Borlaug in the Capitol’s Statuary Hall.

In an interview with the FBI, he told investigators that he was in the area to shoot a music video. During the shoot, he said he saw a group of protesters storming the Capitol building. Brodnax admitted to following the rioters and entering the Capitol building, but said that he was there peacefully. He added that he spent about 40 minutes in the building walking around and taking pictures and videos of the architecture, according to the affidavit.

Brodnax has been using the photos from the riot to promote his new Bugzie the Don album, which is titled, "The Capital. [sic]"
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brodnax pleaded Guilty to all four charges. Sentencing set for 9/6/2022

summary:
“We don’t win this thing sitting on the sidelines. Excited to stand for truth with my fellow patriots and freedom fighters in DC today. Lessss do this,” read a post on Facebook by Jessica Bustle, according to court documents. Bustle — wearing a tan and white knitted cap, with the slogan “LIONS NOT SHEEP” — is apparently seen on multiple videos walking inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with her husband.

“Pence is a traitor. We stormed the capital. An unarmed peaceful woman down the hall from us was shot in neck by cops. It’s insane here. We’re safe and heading home but have limited service,” she later posted on social media, according to the FBI. Bustle and her husband attended the “Health Freedom Rally” which also took place in D.C. on the same day. According to court documents, Bustle was wearing a sign that read, in part: “VACCINE INJURY is the REAL PANDEMIC.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bustle pleaded Guilty to: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Buildings; the other charges were dismissed. Sentenced to 24 Months of Probation, which includes 60 days of home confinement; and 40 hours of community service; Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution of $500.00

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Joshua Bustle and his wife attended the “Health Freedom Rally” in Washington, according to court documents. The two of them later walked into the U.S. Capitol building, carrying a sign that read: “VACCINE INJURY is the REAL PANDEMIC.”

According to the FBI, Bustle’s wife posted multiple times on Facebook explaining in detail what the couple saw inside the Capitol and expressing their views on the election and the COVID-19 vaccine. She also allegedly called former Vice President Mike Pence “a traitor.” According to local media, Bustle works in real estate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bustle pleaded Guilty to: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Buildings; the other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 8/4/2021 to 24 Months of Probation; 30 days of home confinement; and 40 hours of community service;  Special Assessment of $10.00; and Restitution of $500.00

summary: “We’re going to take this damn place. If you haven’t heard it’s called the insurrection act and we the people are ready,” said Boyd Camper in an interview with CBS News on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Multiple witnesses confirmed to the FBI that Camper went inside the U.S. Capitol building carrying a GoPro camera on a stick. Days later, Camper told FBI agents in an interview that “in my mind, we were going to take the Capitol steps.” He also said he entered the building through a small door that led to the Rotunda and then proceeded to a room “with statues.” According to court documents, Camper told the FBI they couldn't review the footage he took on his camera if they would use the content against him. In a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Camper is identified as having military service. In that memo, a U.S. prosecutor wrote: "While Camper’s military service is laudable, it renders his conduct on January 6 all the more egregious. As a former military member, Camper was well aware that taxpayer status does not bestow upon a person the right to enter restricted government buildings. His voluntary decision to storm a guarded government building is nothing short of shocking in light of his former military service and training."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Camper pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 11/12/2021 to 60 days incarceration; 60 hours community service; special assessment fee of $10; $500 restitution

summary: A little after 2 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, Julian Elie Khater was allegedly seen in a video on the U.S. Capitol grounds. According to court documents, Khater made his way toward another man charged in the attack, George Pierre Tanios, and said, "Give me that bear s***," referring to a "can of chemical spray" that he then pulled out of Tanios' backpack. A few minutes later, Khater walked over to a bike rack barrier and stood directly across from a line of U.S. Capitol Police, which included Officer Brian Sicknick. According to police body camera footage detailed in the court documents, Khater was about five to eight feet away from the officers when he appeared to spray them with the substance. Three officers, including Sicknick, immediately retreated from the line and needed to seek medical attention. Around 9:30 p.m. on Jan. 7, Sicknick died in a nearby hospital. It is not clear whether the chemical spray was the cause of death. In a statement that day, the U.S. Capitol Police said Sicknick was "injured while physically engaging with protesters. He returned to his division office and collapsed." According to local news, Khater was the manager and co-owner of a franchised cafe in State College, Penn., which closed in June.
charges: Conspiracy to Impede or Injure an Officer; Assault on a Federal Officer with a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury: Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Khater pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Dec. 16, 2020, Corrine Montoni posted on Instagram that "January 6th is the day to keep an eye on." Four days after that, she mentioned to another person on Facebook that “Trump called us to dc jan 6th [sic]” Less than three weeks later, Montoni had taken a flight to Washington, D.C., from Tampa, Fla., and was posting videos on her Instagram and Parler accounts from inside the U.S. Capitol with fellow rioters, court documents indicate. That day, she also posted on Facebook: "Today we showed them how done we are. The Capitol building belongs to US, we the people. This is our house. ... We broke a few windows, sure but we were a peaceful protest occupying the people's property." On Parler, she said, "I was there. We were 99% MAGA. I didn’t see one ANTIFA. And I was inside the Capitol.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Aiding and Abetting the Commission of These Offenses Against the United States

summary: According to court documents, Thomas Sibick posted a video to his Instagram account on Jan. 6, 2021, from the inauguration ceremony stage, where he yelled: "Just got tear-gassed, but we’re going, baby, we’re going! We’re pushing forward now!” Later, Sibick is seen on security footage moving to the opening of a tunnel that leads inside the U.S. Capitol building, but then retreating. On Jan. 27, 2021, Sibick was interviewed by FBI agents and told them that he had decided to leave because of the violence he had seen, including rioters beating and trying to get the gun of a Metropolitan Police officer, later identified as Officer Mike Fanone, who was hospitalized for his injuries. On body camera footage, however, Sibick is seen ripping off Fanone's badge and radio. Sibick told agents that he had been trying to pull Fanone to safety and subsequently dropped the badge and radio, but later admitted to pocketing the badge, which he buried in his yard and later dug up to give to the FBI. Sibick maintained he was not involved in the assault and had been trying to help, but a federal judge referred to his behavior as "lawless" and "egregious," according to news reports.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Robbery; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sibick pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
George Pierre Tanios is the manager of Sandwich University, a sandwich shop in Morgantown, W.Va., according to documents he filed when applying for Chapter 7 bankruptcy in May 2020.
A criminal complaint reveals Tanios maintains social media accounts under the names “King of the fat sandwich” and “the sandwich nazi.” 
Tanios wore a sweatshirt bearing the Sandwich University logo to the U.S. Capitol riot, which helped tipsters identify him to the FBI after he “had bragged about going to the insurrection” on Facebook, according to the criminal complaint. 
The complaint alleges surveillance footage shows another man charged in the riots, Julian Khater, reaching into Tanios’ backpack during the Jan. 6 siege, saying, “Give me that bear s***.” Tanios allegedly replies, “Hold on, hold on, not yet, not yet … it’s still early.”
About nine minutes later, bodycam footage apparently shows Khater holding a can aloft, spraying chemical irritant toward police officers. The criminal complaint says three officers were temporarily blinded. One of the officers died at about 9:30 p.m. Jan. 7, but it is not clear whether the chemical spray was the cause of death. Another officer suffered scabbing underneath her eyes for weeks.
One of Tanios’ former business partners was among the FBI’s informants. This person accused Tanios of embezzling $435,000 from their company. Documents from Tanios’ 2020 bankruptcy filing show he owed more than $400,000 in taxes and debts to the IRS and the state of West Virginia, plus over $110,000 in debts to banks, utility companies and a law firm.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Tanios pleaded Guilty to two charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 12/6/2022

summary:
Jeffery Witcher is a U.S. Marine Corps and Army veteran who traveled to Washington “to take part in civil disobedience,” which he told FBI agents he expected to be nonviolent. A criminal complaint states Witcher told the FBI that free speech is being censored nationwide, and he hoped to help facilitate a dialogue.
Witcher stopped by Trump International Hotel for a photo on his way to the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to the criminal complaint.
While inside the Capitol building, the complaint alleges Witcher sent videos to friends, who later forwarded them to the FBI.
“I am in the White House! We crashed this. Our house!” Witcher said in a video the FBI recovered from his phone. He clarified to the FBI he “was so emotional and invested in the moment, he briefly forgot he was in the Capitol building and not the White House.”
The video also includes a heavy thud, which Witcher said was someone throwing a fire extinguisher at police officers. Witcher can be heard shouting, “Don’t do that! No, no! No! These are not our enemies,” according to the criminal complaint.
The complaint said Witcher was hesitant but eventually identified a fellow Marine, Richard Barnard, who accompanied him inside the Capitol building.
On a layover in Atlanta on his way home on Jan. 6, Witcher deleted most of the videos and photos he had taken at the Capitol. The complaint says he “saw what was happening on the news, and felt the videos could be self-incriminating.” However, during Witcher’s interview with the FBI on Jan. 26, 2021, the complaint says agents located files in his iPhone’s folder of deleted pictures.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Witcher pleaded Guilty to one count of: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The remaining charges were dismissed. Sentenced 2/4/2022 to 12 months of Probation; Special Assessment of $25.00; Restitution of 500.00; 60 hours of community service

summary:
An FBI tipster alleges Facebook videos show Christopher Worrell is a member of the Proud Boys who traveled to Washington for the Jan. 6, 2021, riot with his girlfriend, according to a criminal complaint.
Worrell became “extremely agitated” when the FBI visited his home in Naples, Fla., on Jan. 18, 2021, and he denied entering the U.S. Capitol building or committing any crimes.
“The Proud Boys were not a racist white supremacist group like the media tries to portray,” Worrell told FBI agents, according to the complaint.
Worrell’s girlfriend told the FBI they carpooled to Washington with other Proud Boys, and that the large group used radio communication devices to stay in contact as they marched down Constitution Avenue to the Capitol, according to court documents.
The criminal complaint includes multiple photos depicting Worrell sporting Proud Boys logos, including on his tactical vest; flashing the “OK” hand gesture now connected with white supremacy; and unleashing a stream of pepper spray gel off-camera. 
“The likely intended target of Worrell’s pepper spray assault was the line of law enforcement officers present in these photographs,” the criminal complaint alleges.
Worrell’s attorney told CNN his client went to Washington and marched to the Capitol because he was inspired by former President Donald Trump's "invitation" to do so.
In 2009, Worrell was charged with impersonating a police officer after deputies accused him of flashing a gold badge at a young woman to pull her over. Worrell had a loaded handgun, handcuffs, knives, and boxes of ammunition in his car at the time, according to a 2009 news release from the Collier County Sheriff’s Office in Florida. Court records show Worrell pleaded no contest and was sentenced to three years' probation and two years of community control for the incident in May 2010. Community control is a stricter form of probation in Florida that can require an individual to remain under supervision at home or within the community.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon
case_updates: Worrell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Robert Ballesteros posted a video on his Instagram account from inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. The next day, a person who had known him for years turned him in to the FBI, which later recovered a conversation on his Instagram account. In the exchange, Ballesteros is asked whether he stormed the building. He replies: "Put my foot in that door" and "Made my stand."
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ballesteros pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 4/28/2022 to 36 months probation; 40 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: In response to a search warrant, Facebook provided the FBI with information associated with Annie Howell's account that suggests she was among the rioters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. A Facebook group chat allegedly shows Howell refusing to leave the building when a member of the group chat urged her to exit. "No… No… They just killlex [sic] two f****** women… American women… No… I WATCHED THEM DIE… NO F****** WAY.” According to an FBI affidavit, Facebook also turned over information that indicates that on Jan. 26, Howell "was unable to answer a Facebook call from her father because she was conducting a factory reset of her cell phone and was accessing Facebook from a computer." In that Facebook conversation, Howell's father warned her to “Stay off the clouds!" Tipsters also submitted to federal investigators videos they saw on Howell's social media accounts, including one filmed inside a ransacked room of the Capitol with people chanting, "Whose house? Our house," led by a female voice that investigators believe is Howell's.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Howell pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/2/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 days of intermittent incarceration; 60 hours of community service, $500 in restitution; $25 assessment fee

summary: Photos and videos that Mark Rebegila took of himself on Jan. 6, 2021, place him inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot. In an interview with the FBI, Rebegila said he arrived at the Capitol after crowds that had knocked down barriers were already entering the building. He told agents that he asked a police officer if he could go inside and claimed the officer shrugged his shoulders. The FBI is investigating allegations from a tipster who told the bureau that Rebegila sat in a lawmaker's chair and stole a bottle of liquor from an office in the Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rebegila pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/20/2022 to 24 months probation including 30 days home detention; 60 hours community service; $2,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Federal agents identified Andrew Cavanaugh in videos shot inside the U.S. Capitol and posted on the conservative social media platform Parler. One video appears to show Cavanaugh on the first floor of the Capitol in the Small House Rotunda. At one point, according to an FBI affidavit, a man taking the video shouts, “Where are the f****** traitors at? Drag them out by their f****** hair,” seemingly referring to U.S. senators and representatives, and Cavanaugh responds off camera with “Yeah!” While participating in the riot, Cavanaugh wore a hat with the name of his firearm training academy, Tactical Citizen, according to the FBI. Cavanaugh's LinkedIn page states he served on "multiple security details protecting U.S. Presidents Bush and Obama, Secretary of Defense, and Secretary of State." The profile also mentions that he "provided armed internal security to U.S. diplomatic and consular facilities and protected U.S. citizens, government property and classified material and equipment." Cavanaugh served in the U.S. Marines from 2003 to 2011 and was deployed to Afghanistan and Iraq, a Marine Corps spokesperson confirmed.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cavanaugh pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced 8/4/2022 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution

summary: Jeffrey McKellop, a military contractor and retired U.S. Army Special Forces soldier, is accused of attacking several police officers and jabbing one officer in the face with a flagpole during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Federal prosecutors allege McKellop can be seen in multiple videos from that day wearing a gas mask and helmet, fighting with a line of police officers guarding the U.S. Capitol and trying to grab their pepper spray. McKellop was identified by a couple of tipsters, including one who claimed they served with him and recognized the military "kit" he was wearing during the riot. The witness said the kit included a helmet and ballistic vest which resembled what he wore "in an overseas combat zone in 2018," according to the criminal complaint. In one video, a patch that is a symbol of the U.S. Army Special Forces can also be seen on McKellop’s backpack. According to McKellop's memorandum in opposition to pre-trial detention, he served in the Army for more than two decades and spent nine years of that time in the Special Forces. McKellop honorably retired in 2010, with 3 Bronze Stars and a Meritorious Service Award.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: McKellop pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Mark Ponder was allegedly recorded repeatedly striking police with a long pole during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. After officers tackled him to the ground, he was arrested but officers eventually released him back into the crowd. "Eventually, the officers learn that transport will not be arriving for Ponder and that they are needed for continued crowd control," said an FBI agent in charging documents. "At that point, they inform Ponder that he will be released." Federal investigators reviewed police body camera footage from that day and learned that Ponder later returned to the Capitol grounds, ending up on the Inauguration stage almost two hours after he was released. They believe he left after tear gas was deployed on the crowd.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Ponder pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. Sentenced 7/26/2022 to 63 months in prison; 3 years of supervised release; $2,000 restitution; special assessment of $100

summary: Stephanie Miller entered the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot with her husband, court documents indicate. A family member called the FBI after seeing a Facebook Live video that showed the Millers inside the Capitol. Prosecutors also identified the couple on security camera footage from inside the building. On Jan. 7, Stephanie Miller posted on Facebook about the riot: "What an experience it was and feeling to have after!” Miller told her local news in Dayon, Ohio, that she understands that the charges against her are serious but believes the Capitol riot was not.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stephanie Miller pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/15/2021 to 14 days of incarceration to be served sequentially to defendant Brandon Miller's sentence; 60 hours community service; Special assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500.00.

summary: Brandon Miller entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with his wife, court documents indicate. On Jan. 5, Miller posted on Facebook: "How much longer are ‘We the People’ Going to let 535 people Tell 330 MILLION People What to Do??? They Work FOR US!! We Pay Them.” After the riot, a family member called the FBI and reported that they had seen Miller in a Facebook Live video from inside the Capitol. A search warrant of Google GPS records also placed Miller inside the building during the riot for approximately 30 minutes. On Jan. 7, he responded to a Facebook message asking if he had gotten in trouble: "No not yet anyway lol I’m home now."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brandon Miller pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/15/2021 to 20 days of incarceration to be served sequentially to defendant Stephanie Miller's sentence; 60 hours community service; Special assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500.00.

summary: The FBI initially identified Jennifer Heinl through her connection to Kenneth Grayson, who is also charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and whom Heinl can be seen talking with in security camera footage from inside the Capitol rotunda, court documents indicate. Investigators obtained a search warrant for Grayson's Facebook account and found messages between Heinl and Grayson discussing travel plans to Washington, D.C., in the weeks leading up to the riot. In an interview with the FBI, Heinl said she had "fallen out of touch with Grayson." She said she saw him at the pro-Trump rally that day but did not enter the Capitol. Heinl’s husband, Michael Heinl, is a detective with the Shaler Township Police Department near Pittsburgh. Michael Heinl was on duty at the time of the riot and does not support the events, the department's police chief told local news.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Heinl pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/8/2022 to 2 years probation; 14 days of intermittent incarceration; 50 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
Florida state corrections officer Jonathan Carlton initially told the FBI that he had traveled to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, for a pro-Trump rally but never entered the Capitol on Jan. 6. But text messages and GPS coordinates associated with Carlton’s phone, court documents say, suggested otherwise.

“Where are you?” Carlton allegedly texted his friend Bradley Weeks the afternoon of the insurrection. Weeks, who is facing his own charges related to Jan. 6,  allegedly responded that he was on the left side of the Capitol. As the two tried to meet up that day, court documents say, Carlton wrote that he was “inside by the window we breached.” He allegedly complained that his leg was injured and his face was burning. He told the FBI later that he assumed the burning was a result of pepper spray.

Court documents show photographs of Carlton and Weeks together outside the Capitol on Jan. 6 and surveillance inside the building allegedly shows him inside the Capitol as well.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Carlton pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/26/2022 to 36 Months of Probation; 40 hours community service; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500

summary: An FBI criminal complaint alleges that Yvonne St Cyr went into the U.S. Capitol without authorization sometime between 2 p.m. and 4 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021. Part of the evidence against her includes a 38-minute video that St Cyr allegedly shot of herself inside the building, which included the destruction of an office window inside the Capitol, and a recording of her standing in the window shouting to the crowd below. Facebook eventually suspended her account for violating its policy against posting depictions of violence, court documents say. The FBI also said tipsters sent them screenshots of St Cyr’s postings on social media during the siege. They show her inside the building, and the caption on one reads: “Patriots are in our house.” St. Cyr served in the U.S. Marines from 1988 to 2005 and had no deployments, a Marine Corps spokesperson told NPR.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: St Cyr pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say the FBI received multiple tips from the public indicating Aaron Mileur breached the Capitol building Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, one of those tipsters told the FBI that Mileur "posted on Facebook, photographs and video footage of himself inside the United States Capitol Building." The FBI received copies of those photos and videos and included screenshots of them in charging documents regarding Mileur. He was arrested on March 16, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mileur pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Clifford Mackrell can be seen in footage from the exterior of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021,  "pushing back barricades and later repeatedly striking a U.S. Capitol Police Officer and grabbing the officer’s gas mask," according to federal court documents. Just before Mackrell tried to grab the officer's gas mask, prosecutors allege, another member of the crowd sprayed "what appears to be bear-spray towards the officers. As such, the assailant attempted to expose the officer to the spray by grabbing the officer’s gas mask." The government's case against Mackrell also cites Facebook posts and messages. On Jan. 6, he allegedly posted, "it is out [sic] literal job as american’s to kill the tyrannical government. Also f*** all news stations.” Mackrell was arrested on March 17, 2021, in Wellington, Ohio.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mackrell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The case against brothers Kevin and Sean Cordon began with an interview with the Finnish newspaper Ilta-Sanomat, according to federal prosecutors. "It's clear that this election is stolen," Kevin Cordon said in a video interview with the paper's Washington correspondent. The reporter asked Kevin Cordon why he entered the Capitol, and he replied, "It was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to show that the people of this country are not gonna take this corruption laying down," adding, "So we had to actually step foot in their building." According to an FBI affidavit, Sean Cordon is visible in the background of that video interview. Subsequently, FBI investigators obtained video footage and phone and travel records that allegedly demonstrate both men breached the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cordon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/15/2021 to 12 months probation; $25 special assessment; $4,000 fine; $500 restitution; 100 hours community service

summary: The case against brothers Sean and Kevin Cordon began with an interview with the Finnish newspaper Ilta-Sanomat, according to federal prosecutors. "It's clear that this election is stolen," Kevin Cordon said in a video interview with the paper's Washington correspondent. The reporter asked Kevin Cordon why he entered the Capitol, and he replied, "It was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to show that the people of this country are not gonna take this corruption laying down," adding, "So we had to actually step foot in their building." According to an FBI affidavit, Sean Cordon is visible in the background of that video interview. Subsequently, FBI investigators obtained video footage and phone and travel records that allegedly demonstrate both men breached the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cordon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/12/2021 to 2 months probation; $4,000 fine; $10.00 Special Assessment; and $500 restitution

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Salvador Sandoval Jr. stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with his mother, Deborah Sandoval. The case against both Sandovals relies on evidence gathered from their social media accounts, which FBI investigators say they then corroborated with surveillance footage from inside the Capitol. Salvador Sandoval allegedly posted a selfie-style video on Jan. 6 in which he stated, "We're at the state Capitol, or the U.S. Capitol." He added, according to court documents, "got pepper sprayed in the face and mouth...Got out cause I could hear a break, and there's still people inside." Prosecutors allege that Salvador Sandoval Jr. can also be seen in surveillance footage "engaged in assaulting law enforcement officers" by pushing two officers and attempting to take an officer's shield.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sandoval pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Deborah Sandoval stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with her son, Salvador Sandoval Jr. The case against both Sandovals relies on evidence gathered from their social media accounts, which FBI investigators say they then corroborated with surveillance footage from inside the Capitol. Prior to the riot, Deborah Sandoval allegedly messaged a witness that she was headed to Washington, D.C., because "This is history in the making Saving America.” Later, prosecutors say, she messaged that witness a video from inside the Capitol crypt.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sandoval pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A law enforcement filing in federal court alleges that Johnny Harris posted photos of himself from inside the Capitol during the insurrection. Investigators tracked him down after an anonymous tipster flagged photos that Harris had allegedly posted on his Facebook page. In four photos gathered by investigators, including from body camera and security camera footage from inside the Capitol, Harris can be seen holding a flag inside the Capitol rotunda. According to prosecutors, two individuals who traveled with Harris to Washington, D.C., identified Harris as the individual pictured in several photos apparently taken inside the Capitol.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Harris pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Treniss Jewel Evans was reported by multiple members of the public, according to the FBI. One of those individuals said they understood that Evans took "shots of fireball," a type of whiskey, in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office. Using location data obtained from Google, as well as closed-circuit TV footage from inside the Capitol, federal law enforcement concluded that Evans had climbed through a broken window at approximately 3 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021. One video appears to show Evans using a cellphone and megaphone in the Capitol crypt, the FBI said.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Evans III pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 8/16/2022

summary: Dillon Homol was brought to the FBI's attention by two former classmates, who say they observed Homol livestreaming while entering the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. The livestream allegedly showed Homol inside and around the Capitol, and featured him holding a red flag inscribed with "Make America Great Again." According to video obtained by federal investigators, Homol said, "They can't stop us all, come on we are going into the Capitol, can't stop us all." In another clip, Homol allegedly declared, "We're tired of it, the communist cops of Washington, D.C, we're storming the Capitol building. ... This is our country." According to an FBI special agent assigned to the case, Homol claimed he walked to the Capitol at President Trump's urging, and he believed that Trump was leading the crowd there. Homol also claimed the crowd forced him into the Capitol.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Obstruction of Justice/Congress

summary: A video submitted by a witness, and subsequent information obtained after a search warrant was issued to Facebook, show Daniel Herendeen inside the U.S. Capitol in an area known as the crypt, federal investigators allege. These investigators say that Herendeen deleted the video, captioned "front line," from his Facebook page. Before attending the "Stop the Steal" rally in Washington, D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021, Herendeen told an associate that he planned to bring a knife, a canister of what he called "antifa spray" and body armor to the event.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Herendeen pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/1/2022 to 36 months of Probation with 14 days of intermittent confinement and 2 months home detention/location monitoring; a special assessment of $25 and restitution in the amount of $500

summary:
According to court documents, Nicholas Reimler was wearing a Trump flag as a cape when U.S. Capitol surveillance cameras caught him entering the building with other rioters. Surveillance reportedly picked him up again, a short time later, in the crypt area of the Capitol. Reimler also allegedly posted photos of himself on Snapchat and Facebook inside the building.

Two people who said they were longtime friends of Reimler's and were in his same social circle said he had posted several conservative political posts before Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. He retweeted a Dec. 30 tweet from President Trump that read: “JANUARY SIXTH, SEE YOU IN DC!” and told a redacted Twitter follower that he was going to Washington, D.C., with “2 guys from work” and was leaving on “Tuesday evening, coming back Thursday night.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Reimler pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 36 Months of Probation; 60 hours community service; $10.00 Special Assessment; Restitution in the amount of $500.00

summary:
Court documents provide Facebook messages that allegedly lay out Robert Schornak’s preparations for the pro-Trump rally on Jan. 6, 2021. He and a friend allegedly packed body armor, a knife, helmets and gear that included what they called “antifa spray.” The FBI obtained messages allegedly written by Schornak to his friend Daniel Herendeen, who has also been charged with breaking into the U.S. Capitol.

“Cant stay home, I would not be able to live w myself,” Schornak allegedly wrote. “That’s how I feel,” Herendeen allegedly responded back. “I’m supposed to go with [redacted], but it sounds like he might back out. I heard it might be hard to get to DC. I go regardless.” 

Schornak is a manager at a debt services company in Macomb County, Mich., and investigators who searched his social media accounts allegedly found a selfie of Schornak and Herendeen inside the Capitol.
