charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schornak pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/18/2022 to 3 years probation; 28 days intermittent confinement; 60 days home confinement/location monitoring; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary:
Former Marine Zach Rehl is president of the Philadelphia chapter of the far-right group the Proud Boys. He stands accused of guiding 100 followers through Washington, D.C., to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. 

Court documents say Rehl conspired with three of the group’s leaders to incite a riot and storm the Capitol -- making the charges against him among the most serious brought to date. 

“Hopefully the firing squads are for the traitors that are trying to steal the election from the American people,” he allegedly posted on social media in late November shortly after former President Donald Trump lost the election. 

In a six-count indictment -- which includes other members of the Proud Boys in addition to Rehl -- the Justice Department alleges he was part of a cabal within the group that plotted the siege for months. 

Rehl allegedly encouraged members online to show up at the pro-Trump rally, helped with fundraising for the trip, secured paramilitary gear and supplies for the Jan. 6 attack, and programmed radios so the group could communicate during the insurrection. He is also alleged to have been part of the original group that broke through police lines to breach the Capitol and entered that afternoon.

A day after the insurrection, Rehl allegedly posted a message on social media that read: “I’m proud as f*** what we accomplished yesterday, but we need to start planning for a Biden presidency.”
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts)
case_updates: Rehl pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Charles “Yut Yut” Donohoe is president of his local chapter of the Proud Boys in Kernersville, N.C., where he’s employed by a bottle shop and bar called the Brewer’s Kettle, according to court records.
He was arrested March 17, 2021, after an indictment alleges he conspired with other Proud Boys using radios and encrypted messaging applications to storm the U.S. Capitol building. The indictment says Donohoe interfered with police officers’ crowd-control efforts by helping to push people up the steps and into the Capitol. When the Proud Boys’ chairman was arrested two days before the Jan. 6 riot, Donohoe became concerned police would find the Proud Boys’ encrypted communications, the indictment says. The indictment alleges Donohoe created a new channel on the group's encrypted messaging application the evening of Jan. 4, 2021, and instructed others to “Stop everything immediately” and that “this comes from the top.” Later, Donohoe celebrated the events of Jan. 6 by posting a message that “we stormed the capitol unarmed … and then we took it over unarmed,” according to the indictment. In an episode of the “Leatherneck Reconnect” series on YouTube posted in February 2019, Donohoe said: “The only things that I care about are life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness ... Anyone that doesn’t agree with that is a traitor, and they deserve a traitor’s death.” According to court records, Donohoe served in the Marines for four years and then as a military contractor for six years.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts)
case_updates: Donohoe pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers.

summary:
Jordan Stotts told an FBI agent he works in greenhouses and nurseries in the summer but decided to travel in his van over the winter, according to a criminal complaint. 
Stotts said he drove his van alone to Washington, D.C., when he saw President Trump wanted supporters to rally there on Jan. 6, 2021. He parked his van overnight at a state park in Virginia and attended rallies on Jan. 5 and 6 before walking with the crowd to the U.S. Capitol building. He told the FBI he walked around the Capitol for about an hour, filming videos in the rotunda that he posted to Facebook, along with comments such as “For too long has Satan ran this country! They attack our religious freedom, freedom of speech, and our freedom to do as we please! They work for us and have no right telling us what we can and can’t do!”
According to the criminal complaint, Stotts posted on Jan. 8 to Facebook, “They call us terrorists, we are patriots. Each one a George Washington! Most of them are Benedict Arnolds!” Later that same day, Stotts wrote on Facebook he was “a wanted man and will be going off the grid for a while!”
He was arrested March 19 in Bemidji, Minn.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stotts pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/9/2021 to 24 months of Probation; 60 days home detention; 60 hours community service; $10 Special Assessment; and Restitution in the amount of $500.00

summary:
Debra Maimone was identified through a video she posted on the social media site Parler. According to court documents, she can be seen in the video inside the Capitol building alongside other rioters. Court documents also identify the videographer to be Philip C. Vogel, who was charged separately in relation to his involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot.

Closed-circuit television footage captured Maimone walking inside the Capitol building interacting with Vogel, according to an affidavit. In the video, she allegedly can be seen near a group of individuals who are pushing through law enforcement and forcefully opening a door. According to the FBI, Maimone and Vogel can also be seen picking up a bag clearly marked “POLICE,” rummaging through it and stealing silver packages, which contained escape hoods, a form of personal protective equipment designed to protect individuals from chemical agents, biological agents, nuclear or radiological particles and toxic industrial chemicals for a short period of time.

Maimone and Vogel operate the McKees Rocks, Pa.-based Vera General Contracting and Cleaning Services, with Maimone listed as owner and Vogel as company president on the business’ website.
charges: Aiding and Abetting the Theft of Property—$1,000 or Less; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Maimone pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
According to court records, Philip C. Vogel was identified through a video that Debra Maimone, also charged in relation to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack, posted on her Parler account. Although Vogel is not seen in the video, his voice can be heard as he allegedly tells Maimone to keep her mask on so her face can’t be seen.

Closed-circuit television footage captured Vogel walking inside the Capitol building interacting with Maimone, according to an affidavit. In the video, he can allegedly be seen near a group of individuals who are pushing through law enforcement and forcefully opening a door. According to the FBI, Maimone and Vogel can also be seen picking up a bag clearly marked “POLICE,” rummaging through it and stealing silver packages, which contained escape hoods, a form of personal protective equipment designed to protect individuals from chemical agents, biological agents, nuclear or radiological particles and toxic industrial chemicals for a short period of time.

Maimone and Vogel operate the McKees Rocks, Pa.-based Vera General Contracting and Cleaning Services, with Maimone listed as owner and Vogel as company president on the business’ website.
charges: Aiding and Abetting the Theft of Property—$1,000 or Less; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vogel pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Elliot Bishai attends The Citadel, a military college in South Carolina, and was identified by other cadets who reached out to the FBI as witnesses, according to court documents. Bishai is seen entering the U.S. Capitol with a fellow cadet through a broken window, then walking around the building, according to photos and video footage on Jan 6, 2021.  According to local media reports, the parents of the two cadets told reporters “their sons intended no harm and were swept up in the hundreds who stormed inside the Capitol to protest the results of the 2020 presidential election.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bishai pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/29/2022 to 14 days of incarceration; 12 months of Supervised Release; $500 restitution; Special Assessment of $25.

summary: According to court documents, several witnesses came forward identifying Elias Irizarry based on footage taken from inside the Capitol on Jan 6, 2021. Irizarry is a freshman at The Citadel, a military college in South Carolina. Together with a fellow cadet, he is seen entering through a broken window and walking inside the rotunda taking pictures. “Once this matter is resolved, The Citadel will take appropriate actions in accordance with the college’s rules and regulations," according to an official statement from the school. "It would be inappropriate to speculate about any subsequent actions the college would take pending resolution of the charges.” Irizarry is the son of actor Vincent Irizarry, who is known for the soap operas Days of Our Lives, The Young and the Restless and The Bold and the Beautiful.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Irizarry pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI obtained location records from Google that indicated Kevin Blakely was inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, for nearly two hours. Blakely is also seen in videos from that day from both inside and outside the Capitol building, court documents suggest. According to local news reports and the Better Business Bureau, Blakely is the owner of a car repair shop in McKinney, Texas.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Blakely pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/14/22 to 120 days incarceration; 18 months probation; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 100 hours community service

summary: Sara Carpenter is a retired New York City police officer who served there from 1994 to 2004, according to the New York Police Department. Her travel from the New York area to Washington, D.C., was documented by a device meant to bring her convenience: her E-ZPass, which paid the tolls she passed as she made her way south on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Carpenter said she attended the pro-Trump rally, where she heard the then-president tell people to march to the U.S. Capitol. She did march there and told the bureau that she entered the Capitol rotunda, where she is seen on security footage taking a video and shaking a tambourine, according to court documents. Later that evening, her E-ZPass documented her return trip back to New York.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Carpenter pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: Kari Kelley was identified to the FBI as being inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by someone who was inside the building with her, court documents indicate. She is also allegedly seen on security footage that day crawling through an open window to enter the Capitol and later holding her phone up in the crowd that filled the Senate wing, where she appears to be on a FaceTime call or other video chat with another person. According to local news, Kelley is an insurance adjuster in Mobile, Ala.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kelley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/17/2022 to 36 months of probation, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: According to an FBI agent, a week after the storming of the U.S. Capitol, two cooperating witnesses said Ethan Seitz took part in the attack. The agent viewed statements made on Seitz's Facebook account in which he said he entered the Capitol building. The Facebook account also includes statements and a photo believed to be of Seitz in a Washington, D.C., hotel room. More posts included photos and videos of Seitz’s progress into the Capitol as he passed police barricades and made his way into the building. Seitz appears to describe his activities during and after the attack, including "I did storm the f***** capitol and climb in through a window. Got gassed and pepper sprayed. Flash bombs thrown at me. And f***** rubber bullets shot at me." In addition to the Facebook posts, the FBI agent viewed a video posted to YouTube by a former radio host in which it appears Seitz is interviewed later in the evening on Jan. 6, 2021. In the interview, he gives his name, says he was in the group that pushed through a door locked by the "cops" to let rioters through another entrance. He says he was there because of "election integrity" and because he believes former President Donald Trump won the 2020 election. There are multiple security cameras from inside the Capitol that appear to show Seitz inside the Capitol during the attack.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Seitz pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: David Lee Judd was allegedly seen on video as part of a group of rioters who tried to push their way through a tunnel that led to entry to the U.S. Capitol. This tunnel was the site of a violent and prolonged confrontation between rioters and police officers guarding the building. Judd appears in footage several times inside and outside the tunnel wearing a red "Make America Great Again" hat, and he can be seen pushing against the line of officers, while they yell, "ready, heave," according to court documents. Judd was also allegedly with a group who passed stolen riot shields back to other people in the mob, yelling, "shield wall" while pumping his fist. In another piece of tape from surveillance footage, he is seen walking into the tunnel, lighting an object on fire and throwing it at officers -- others in the crowd can be heard saying it's a firecracker. Court papers say that a witness who knows him showed law enforcement an advertisement that Judd posted on social media asking for a ride to the rally, saying, "If anyone has an extra spot for the ride there and a place to stay, I HAVE MY LICENSE TO CARRY A FIREARM....Let's fight to Save this Country and Support the greatest President."
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: At a stipulated bench trial on 8/23/2022, Judd was found Guilty of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. He admitted to a stipulated set of facts.

summary: Federal prosecutors said that a tipster contacted the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives about a week after the Capitol riot, and informed the agency that Michael Orangias stormed the Capitol. According to the tip, Orangias was an employee of KCC International, a company that installs heating and cooling systems in Louisville, Ky., and he took a vacation day, along with another employee, to travel to Washington, D.C. Federal agents then interviewed Orangias, who voluntarily provided videos and photos he took of the Capitol to the government. Court papers state that Orangias "admitted that he stayed in the entryway area of the Capitol building for approximately five to seven minutes before going back outside." The government reviewed surveillance footage from inside the Capitol and confirmed that Orangias was in the building for about five minutes.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Orangias pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 3/17/2022 to 36 months probation; 90 days home detention/location monitoring; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Frank J. Scavo is a former member of the Old Forge, Pa., school board, who unsuccessfully ran for seats in the Pennsylvania Legislature as a Republican. According to federal prosecutors, Scavo stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6. Scavo helped organize charter buses to take Trump supporters from Pennsylvania to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, court papers state. About a week after the riot, the Times Leader newspaper in Pennsylvania published a report based on photos taken inside the Capitol, questioning whether Scavo was among the rioters. At the time, Scavo denied he breached the building. But during a subsequent interview with FBI agents, federal prosecutors contend, Scavo "claimed he was pushed inside the Capitol due to the movement of the large crowd and was unable to resist getting pushed into the building." Federal prosecutors said the FBI reviewed footage Scavo recorded as he breached the Capitol but could not corroborate his claim. At one point, Scavo allegedly recorded himself inside the Capitol saying, "This is top-secret s***. We’re in the Capitol. Stormed the f****** Capitol of the f****** United States at 58 years old. What the f*** is wrong with America?" In another video described by federal prosecutors, Scavo allegedly said, "Your own personal tour of the freaking Capitol. We f****** took it back. Took it back.” According to the Times Leader, Scavo's defense attorney, Ernie Preate Jr., said that his client intends to plead not guilty to all charges and said, "Mr. Scavo is entitled to a fair shake. People shouldn’t jump to any conclusions."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Scavo pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 11/22/2021 to 60 days incarceration; pay a $10 special assessment, $5,000 fine and restitution in the amount of $500

summary: Anthony Robert Williams was initially identified when a witness contacted the FBI and cellular data was used to locate him inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Agents later retrieved Williams’ personal camera, where pictures and videos could be seen of him walking around the building. “Desperate times call for desperate measures,” he says on one video. “We took this f***ing building,” he reportedly says on a different one. According to the FBI, Williams also discussed on tape having “stormed” the building and having “pushed back cops.” "Was the proudest day of my life…felt like the founding fathers were smiling down on us in that room, and I guarantee my dad and gramps, both vets, would be proud,” he wrote on Facebook three days later, according to a complaint. Williams was arrested and released on bond but continued to post conspiracy messages on social media after his release, according to local media.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Jury trial found Williams Guilty on all charges on 6/30/2022.  Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 9/16/2022

summary: Matthew Eugene Loganbill is a federal firearms dealer and owner of the Tooth and Nail Armory, a firearms store in Gravois Mills, Mo., according to court documents. A witness who contacted the FBI described Loganbill as a hothead who had "grown bitter" because of the negative financial impact caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The witness also told agents Loganbill was “extremely immersed in the paramilitary lifestyle” and “viewed himself as a patriot.” In an interview with the FBI, Loganbill said he was accompanied to the U.S. Capitol by protesters who were retired military veterans, but he declined to identify them. He also told agents that he brought a gas mask and helmet with him to the Capitol, because he was afraid antifa "would infiltrate the rally/protest.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Loganbill pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Matthew Leland Klein is a member of the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys and that he stormed the Capitol along with his brother, Jonathanpeter Klein, who is also a Proud Boys member. "Both have demonstrated a preparedness and willingness, if not eagerness, to engage in violence against those with whom they disagree, be it Black Lives Matters supporters or the United States government," prosecutors said in a court filing in the case against both Kleins. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in the fall of 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. At that time, Portland police stopped a truck in which Matthew Klein was riding. Court records state that "officers recovered five paintball guns, five shields, including a black and yellow shield (i.e., consistent with Proud Boys colors) and a blue shield that displayed the words 'F*** BLM,' three baseball bats, and an axe handle in the bed of a truck." Matthew Klein was also allegedly found in possession of a loaded 9 mm handgun. A criminal case related to the gun is pending in Oregon. On Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Klein pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Jonathanpeter Klein is a member of the far-right extremist gang the Proud Boys and that he stormed the Capitol along with his brother, Matthew Leland Klein, who is also a Proud Boys member. "Both have demonstrated a preparedness and willingness, if not eagerness, to engage in violence against those with whom they disagree, be it Black Lives Matters supporters or the United States government," prosecutors said in a court filing in the case against both Kleins. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Klein pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Paul Rae can be seen on multiple images in close proximity and communicating with Joseph Biggs, the self-described organizer of the Proud Boys, according to court documents. Cellular data shows Rae entered the Capitol building only seconds after another well-known Proud Boys member smashed a window. According to the FBI, there are also selfies of him and Biggs. During a court hearing in Tampa, Fla., a prosecutor described Rae as an "associate" to the Proud Boys, according to local media. The prosecutor also said Rae told pretrial services he used cocaine recently. The judge released Rae on a bond and ordered him to receive drug testing and any recommended treatment, a news report said.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rae pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “I wondered when y’all were going to show up. Guess you’ve seen the videos on my Facebook page,” Russell Alford said when FBI agents went to his house to detain him, according to court documents. Alford, who owns an auto body shop in Hokes Bluff, Ala., uploaded multiple videos on social media of himself both at the “Stop the Steal” rally and inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. According to the FBI, Alford entered the building through a broken door.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Alford pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI claims a video posted to YouTube shows Christian Cortez at a doorway to the U.S. Capitol building hurling expletives at police officers and egging them on to fire at him with pepper spray and fire extinguishers as they tried to force the doors closed. "Do it! We’re just standing here!” Cortez demands in the video. “Do it some f***in’ more!” Two weeks after the riot, court documents said Cortez told FBI investigators he drove with a friend from Texas to Virginia on Jan. 4, 2021, to attend the Jan. 6 rally with  former President Donald Trump. Cortez told the FBI he did not see barricades, ropes or officers at the Capitol. He confirmed to FBI agents that he entered an atrium of the Capitol but said he was “trying to help the officers when he got sprayed with something.”
charges: Civil Disorder
case_updates: Cortez pleaded Guilty to Civil Disorder. Sentencing set for 8/31/2022

summary: The FBI claims photos of a well-dressed man standing inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, are Jeffery Finley of Martinsburg, W.Va. The man’s face is obscured by a mask with a skull design, but agents said his blue suit, black dress shirt and red Trump cap match other photos of Finley taken outside the Capitol building that day in which he is also wearing a wired earpiece. Court documents said the FBI obtained AT&T records through a search warrant showing Finley's phone used a cell tower that provides service to the interior of the Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Finley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building.

summary: Nearly three months after the Capitol riot, Richard Harris was arrested in Florida and held without bond. Federal prosecutors said that Harris "was on the leading edge of a group" that breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Harris allegedly told a police officer that there are "a f***ing million of us out there" and that the rioters were "listening to Trump." Harris also allegedly was filmed inside the Capitol making disparaging remarks about House Speaker Nancy Pelosi while asking for her whereabouts and saying about then-Vice President Mike Pence, "We're coming for you too, you f***ing traitor!" According to Oregon Public Broadcasting, Harris is also accused of attacking a journalist in December during a rally in which a small crowd tried to break into the Oregon State Capitol.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Harris pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Jury Trial set for 9/26/2022

summary: Numerous individuals cooperated with the FBI in their investigaton of Caleb Jones. According to a federal filing, the FBI Cincinnati Field Office was first alerted to the prospect that Jones entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by a friend who said they had known him for years. Photographs obtained by the FBI allegedly show that Caleb acknowledged that he had entered the Capitol during the riot. Jones approached the Capitol by climbing an exterior wall, federal law enforcement claims, and was subsequently tear-gassed and escorted out of the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Jones pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/1/2021 to 24 months Probation, the first 2 months under Home Confinement; 100 hours community service; $500 Restitution; and a Special Assessment of $10.

summary:
According to court documents, Benjamin Larocca was identified after a video from his Instagram account was submitted to the FBI tip line. The video allegedly shows Larocca filming a crowd of rioters pushing toward a line of law enforcement officers inside the Capitol as the rioters chant, “Forward!” Later in the video, Larocca appears to flip the camera to himself and chants, “Our house!” in response to other rioters chanting, “Whose house?” 
On Jan. 20, 2021, in a voluntary interview with law enforcement, Larocca admitted to entering the Capitol building with his friend Christian Cortez, who has also been charged. He added that at the time they entered the building, law enforcement was not present at the door, according to court documents. He also provided the FBI with a thumb drive that contained videos and pictures of his trip to Washington, D.C.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Larocca pleaded Guilty to one charge, amended on 8/10/2022: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 8/10/2022 to 60 days of incarceration; 12 months of Supervised Release; Special assessment of $25; fine of $2,000; Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service

summary:
According to court documents, Ezekiel Stecher was identified in a video that was uploaded onto the FBI’s online tip line. In the video, a male, wearing a black jacket with a fur-lined hood and a camouflage baseball hat with “Growmark FS” embroidered on its crown, is observed inside the U.S. Capitol building identifying himself as “Zeke Stecher from New Jersey.” According to the FBI, a farmer based in Sewell, N.J., who previously purchased produce from Stecher also identified him through the video.

Stecher’s presence in the Capitol was also corroborated through surveillance video, according to an FBI affidavit. In the surveillance video, Stecher can allegedly be seen forcefully pushing the crowd forward toward the Metropolitan Police Department's riot line and into the doors of the Capitol building. Later, Stecher, along with the crowd, is observed being sprayed with a chemical irritant by officers.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Stecher pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Eric Von Bernewitz and his brother, Paul Von Bernewitz, were identified by law enforcement after a witness saw their sister post on Facebook that her brother had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and had FaceTimed with her inside the building. The sister didn't specify which brother she was referring to. When the FBI interviewed Eric Von Bernewitz, he admitted to being inside the Capitol that day and that he was there with his brother, according to court documents. Eric Von Bernewitz told the FBI that "he got caught up in the excitement of the crowd, went in the Capitol Building unexpectedly, and left within ten minutes."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Von Bernewitz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/26/2022 to 24 months Probation; 60 days home confinement; $1000 fine; Restitution of $500; and a $10 Special Assessment

summary: In an interview with the FBI, Paul Von Bernewitz said that his brother, Eric Von Bernewitz, had asked him to go to Washington, D.C., with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Paul Von Bernewitz said he agreed so that he could take care of his brother, whose right arm is paralyzed. Paul Von Bernewitz told the FBI that he and his brother attended the pro-Trump rally that day and followed the crowd to the Capitol, where they eventually made it inside the Capitol building for less than 10 minutes. Several photos from inside the building were also recovered from his cellphone, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Von Bernewitz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/26/2022 to 30 days in jail; $500 restitution

summary: Federal prosecutors say that Arthur Jackman is a member of the far-right extremist gang known as the Proud Boys. During the Capitol riot, a childhood friend texted Jackman, and Jackman confirmed that he was inside the Capitol and sent the friend a photo of himself in the building, according to court records. Jackman also allegedly appears in video footage taken by a reporter for the New Yorker magazine and can be seen giving the "OK" sign, the common hand signal that has recently been co-opted by the Proud Boys and other far-right extremists. About two weeks after the riot, according to court records, Jackman gave a voluntary interview to FBI agents in which he admitted that he had been a member of the Proud Boys since 2016, stated that the 2020 election was "stolen" and said he had "no comment," when asked whether he breached the Capitol. Based on a review of video evidence and records obtained from Google, federal prosecutors allege that Jackman entered the Capitol twice on Jan. 6, 2021. Jackman was arrested on March 30, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Jackman pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Daniel Rodriguez was arrested on March 31, 2021, and is facing several charges related to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, including assaulting a federal officer with a dangerous weapon. According to his indictment, Rodriguez is accused of using an "electroshock weapon" on an officer with the Metropolitan Police Department, identified by various news sources to be officer Mike Fanone. Rodriguez is also accused of using a flagpole as a weapon. He is also being charged with destruction and theft of government property for allegedly breaking a window at the Capitol and stealing an "emergency escape hood bag," which is essentially a respirator stored underneath the seats of Congress members and designed to protect them against terrorist attacks. In an interview with the FBI, Rodriguez reportedly said of Jan. 6: "Trump called us. Trump called us to D.C ... I thought he was calling for help ... I thought we were doing the right thing."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds with a Dangerous or Deadly Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon
case_updates: Rodriguez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Feb. 3, 2021, a tipster called the FBI to tell agents that shortly before Jan. 6, Marc Bru had said he planned to travel to Washington, D.C., to "witness history in the making." When the tipster asked Bru what he meant, Bru replied, “You are about to see — it’s going to be big.” According to court documents, several photographs and videos from Jan. 6 show Bru marching with the Proud Boys and flashing the "OK" hand sign, a gesture associated with the far-right hate group. Later, he is allegedly seen grabbing a police barricade in an attempt to wrench it away from officers. Photographs and security camera footage from inside the U.S. Capitol that day, as well as location records obtained from AT&T, also place Bru inside the building that afternoon, court records show.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Bru pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Ryan Suleski, a federal firearms licensed dealer, was found after a text tip from a TikTok user who sent a link to a video on the social media platform that appeared to be a recording of Suleski speaking to the camera about the riot at the U.S. Capitol. After another search, investigators found a longer video in which Suleski says, "Today was fucking nuts. But we got our point across. We showed how weak their defense was. And we showed Congress that America is tired of being f***ing quiet and that we're about that life." Another witness called in a tip to the FBI and identified Suleski as a person of interest in a photograph on the Metropolitan Police Department's website. That witness also said he had heard from a relative of Suleski who alleged that he had stolen mail from the Capitol. According to court documents, when FBI agents went to Suleski's residence, "he admitted to being inside the Capitol on January 6, 2021, but claimed that he left as soon as he was told to do so."  When asked about the allegation of stolen mail, he said he did not take any property from the Capitol. When law enforcement reviewed surveillance footage taken from the Capitol building the day of the riot, the footage captured a person of Suleski's appearance entering the building, heading upstairs, picking up papers outside a known congressman's office and putting the papers inside his backpack.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Theft of Government Property
case_updates:
Suleski pleaded Guilty to two charges:  Entering and Remaining in a Restricted
Building or Grounds and Theft of Government Property. Sentencing is set for 10/14/2022

summary: Grady Douglas Owens is accused of striking a police officer with a skateboard on Jan. 6, 2021, in the mob outside the U.S. Capitol. Owens is allegedly seen on body camera footage worn by another officer, but photographs eventually surfaced on the Twitter account @SeditionHunters that appear to show him more clearly. The FBI used those photos to conduct an image search, which led them to Owens' Instagram account. Flight manifests from United Airlines, given to the FBI through a grand jury subpoena, confirmed that Owens flew from San Antonio on Jan. 5, 2021, to Dulles International Airport outside Washington, D.C. He flew back to San Antonio on Jan. 7, court documents indicate. According to Owens' Instagram account, he is an instrumentalist, producer and sound engineer.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Using and Carrying a Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Using and Carrying a Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Owens pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A person who knows William Rogan Reid called the FBI a few weeks after Jan. 6, 2021, to tell about seeing a video on Reid's Instagram that showed the inside of the U.S. Capitol building and in which Reid's voice could be heard. That Instagram account led federal investigators to what they believe is Reid's Discord account. According to court documents, Reid posted on Discord on March 11, 2021, that "The 6th was our Boston Tea Party." Two days later, he wrote, "I rushed the Capitol," "Hi, Feds," and "I'LL F***IN DO IT AGAIN." A search warrant of AT&T records indicated Reid was in the vicinity of the Capitol, including its interior, on the day of the riot, according to prosecutors.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Corruptly Altering, Destroying, Mutilating, or Concealing a Record, Document, or Other Object
case_updates: At a stipulated bench trial on 8/23/2022, Reid was found Guilty of all charges. He admitted to a stipulated set of facts. Sentencing set for 12/7/2022

summary: Among other charges, Jack Wade Whitton is charged alongside four others with assaulting officers with the Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department on Jan. 6, 2021. According to video footage detailed in court documents, Whitton began striking one officer with a crutch. He then grabbed the officer "by the head and helmet" and "started to drag him down the steps in a prone position" and over the top of another officer who had already been knocked to the ground. Whitton is also seen holding down the officer he dragged into the crowd, who is then "repeatedly struck by other assailants." On Jan. 15, 2021, people on Twitter began using the nickname Scallops, a reference to the pattern of his backpack, to refer to an unidentified man prosecutors now believe to be Whitton. Two days later, a person who went to high school with Whitton called the FBI to identify him. That person also showed law enforcement a text message from Whitton talking about a "bad cop" and saying he had "fed him to the people."
charges: Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Whitton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A relative of William Tryon's turned him in to the FBI after seeing him on CNN during the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate. Tryon is also allegedly seen in photographs from both outside and inside the Capitol that day. In one video from that day, Tryon is interviewed, clutching a laptop and an American flag in one arm and his cellphone in the other. The screen of Tryon's cellphone is visible, and it appears he is actively on a call with someone saved in his contacts as "Bill & Jill Tryon.” In the video, he says, "All we want to do is enter and tell our representatives that we want our country back. We’re not going to take this.” According to court documents and news reports, Tryon is the founder of the Liberty Bell Alliance 76, described on its Facebook page as a group of "Modern day Minutemen and women working together through peaceful channels to protect our children’s beautiful America from ungodly socialist forces that would destroy it from within, and enslave our posterity." Tryon has also been seen at pro-police rallies in the Albany, N.Y., region, according to local public radio station WAMC.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tryon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building. The remaining charges were dismissed. Sentenced 1/14/2022 to 50 days of incarceration followed by 12 months of Supervised Release; special assessment of $25 dollars; $500 Restitution; and $1,000 fine

summary: The day after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, a friend of Michael Lee Hardin's told the FBI that Hardin was inside the Capitol building during the riot and that he had sent text messages that day, including “We stormed the Capitol, I am in here now!" “I know you don’t like Trump, but He is the rightful President!" and “We will return until we win!” Another tipster, photographs and Google location records obtained by law enforcement also allegedly place Hardin inside the Capitol during the riot. Hardin is a former Salt Lake City police officer. He retired in December 2017, the department said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hardin pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/11/2022 to 18 months of Probation; 30 days location monitoring; $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500; 60 hours community service

summary: According to court documents, Jeramiah Caplinger told a Detroit news website in mid-February that he scaled the U.S. Capitol's wall and went inside the building during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Caplinger told the news organization the events of 2020 “fueled outrage” among former President Trump’s supporters and “being told the election was stolen was one poke too many." Videos from social media show Caplinger wearing a red bucket hat labeled Trump 2020 and carrying an American flag attached to a tree branch through the halls of the Capitol, according to court documents. Caplinger also told the Detroit news website he hopes to run for political office some day and said, “My rage towards the establishment, Democrats and RINO Republicans is great. Think of Pompeii when it was destroyed by Mount Vesuvius.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Caplinger pleaded Guilty to one charge: Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds. Sentenced 8/1/2022 to 35 days in jail; 24 months of probation; 60 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Court documents cite publicly available videos from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot that show a man in a gas mask with a red, white and blue, star-spangled jacket emblazoned with the phrase “Make America Great Again." He is shaking his fist, yelling at and shoving police officers as well as unleashing pepper spray directly into officers’ faces, according to an FBI affidavit. Tipsters identified him as Christopher Quaglin, and a search warrant of his social media accounts revealed numerous posts indicating his presence at the Capitol riot, according to the affidavit. A direct message dated Dec. 22, 2020, included a photo of weapons and tactical gear mounted on a wall with the caption: “That’s my basement gun room. I have been planning for this since f**king Bush left office and Obama came in.” The affidavit says that Quaglin rented six hotel rooms in Washington, D.C., and that he had sent Facebook messages to others offering them spare rooms if they joined his trip. Quaglin's Google history revealed multiple searches for “guy gets bear sprayed at capital,” “countries where you can buy citizenship, residency, or passport,” and multiple visits to the FBI’s website seeking information. Quaglin was arrested April 7, 2021, in New Brunswick, N.J.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Robbery and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Quaglin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: The FBI received two tips that directed them to Jeremy Vorous' Facebook page, where court documents indicate he had posted several photos of himself inside the U.S. Capitol. In one, Vorous is wearing a shirt that reads "NOT TODAY LIBERAL" and is standing in front of a bust of Abraham Lincoln. Vorous also allegedly posted messages on Facebook during the riot, including one that read: "Yeah we in dis m*fo" and another that read, "We will take what we want." In an interview with the FBI, Vorous admitted to entering the building but said he did not go in to commit violence. Vorous told the FBI that a police officer took one of the photos of him standing in front of a statue in the building and that the officer was "nice and never said anything to him about not being able to be there or that he was trespassing." Earlier in the day, Vorous is seen on video yelling at police officers behind a barricade, court documents indicate, and calling them "cowards" and "p*****s." When interviewed by the Erie Times-News on Jan. 7, 2021, he joked that he might leave the country: "Peru is nice."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Vorous pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. came to the Jan. 6, 2021, rally wearing a press badge. He runs a YouTube channel called the Political Trance Tribune, and he uploaded a video of the riot from both outside and inside the U.S. Capitol that day, court documents indicate. But unlike the journalists who were there, Morgan can be heard in his videos encouraging the mob to take over the building, saying, "I want my bullet! Give me my bullet! Give me my tear gas," as he reaches an entrance where a police standoff was occurring, according to court documents. In an interview with the FBI, Morgan said he traveled to Washington, D.C., because “something unprecedented” was going to happen. He said he was there as a "chameleon" and law enforcement "auditor" but now regrets yelling what he did, according to court documents. He told the FBI he is a QAnon follower and believes that those in power "use child pedophilia to control the masses."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Morgan pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A person who knew John Clarence Wilkerson IV from a decade earlier but still followed him on social media turned him in to the FBI. That person called the FBI after seeing a photo of Wilkerson at a bar on Jan. 6, 2021, with the caption "today was a good day, we got inside the Capitol," according to court documents. Wilkerson also allegedly said he wouldn't be posting photos or videos from inside the U.S. Capitol “for obvious reasons.” According to court documents, Wilkerson lives on a boat in Maryland.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wilkerson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/16/2021 to 36 months of Probation; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; a fine of $2,500; and 60 hours of community service

summary: During an interview with the FBI, Shawn Bradley Witzemann admitted to being inside the U.S. Capitol building during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. He told agents he travels to demonstrations "to provide live-streaming video coverage" and participates in a nightly podcast called The Armenian Council for Truth in Journalism. He told investigators he was inside the Capitol for about two hours.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Witzemann pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/4/2022

summary: Elizabeth Rose Williams was identified as a participant in the storming of the U.S. Capitol via multiple tipsters who submitted video and photographs to the FBI. She is named in a criminal complaint with her significant other, Bradley Bennett, with whom she is shown in multiple images inside the Capitol, in the Capitol Crypt and in the gallery of the Senate chamber. Bennett appears to be a follower of QAnon, a far-right conspiracy theory that claims pedophiles are running a global child sex-trafficking ring and plotting against former President Donald Trump.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: Bradley Bennett was identified with his significant other, Elizabeth Rose Williams, by multiple tipsters, including one who found him while researching people connected to QAnon, a far-right conspiracy theory. This tipster had routinely been checking Bennett's social media posts and noted that the content was "more combative" than other QAnon posts and that Bennett made many posts encouraging people to gather in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. Other tipsters saw posts from Bennett of himself and Williams inside the U.S. Capitol, in both the Capitol Crypt and the gallery of the Senate chamber. Law enforcement was also tipped off to a post that appeared to be copied from Bennett's Facebook page and reads in part, "There was Ant-ifa instigators. But I saw no severe violence.  And certainly not from the right." Federal prosecutors add that one tipster says Bennett deleted most or all of the posts he made related to the riot within 24 hours of the event.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bennett pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Michael Fitzgerald was part of a crowd who pushed law enforcement officers guarding the doors of the U.S. Capitol and breached the building on the Senate side, according to federal prosecutors. He was seen on video wearing a red hat and a shirt that said "Wild Protest," prosecutors say. (In the days leading up to the riot, then-President Trump tweeted, "Big protest in D.C. on January 6th. Be there, will be wild!") After the insurrection, the FBI sought information about people thought to be involved and asked the public to help identify a photo now alleged to depict Fitzgerald. A tipster contacted the FBI and said he or she "knew Fitzgerald through employment and provided Fitzgerald's address and phone number." Fitzgerald's attorney told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel: "He's cooperated with [the government]. He's not a major player."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fitzgerald pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Stephen Horn admitted to FBI agents that he joined the storming of the U.S. Capitol but told them he "thought it was important to document the event" by filming on his phone, according to court records the government submitted. Horn wore a black helmet, black jacket, black gloves and a backpack, and was seen standing on a monument inside the Capitol, prosecutors say. Horn uploaded a first-person video of the riot to his Facebook page, the records say, "as he entered the Capitol, exited the Capitol, reentered the Capitol, walked upstairs inside the Capitol, and eventually entered the office of Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi." At one point in the video, the government says, Horn raised his voice and said, "USA."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Horn pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say Brady Knowlton breached the U.S. Capitol while wearing a "black tactical vest," a green jacket and an American flag neck gaiter. A tipster, who has known Knowlton "for many years," identified him to the government and spoke to federal agents, according to court records. The government alleges that Knowlton can be seen in surveillance footage inside the Capitol, including inside the Senate chamber, and that cellphone records also indicate he was inside the building. A local Salt Lake City Fox TV affiliate reported that Knowlton is best known as an advocate for "noodling" -- the practice of catching catfish with bare hands. According to Internet Movie Database, he appeared in a 2013 reality TV show called Catfishin' Kings. While Knowlton awaits trial, he was ordered to remove all firearms from his home, the Deseret News reported. "Assistant U.S. attorney Bryan Reeves said agents found five or six guns as well as ammunition and paraphernalia for other firearms during the search of his house," according to the newspaper.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting, Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Knowlton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Anthony Moat contacted the FBI on Feb. 19, 2021, and turned himself in, sending the bureau cellphone videos he filmed inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, according to court documents. The documents don’t provide any further details about Moat’s visit to Washington or his motives for attending the event.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Moat pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Publicly available video shows Robert Palmer on the steps of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, flinging a wooden plank at U.S. Capital Police and then unleashing the contents of a fire extinguisher at them, according to court documents. He then tosses the empty fire extinguisher at police officers at least twice. Wearing a red “Florida for Trump” hat, Palmer takes off his mask and identifies himself by name in one of the publicly available videos, the court documents say. According to his attorney, Palmer served two years in the U.S. Navy. Palmer was arrested on March 17, 2021, in Tampa, Fla.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Palmer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/17/2021 to 63 months in prison, three years of supervised release, special Assessment of $100; and $2,000 in restitution.

summary: A court affidavit says a former grade-school classmate sent photos posted on Ashley Aho’s social media accounts to the FBI taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, showing her and Jeremy Sorvisto, whom she identifies online as her fiancé. Posts included in the affidavit show Sorvisto and Aho in the backseat of a car traveling from Michigan’s Upper Peninsula to Washington, D.C., captioned with the hashtag “#trump2020.” An FBI examination of Facebook records from Karl Dresch, another defendant from a nearby Michigan town, revealed someone using Sorvisto’s Facebook account sent Dresch a video on Jan. 8, 2021, titled “Ashli [Babbitt] ALIVE and WELL,” which contends the shooting that killed the Air Force veteran during the riot was staged. Instant Messenger records from Aho’s account included in the affidavit show the couple were nervous on Jan. 21, 2021, after Dresch’s arrest. "Every time we hear someone outside we freak tf out,” Aho wrote. “Last one straight says fb friend turned him in. … idk man I might get f**ked.” Publicly available court records do not indicate that Aho is facing charges.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sorvisto pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/15/2021 to 30 days in jail; $500 in restitution; Special Assessment of $10.00

summary: “Come get me, You don’t know the story, it’s not what you think,” Victoria White allegedly wrote on a Facebook page a few days after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. The Rochester, Minn., woman was actually arrested by police that day. According to court documents, she was apprehended inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, put in zip-tie handcuffs and driven to a police station for processing. She was reportedly released later that evening without any charge. Afterward, White allegedly continued to post comments and links about the riot on her Facebook page. Among the posts: an interview of a woman who identifies herself as “Victoria” and says she was part of the mob pushing to get into the Capitol. “There’s police there and they’re spraying mace,” the woman in the interview allegedly says. “I’m getting beat in the head with a metal baton by the police, and I’m getting massively sprayed with pepper spray by the police … and the next thing I know I’m in the State [sic] Capitol.” Court documents point to that interview, surveillance photos and videos of White as proof that she was in the Capitol that day and forced her way into a lower terrace tunnel.
charges: Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds
case_updates: White pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster told authorities that North Carolina native James Little was part of the mob storming the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. Little allegedly texted the tipster with a simple message: “We just took over the Capital!” The tipster responded with alarm and wrote that Little shouldn’t be bragging about such things. Little allegedly responded: “We are stopping treason! Stealing elections is treason! We’re not going to take it anymore!” The tipster took a screenshot of the exchange and allegedly sent it to an FBI tip line. In an interview with authorities about a week after the riot, Little allegedly told them he had been caught up in the moment and entered the Capitol. Authorities subpoenaed the phone company and found a cellphone associated with Little and those texts placed him inside the Capitol.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Little pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, and Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/14/2022 to 60 days incarceration; 36 months of Probation;  $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Michael Joseph Rusyn turned himself in to the FBI on April 9, 2021, in Pennsylvania. The details of the allegations against him have not yet been released, but he is charged with four counts related to the Jan. 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol. According to local news reports, Rusyn is from Olyphant, Penn.
charges: Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rusyn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/11/2022 to 24 months of Probation; 60 days location monitoring/home confinement; Special Assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500.00; Fine of $2,000.00

summary: Someone who went to high school with Jonah Elijah Westbury saw video posted on TikTok and Snapchat of Westbury inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and contacted the FBI, court documents indicate. In one of the videos reviewed by law enforcement, Westbury allegedly has the camera turned on himself while inside the Capitol and says, "First time in the Capitol. First time in the Capitol. … I’m proud of every f***ing one of you.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building and Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Westbury pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
A relative of Samuel Montoya told the FBI on Jan. 11, 2021, that Montoya works for the far-right website Infowars and had showed family members video of himself walking through the Capitol building on Jan. 6, according to court documents. He also showed his family footage he took of the shooting of Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt.
The relative pointed to a 44-minute video narrated by “Sam with Infowars.com.” The court documents state Montoya repeatedly identifies himself to others as a “reporter” and “journalist” in the video as he works his way through the crowd, but the Senate press office confirmed that Montoya does not possess congressional press credentials.
At one point, Montoya narrates, “We’re gonna do whatever it takes to MAGA.” A minute later in the video, he adds, “We have had enough! We’re not gonna take your f***ing vaccines!”
In the days following the riot, Montoya was interviewed three times to share his “exclusive” eyewitness account on the Infowars podcast “War Room,” according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Montoya pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Michael Lee Roche, prosecutors say, can be seen during the rioting in videos from inside the Senate chamber, where he stood behind the vice president's desk and shouted and prayed alongside other rioters. That same day, according to court documents, Roche posed for a photo outside the Capitol with Jacob Chansley, who is widely known for his distinctive horned hat and face paint and has been called the "QAnon Shaman." In another video posted to Facebook, Roche allegedly said, "We're here in Washington, D.C. We did get a chance to storm the Capitol." According to court documents, he added, "We managed to convince the cops to let us through. They listened to reason. And when we got into the chamber ... we all started praying and shouting in the name of Jesus Christ and inviting Christ back into our state capitol." Roche was arrested on April 13, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Roche pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Duke Edward Wilson was identified from numerous video recordings, including some posted on YouTube as well as surveillance footage and body camera footage from law enforcement, according to court documents. Several law enforcement officers who had run-ins with Wilson identified him from the footage as the man who can allegedly be seen pushing, punching and striking officers with what prosecutors believe was a long thin PVC pipe, during a confrontation in the tunnel of the lower west terrace at the U.S. Capitol. Wilson can be seen wearing a purple and white basecall cap that said "CNN" along with the words "Fake News" on it.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Guilty to two charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 3/4/2022 to 51 months incarceration to run concurrent; 36 months Supervised Release to run concurrent; a $100 Special Assessment on each of the  counts totaling $200

summary: Albuquerque Cosper Head is one of three men charged in relation to an assault of law enforcement officers during the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Among other charges, federal prosecutors say that, along with Kyle Young and Thomas Sibick, Head assaulted Metropolitan Police Department Officer Michael Fanone. The indictment contains 13 counts, including civil disorder, robbery and engaging in physical violence on a restricted building or grounds. Head was arrested on April 14, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Head pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers. Sentencing set for 9/23/2022

summary: Federal prosecutors accused Kyle Young of assaulting a Metropolitan Police Department officer, as well as attempting to take "by force and violence, and by intimidation" an MPD-issued service weapon. Young was indicted along with two other men, Albuquerque Head and Thomas Sibick, on charges of assaulting a law enforcement officer.
