He was arrested by the FBI's Omaha field office in Nebraska on April 14, 2021. Young was indicted on charges related to their alleged assault of MPD oficer Michael Fanone -- an officer who on the day of the insurrection was knocked down, tased, and recalls hearing the crowd around him chanting, "Kill him with his own gun."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts); Robbery; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Young pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers. Sentencing set for 8/25/2022

summary: Federal law enforcement was first notified about Philip Kramer after an anonymous tip. An FBI special agent followed up and interviewed Kramer, during which Kramer allegedly acknowledged being inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. 2021. He claimed to have been pushed through the door by the crowd. In this conversation, Kramer said he carried a snowboard helmet and a walking cane for the purposes of defending himself. According to the criminal complaint, Kramer added in subsequent conversations that he carried a Master Lock and climbing rope "in case someone was coming at my throat or something." He also allegedly admitted that he took a "do not enter" sign from the Capitol and brought it back to California. He said he disposed of it shortly after. This became the basis for a charge of theft of government property. Kramer seemed eager to cooperate with law enforcement, telling one FBI special agent, "I would like to explain as an average hard-working middle-class American that loves his country... the events that lead [sic] up to me attending in Washington DC January 6th."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building with a Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Kramer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/12/2022 to 30 days incarceration; $2,500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Paul Johnson was reported to the FBI by numerous acquaintances, including one who allegedly received a text message on the day of the insurrection that said, "We got in the Capitol." Open-source video taken outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, shows a man that federal law enforcement identified as Johnson shouting at Capitol Police, including the words, "We pay your bills, you back the f*** off." Video also allegedly shows Johnson pushing and pulling barricades around the Capitol and, with a group of others, knocking over a U.S. Capitol police officer, who hit her head and lost consciousness. In a livestream broadcast after the riot, an individual the FBI identified as Johnson states, "We're fighting cops and s***. I have video where I'm slinging one around." Johnson was arrested on April 13, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury, and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapons, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Johnson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
"Sorry friends and family I guess you all hate me now," wrote Michael Timbrook on Facebook four days after the Capitol riots, according to court documents. "I'm proud of everyone who went in there, even the 30 or so rowdy ones. Go ahead and ban me now, because I have found my voice and am going to tell my story," he added.

According to the FBI, a tipster identified Timbrook on multiple pictures taken inside the Capitol building. Later, FBI agents visited Timbrook in his home, where he confessed to traveling to Washington, D.C,. and stated that he “was ready to take the penalty for what he did on January 6, 2021.” Timbrook was released on bond under supervisory conditions, including a DNA test and a travel ban to D.C., unless it directly relates to his court case.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Timbrook pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/20/2022 to 14 days intermittent incarceration on 7 consecutive weekends; 12 Months Probation; $10.00 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500

summary:
A day after the riots in Washington, D.C., an article titled “Men Who Joined in Violently Storming the U.S. Capitol Describe a Carnival Atmosphere Inside” published on the news site “Insider”. The author of the article, Abigail Higgins, interviewed Thomas Adams, who said he trampled over police barricades, entered the Capitol building and walked as far in as the Senate chamber. He also said he observed rioters smash a window ahead of him and make entry. “It was a really fun time,” he told her. 
According to court documents, agents interviewed Adams the following month at his home, where he told them he did not realize that he had illegally breached the building until he was walking on broken glass. He also told agents that once inside the building, he thought to himself, “What are they going to do if a half a million people are here and standing inside of a building and want to be heard?” Adams has been released on bond.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Adams pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: After a tipster provided a video showing Dovid Schwartzberg apparently exiting the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, two FBI agents interviewed him in March. Schwartzberg allegedly told federal law enforcement that he was the individual in the video and that he was at the Capitol because he wished to "be where the action was." He also told the FBI agents that he had entered the Capitol through a broken window and that he had posted a video to his TikTok account with the caption, "It was intense inside congress today." Schwartzberg also sent numerous videos to the FBI that apparently show him filming inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. He surrendered to an FBI agent on April 20, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schwartzberg pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: The FBI identified Stephen Chase Randolph as the individual assaulting a U.S. Capitol Police officer in a publicly-posted video on Instagram. The FBI claims that Randolph, wearing a gray hat and a black jacket, was one of those who knocked over an officer as the crowd pushed past barricades near the Capitol. That officer, according to a federal filing, hit her head on the stairs behind her and lost consciousness. Randolph then allegedly assaulted two other Capitol Police officers, the filing says. Federal agents used an "open source facial comparison tool" to find a photo he was in on an acquaintance's Instagram account. Through social media searches, the FBI identified Randolph and followed him to work on March 3, 2021, noting that he appeared to be wearing the same gray hat and black jacket shown in the videos of the riot on Jan. 6, 2021. Two undercover agents then spoke to Randolph, who acknowledged being in the crowd at the U.S. Capitol and that "it was f****** fun."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury, and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury, and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Randolph pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew Greene is a member of a local New York state chapter of the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys, according to federal prosecutors. Greene "kept at his residence a Proud Boys pin, and he advertised on at least one of his social media profiles that he was a first-degree Proud Boy," according to an indictment against Greene and two other alleged members of the Proud Boys, Dominic Pezzola and William Pepe. Prosecutors allege that Greene conspired with Pezzola and Pepe in the runup to the attack on the Capitol. On the day of the riot, Greene, Pezzola and Pepe were allegedly near the front of a group of rioters and pushed past barriers erected to keep out the crowds. Later, prosecutors say Greene "celebrated" the events of Jan. 6, 2021 and sent a message to an "associate," in which Greene said, "I'm good, we took the capital [sic]." Greene was arrested on April 21, 2021.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Greene pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding.

summary: An acquaintance of Nicholas Languerand tipped off the FBI in February that he had posted photos to Instagram and Reddit from the U.S. Capitol riot. Court documents include a Reddit post from a user identifying himself as Languerand, along with the QAnon rallying cry “where we go one, we go all.” The court documents allege Languerand threw a number of objects at officers blocking an entrance into the U.S. Capitol. These objects include a large orange traffic barrier, a canister of pepper spray and a sticklike object. Publicly available videos also show Languerand pounding a police shield against the ground, the FBI alleges. Languerand was arrested on April 15, 2021, in Little River, South Carolina. Court documents state the FBI confiscated drugs, tactical gear and weaponry from his home, including an AR-15. It also claimed Languerand has “a history of committing assault, battery and threats of violence” toward others and himself. According to a U.S. Army spokesperson, Languerand served in the Army as an infantryman from 2016 to 2018. He had no combat deployments.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Languerand pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/26/2022 to 44 months incarceration with credit for time served since April 15, 2021; 24 months of supervised release; special assessment of $100; restitution of $2,000; 60 hours of community service

summary:
The FBI has accused Grady Owens of striking a police officer with a skateboard during the U.S. Capitol riot. While the FBI was investigating that case, phone records showed two mobile phones belonging to Owens’ father, Jason, also appeared to use cellphone sites at the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. 
Court documents say a witness identified Jason Owens as a masked man in photos with his son Grady Owens at the Capitol. Videos from the day show Jason Owens shoving and laying hands on at least two police officers, according to court documents. 
While FBI agents conducted a search of Jason Owens’ home in Blanco, Texas, he told them that he and his eldest son, Grady, and other family members had traveled to Washington on Jan. 5, 2021, to "show support for President Donald Trump and the country." 
Jason Owens told FBI agents that they also took Motorola radios to communicate throughout the day. He said he “did not recall having any violent encounters with law enforcement.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Owens pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Several witnesses identified Anthony Alexander Antonio to the FBI after he appeared on one of the bureau's "Seeking Information" posters. On Jan. 6, 2021, Antonio is allegedly seen on police body camera footage shouting at officers outside the U.S. Capitol, yelling: "You want war? We got war. 1776 all over again." Later, Antonio can allegedly be seen on surveillance video holding a riot shield and entering a tunnel that leads into the Capitol. As a police officer with the Metropolitan Police Department was dragged down a flight of stairs by rioters, Antonio is seen on video "squirting water and throwing his water bottle" at the officer, court documents indicate. Afterward, Antonio is heard telling another officer "This isn't against you personally. This is against our country," according to police body camera footage. Later, Antonio is allegedly on video speaking into a bullhorn, saying "This is a peaceful protest now and always has been" and adding that he was trying to "work with" law enforcement. Soon after, he is seen on video climbing through a broken window into the Capitol, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Antonio said he saw "death" in the eyes of the officer who was dragged down the stairs. "I didn't help him when I should of," he told the agents. According to the FBI, Antonio had on a tactical vest that had a patch on it for the Three Percenters, a far-right, anti-government militia group.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Antonio pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Matthew Martin was linked to the riot through cellphone records obtained by the FBI.  He turned himself in on Jan. 20, 2021, and admitted that he had indeed unlawfully entered the U.S. Capitol, after reading President Trump's false claims on Twitter about the election being stolen. Court documents say Martin claimed Capitol guards opened the doors for people to walk into the Capitol rotunda. He provided photos and videos from his cellphone taken at the time of the riot, including one of a police officer standing near the door to the Capitol, near a pane of glass that has been smashed. A colleague of Martin's told the FBI that Martin said he would be taking leave on Jan. 6, 2021. In a Jan. 20, 2021, interview with law enforcement, Martin stated that he realized later that "the protests were worse than he thought," court documents indicate. Martin works for a defense contractor for the federal government and holds a security clearance, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Martin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. He was found Not Guilty of all charges on 4/6/2022 after a misdemeanor bench trial.

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Jalise Middleton, along with her husband, Mark Middleton, traveled from Texas to Washington, D.C., where they assaulted police officers outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, Jalise Middleton is seen on police bodycam footage from that day as she "repeatedly grabs and strikes" an officer with her hand, and grapples with officers "as various flags are jabbed toward the officers’ faces." Police then used a chemical spray on her and her husband, forcing them to retreat, the court documents say. Jalise Middleton allegedly commented on Facebook after the riot, "We fought the cops to get in the Capital and got pepper sprayed and beat but by gosh the patriots got in!" When someone asked her on Facebook why she had fought the police, prosecutors say, Jalise Middleton responded, "[T]o send them b******* a clear message that this won’t be tolerated." The Dallas Morning News reported that Jalise Middleton is an account executive with a home health care company. The Middletons were arrested in Texas on April 21, 2021.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence within the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Middleton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Middleton, along with his wife, Jalise Middleton, traveled from Texas to Washington, D.C., where they assaulted police officers outside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, police officers repeatedly ordered Mark Middleton to “get back,” to which he responded, "f*** you, and pushed against a barricade protecting the Capitol. Middleton then allegedly grabbed a police officer's wrist and pulled him forward and grappled with officers "as various flags are jabbed toward the officers’ faces." Police used a chemical spray on him and his wife, forcing them to retreat, court documents say. Prosecutors say that Mark Middleton then posted on Facebook, "We are on the front lines. We helped push down the barriers. Jalise and I got pepper sprayed, clubbed, and tear gassed. We had to retreat, but more patriots pushed forward, and they’re taking back our house." The Dallas Morning News reported that Mark Middleton had said on LinkedIn that he works in sales for an internet services company. The Middletons were arrested in Texas on April 21, 2021.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence within the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Middleton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal law enforcement identified Jennifer Parks after an unidentified tipster shared a text by Parks' daughter. The text allegedly said that Parks had gone to Washington, D.C., and that "we should all be climbing over those walls. They pushed us too far." Parks was later interviewed voluntarily, according to the FBI, and admitted to entering the U.S. Capitol for 30 minutes to an hour. Parks told federal officials she sang the national anthem on the second floor of the Capitol. A search warrant also revealed that Parks' cellphone was present inside the Capitol on the day of the riot, the FBI's court filing says.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Parks pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/8/2021 to 24 Months Probation; 60 hours community service; Restitution of $500.00; Special Assessment of $10.00.

summary: Willard Peart's attorney voluntarily reached out to the FBI to offer an interview. During the interview, Peart allegedly admitted to traveling to Washington, D.C., from Utah and entering the U.S. Capitol during the insurrection. After reviewing video footage of Jan. 6, 2021, the FBI identified Peart as an individual holding a Trump flag inside the Capitol before Capitol Police escorted him out of the building. An FBI special agent alleged that Peart's conduct was "disorderly and disruptive" because he "chanted loudly inside while parading and demonstrating inside the building."
charges: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Peart pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced on 4/2/2022 to 36 months of Probation; 60 days home detention with electronic monitoring; 240 hours of community service; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500; Fine of $500

summary: “I did storm the Capitol and made it all the way to Statuary Hall,” Robert Chapman wrote to a romantic interest on the dating app Bumble, according to court documents. “We are not a match,” the interest replied. “I suppose not,” Chapman noted. That person reported Chapman to the FBI. FBI agents later identified Chapman, who also goes by the name Robert Erick, on multiple images depicted inside Statuary Hall in the U.S. Capitol building. In a screenshot captured by the FBI, Chapman as Robert Erick wrote: “I’M F***IN INSIDE THE CRAPITOL!!!” Chapman was arrested earlier in New York in 2017, which helped federal officials to identify him, working alongside state police.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chapman pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced on 5/18/2022 to 18 months of probation with 3 months location monitoring; 60 hours community service; Special Assessment $10; Restitution $500; Fine: $742

summary: During the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, officers say they're just doing their jobs, and Jacob Travis Clark screams, “So were the Nazis!” in an exchange depicted on a Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department officer's body-worn camera, according to court documents. “Stand down!” Clark later shouts at them. According to the FBI, those are examples of multiple interactions Clark had with law enforcement officials while walking around the hallways of the U.S. Capitol building. At times he was seen pushing to break through police lines, putting his hands on a different officer or picking up a folder from an office and later dropping it, court documents say. Clark has been released on a $10,000 bond.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Clark pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: An FBI agent identified Kevin Galetto from hours of video obtained from surveillance footage, social media and officers' body-worn cameras. One of the most serious charges against Galetto involves a confrontation with a Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department officer identified in court documents only by the initials "B.S." Galetto allegedly clashed with police officers while attempting to force his way into the U.S. Capitol building through the lower west terrace. The officer's body camera captured video of Galetto in a struggle in which the officer was knocked to the ground, according to court documents. A day later, the officer filed a report saying his helmet was ripped off his head and he was hit twice by an unknown object, suffering a head injury as a result. The court documents indicate that video footage of Galetto yelling, "More people!" is reason to believe he was trying to get more rioters to try to break through the police line. Galetto was also linked to the area of the insurrection by airline records, cellphone data, credit card records and Google data, according to court documents. All show that Galetto traveled to Washington from Los Angeles, stayed at a Washington hotel and was at the Capitol on and around Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Galetto pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Kenneth Kelly was identified from an online tip by an informant claiming to be related to him. The informant provided agents with photos of Kelly and another person going to the riot at the U.S. Capitol and "breaking into the Capitol building via smashing windows." Court documents indicate the informant told the FBI that Kelly held "extreme political views and had mentioned 'QAnon' " in the months leading up to the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. Surveillance footage allegedly shows Kelly taking pictures inside the Capitol, wearing an outfit that matched a photo he had sent to the unidentified informant. Kelly refers to the Capitol as the "White House" in two of the texts, according to the FBI statement of facts. "Inside White house via breaking in windows," Kelly allegedly wrote.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kelly pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/14/2022 to 1 year probation with 60 days home detention/location monitoring; restitution of $500; Special Assessment of $10.00

summary: Court documents allege Reed Christensen initiated the removal of bike racks that were keeping rioters away from the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Despite officers using pepper spray on him, Christensen pushed through the bike racks and struck at least two police officers, according to an FBI statement of facts. Christensen flew from his home near Portland, Ore., to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 5, 2021, and returned Jan. 7, 2021, according to law enforcement databases cited in the court documents. A witness knew he had traveled to “participate in the events of Jan. 6” and contacted the FBI after seeing Christensen’s photo on FBI flyers advertised on a national news network. Christensen served in the U.S. Army from 1983 to 1987; and in the Army Reserve from 1988 to 1995. He had no combat deployments, an Army spokesperson confirmed. Before his service in the Army, he was in the Army National Guard.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Christensen pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI identified Jonathan J. Munafo as one of its 10 most-wanted Capitol riot suspects in March, according to court documents. The FBI claims video shows Munafo, dressed in a black, hooded jacket, as he punched a police officer twice and ripped a riot shield out of his hands in front of a tunnel leading into the building. The documents also accuse Munafo of striking a Capitol window with a flagpole in an effort to break through. Munafo's Twitter profile, identified in court documents as @therightstuff87, shows videos from various Donald Trump rallies and a protest against COVID-19 lockdowns. "President Trump is someone we want to back and show our support in any way possible,” Munafo told a TV station before a Trump rally in February, 2020, in Manchester, N.H., an interview the FBI cites in its statement of facts. Munafo reportedly appeared to be wearing the same jacket as during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Munafo’s Twitter profile also includes a link to an Oklahoma radio station’s write-up on his visit to Tulsa, where Munafo claimed to have camped for three days on a sidewalk in front of an arena to see Trump.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining on Restricted Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence against Property on Restricted Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence against Person on Restricted Grounds; Theft of Government Property; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence on the Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Munafo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Footage from inside the U.S. Capitol shows Jeffrey Register, dressed in a hoodie with the slogan, “God, Guns and Trump,” walking around the building and disregarding law enforcement instructions, according to court documents. FBI agents traveled to Register’s workplace in Florida for an interview. At first, Register denied being in Washington, D.C., but after seeing images of himself inside the Capitol, he admitted to traveling there for the “Stop the Steal” rally and entering the Capitol building, because he said that “he wished he had been able to enter the House chamber during the certification process to show his support for the President.” According to the FBI, Register also admitted he had erased pictures he took on his phone from that day as well as attempted to reset his cellphone, so he couldn't be traced. The FBI obtained his records through a search warrant served on Google LLC associated with a Gmail account linked to his cellphone. Register has been released on a $25,000 bond.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Register pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/24/2022 to 75 days of Incarceration; $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500.00

summary: Landon Kenneth Copeland was first identified by the FBI through a Facebook account named "lostforevermore." Court documents indicate that the account showed photographs of him posing in front of multiple Washington, D.C., landmarks and at the Jan. 6, 2021 pro-Trump rally. Law enforcement used these photos, and the clothes Copeland was wearing, to help place him in videos showing a mob of people attempting to breach a police line near the U.S. Capitol that day. In the videos, Copeland can allegedly be seen pushing another person in the crowd into the police line, grabbing an officer's jacket and using a riot shield to push back on the officers. According to court documents, Copeland is also seen in an Instagram video that day throwing a metal police barricade toward multiple police officers. In an interview with the FBI, Copeland admitted to "fighting with police officers" but said he did not enter the Capitol building. In a detention memorandum filed in federal court, Copeland is described as having been "dishonorably discharged from the United States Army after being convicted, at court martial, of distributing marijuana and related offenses."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Copeland pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Law Enforcement Officers. Sentencing set for 9/9/2022

summary: According to a witness interviewed by the FBI, Logan Grover left his Colorado home early in the morning on Jan. 4, 2021, and came back on Jan. 7, 2021. In that time, Grover posted a photo of the Washington monument to his Facebook page with a long message. In it, he wrote, "I won't sit idle while the nation is stolen in some insane, slow motion, treasonous insurrection." He also said that he "fought for this nation" and that he "can't see another video of families & children being attacked & terrorized by Antifa & BLM thugs." Near the end of the message, he wrote: "I have no interest in violence. Sadly, I recognize that violence is highly likely." According to court documents, various video footage from Jan. 6, 2021, shows Grover inside the U.S. Capitol building. Grover served in the Army Reserve as a general engineer from 2001 until 2011, the Army confirmed. He deployed to Iraq from February 2004 to February 2005, and left the service as a captain.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grover pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 12/2/2022

summary: Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and  "Veterans for Trump." According to a U.S. Army spokesperson, Watson was a Medical Laboratory Specialist in the Army from 2005 to 2010. He had no deployments.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct;; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Watson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 8/26/2022.

summary: The FBI's path to Brian E. Stenz was somewhat like a game of telephone: Stenz allegedly texted a selfie from inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, to someone he knew, who then told someone else, who then told the East Norriton Police Department in Norristown, Pa., who then told the FBI. In a subsequent interview with the FBI, Stenz said he traveled to Washington, D.C., on the morning of Jan. 6 and admitted to having entered the Capitol after he saw others go in. Stenz's attorney told The Philadelphia Inquirer that Stenz regrets going to Washington that day.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stenz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/17/2022  to 36 months of probation, including 14 days intermittent confinement; two months of home detention/location monitoring; $2,500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Four different witnesses turned John Douglas Wright in to the FBI for his alleged involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot after seeing videos and posts on Wright's Facebook page that indicated that he was there that day. The FBI later obtained a search warrant, which gave them access to Wright's Facebook messages. In them, he referred multiple times to a need for "war." Just after midnight on the day the riot would take place, he wrote: "THE FIRST MISTAKE THEY MAKE IN CHAMBERS WE ARE GOING IN AND DRAG THEM OUT." He referred in another message to the events that would unfold later that day as the "First battle." Around 1:30 a.m. ET that morning, another individual messaged Wright that lawmakers would likely try to escape through the Capitol's tunnels and that "People need to find the tunnel exits and get them." To that, Wright replied "DONE ... ALL PLANNED OUT." The next day, Wright was interviewed by the Canton Repository. He told the paper: "It's not about overthrowing the government. It's about creating a new party."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; False Statement to Federal Agent
case_updates: Wright pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Abram Markofski and his friend Brandon Nelson drove from Wisconsin to Washington, D.C., on the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, to attend former President Donald Trump’s rally, according to an FBI affidavit. Markofski allegedly told FBI agents that during the 40 minutes the pair were inside the U.S. Capitol building, a police officer told them, “I can’t make you guys leave. However, for your safety, you should leave.” According to a Wisconsin Army National Guard spokesperson, Markofski enlisted in July 2019, and he is currently a private first class. He was arrested May 3, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry or Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Markofski pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 24 months of Probation; $500 in restitution; a fine in the amount of $1,000.00; a special assessment of $10.00; 50 hours of community service

summary: Brandon Nelson told FBI agents that U.S. Capitol police were guiding people into the building during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a court affidavit. He and his friend Abram Markofski drove from Madison, Wis., to Washington, D.C., to attend former President Donald Trump’s rally. Nelson allegedly told agents they remained in a room with a dome-like ceiling for about 20 minutes before following the crowd into another room. Stills from surveillance footage included in the court affidavit show the pair snapping cellphone photos inside the Capitol. Nelson said they remained in the building for approximately 40 minutes before leaving to drive back to Wisconsin. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Nelson was enlisted in the Air National Guard from 2012 to 2018, and was a reservist from 2018 until 2020.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Violent Entry or Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Nelson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 24 months of Probation; $500 dollars in restitution; a fine in the amount of $2,500.00; a special assessment of $10.00; 50 hours of community service

summary: Gary Edwards did not post on his own social media accounts about being inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but his wife did. Edwards was initially identified from a tip that led the FBI to what appears to be his wife's Facebook page, where she wrote, "Okay ladies let me tell you what happened as my husband was there inside the Capitol Rotunda." She proceeded to describe her husband's activities inside the Capitol, saying that Edwards chatted frequently with the police, who she described as "very calm." Later she defended the motivations of the rioters, saying, "These were people who watched their rights being taken away, their votes stolen from them, their state officials violating the constitutions of their country and people who are not being given the opportunity to be able to have evidence shown." Federal prosecutors allege that photos and videos depict a man who appears to be Edwards inside and outside the Capitol building on the day of the riot. According to court documents, publicly available footage also shows Edwards making his way into the foyer of the Capitol, going deeper inside the building and eventually exiting.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disruption of Official Business; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Edwards pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/20/2021 to 1 year of probation; a $2,500 fine; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution; 200 hours of community service

summary: An anonymous tipster forwarded text messages allegedly sent by Eric D. Clark, saying that “it was ridiculously easy to get in [to the U.S. Capitol] and they did not try to stop us like they should have,” according to an FBI statement of facts. Clark worked for an automotive manufacturer in Louisville, Ky., but never showed up to work again after Jan. 5, 2021. He unsuccessfully requested to be paid out for the remainder of his vacation days and “was very vocal about where he was going,” according to a colleague the FBI interviewed, court documents say. Capitol surveillance footage shows Clark was initially disguised in a Guy Fawkes mask, made famous as a symbol of protest in the film V for Vendetta, but he unmasked himself inside the building, according to the FBI statement of facts.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: Like many charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Glen Mitchell Simon was identified via social media by multiple tipsters, including one who attended school with him. Photos and videos posted on Simon's Facebook account showed him inside the U.S. Capitol, with one video saying, "We weren't invited, we broke in here," according to court documents. One photo shows him on the steps of the Capitol building, embracing a person wearing a rubber mask shaped like a bald eagle. Simon reportedly deleted many of the posts, but FBI agents tracked him down via a search of publicly available databases. When agents called him, Simon asked if they were contacting him about being in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents say. He then admitted that while he was in the picture on the steps of the Capitol, he was not in the building, and he denied taking any photos or video that day, documents say. However, law enforcement was able to identify him by comparing the Facebook photos with surveillance videos that appear to show him walking through the Capitol, the documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Simon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/12/2022 to 8 months incarceration; 12 months of supervised release; $1,000 fine; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary: Robert Lee Petrosh Jr. was identified by a tipster whose grandmother is a friend of Petrosh's mother, according to court documents. Petrosh's mother reportedly told the grandmother that her son went inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the insurrection. The tipster didn't have any images of him, but based on that information, law enforcement tracked down images in surveillance footage that appear to depict Petrosh inside the Capitol. Petrosh, law enforcement was told, had been "lying low" after a number of individuals were charged in the Capitol riot in the weeks after Jan. 6, 2021, court documents say. Furthermore, the court records show that the investigation led to a current FBI Task Force officer, who has known Petrosh for about 15 years.  The officer identified him from screenshots and said that not only had he worked with and attended social gatherings with Petrosh, he had also seen him gardening on occasion. Petrosh was arrested on May 5, 2021. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Petrosh served in the U.S. Marines from 1987 to 1991 and fought in Operation Desert Storm. Petrosh has co-owned a party rental business since the late 1990s, according to the memorandum.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Petrosh pleaded Guilty to one charge: Theft of Government Property. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 3/25/2022 to 10 days in jail; 12 months supervised release; $1,000 fine; $938 restitution; $25 special assessment.  Ordered to return the two microphones he took from the Speaker's lectern

summary: According to court documents, a witness who knows Elijah Yazdani, also known as Loammi Yazdani-Isfehani, told the FBI about his involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot. The witness allegedly received texts in which Yazdani admitted to entering the U.S. Capitol, the FBI said. Yazdani also reportedly sent videos of the interior of the Capitol to the witness. Before Jan. 6, 2021, Yazdani allegedly was vocal in his support of former President Donald Trump and his belief that Trump was “unfairly cheated” out of a second term, according to the witness. Yazdani apparently told the witness he believes the violence on Jan. 6, 2021, was caused by antifa, a conspiracy theory for which there is no evidence. Yazdani was also captured in the Capitol closed-circuit TV surveillance footage, according to an affidavit. The surveillance video places Yazdani inside of Statuary Hall wearing a red “Keep America Great” hat, court documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Yazdani pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: According to court documents, John Maron Nassif was identified by a tipster through photos and videos he posted on Facebook inside and outside the U.S. Capitol building during the Jan. 6, 2021 riot. One video allegedly shows people entering the Capitol building, with Nassif’s voice in the background indicating they are inside. The FBI was provided with copies of Nassif's Facebook posts. In one, days after the riot, he says in a conversation, "You know I was there right?" and later, in another thread advises others to hide their tracks, saying, "Download this and turn off auto updates for your apps on your phones. Encrypted comms should we need them," court documents say. In a photo, he is seen taking a selfie among a crowd of protesters, with part of the caption reading, “I found myself inside the building,” documents show. Nassif was also captured on media footage taken inside the Capitol building during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to an affidavit.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Nassif pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A person that went to college with Anton Lunyk contacted the FBI after recognizing him in the background of a New York Post Twitter image from the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot, court documents say. The photo in which Lunyk allegedly appears is from inside the Capitol building, and it is a screenshot from a video livestreamed by well-known far-right personality Tim Gionet, known as Baked Alaska. Ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, Lunyk also allegedly posted on his Instagram account, "This is going to be an interesting next few weeks . . . who else is going to DC this week?” Law enforcement used license plate reading technology from New York City and Washington, D.C., to capture Lunyk's travel to the Capitol as well as surveillance footage from the Capitol to confirm his presence inside the building, court documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lunyk pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. Sentencing set for 9/1/2022

summary: A few days after the U.S. Capitol riot, a tipster contacted the FBI to say that Gary Wickersham had allegedly texted another person on Jan. 6, 2021, indicating he was inside the Capitol. A few days afterward, law enforcement interviewed Wickersham. In the interview, he admitted that he had taken a bus to Washington, D.C., with other Trump supporters for the rally and that he had entered the building, court documents say. He said that he saw people breaking windows and doors there and that he believes many of the rioters were part of antifa, a conspiracy theory for which there is no evidence. Wickersham said he believed he was allowed to enter the Capitol building because he pays taxes, court documents say. In court documents, Wickersham is identified as a U.S. Army veteran and according to his engagement notice on Feb. 26, 1966, in The Morning Call, a local newspaper in Allentown, Pa., he "served as a paratrooper with the Army in Germany."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wickersham pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 12/21/2021 to 36 months of Probation; 90 days location monitoring/home confinement; a $10 special assessment; $2,000 fine; and $500 in restitution.

summary: Oliver Louis Sarko posted several videos on Jan. 6, 2021, to his Snapchat account, where at least two people who know him saw the videos and turned him in to the FBI, court documents say. The videos are taken from both inside and outside the U.S. Capitol building. In one, Sarko can allegedly be heard saying, "We are storming the Capitol out here," “We’re actually breaking in right now," and "Bring out Pelosi." One video  has the caption, "We're in," and shows a room that appears to be inside the Capitol. Law enforcement also identified Sarko on surveillance video taken from inside the building, court documents say.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sarko pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 4/29/2022 to 30 days incarceration; 36 months probation; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Christopher Warnagiris was identified from photos and screenshots posted to an FBI website by a witness who believed him to be an active-duty Marine officer stationed at the Marine Corps Base Quantico, according to court documents. The court documents depict him as one of the people at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, who struggled against Capitol Police officers at the doors to the East Rotunda; he entered the building from another door and attempted to push the doors open to grant more rioters entrance. He allegedly pushed one Capitol Police officer attempting to secure the doors. At one point, RMG News video obtained by the FBI allegedly shows him using his body to keep a door open and reaching to pull others inside. FBI agents went to his military command, where another witness identified Warnagiris from photos and video, according to court documents. Warnagiris is a major in the Marine Corps, and he has been stationed at the Marine Corps Base Quantico since the summer of 2020.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Warnagiris pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Three witnesses contacted the FBI identifying Michael Gareth Adams being inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. One witness told the agents about seeing pictures on his phone and being told by Adams that “he was one of the first persons that entered the Capitol building.” Footage inside the building shows Adams walking around and recording on his cellphone while carrying a large flag and a longboard with orange wheels, court documents show. Adams was arrested in the Eastern District of Virginia and placed on bond, awaiting trial.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Adams failed to appear at two hearings in July, 2021. Oral request by the Government that a bench warrant be issued. On 6/7/2022 the Adams case is directly reassigned to the Calendar Committee as defendant is a fugitive.

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Eric Bochene told an individual, who later spoke to the FBI, that he had broken a window and was one of the first persons inside the U.S. Capitol building, according to court documents. Multiple images inside the Capitol show Bochene standing near QAnon conspiracy follower Jacob Chansley, who wore a horned headdress, court documents indicate. The FBI interviewed Bochene, who confirmed he was inside and showed agents pictures and videos he took himself. “It was all a false flag. Insurrection act signed last night. Leftist trash are being executed right now,” he reportedly wrote to an acquaintance, who asked if he was inside the Capitol after Bochene sent a screenshot that appeared to be of him. Bochene, who also goes by the name Eric Festo, was arrested and placed on bond.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bochene pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement identified Brittiany Angelina Dillon through text messages she allegedly sent to Bryan Betancur, another person charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. In the text messages, which were sent on the day of the insurrection, Dillon claims that she was pepper-sprayed while approaching the U.S. Capitol and that she witnessed someone being shot by Washington, D.C., police. The FBI later identified Dillon in multiple videos from inside and outside the Capitol building, court documents indicate.
charges: Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building and Grounds
case_updates: Dillon pleaded Guilty to: Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building and Grounds. Sentenced 11/4/2021 to 3 years of probation with 2 months of home detention; $500 in restitution and a $10 special assessment; must seek and maintain at least part-time employment

summary: At least three people called the FBI saying that someone they knew on Facebook had posted about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. This individual, who is not named in court documents, tagged Jon Thomas "JT" Mott in those Facebook posts, including one that read: "We did it. JT and I got separated for about 20 minutes. ... I'm now trying to get us the hell out of here. Good work patriots. Protecting pedophiles and denying people freedom don't fly here. The silent majority has spoken." A few days before the riot, Mott's wife, Hope Anderson-Mott, posted a link to a GoFundMe page on Facebook titled "Protesting corruption in DC on Jan 6th," according to court documents. In it, Mott's unnamed travel companion was soliciting funds to go to Washington, D.C., and he mentioned he was traveling with a "fellow patriot," court documents indicate. Law enforcement also allegedly identified Mott in police body camera footage from inside the Capitol, where Mott reportedly can be heard saying to an officer, "[I]f you don't touch me, I won't touch you." According to court documents, Mott is an employee at the Bean Barn Coffee Shop in Flippin, Ark.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mott pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Videos that show Hunter Palm inside the U.S. Capitol came from a flash drive that he shared with federal agents after they tracked him down via a tip from a family member, according to court documents. The tipster said that Palm called from Washington, D.C., and said that police allowed him to enter the building on Jan. 6, 2021, and that once inside he wandered around, looked at statues and eventually sat down to rest in a conference room before climbing out a window, documents say. When the FBI interviewed Palm, he said he was pushed through a door, and admitted that he had entered the Capitol building on Jan. 6. He told agents he removed all the photos and videos related to the riot from his phone and put them on a flash drive, which he provided to law enforcement. The videos on the drive show Palm and others walking toward and through a Capitol entrance, shouting "Stop the Steal," which matches surveillance footage. There is no evidence of anyone pushing him, according to court documents. Later videos taken by Palm, along with more surveillance footage, show him in the Crypt of the Capitol, pushing deeper into the building and walking through a hallway while voices shout threats apparently to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi outside a door marked Office of the Speaker. Rioters then open the door, according to court documents, and Palm enters the speaker's conference room and can be heard asking, "You guys want a tour?" He walks around the conference room, filming a laptop on the table and asks, "Who's good at hacking?" Court documents show that finally, he sits at the head of a long table, puts his feet up and is heard saying, "I think I like my new dining room. I pay for it." More open-source video captured Palm with his feet up at the conference table. Palm was arrested May 12, 2021, in Colorado.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Palm pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The man who federal agents believe to be Joseph Zlab appears easy to spot in news footage of the U.S. Capitol breach. According to court documents, he was dressed in a red hat and jacket, and carried what looks like a reproduction of the Gadsden flag, large and yellow, reading, "Don't Tread on Me." An anonymous tipster to the FBI indicated being informed of Zlab's presence in the Capitol by the tipster's parent. The tipster confirmed it was Zlab when shown a photograph from that day, the documents say. When contacted by an FBI agent, Zlab said he had gone to then-President Donald Trump's speech on Jan. 6, 2021, marched to the Capitol and walked around the outside of the building taking pictures, according to court documents. He did not answer when asked if he entered. But a search warrant executed on Zlab's Google account showed a number of photos organized by date: Under a folder marked "January 6, 2021," there were several photos, including a full shot that appears to be the fresco on the ceiling of the Capitol Rotunda, and a picture of the door to the House Appropriations Room. Video footage appears to indicate that after Zlab took that photo, he entered the room, documents say. Agents conducted surveillance of Zlab and compared a photo taken of him in April with shots from inside the Capitol. According to The Seattle Times, Zlab runs a construction firm called JMZ Contractors in Everett, Wash. According to a sentencing memorandum that Zlab filed in federal court, Zlab served in the U.S. Navy Reserves.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Zlab pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. THe other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/1/2022 to 36 months probation; 200 hours community service; $5,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Daniel Warmus was identified by a tipster who overheard him in a dentist's office talking about his experiences at the U.S. Capitol.  The tipster heard him say he smoked a joint inside the U.S. Capitol and that a police officer told him to leave, but he refused.  Warmus also played a video at the dentist that he had taken while he was inside the Capitol. The tipster said they heard it but didn't see it.  Federal agents tracked down DMV and passport photos and compared them to footage given to them by a film crew in which Warmus says he runs an auto shop in Orchard Park, N.Y. In the video he's wearing a sweatshirt that reads "CNN is fake news," a hat that says Trump 2020 on it, and he holds a tree branch with a large flag on it that says: "F*** ANTIFA" in white letters. Security footage from inside the Capitol shows a person who looks like Warmus entering the building, going up the stairs to the second floor, taking photos and video, and briefly struggling with a police officer.  Comparisons to Warmus' driver's license and passport photos convinced the FBI that the footage is of Warmus, and a search warrant served on Verizon, Warmus' cell service provider, shows that his telephone was near a site that provides coverage to an area that includes the inside of the Capitol. Warmus owns the Worm-A-Fix Automotive shop and was arrested on May 18, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Warmus pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/12/2022.

summary: Federal law enforcement alleges that Daniel Ray Caldwell is the man shown in a YouTube video spraying some sort of unidentified mist at police officers near the Capitol steps. A court filing states that Caldwell was wearing an olive hoodie, dark glasses and a camouflage backpack at the time. In a second video posted online, Caldwell is alleged to have described his involvement in storming the Capitol, telling two off-screen females that he sprayed about 15 officers. Records subsequently showed that a phone device belonging to Caldwell was located inside the Capitol around the time of the riots on Jan. 6, 2021. A witness who claimed to know Caldwell was later intervewed by law enforcement and said that Caldwell was "a huge white supremacist" and a "complete wacko." In legal filings, Caldwell is identified as having served in the U.S. Marines.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Caldwell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement said they tracked down Micajah Jackson through Instagram accounts that show photos and videos of people inside the U.S. Capitol. Photos on the accounts show an individual who matches with Jackson's driver's license, federal officials say. Images on Facebook allegedly show Jackson wearing an orange armband, which he told law enforcement was given to him by Proud Boys from Arizona. The FBI claims that the Proud Boys from Arizona, which Jackson congregated with on Jan. 6, 2021, seemed to have chosen the color orange to show they were associated with one another. By matching CCTV from the Capitol to when Jackson allegedly posted content to his social media, they were able to identify him as being in the Capitol, and in particular in National Statuary Hall. During a March 24, 2021, interview with FBI agents, Jackson allegedly said he entered the Capitol without authorization and acknowledged that he was the individual whom law enforcement had identified on CCTV footage. He also claimed that while he was with the Proud Boys on Jan. 6, 2021, he had traveled to the nation's capital by himself and had only wanted to find other people from Arizona. Jackson served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 2015 to 2017 and reached the rank of Lance Corporal, a spokesperson from the Marines confirmed to NPR. Jackson did not deploy as part of his military service, according to the spokesperson.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Jackson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/24/2022 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days in a residential re-entry center; $1,000 fine, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: According to court documents, law enforcement received an online tip with a photo of Kerry Wayne Persick participating in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot. In the photo, Persick reportedly was wearing a dark-colored jacket, a backpack and a red baseball cap with a “Make America Great Again" logo. The FBI said it later identified Persick on videos taken inside the U.S. Capitol building by using this photo. The tipster, who has known Persick for almost 20 years, also allegedly identified him in videos the FBI obtained. In addition, the FBI investigation revealed that Persick’s phone was identified as having used a cell site tower consistent with providing service to a geographic area that included the Capitol building's interior, according to an affidavit.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Persick pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced 7/14/2022 to 36 months Probation with 90 days home detention/location monitoring; $10 special assessment; $5,000 fine; restitution of $500

summary: According to court documents, Bruce J. Harrison was captured on U.S. Capitol surveillance videos entering and exiting the building with his friend Douglas K. Wangler, who was also charged as a part of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. In the videos, Harrison reportedly is wearing a white baseball-style hat and distinctive jacket with red and white stripes on the sleeves. In an interview with the FBI, Harrison told agents he attended a rally for then-President Donald Trump with Wangler. Following the rally, he said he walked over to the Capitol building with his friend and a crowd. Harrison told the FBI that as they approached the Capitol building, he heard loud bangs that sounded to him like a Civil War re-enactment and saw a violent crowd trying to get to the scaffolding and pushing against bicycle barricades. He said they watched the crowd by the scaffolding for a short time, then decided to go around to the other side of the Capitol building to get away from the violence. He added that on the other side of the building they saw open doors leading into the building, where people were freely going in, including what appeared to be family groups. He allegedly admitted to entering through these doors and wandering inside the building. Harrison said he and Wangler tried to find bathrooms but couldn't get to them. He said he was inside the Capitol building for about 10 to 15 minutes. Harrison added they felt it was time to leave because they “got caught up in the moment” and realized they should probably not be inside, according to the FBI.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Harrison pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/16/2021 to 2 years of probation; 60 hours community service; $500 restitution; and $10 special assessment.

summary: According to court documents, Douglas K. Wangler was identified as a participant in the Jan. 6 riot by a tipster. In a video the tipster submitted, Wangler can be seen inside the U.S. Capitol building chanting “USA,” according to the FBI. The same video reportedly shows him wearing bluejeans, dark gloves, a dark jacket and a dark beanie with a short bill. Wangler was also allegedly captured on Capitol surveillance cameras. In the closed-circuit TV footage he is allegedly seen walking inside the building with his friend Bruce J. Harrison, who was also charged as a part of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. The FBI investigation also revealed that Wangler’s phone was identified as having used a cell site tower consistent with providing service to a geographic area that included the Capitol building's interior during the riot, according to an affidavit. In an interview with the FBI, Wangler said he attended a rally for then-President Donald Trump with Harrison. Following the rally, he said he walked over to the Capitol building with his friend and a crowd. At the Capitol building, he saw people climbing up the scaffolding waving flags and chanting “USA” Wangler described the crowd by the scaffolding as a “big crazy mob” because they were throwing objects at police and spraying officers with what he assumed to be Mace, according to the affidavit. He said they watched the crowd by the scaffolding for a short time, then decided to go around to the other side of the Capitol building to get away from the violence. He added that on the other side of the building they saw some wide-open doors leading into the building, where people were freely going in, including what appeared to be family groups. He allegedly admitted to entering through these doors and wandering inside the building. He said he was inside the Capitol building for about 10 to 15 minutes, according to the FBI.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wangler pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 12/16/2021 to 2 years of probation; 60 hours community service; $500 restitution; and $10 special assessment.

summary: For weeks Daniel Paul Gray seemed ready for a confrontation over the election, according to court documents. “The only day that matters is the 20th. On the 6th a f***ing s*** ton of us are going to Washington to shut the entire city down. It's gonna be insane I literally can't wait,” he wrote on social media, according to the documents. In a private message to a friend, he reportedly said: “Are you gonna be in DC on the 6th like Trump asked us to be?” According to court documents, Gray entered the U.S. Capitol building and engaged in altercations with law enforcement, pushing officers both inside and outside the building and visibly injuring one of them. According to the FBI, Gray, who posted a lengthy Instagram video describing his actions on Jan. 6, 2021, also said he was in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office as well as possibly in close proximity to Ashli Babbitt, the woman who was fatally shot inside the Capitol. In December of 2020, Gray allegedly posted on social media he had joined a militia, but court documents don’t specify which one. In the video posted to Instagram, Gray also reportedly said: “This is far from over, that was the coolest thing I’ve ever done in my entire life and stay tuned.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gray pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Traci Sunstrom was initially identified from an anonymous tip saying she had appeared on a Facebook livestream video on the day of the riot inside the U.S. Capitol building. After obtaining a search warrant from Google to look at the account associated with her email address, federal agents found that a mobile device associated with that account had displayed a location radius within the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, around 2 p.m. According to court documents, the FBI compared the picture from Sunstrom's driver's license with surveillance footage at and around the Capitol and alleged that she appears in several images. Sunstrom is allegedly seen inside the building, dressed in a green jacket and pants with a large-scale Stars and Stripes pattern on them. She was arrested on May 19, 2021.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sunstrum pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 2/24/2022 to 3 years of probation; 30 days home detention/location monitoring;  $10 special assessment;  $500 in restitution.

summary: Six different witnesses alerted the FBI that Pauline Bauer had potentially been involved in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, court documents said. According to the FBI, one witness led the bureau to comments on Facebook from Bauer's profile that said, among other things, "I am at the capital and was inside. No [sic] of us are armed just pissed that this is what we have to do to take back our country from communism." Another post referenced a common conspiracy theory among QAnon believers, saying, "You can thank me after you start researching that these Democrats not only cheated and stole this election from the people but they have been trafficking children for years." But there is no suggestion in the charging documents that she follows the group.
