Another witness told the FBI about observing that Bauer's political rhetoric had become so constant she was losing business from a restaurant she owns. Bauer allegedly entered the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with another man, William Blauser, and surveillance footage shows them in multiple places inside the building, including in the Rotunda, where both appear to have a brief struggle with law enforcement. Body camera video from law enforcement recorded Bauer telling officers, "Bring them out. ... We want them out here. ... Bring Nancy Pelosi out here now. We want to hang that f**king b***h." Bauer was arrested on May 19, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bauer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: When William Blauser Jr. of Ludlow, Pa. allegedly entered the U.S. Capitol through the east Rotunda door of the Capitol, he was walking backward. Three police officers were trying to stop the rowdy crowd from entering, and surveillance video allegedly shows Blauser walking backward to push his way through. He got in, according to court documents. In its statement of facts, the Justice Department said that Blauser came into the Capitol about 20 minutes after members of Congress had been evacuated from their chambers. At one point, Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department officers “attempted to deny individuals access to the hallway entrance that resulted in a brief confrontation with Blauser and some other protesters.” That is allegedly caught on surveillance footage as well. Prosecutors said Blauser entered the Capitol with his friend Pauline Bauer. Body camera footage reportedly recorded her saying, among other things, “Bring Nancy Pelosi out here now. We want to hang that f***ing b***h. Bring her out. We’re coming in if you don’t bring her out. … Why are you trying to protect a f***ing Nazi. Is that what you’re protecting?” Court papers said that police forced Blauser and Bauer out of the Rotunda area a short time later. The two were in the Capitol, the statement of facts said, for about an hour. According to the government's sentencing memorandum, "From September 1965 to June 1969, Blauser was enlisted with the United States Navy. His highest rank and rank at separation was E-4. He received several ribbons and medals, most notably a Purple Heart and Navy Commendation medal with Combat Valor."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Blauser pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/3/2022 to $10.00 Special Assessment; a $500.00 Fine; restitution in the amount of $500.00

summary: The tipster who told the FBI that John “Jack” Juran was inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, was reportedly apologetic. “A person I know who is on Facebook was there. Admits to being on the scaffolding,” the tipster wrote, according to court documents. “Not sure if this is trespassing or not. Do not believe he was involved in violence but anyone there especially on the scaffolding seems to be breaking the law. If not my apologizes [sic].” Authorities got a search warrant, and Google provided location information associated with an email account and a mobile device allegedly belonging to Juran. It put Juran’s mobile device inside the Capitol (within 10 meters of accuracy) on Jan. 6, 2021. Officials said they compared Juran’s New York driver’s license photo with surveillance footage from the Capitol, and he was easy to pick out. He had a mustache and was wearing a white cowboy hat that read, “Trump 2020,” according to court documents. The underside of the hat’s brim had Stars and Stripes.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Juran pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/23/2022 to 3 years of Probation; 60 days home detention/location monitoring; Special Assessment of $10; Fine of $500; Restitution of $500

summary: In an interview with the FBI, William Michael Sywak said he and his son traveled to Washington, D.C., together to "see the protests" on Jan. 6, 2021, but he denied going inside the U.S. Capitol building. However, law enforcement later placed Sywak inside the Capitol that day through surveillance footage, a YouTube video and Google location records, court documents indicate. During the interview, FBI agents showed Sywak a photo of himself on the U.S. Capitol grounds and he confirmed to the agents that it was him, saying he was surprised his hair looked so neat, since he had been wearing a beanie.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sywak pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/9/2022 to 24 months probation; 4 months of home confinement/location monitoring; $500 restitution; $10 assessment; 60 hours community service

summary: William Jason Sywak traveled to Washington, D.C., from New York to "see the protests" on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI interview with his father, who traveled with him. Law enforcement also identified the younger Sywak in surveillance footage and police body camera footage from inside and outside the U.S. Capitol that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sywak pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/9/2022 to 12 months probation; 2 months home confinement; 60 hours community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
"We weren't burning down the city. We wanted access to the Capital [sic] to watch the vote and have our voices heard. They put barricades up. It's our house not theirs,” wrote James Breheny on Facebook on Jan 6, 2021. Breheny, a member of the Oath Keepers, served as the coordinator of the Bergen County, N.J., chapter of the organization, according to court documents. On Jan. 3, 2021, Breheny is believed to have held a leadership meeting for the Oath Keepers of the Mid-Atlantic region in Quarryville, Pa., to prepare for the rally on Jan. 6, 2021, according to the FBI. 

“This will be the day we get our comms on point with multiple other patriot groups, share rally points etc. This one is important and I believe this is our last chance to organize before the show. This meeting will be for leaders only,” he wrote to the group.  

On Jan. 14, 2021, Breheny was interviewed by law enforcement about his involvement on Jan. 6, 2021, but further investigation revealed that he lied to the FBI on multiple occasions about his actions that day. Breheny stated to the officers that he was unwillingly pushed inside the building by the large group and did not engage in violence. Footage, however, shows Breheny in close proximity to ongoing violence involving assault on police officers with flagpoles and irritants, as well as communication between him and other members of the Oath Keepers on the platform Signal that read, “We breached the door Baby” and “Made it in Brother.” 
In addition, Breheny indicated on the same chat that he is deleting all his social media posts in order to avoid being caught. Breheny goes by the alias “Seamus Evers.”
charges: Knowingly Enter or Remain in any Restricted Building or Grounds without Lawful Authority to do; Knowingly, and with Intent to Impede or Disrupt the Orderly Conduct of Government Business or Official Functions; Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Utter Loud, Threatening, or Abusive Language, or Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct, at any place in the Grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings with the Intent to Impede, Disrupt, or Disturb the Orderly Conduct of a Session of Congress or either House of Congress; Parade or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings; Corruptly Alter, Destroy, Mutilate, and Conceal a Record, Document, and other Object, and Attempted to do so, with the Intent to Impair its Integrity and Availability for Use in an Official Proceeding; Obstruct, influence, Impede an Official Proceeding by Entering and Remaining in the United States Capitol without Authority

summary:
On Jan. 6, 2021, Daniel Lyons Scott wore a black ballistic vest, goggles and a carabiner on his vest, according to court documents. Scott, who goes by the nickname “Milkshake,” is a known member of the Proud Boys and has a tattoo of the organization on his left arm, according to the FBI. In a Wall Street Journal video from Jan. 6, 2021, Scott is seen walking alongside known members of the Proud Boys in Washington, D.C. On the same video, a man is heard screaming: “Let’s take the f***ing Capitol.” Another individual then answers: “Let’s not f***ing yell that, all right?” Ethan Nordean, one of the most powerful leaders in the organization, then responds: “It was Milkshake, man, you know … idiot.” 

Later at the Capitol, additional footage from various sources shows Scott pushing two police officers backward up the steps. Scott appears to be one of the first people to initiate contact with law enforcement and is seen later pulling officers into the crowd.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Civil Disorder (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts)
case_updates: Scott pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
“The election was completely stolen,” wrote Leonard Pearson Ridge on Snapchat to a friend in December, 2020, according to court documents. “If they can steal it once they can steal it the next time too, forever screwed if we don’t stop it this time,” his friend responded. “Yeah man something needs to change and something big will happen in this nation very soon either in our favor or theirs and it’s just the final boiling point whoever gets the upper hand will just control the country honestly,” Ridge responded.

In the days following Jan. 6, 2021, a confidential witness contacted the FBI, stating that Ridge uploaded multiple pictures and videos of himself inside and outside the Capitol to a Snapchat messenger group. “Currently making history,” one caption read. Additional footage and geodata show Ridge walking inside the rotunda. “I got tear gased [sic] and maced five times,” he wrote to a friend that same day in the evening. “Yeah man so epic I have a video of me fighting riot police in the capital [sic] building.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ridge pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/4/2022 to 14 days incarceration; 1 year supervised release; 100 hours community service; $1,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary:
“Do Terrorist break into the building to take selfie’s?  Do they stop to ask the riot police in the Capitol where the bathroom is? Do they ask if they can take selfies with the riot police? Patriots do. And this is what happened,” wrote Vic Don Williams, who goes by Stiemy Vic Williams on Facebook, next to a picture of himself on the steps of the Capitol, according to court documents. 

Several witnesses contacted the FBI and reported that Williams participated in the Jan. 6, 2021 events at the Capitol based on content they viewed on Facebook. Agents interviewed Williams at his home, where he admitted posting on social media and being outside the Capitol, but not entering. According to the FBI, Williams, who owns a roasting company, gave two bags of coffee to the interviewing agents as they were leaving. Later footage reviewed by the FBI shows Williams inside the Capitol, contradicting his previous statements.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Williams pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/7/2022 to 12 Months of Probation; 60 days home confinement/location monitoring; Special Assessment of $10.00; Fine of $1500.00; Restitution of $500.00; 60 hours of community service

summary: Jeremy Grace flew to Washington, D.C., from Washington state with his father, Jeffrey Grace, to attend the Jan. 6, 2021, pro-Trump rally. The elder Grace was arrested in early February after appearing in the background of a viral photograph, taken inside the Capitol, of a man holding a lectern. When Jeffrey Grace was interviewed by the FBI, he admitted that he had entered the Capitol. However, he said that in the melee he had lost track of his son, Jeremy, whom the FBI then interviewed. In that conversation, Jeremy Grace told the FBI that he had not entered the building and that the closest he got to it was a “roundabout thing” on the Capitol's west side. However, a deleted video recovered from Jeffrey Grace's cellphone shows Jeremy Grace inside the building with his father, court documents indicate. In the video, Jeremy Grace allegedly says: “Just made it into the Capitol here. Oh yeah, oh yeah.” His father then says, “It gets no better than this," to which his son replies: “Freedom.” Jeffrey and Jeremy Grace can also be seen in videos taken outside the Capitol, where the two of them are seen marching with members of the Proud Boys, according to court documents, and Jeffrey Grace is seen in one video flashing a "white power" hand signal. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Grace served in the U.S. Navy from 2002 until 2006.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing
in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grace pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/8/2022 to 21 days incarceration; 12 months supervised release; 60 hours community service; $500 restitution; $25 special assessment

summary: A tipster told the FBI that Jonathan Ace Sanders had been bragging about being at the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and had said he "was only 70 feet away from the lady who was shot at the Capitol Building," court documents indicate. In a subsequent interview with the FBI, Sanders admitted that he had entered the Capitol and had taken pictures and videos while inside. Sanders is also allegedly seen in Capitol security footage from that day. According to court documents, Sanders works at Lewis Bakery in Vincennes, Ind. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Sanders is a U.S. Air Force veteran.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sanders pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 11/4/2021 to 3 years of probation; $500 in restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: A tipster turned Adam Mark Weibling in to the FBI after seeing him in a video of the Jan. 6, 2021 Capitol riot published by The New Yorker. In the video, which was corroborated by security footage from the building, Weibling can allegedly be seen inside the Capitol trying to force his way past a Capitol Police officer, along with a throng of others. After a 90-second struggle, Weibling wanders into the rotunda of the Capitol, appearing "disheveled' and repeatedly checking his head as if for a wound, court documents indicate. Weibling is allegedly seen leaving the Capitol after he spent about 15 minutes in the rotunda. Leading up to Election Day, Weibling was active on Twitter, expressing doubts about the integrity of the U.S. presidential election and saying that he planned to come to D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Weibling pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing is set for 10/28/2022

summary: Federal prosecutors say that Kenneth Joseph Owen Thomas also goes by the alias "Pi Annon" (sometimes spelled "Pi Anon") and that he traveled to Washington, D.C., from Alabama late on the evening of Jan. 5, 2021, along with a "caravan of approximately 60 vehicles." Thomas appeared in a video addressing the caravan, prosecutors say, in which he stated, “We all are meeting at the Ellipse to listen to Mike Lindell and President Trump speak. After that, we’re all going to march together down to the [U.S.] Capitol to listen to Michael Flynn and the events going on down there. ... See you in D.C.” (Lindell is a supporter of former President Donald Trump and the founder and CEO of the company MyPillow, and Flynn briefly served as national security adviser in the Trump White House. Both men have spread conspiracy theories regarding the 2020 election.) On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, Thomas posted a video in which he stated, “Right now, we got a whole [list] of people going to storm the Capitol.” Later, he can allegedly be seen in police body camera footage pushing and striking police officers outside the Capitol and telling the crowd to "hold the line" against law enforcement. After Jan. 6, 2021, the FBI received multiple tips identifying Thomas and his social media accounts, according to court papers, including evidence submitted by the online group of civilians known as Sedition Hunters. A review of the social media accounts identified in court papers reveals multiple posts indicating support for QAnon, the pro-Trump conspiracy theory. Thomas was arrested in Birmingham, Ala., on May 26, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Thomas pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Nicholas James Brockhoff assaulted law enforcement officers outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by spraying a fire extinguisher from a terrace above members of the Metropolitan Police Department and the Capitol Police who were trying to hold back rioters. As a result, prosecutors say, Brockhoff "caused law enforcement to disperse, and obstructed law enforcement’s ability to see." Surveillance footage allegedly shows Brockhoff then entering the Capitol through a broken window. Later, according to body camera footage described in court documents, Brockhoff was seen wearing a police officer's helmet. Brockhoff also allegedly joined rioters in "making a forced entry" into a Republican conference room inside the Capitol. Brockhoff was arrested in Tennessee on May 27, 2021.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brockhoff pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI began an investigation into Kene Brian Lazo after receiving a tip about a Facebook photo showing an individual inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the riot. Using a combination of open-source searches and Facebook records obtained through a warrant, the FBI found that Lazo operated that Facebook page with his wife, according to court documents. Lazo allegedly posted ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, that he would be attending protests in Washington, D.C., that day and that he would be "the only 1 with a boi boi representing asians," an apparent reference to a type of broom used in the Philippines. Ahead of the riot, Lazo apparently wrote on social media that "if s**t hits the fan i will get some dead guys gear and guns if it comes down to it," court documents say. Lazo was also captured on closed-circuit TV footage inside the Capitol, the FBI alleges. He was arrested May 28, 2021, in Norfolk, Va.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lazo pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/18/2022 45 days Incarceration; Special Assessment  $10; Restitution $500

summary: A Facebook friend tipped the FBI off to Anthony Puma, who allegedly livestreamed his actions on Jan. 6, 2021. FBI agents then interviewed Puma, who reportedly admitted to being inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the insurrection but denied seeing anyone looting or committing violence. GoPro video footage Puma took on that day, obtained by the FBI, allegedly shows him climbing through a window to enter the Capitol building. A search warrant issued for Puma's Facebook account showed that he posted ahead of the insurrection: "On the 6th when we are all there in the capital and he is givin [sic] his second term the people will see. Then you never know we might have to start killing some commie b******s. #stopthesteal." On Jan. 5, 2021, according to a legal filing, he also posted, "War is coming," and, "Hopefully we are storming the House of Representatives tomorrow at 100 pm." After the insurrection, he reportedly wrote: "When I got up and over the wall I walked right into the front door and walked around the capital bldg."
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Puma pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jason Dolan, according to federal prosecutors, has connections with the anti-government extremist militia group known as the Oath Keepers and goes by the moniker Turmoil. After the November 2020 presidential election, Dolan allegedly conspired with other members of the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of President Biden's electoral victory by Congress. Dolan participated in an encrypted group chat (called "OK FL DC OP Jan 6") with the Oath Keepers using the app Signal, prosecutors allege. Two days before the riot, Dolan rented a van and traveled to Washington, D.C., with another defendant from Florida, Kenneth Harrelson, prosecutors say. Around 2:40 p.m. on the day of riot, Dolan and Harrelson joined a military-style "stack" formation with other alleged members of the Oath Keepers and breached the Capitol building, according to the federal allegations. The group then moved into the Capitol Rotunda, and Dolan and Harrelson allegedly remained inside the building until 2:57 p.m. Around 4 p.m., prosecutors say, Dolan joined with other Oath Keepers near the Capitol, including the organization's leader, Stewart Rhodes. Rhodes is identified as "Person 1" in the indictment and has not been charged in connection with the Capitol breach. A spokesperson for the United States Marine Corps confirmed to NPR that Dolan served in the Marines for nearly 20 years and reached the rank of Staff Sergeant. He deployed to Iraq in 2004, a year after the U.S. invasion.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Dolan pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding

summary: Joseph Hackett is facing criminal charges as part of the government's case against multiple alleged members of the anti-government extremist militia group known as the Oath Keepers. Federal prosecutors say Hackett has used the moniker "Ahab." Soon after the November 2020 presidential election, Hackett allegedly joined an online meeting with the leader of the Oath Keepers, Stewart Rhodes, in which Rhodes told members of the group to go to Washington, D.C., to support then-President Donald Trump. "We’re going to defend the president, the duly elected president, and we call on him to do what needs to be done to save our country," Rhodes told the group, according to court documents filed by the government. "Because if you don’t, guys, you’re going to be in a bloody, bloody civil war and a bloody — you can call it an insurrection or you can call it a war or fight.” After that meeting, Hackett allegedly took part in planning for an "operation" on Jan. 6, 2021 with members of the Oath Keepers via encrypted email and messaging services. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, Hackett and other Oath Keepers members "prepared themselves for battle before heading to the Capitol by equipping themselves with communication devices and donning reinforced vests, helmets, and goggles." Just after 2:30 p.m. on that day, Hackett and other Oath Keepers members formed a military-style "stack" formation and "forcibly entered" the Capitol, according to prosecutors. Court documents state that Hackett left the building at 2:54 p.m. and then met with other members of the group, including Rhodes, outside the building around 4 p.m.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Hackett pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster called the FBI after overhearing Nicholas Patrick Hendrix talking about being pepper-sprayed at the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. In a later interview with agents from the bureau, Hendrix admitted that he entered the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and that he knew it was illegal to do so. Hendrix told agents that on Jan. 5, 2021, he drove from where he lives near Portland, Maine, to Boston and then took a bus from there to Washington, D.C. Wearing a sign around his neck that read "STOP THE COMMUNIST & TERRORIST REVOLUTION" and brandishing an American flag, Hendrix followed the crowd to the Capitol after the pro-Trump rally and said the crowd "pushed" its way in, court documents indicate. In his FBI interview, Hendrix said that there was "not too much resistance from law enforcement" and that he believed the U.S. Capitol Police "were quitting and allowing them to go inside." Hendrix is also allegedly seen in security footage from inside the building that day.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hendrix pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 12/9/2022

summary: William Isaacs is facing a federal criminal indictment alongside several alleged members of the anti-government extremist militia group known as the Oath Keepers. According to the indictment, Isaacs conspired with members of the Oath Keepers and helped plan for the group to storm the Capitol to disrupt the certification of the 2020 presidential election. On Jan. 6, 2021, Isaacs allegedly joined a military-style "stack" formation with members of the group and helped the crowd breach an outer door of the Capitol. Once inside, the indictment states, Isaacs moved to the Capitol rotunda and then headed toward the Senate side of the building as he "yelled 'the fight’s not over' and waved rioters down the hallways towards the Senate." He then allegedly "joined the mob in pushing against a line of riot police officers guarding the hallway connecting the Rotunda to the Senate" and retreated only after officers used chemical spray. The indictment states that Isaacs exited the Capitol building at 3:05 p.m. and about an hour later gathered with members of the group, as well as the Oath Keepers' leader, Stewart Rhodes, outside the building.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Isaacs pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Sean Michael McHugh flew from Sacramento, Calif., to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 5, 2021, according to records obtained by the FBI from the travel company Expedia. He stayed at the Yotel in D.C., hotel records obtained by the FBI indicate, and returned to Sacramento on Jan. 7, 2021. According to court documents, McHugh is seen in videos and body camera footage from the Jan. 6, 2021 riot yelling at police officers through a megaphone, including yelling, “You guys like protecting pedophiles?”; “You’re protecting communists!”; and “I’d be shaking in your little s*** boots too." McHugh is allegedly seen and heard in the videos encouraging the rioters, pushing a large metal sign into police officers and shooting officers with a "yellow spray."
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: McHugh pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two people called the FBI after Stacy Wade Hager posted photos on his Facebook account that allegedly show him at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Hager is also seen in videos from inside the building that day, according to court documents. In one exchange captured on police body camera footage just outside the Capitol, Hager is asked to not walk behind the police line. The officer says: "If you could not, we are all trying to stay safe and get home.” Hager replies, “I know you are and I really respect y’all" and then continues to walk past the officer. On Jan. 13, 2021, Hager allegedly posted a lengthy description online of the events where he describes scaling a wall at the Capitol: "This was the wall that divides sane and insane, civil and disobedient, frantic and mayhem, relative safety and imminent danger." He wrote that it was the first time he felt "invincible."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hager pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that James McGrew was identified from video and photographs of the attack on the U.S. Capitol — in particular, from a police body camera video that shows him lifting his shirt to wipe his eyes. The gesture allowed investigators to spot a prominent stomach tattoo reading "KING JAMES" in elaborate Gothic letters that curved over his belly button. The tattoo appears to match one in an old police booking photo from 2012. Photos and police footage show McGrew both inside and outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, including inside the rotunda, where he confronted police officers "aggressively" and yelled, "We're coming in here whether you like it or not." When law enforcement endeavored to push rioters toward an exit, court documents allege that McGrew responded by "lunging forward" to strike an officer. McGrew backed up a bit after that but returned to approach the officers again, screaming, "You leave. You leave. This is our house." As police tried again to move the crowd toward the door, McGrew reached out to strike another officer and then grabbed for his baton. A tipster who contacted law enforcement a day after the riot said that McGrew had planned to travel to Washington, D.C., to "protest" the "stolen vote."
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McGrew pleaded Guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 10/14/2022

summary: An FBI affidavit says Audrey Ann Southard-Rumsey drove from Florida to Washington, D.C., with three friends for then-President Donald Trump’s Jan. 6 rally. One of them told FBI agents that Southard-Rumsey disappeared for a while but then was finally found crying on the east steps of the U.S. Capitol building, saying she had entered the building, according to the affidavit. A U.S. Capitol Police sergeant identified Southard-Rumsey as one of the main agitators in a group of rioters, according to court documents. Video footage reportedly shows her pushing a flagpole into the officer’s chest and yelling, “Tell Pelosi we are coming for that b**ch,” and, “There’s 100,000 of us, what’s it going to be?” The affidavit alleges the officer “felt like he was being trampled” as Southard-Rumsey pushed him into a set of doors leading to the House floor, causing him to strike his head on the base of a marble statue. An agent in the FBI’s Tampa, Fla., office who has had interactions with Southard-Rumsey through her protest activities in Florida also identified her in video footage. She was arrested June 2, 2021, and released on a $50,000 bond.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Southard-Rumsey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jonathan Walden has been indicted along with several members of the anti-government extremist militia group known as the Oath Keepers. According to that indictment, Walden goes by the moniker "EoinAL" and allegedly participated in a conspiracy with other members of the Oath Keepers to obstruct Congress' certification of President Biden's electoral victory by helping to plan the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Prior to the attack on the Capitol, according to the indictment, Walden "applied" to join the Oath Keepers' planned operation by sending an email in which he said, "I am interested in the [Quick Reaction Force] team in D.C. I am former Firefighter, EMT-B and have a K-9 trained for security patrol (82 lb. German Shepherd named ‘Warrior’). I have a Jump Bag with Trauma supplies and have ALL the necessary 2A gear that the situation may require." In other messages described in the indictment, the Oath Keepers discussed having the "Quick Reaction Force" near the Capitol and available with weapons. On the day of the attack on the Capitol, Walden was "equipped with goggles, scissors, a tactical vest with attachments, gloves, a backpack, fatigues, boots, and his dog," according to the indictment. At about 2:30 p.m., Walden allegedly rode in a golf cart toward the Capitol along with other Oath Keepers before they continued on foot. Walden and another Oath Keeper then "aggressively berated and taunted law enforcement officers in riot gear guarding the perimeter of the Capitol building," the indictment states. At 3:15 p.m., Walden forcibly entered the Capitol along with his dog and exited about 20 minutes later, prosecutors allege. Just after 4 p.m., a group of Oath Keepers including Walden allegedly gathered outside the Capitol and met the group's leader, Stewart Rhodes. Walden was arrested in Alabama on June 3, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Walden pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Three people called the FBI after seeing videos on Stewart Parks' Instagram account from inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. The FBI then obtained a search warrant for Parks' account, where they allegedly found messages between him and other users talking about the riot. In one, Parks says: "Let's just say this dc trip was more eventful than the 8th grade trip," referencing the popular custom of taking eighth-graders on a trip to Washington, D.C. The person he messaged replied: "It f***ing looked like it. I'm glad you took those vids down now because the fbi is hunting yall." Parks is also seen in video surveillance from inside the Capitol that day, according to court documents, and in one he is allegedly seen taking a hand-held metal detector wand and exiting the building. Records obtained by the FBI from Southwest Airlines show Parks traveled from Nashville to Washington on the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, with another man now charged in connection with the riot, Matthew Baggott. They flew back on Jan. 7, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Parks pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew Baggott was identified by the FBI through an investigation relating to another man charged in the U.S. Capitol riot, Stewart Parks. A witness who knows Parks was able to also identify Baggott in video surveillance footage taken inside the Capitol, court documents indicate. Additionally, Parks mentioned Baggott in Instagram messages about the day, which were recovered by the FBI. The pair flew together from Tennessee on Southwest Airlines and landed in Washington, D.C., on the morning of Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baggott pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 8/5/2022 to 3 months incarceration, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution

summary: Richard Crosby Jr. was identified, court documents allege, when he named himself in the aftermath of the riot at the U.S. Capitol as Rick C. on a YouTube video and gave out his phone number. FBI agents traced the number and tracked down his parents. Agents talked to both his father and mother in Connecticut, who told them that Crosby Jr. said to them that he believed the 2020 election had been stolen and that he'd gone to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021 for the Trump rally. When the FBI agents questioned Crosby Jr. at his home, he corroborated what his parents had said and told them he wanted to attend the rally because he wanted his "voice heard." After the rally, he said, he walked toward the Capitol. He showed agents where he had entered the building, where it was, he said, "chaos." He ultimately ended up in the Senate chamber, on the dais with two other men including Jacob Chansley, known as "The QAnon Shaman." Video footage shows Chansley offering a prayer that includes the words "Thank you for allowing us to get rid of the communists, globalists, and traitors within our goverment," and Crosby Jr. at the end of it yells "Amen!" He told the FBI that he participated in "Stop the Steal" chants for a little while on his way out before walking back to his hotel.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Crosby pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Leonard Q. Gruppo Jr. is a physician assistant at Plains Regional Medical Center in Clovis, N.M., who was arrested June 1, 2021, according to court documents. Three tipsters identified him in photos walking through the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, alongside a man charged in April 2021, Kenneth Kelly. An attorney claiming to represent Gruppo also contacted the FBI on May 17, 2021, to identify him. Two of Gruppo’s co-workers told the FBI that the usually clean-shaven Gruppo has been growing out his hair and beard recently, according to the criminal complaint.
Gruppo was a physician assistant for the Army.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gruppo pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed.  Sentenced 10/29/2021 to 24 months probation; 90 days home detention/location monitoring; $10.00 special assessment; $500.00 restitution, and $3,000.00 fine.

summary:
Carey Jon Walden of Kansas City, Mo., is a U.S. Marine Corps veteran who told FBI agents he scaled a wall at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 climbed through a broken window, “which was already broken,” and spent about five minutes inside, according to a criminal complaint.
“I was not asked to leave. I fist bumped and ‘Devil horned’ the SWAT line,” Walden wrote when the FBI asked him to describe his actions in his own words. “I am not part of any hate groups. I went with a bus of Trump supports (sic).”
A witness who reported to Walden during his time in the Marine Corps told the FBI that Walden streamed several Facebook Live videos as he climbed the walls and entered the building. The complaint includes a photo looking down from the Capitol plaza that was posted to Walden’s Facebook, captioned “I had just climbed the west wall lol.”
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Walden pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/19/2022 to 3 years of probation, 30 days home confinement/ location monitoring; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: An anonymous tip to the FBI identified Timothy Wayne Williams as entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after attending President Trump’s rally, according to court documents. In March, the FBI interviewed Williams in person, where he confirmed to the agents that he had entered the building. Williams also told the FBI that he previously worked for a company called “GrowGeneration,” a hydroponics equipment supplier, but lost his job because he would not take a COVID-19 test. He denied having been involved in any acts of violence or property damage but stated that he “got pushed” inside the building by the crowd and that he saw people “tearing things up inside.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary:
“People got mad, yes, an election was stolen! But Trump was an angel! Also Antifa was there 100%,” wrote Stephanie Baez on Instagram days after entering the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. “My proudest moment,” she wrote on the same platform. According to the FBI, Baez, who traveled to Washington to attend the “StopTheSteal” rally, entered the Capitol Crypt wearing deep blue eyeshadow, a gray jacket and a T-shirt with the slogan “Boy Did I Call It Or What?” next to a picture of 1984 author George Orwell.

In April, FBI agents interviewed Baez, who told them that she went online to check the hours of the Capitol to see whether it was open, and confirmed that it was, so she could tour it. Baez also told the FBI that it was possible that she read the website wrong or visited the wrong website. In a video posted on social media, Baez stands in front of the Capitol building and is asked about the Proud Boys, to which she responds laughing: “I love the Proud Boys. I want to find me a Proud Boy.” When asked by the interviewer how the Proud Boys can reach her, she gives her Instagram username. According to court documents, Baez was arrested in Huntsville, Ala.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A person turned Christian Kulas in to the FBI after seeing videos on an Instagram account registered to Kulas that showed the events of Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Those videos allegedly depicted the Trump rally, people marching to the U.S. Capitol, people scaling the building's walls, a crowd moving up the steps of the building, and, later, the inside of the Capitol, with a man heard saying, "[S]torming the Capitol." Kulas was identified as that male voice and as the person shown in selfie mode in one of the videos by a former classmate, court documents indicate. In a different message on social media recovered by the FBI, Kulas' mother was asked if the videos showed her son. According to court documents, she responded yes, with an emoji.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kulas pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/26/2022 to 6 months of Probation; 60 days home detention; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500

summary: On the day of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, Shawn Price sent multiple Facebook messages claiming, "I led the storm!" according to court documents. Prosecutors say they have evidence that Price is a member of the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys, and is a leader in a New Jersey chapter of the group. “[I] got really f***** up but me and 4 of my chapter brothers pushed that line and started it ourselves had to be done,” he allegedly said on Jan. 6, 2021. Price took videos from outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say, in which he urged rioters to push forward against police lines protecting the Capitol. In other videos from the scene described by prosecutors, Price "is helping to push a crowd forward into the line of law enforcement officers." Later that day, Price messaged with his mother on Facebook, according to court records. When she asked whether he had entered the Capitol building, he replied, "[Y]es i did after getting tear gassed pepper sprayed and shot with rubber bullets." Messages between Price and his mother cited in the documents show Price asking her how to deal with pepper spray used by law enforcement, and his mother responding that he should use baby shampoo. FBI agents arrested Price in New Jersey on June 8, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Price pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Dillon Colby Herrington was turned in to the FBI by someone who has known him for 17 years after he appeared on an FBI wanted poster, court documents indicate. In video footage from Jan. 6, 2021, Herrington, dubbed the #MAGALumberjack by the FBI, can allegedly be seen throwing a 4-by-4 piece of lumber and also a metal barricade in the direction of law enforcement. According to court documents, Herrington did not hit any officers with the objects. On the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police detained Herrington on U.S. Capitol grounds over having a knife sticking out of his pocket, court documents say. The officers placed the knife into Herrington's backpack and escorted him off the premises. The officers took down Herrington's contact information and released him. The FBI does not believe Herrington entered the Capitol building. Herrington served as an Indirect Fire Infantryman in the U.S. Army from 2017 to 2019. He had no deployments, an Army spokesperson confirmed.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Knowingly Engage in any act of Physical Violence Against any Person or Property in a Restricted Building; Willfully and Knowingly Engage in an act of Physical Violence in the Grounds of the Capitol Building; Commit or Attempt any act to Obstruct, Impede or Interfere with Law Enforcement in Performance of his Official Duties; Forcible Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, Intimidate, or Interfere with Law Enforcement

summary: Prosecutors allege that Kevin Creek was involved in some of the most intense clashes with law enforcement during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol around the West Terrace. Body camera footage from police appears to show Creek punching and kicking police, court documents say. A complainant reported to the FBI he heard Creek talking about his role in the events of the day while visiting Northside Forsyth Hospital in Georgia a few days later, according to court documents. Creek reportedly said he was bruised and had been tear-gassed attempting to get inside the Capitol building. Agents traced his route from Georgia to Washington, D.C., through credit card statements, transit records and hotel charges. When FBI agents spoke with Creek and his attorney, Creek admitted to his involvement and confirmed his identity in photos shown to him of the riot, court documents say. The assaults on law enforcement were also shown to Creek, who said the video did look like him but that he didn't remember "assaulting any officer." Creek described his movements that day in "great detail," according to court documents, and disclosed he was armed with Mace and a boot knife at the Capitol. When asked if he regretted his conduct that day, Creek reportedly responded: "50/50." Creek is a former U.S. Marine and served from 1995 to 1999, a Marine Corps spokesperson confirmed. He had no deployments and obtained the rank of Corporal, the spokesperson said. He is also the registered agent of Nailed It Roofing and Restoration in Johns Creek, Ga., according to Georgia Corporations Division records.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers
case_updates: Creek pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 5/2/2022 to 27 months of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $100 special assessment and $2,000 restitution.

summary: Alan Hostetter founded a group called the American Phoenix Project, whose mission was to oppose coronavirus-related lockdowns, according to federal court records. The Los Angeles Times reported that Hostetter is a former police chief in La Habra, Calif. In the 1980s, prior to his law enforcement career, Hostetter served in the U.S.  Army and has said he was stationed in West Germany. After the election, Hostetter used his group to “advocate violence,” prosecutors allege in those records. In a November YouTube video, Hostetter supported then-President Donald Trump’s false claims the election had been stolen, and allegedly said, in response, that “tyrants and traitors need to be executed as an example.” At a “Stop the Steal” rally on Dec. 12, 2020, in Huntington Beach, Calif., Hostetter allegedly told a crowd that “execution is the just punishment for the ringleaders of this coup.” According to a criminal indictment of Hostetter and others, Hostetter helped coordinate plans for a pro-Trump rally on Jan. 6, 2021, with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Three Percenters. Prosecutors say those plans were developed on the encrypted messaging app Telegram and included discussions of bringing protective gear, weapons and the use of radios. At around 2:30 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, Hostetter, along with another defendant, Russell Taylor, joined rioters on the west side of the Capitol, “pushing through a line of law enforcement officers trying to hold them back,” court documents say.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds
case_updates: Hostetter pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Russell Taylor, according to federal court records, joined the American Phoenix Project in 2020 and used the group as a platform to support then-President Donald Trump’s false claims of a “stolen election.” Taylor allegedly communicated with the leader of the group, Alan Hostetter, via the encrypted messaging app Telegram. After Trump called for a “wild” protest on Jan. 6, 2021, Taylor made plans to travel to Washington, D.C., with others, the records say. In one Telegram message described in court documents, Taylor said he was planning to be at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and wrote, “I personally want to be on the front steps and be one of the first ones to breach the doors!” Prosecutors say Taylor also created a channel on Telegram called the California Patriots-DC Brigade, which attracted more than 30 participants. In that channel, Taylor allegedly asked for members to describe any military or law enforcement experience they had, and said, “I am assuming that you have some type of weaponry that you are bringing with you.” On Jan. 5, 2021, Taylor spoke at a pro-Trump rally in front of the U.S. Supreme Court, where he allegedly pledged that “we will fight and we will bleed before we allow our freedom to be taken from us.” On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, Taylor carried a protective “plate-carrier vest” as well as a knife and a “stun baton.” At around 2:30 p.m. that day, Taylor and Hostetter joined rioters on the west side of the Capitol “pushing through a line of law enforcement officers trying to hold them back,” court documents say. Taylor sent a message at 6:18 p.m. that evening, prosecutors say, in which he said, “I was pushing through traitors all day today. WE STORMED THE CAPITOL!” In subsequent messages described by prosecutors, Taylor said he did not breach the Capitol building because he “had weapons.” When he was asked about what would happen next, Taylor allegedly responded, “Insurrection!”
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds and Carrying a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon (knife); Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Taylor pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors say that Erik Scott Warner started a group text message with three others -- Derek Kinnison, Felipe Antonio Martinez and Ronald Mele -- to arrange travel from California to Washington, D.C., for a pro-Trump rally planned on Jan. 6, 2021. Later, according to a criminal indictment, he and more than 30 others used the encrypted messaging app Telegram to participate in a channel called the California Patriots-DC Brigade, which was started by a leader of a group called the American Phoenix Project. That channel was then allegedly used to plan and coordinate logistics, including the use of protective gear, radios and weapons, for the events of Jan. 6, 2021. In a photo posted to the channel, Warner can allegedly be seen flashing the hand signal of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Three Percenters. Kinnison also allegedly texted Martinez, Mele and Warner about bringing a shotgun and ammunition to Washington. At 2:13 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, Warner allegedly breached the Capitol building by entering through a broken window.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Warner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors say that Felipe Antonio Martinez participated in a group text message with three others -- Derek Kinnison, Ronald Mele and Erik Scott Warner -- to arrange travel from California to Washington, D.C., for a pro-Trump rally planned on Jan. 6, 2021. Later, according to a criminal indictment, he and more than 30 others used the encrypted messaging app Telegram to join a channel called the California Patriots-DC Brigade, which was started by a leader of a group called the American Phoenix Project. That channel was then allegedly used to plan and coordinate logistics, including the use of protective gear, radios and weapons, for the events of Jan. 6, 2021, at the U.S. Capitol. In a photo posted to the channel, Martinez can allegedly be seen flashing the hand signal of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Three Percenters. Kinnison also allegedly texted Martinez, Mele and Warner about bringing a shotgun and ammunition to Washington. On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say, Martinez wore a protective “plate-carrier vest” and “joined rioters in the restricted area on the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol Building.”
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds
case_updates: Martinez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors say that Derek Kinnison participated in a group text message with three others -- Felipe Antonio Martinez, Ronald Mele and Erik Scott Warner -- to arrange travel from California to Washington, D.C., for a pro-Trump rally planned on Jan. 6, 2021. Later, according to a criminal indictment, he and more than 30 others used the encrypted messaging app Telegram to join a channel called the California Patriots-DC Brigade, which was started by a leader of a group called the American Phoenix Project. That channel was then allegedly used to plan and coordinate logistics, including the use of protective gear, radios and weapons, for the events of Jan. 6, 2021, at the U.S. Capitol. Kinnison allegedly posted a photo to the channel depicting himself flashing the hand signal of the extremist anti-government militia called the Three Percenters. In one message described in the indictment, Kinnison said he and the others in his group would be traveling by car, so they could bring heavy equipment, including “medical kits, radios, multiple cans of bear spray, knives, flags” as well as other protective equipment. He also allegedly texted Martinez, Mele and Warner about bringing a shotgun and ammunition to Washington. On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say, Kinnison wore a gas mask and “joined rioters in the restricted area on the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol Building.”
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Kinnison pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Dec. 24, 2020, Ronald Mele posted on Facebook that he was planning to travel to Washington, D.C., “to support our President on the 6th and days to follow just in case,” according to federal court records. Prosecutors say Mele then participated in a group text message with three others -- Derek Kinnison, Felipe Antonio Martinez and Erik Scott Warner -- to arrange travel and logistics. Later, according to a criminal indictment, he and more than 30 others used the encrypted messaging app Telegram to join a channel called the California Patriots-DC Brigade, which was started by a leader of a group called the American Phoenix Project. That channel was then allegedly used to plan and coordinate logistics, including the use of protective gear, radios and weapons, for the events of Jan. 6, 2021. In one message, Kinnison allegedly said that Mele is a member of the extremist anti-government militia called the Three Percenters. Kinnison also allegedly texted Martinez, Mele and Warner about bringing a shotgun and ammunition to Washington. On Jan. 6, 2021, according to court records, Mele took a selfie video from the steps on the Upper West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol building and said, “We stormed the Capitol.”
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Two counts of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds
case_updates: Mele pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: After the FBI posted an image seeking information about him, Robert Morss was identified by at least four witnesses. Morss is allegedly seen in photos and videos from Jan. 6, 2021, wearing camouflage, a tactical vest and a "Make America Great Again" hat. In a crowd trying to push past law enforcement in the Lower West Terrace area of the U.S. Capitol grounds, Morss can be seen on police body camera footage trying to take a police baton away from an officer and later grabbing a fence held by officers and ripping it away, according to court documents. He can allegedly be heard saying to officers: "You guys are betraying us. You get paid enough to betray your people?” and “[T]ake a look around, back up, we are going to take our Capitol back.” In a YouTube video from a tunnel leading into the Capitol, he is seen pushing into and taking a riot shield away from an officer and sending it back into the crowd, where he directs them to form a "shield wall," according to court documents. Rioters then yelled, "Heave ho," as they pushed in unison against the officers guarding the doors, court documents indicate. Morss eventually left the tunnel and could later be seen climbing through a broken window into the Capitol, court documents say. According to court documents, Morss is a combat veteran. He was honorably discharged from the U.S. Army after serving three tours of duty in Afghanistan.
charges: Robbery (baton, fence, shield from 3 different MPD officers); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: At a stipulated bench trial on 8/23/2022, Morss was found Guilty of Robbery; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. He admitted to a stipulated set of facts.

summary: Chicago police officer Karol Chwiesiuk stormed the U.S. Capitol wearing a hoodie emblazoned with a Chicago police emblem, court documents indicate. Using location records obtained from Google and from the officer's phone service provider, the FBI reportedly found that Chwiesiuk left Chicago on Jan. 4, 2021, arrived in Washington, D.C., stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, and was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The FBI also reviewed Chwiesiuk's text messages. According to court documents, Chwiesiuk sent messages on Jan. 3, 2021, saying that he was going to Washington to "save the nation" and that he was planning to "f*** up some commies." On Jan. 6, 2021, he allegedly sent other messages in which he wrote "we inside the capital lmfao," used a racial slur and sent a selfie of himself inside the office of Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Ore. Chwiesiuk has been "relieved of his police powers and is currently assigned to routine administrative duties" pending the outcome of an internal investigation, according to a spokesperson for the Chicago Police Department.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Entering and Remaining in a Room Designated for the Use of a Member of Congress; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chwiesiuk pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In the days following the Jan. 6, 2021, riots, the FBI received multiple tips from individuals identifying Daniel Johnson and his father, Daryl, being inside the U.S. Capitol building, according to court documents. “I was one of the first ones inside the capitol building,” read a screenshot of a Facebook post by Daniel Johnson that the FBI tipster reportedly showed agents. In May, a search warrant for a Facebook account returned posts from Daniel Johnson, identifying him as being at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents say. “Couple thousand?? LOL try like 4 million people!!!" read one of the captions to a picture showing people in front of the building.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Johnson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/1/22 to 4 months incarceration, 1 year of supervised release, $2,000 in restitution, $100 special assessment

summary: In the days following the Jan. 6, 2021, riots, the FBI received multiple tips from individuals identifying Daryl Johnson and his son Daniel as being inside the U.S. Capitol building, according to court documents. A federal judge authorized a search warrant for Daryl Johnson’s Facebook account in late April, court documents say. From the search warrant, the FBI uncovered posts that referenced Daryl Johnson being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. “What the media is saying is completely false. It was Antifa causing the damage. I was there. Trump supporters were restraining the Antifa people. Do not believe the reports – it’s complete BS,” he reportedly wrote.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Johnson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/1/22 to 30 days incarceration, 1 year of supervised release, a $2,000 fine, $2,000 in restitution, $100 special assessment

summary: At least eight people reportedly turned Brian Christopher Mock in to the FBI after seeing photos, videos and comments posted on his and his girlfriend's Facebook accounts indicating he had participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot. Among them was one video in response to the comment "Pics or it didnt happen," court documents say. Mock also appeared in photos on the Twitter account @SeditionHunters, according to court documents. In police body camera footage from that day, Mock can allegedly be seen shoving a U.S. Capitol Police officer to the ground and kicking him. Later, Mock can allegedly be seen shoving a second officer to the ground and then picking up riot shields and passing them back through the crowd. In a lengthy Facebook post three days before the riot, Mock asks: "Will, many years from now when your children and grandchildren ask what you did in 2021 to save this country, tell them I sat on my couch in fear, compliant, wearing a mask, watching TV and mocking the Patriots on social media because I was brainwashed by the Left and Mainstream media?" He ended with the Latin phrase "Sic semper tyrannis," which means "thus always to tyrants" and implied that tyrants will always be overthrown. Two days after the riot, he reportedly wrote on Facebook: “I went to the Capitol not knowing what to expect but said goodbye to my 4 children, not sure if I was going to come home. I was at peace with that knowledge. I held my own and then some when I watched Capitol police beating women and old men." Privately, he allegedly told one of the witnesses interviewed by the FBI he "beat the s***" out of a police officer.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mock pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: Nolan Kidd and Savannah McDonald allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6, 2021 -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 11, 2021, the FBI received a tip that Kidd had been inside of the Capitol building, which included a screenshot of an account believed to be his, showing an album of pictures of the day captioned, “Just made it home, I have tons of photos and videos to share with you guys.” Federal prosecutors say that agents interviewed Kidd at his home days later, and he said that “the doors to the U.S. Capitol were wide open.” A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of him and McDonald smiling for the camera, and Kidd showing a “thumbs up.” Kidd can also reportedly be seen in a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to himself, alongside McDonald saying, “[W]e got in from the back.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald allegedly heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol with a group of rioters that pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group chat in which a user believed to be Kidd reportedly says, “Me and Savannah are F***ING STORMTROOPERS.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kidd pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/9/2022 to 45 days of Incarceration; $10 special assessment and restitution in the amount of $500

summary: Savannah McDonald and Nolan Kidd allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6, 2021, -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 14, 2021, the FBI received a tip that McDonald had been inside the Capitol building and then interviewed her at her home days later. Court documents say that when she was shown a picture from the riot, McDonald acknowledged that the person circled in it was her. A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of the two smiling for the camera. In a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to Kidd, McDonald allegedly can be seen with Kidd, confirming they were “part of the first 100 people to enter the Capitol.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol, with McDonald holding a sign above her head reading, “If the dead can vote just wait and see what the living can do,” court documents say. Kidd and McDonald, along with a group of rioters, allegedly pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group video chat in which McDonald reportedly says, “I’m the only girl that made it into the Senate.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McDonald pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/10/2022 to 21 days of incarceration; $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500

summary: Nicole Prado was identified from a tip given to the FBI that she had participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol with another person. Court documents allege that the FBI found images and cellphone video footage from Instagram that appear to show Prado. A person narrating the video says, "Please meet the new Congresswoman... she uh, she just was in the Capitol for the first time today. She stormed the Capitol, she's the new Congresswoman. She's the new Speaker of the House." Video footage of the Capitol on that day shows a woman who resembled Prado walking through the building and matching the clothing in the Instagram video. FBI agents confirmed with other complainants that the person in the video was Prado, court document say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Prado pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/7/2022 to 12 Months of Probation; 60 days home confinement/location monitoring; Special Assessment of $10.00; Fine of $742.00; Restitution of $500.00; 60 hours of community service

summary: Anthony Scirica was identified to law enforcement by at least two former co-workers as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. A third tipster also sent videos of Snapchat stories Scirica had allegedly posted showing the exterior and interior of the Capitol building. One Snapchat showed a screenshot of ABC News. In it, Scirica can allegedly be seen in the Capitol's Statuary Hall with an American flag draped around his back with an added caption: "Anthony made it on TV." Capitol security footage and location records obtained from Verizon also place Scirica in the Capitol that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Scirica pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/20/2022 to 15 days of incarceration (7 intermittent weekends), with credit for time served (1 day); $500 fine; and $500 in restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: On Jan. 10, 2021, Kurt Peterson alllegedly posted a lengthy message on Facebook indicating that he had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021,. The message, detailed in court documents, begins: "To my family and friends who are able to see this, I am writing it with a voice recognition program while driving. I feel the need to keep moving and trying to keep my phone wrapped such that it can’t be traced most of the time." He then described the pro-Trump rally as peaceful and loving, but added "When there are huge crowds and there are people that are inciting violence, the crowds will many times be pulled in to this action." In the post, Peterson reportedly stated that he was with three military veterans and that he was not there to hurt anybody or damage anything, but was there as a "show of solidarity to right the wrongs of the past election."
