According to court documents, Peterson indicated that he was there when a woman, presumably Ashli Babbitt, was fatally shot by police. Peterson reportedly added that "Nonlethal force could have been used without the lethal shot that was made by this bodyguard in the speaker's lobby" and that he offered to provide first aid but was denied. Phone records obtained from Samsung reportedly place Peterson in the Capitol that day as well. He also appeared in police body camera footage and in at least two publicly posted videos, including one from the location where Babbitt was shot, according to court documents. In one video, Peterson can allegedly be seen using his fist to smash a window on the outside of the Capitol and shouting, “This is our house. Let us in. Our house.”
charges: Obstructing an Official Proceeding; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Peterson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say that Brian Glenn Bingham came to their attention after multiple people who served in the Army with Bingham reported him to law enforcement. On Jan. 6, 2021, charging documents state, Bingham was among the rioters who breached the U.S. Capitol and posted photos from inside the building to Facebook. At one point, he reached the door to the Speaker's Lobby, where a U.S. Capitol Police officer had earlier shot and killed rioter Ashli Babbitt, and Bingham began yelling at police nearby, according to court documents. Bingham also allegedly attacked a police officer inside the Capitol, who was trying to push him out of the building. Footage from surveillance cameras and police body cameras allegedly show Bingham appearing "to throw a punch or a shove at the officer with his right arm" and scratching the officer's eye before other officers pulled him away and Bingham eventually left the building. Prosecutors cite a Facebook message Bingham allegedly sent later that day: "I got to manhandl[e] 5 cops and live to tell."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bingham pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Casey Cusick is the vice president of a church in Melbourne, Fla., according to federal court records. On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, he entered the U.S. Capitol building and can be seen on surveillance footage taken from inside the building. Cusick breached the Capitol along with his father, James Varnell Cusick, Jr., who is the founder and pastor of the church, as well as another man who is one of the church's members, court records indicate. The FBI received an anonymous letter in March tipping law enforcement off to the Cusicks' alleged breach of the Capitol. Both men were arrested on June 24, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cusick pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: James Varnell Cusick, Jr. is the founder and pastor of a church in Melbourne, Fla., according to federal court records. On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors allege, he entered the U.S. Capitol building and can be seen on surveillance footage taken from inside the building. Cusick breached the Capitol along with his son, Casey, who is a vice president of the church, as well as another man who is one of the church's members, court documents indicate. In March, the FBI received an anonymous letter tipping law enforcement off to the Cusicks' alleged breach of the Capitol. Both men were arrested on June 24, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cusick pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Footage inside the U.S. Capitol building allegedly shows Jamie Buteau throwing a chair at two U.S. Capitol Police officers as they are retreating from the crowd, hitting one of the officers. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI identifying both Jamie Buteau and his wife, Jennifer Peck Buteau, as having been inside the building on Jan. 6, 2021, based on live videos they posted on Facebook that were later deleted, according to court documents. Other footage also allegedly shows Jamie Buteau dragging a second chair after the first incident, which he ends up leaving in one of the hallways. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the husband and wife.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Buteau pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jennifer Peck Buteau entered the U.S. Capitol building, alongside her husband, through a broken door on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Her husband is allegedly seen on footage from inside the Capitol assaulting two police officers by throwing a chair at them, and hitting one, as they were trying to move away from the rioters. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI and reported that Buteau had posted live Facebook videos from within the building that she later deleted. “Antifa was infiltrating Trump supporters for the cameras, to cause Chaos,” Buteau allegedly wrote on Facebook. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the couple.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Buteau pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors allege that Geoffrey Sills assaulted multiple law enforcement officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. According to the government, Sills can be seen on police body camera footage and other videos throwing "pole-like objects" at officers trying to protect the outside of the Capitol. Later, Sills allegedly joined rioters inside the Capitol, where he "repeatedly struck multiple police officers with an extended baton while using a strobe light, apparently to try to disorient the officers," according to the Justice Department. Sills was arrested on June 18, 2021, in Virginia.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon (pole-like object, baton); Robbery and Aiding and Abetting (baton); Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: At a stipulated bench trial on 8/23/2022, Sills was found Guilty of Robbery; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. He admitted to a stipulated set of facts.

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that David Lesperance breached the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and can be seen on both surveillance footage and police body camera video inside the building. According to the charging documents, Lesperance gave a voluntary interview to FBI agents and admitted that he entered the Capitol along with the pastor of his church, who is identified in separate court documents as James Cusick, Jr. During that interview, Lesperance allegedly admitted that he took photos and videos from inside the Capitol, but said that he later deleted them due to fear of repercussions. He was arrested on June 24, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lesperance pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, a little after 2:10 p.m., a U.S. Capitol Police officer is seen on a YouTube video being sprayed with what law enforcement identified as bear mace outside the Capitol building, according to court documents. As the officer attempts to go after the individual who sprayed her, Shane Jason Woods, who goes by the alias Shane Castleman, can allegedly be seen tripping and pushing the officer, who falls to the ground and loses her helmet. Several hours later, Woods is reportedly seen on a different video shouting and spitting at journalists who had their equipment broken by the crowd. He is also later seen tripping a cameraman who falls to the ground, court documents indicate. Woods reportedly traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to the FBI, Woods is the owner of Auburn Heating and Air Conditioning LLC.
charges: Civil Disorder; Striking, Beating, and Wounding within the Territorial Jurisdiction of the United States; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in Restricted Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds; Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction
case_updates: Woods pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI began looking into Lois McNicoll after receiving a tip from a work colleague who recognized her in a social media photo about the U.S. Capitol insurrection, court documents indicate. In images presented by federal law enforcement, McNicoll can allegedly be seen on CCTV surveillance video taking photos or video from inside the Capitol with her cellphone. The surveillance footage also shows that she wore a flag on her shoulders -- a variation of the California state flag with the words "Trump Country" on it. The FBI interviewed McNicoll at her workplace in May of 2021, and she allegedly told them that she had been inside the Capitol after the doors had been forced open by others. She claims not to have taken photos or videos while inside the Capitol, which is inconsistent with surveillance footage, the FBI said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McNicoll pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building. Sentencing set for 9/6/2022

summary: "I was one of the first 15 people in the #Capitol. Wild stuff," reads a tweet that the FBI says was written by Mitchell Vukich. Seven online tips sent to federal law enforcement identified Vukich as someone who had bragged about being inside the U.S. Capitol during the insurrection. A subsequent search warrant found that Vukich's cellphone was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In addition, a person who looks like Vukich was identified on surveillance video inside the building. During an interview at the Las Vegas airport, Vukich told the FBI that he had been inside the Capitol and took congressional paperwork from the premises, according to court documents.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vukich pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/5/2022 to 30 days incarceration; Special Assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500.00

summary: “Did u see the woman that got shot,” someone texted Sandra Pomeroy Weyer the day after the siege on the U.S. Capitol. “Hope you guys had nothing to do with the riots they were all hoodlums And traitors,” the person wrote, according to an FBI criminal complaint. “I seen no riots,” Weyer allegedly responded. “I saw Patriots sick of being lied to and the election being stolen from us! I saw no violence from Patriots!” That, according to a criminal complaint filed against Weyer, may not be exactly true. According to court papers, Weyer looked on as a handful of men accosted a New York Times photographer inside the Capitol that day and then stole her camera. Weyer allegedly recorded the assault on a Facebook live feed, and court papers say that on the recording, Weyer can be heard yelling, “Get her out, mace her,” as the photographer tries to get her camera back. In another video recorded from outside the Capitol that day, Weyer is allegedly shown joining the crowd chanting “let us in” and “break that door.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Weyer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “Things got a little crazy,” Mitchell Todd Gardner II allegedly told someone he met a few weeks after the U.S. Capitol riot. According to a criminal complaint filed against him, Gardner told this person that he had been at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. That unnamed person, court papers say, called an FBI tip line and identified Gardner as one of the rioters. Prosecutors say they have photographs and videos that show Gardner in a red Trump hat with some sort of canister in his hand. The images allegedly show him standing on a window ledge on the Senate side of the Capitol. He’s seen on video, court papers say, damaging a window with the canister and then spraying U.S. Capitol Police with its contents. Prosecutors described Gardner as having taken a “defacto leadership role” in the melee that day at the Capitol.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gardner pleaded Guilty to three charges: Civil Disorder, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. Sentencing set for 10/21/2022

summary: Nicholas Perretta’s movements through the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, can be seen on surveillance footage, court documents indicate. Perretta’s image was captured walking through multiple locations in the building with another individual, Mitchell Vukich, who was also charged. When Vukich was presented with images from the videos, he admitted to his own involvement and positively identified Perretta as well. FBI agents say that Perretta later explained that he had travelled to Washington, D.C., with Vukich, where they attended the earlier pro-Trump rally, before heading to the Capitol. While inside, Perretta admitted that the two took papers from the building, which he described as “three-month-old congressional papers” and later disposed of them outside the Capitol.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Perretta pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/5/2022 to 30 days incarceration; special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution of $500.00

summary: Court documents allege that the FBI was tipped off to Samuel Fox’s involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot by a college friend of his. The tipster saw him post pictures from inside the U.S. Capitol on his Facebook feed. A screenshot in the court papers of the Facebook post show the images, along with this caption: "Al [sic] the lefties pissing and moaning right now can take comfort in the fact we walked into a building that was ours instead of using politics to loot stores, We actually have reasons to be there, not virtue signalling twitter points.... I’d do it again, fight me.” The FBI says that surveillance footage of Jan. 6, 2021, show someone they identify as Fox from inside the Capitol, showing that he entered through a broken window, and more images of him using his cellphone to capture photos or video. Later, using a search warrant to get records from Google, the FBI used Fox’s cellphone to find his geographic location at the time of the riot and confirmed that the area included the inside of the Capitol building. A search warrant served to Facebook by FBI agents unearthed deleted posts from Fox had been preserved by the company, including one comment from Fox, reading: “The capitol wasnt overthrown we were let in.”
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fox pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/5/2022 to 36 months of Probation with 60 days  home detention/location monitoring; a special assessment of $10, a fine of $2,500, and restitution of $500

summary: According to the affidavit, four tipsters contacted the FBI to report that John Hubert Getsinger Jr. and Stacie Ann Hargis-Getsinger traveled to Washington, D.C., from South Carolina for the rally on Jan. 6, 2021. One tipster described a video of the pair allegedly entering the U.S. Capitol saying, “This is War! We’re storming the Capitol!” Once inside the Capitol, the charging document says, John Getsinger Jr. appeared to use his cellphone as they walked around the Rotunda. Once they left the Rotunda, the person believed to be John Getsinger Jr. “is seen holding hands with an individual who law enforcement believes to be Stacie Getsinger.” A screenshot of alleged Facebook exchanges between John Getsinger Jr. and others written a few days after the riot acknowledged his presence in the Capitol, according to court documents. One person wrote “Okay, as long as they don’t have you on camera doing any damage, all you did was get pushed with the crowd into the halls.” John Getsinger Jr. replied “Yep and yell a lot.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Getsinger pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/12/2022 to 60 days incarceration; 3 years Probation; Restitution of $500; Special Assessment of $10

summary: According to the affidavit, four tipsters contacted the FBI to report that John Hubert Getsinger Jr. and Stacie Ann Hargis-Getsinger traveled to Washington, D.C., for the protest on Jan. 6, 2021. One tipster described a video of them entering the U.S. Capitol saying, “This is War! We’re storming the Capitol!”  A screen capture of an alleged Facebook post by Stacie Hargis-Getsinger says they went to the Capitol after President Trump’s speech and saw the large group moving up the steps toward the door. “I only saw 2 or 3 people who looked even remotely like antifa members. The Capital bldg. is the peoples house. WE the citizens own it,” she allegedly wrote. “Once it was stormed we also went inside.” After comparing screenshots of social media conversations, CCTV footage from the Capitol and South Carolina DMV photos, federal officials charged the couple.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hargis-Getsinger pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/12/2022 to 60 days incarceration; 3 years Probation; Restitution of $500; Special Assessment of $10

summary: The charges brought against Zvonimir Jurlina center on events that happened in the late afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, at the media staging area outside the northeast corner of the U.S. Capitol. An individual, identified by the FBI as Jurlina and seen in photographs posted on the FBI's website, participated in an assault on the area where the media had gathered. Jurlina allegedly incited "violent acts," along with others in the crowd, that forced members of the media to disperse and abandon their equipment. The photos show him allegedly kicking and stomping on equipment belonging to media outlets and assisting in an attempt to set fire to some of the equipment. In a 12-part video series livestreamed on YouTube, Jurlina documents the incidents cited in the charging documents, including a moment where Jurlina says, “This is reporter Zykotik coming to you live. We are, haha. This is the real news media network. We have taken over. This is mother f**king America first."
charges: Destruction of Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction and Aiding and Abetting; Act of Physical Violence on Grounds

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6, 2021. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21."  Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators.
charges:
Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and
Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Grods pleaded Guilty to Conspiracy and Obstruction Of An Official Proceeding.

summary: Evan Neumann, prosecutors allege, is one of the rioters who engaged law enforcement in a prolonged struggle near a bike rack barricade in front of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Body camera footage allegedly shows Neumann wearing a red “Make America Great Again” hat and wearing a gas mask for some of the time, and yelling at one officer a common QAnon conspiracy theory that the officer is “defending the people who are going to kill your f**king children ... they are gonna kill your f**king children, they are gonna rape them, they are gonna imprison them, and you’re defending the people that are going to do this to your children.” According to court documents, Neumann refused orders by police to move back, and later, after a violent back and forth over the barricade along with other rioters, wrested it from the officers’ hands and used it as a battering ram to break the police line. FBI agents say they identified Neumann in multiple ways: via an anonymous tipster claiming to be a family friend, by comparing passport photos and social media profiles, and by analyzing data obtained from Google that places a mobile device with a number that Neumann confirmed was his geographically within the Capitol at the time of the riot on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Influencing, Impeding, or Retaliating Against a Federal Official; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Neumann fled to Belarus and applied for asylum there. He was granted asylum in March, 2022. On 3/11/2022, Neumann's case was directly reassigned to the Calendar Committee as the defendant is a fugitive.

summary: According to court papers and news coverage of the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, there were numerous reports of news media members who were targeted for harassment and threats.  Gabriel Brown, prosecutors allege, was one of the people identified as participating in an assault on a media staging area outside of the U.S. Capitol building. Brown is allegedly seen on a publicly available YouTube video recording his own view of events and trying to smash cameras and other media equipment; he can also be heard saying to someone,  “my name’s Gabriel Brown GB0083 YouTube channel.” Additionally, the FBI alleges, he can be heard pushing others to destroy and steal equipment, and saying: “F*** the AP. You f***ing frauds. You want to f***ing lie about all of us. Well, you know what, here, report this s***! Because your f***ing media is dead mother f***er. It’s dead, the legacy media is dead.”  Brown was identified by multiple tips that indicate he was well-known in his community. In addition, another video posted on Twitter shows a man whom the FBI identifies as Brown, in which he signs a “Stop the Steal” banner with the words: “Gabriel Brown Freedom!!”
charges: Destruction or Injury to Buildings or Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Violence on the U.S. Capitol Grounds

summary: Prosecutors allege that the FBI received tips from at least four people that Timothy Hart was part of the riot at the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. One person reported that not only did Hart film the riot, but that he also filmed himself driving from Ohio to Washington, D.C. Court documents allege that Hart was among the rioters who helped to remove barricades surrounding the Capitol building and can be seen on the stairs telling others to come nearer to the building. An Instagram video posted to an account called “brotunda" allegedly appears to show Hart inside the Capitol, smoking what investigators infer was marijuana, wearing a sweatshirt bearing a large “Q."  FBI agents say they were able to identify Hart via subscriber information for his YouTube channel and a linked mobile phone that was subscribed to his wife, Stephanie Hart. Hart is the owner of a paintball center in Ohio.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hart pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Publicly available videos show Ricky Christopher Willden cheering at the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021 near the east door around 2:30 in the afternoon, wearing a dark jacket, beanie cap and gloves, according to court documents. About10 minutes later, he can be seen raising his hand and spraying an unknown substance from a green can toward police officers standing guard. According to the FBI, Willden is a self-proclaimed member of the  far right-extremist group The Proud Boys, whose members describe themselves as "Western Chauvinists."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Willden pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers. Sentenced 8/5/2022 to 24 months incarceration; three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution; $100 special assessment

summary: A witness contacted the FBI identifying Steven Thurlow as having been inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The witness also provided screenshots of Thurlow’s Facebook posts, including one in which he is seen wearing camouflage tactical gear with a “Boogaloo” patch on his chest. The extremist Boogaloo movement anticipates a second civil war in America, and some adherents even seek to bring about that conflict. “Ahh nothing like a new pair of 511’s and fresh set of level IV SAPI’s in the plate carrier to go “peacefully protest” with, the caption to the picture read, referring to a high-level ballistic body armor plate, Thurlow had allegedly purchased. According to the FBI, Thurlow served in the Army from 1988 until 1991. A second witness told the FBI that Thurlow had become something of a “conspiracy theorist” after joining the military. Inside the Capitol building, photos show Thurlow lying on what appears to be a conference room table. He is also seen walking around the hallways recording on his cellphone, wearing a camouflage jacket, a yellow scarf and white rimmed sunglasses.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Thurlow pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 8/30/2022.

summary: A little more than a month after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, the FBI received a tip from the Sedition Hunters that Chase Kevin Allen had been at the riot that day, court documents indicate. The tipster provided a photo from a Facebook page called "The Allen Report" where Allen can allegedly be seen wearing a white Boston Red Sox beanie and a camouflage backpack. Law enforcement recognized that outfit from YouTube videos of a previously unidentified young man stomping on and smashing media equipment outside the Capitol, according to court documents. In one of those videos, Allen can allegedly be heard yelling multiple times: "Get the f*** out of here" after a journalist repeatedly said, “We are leaving.” In a May interview with law enforcement, Allen said he runs a YouTube channel called "The Allen Report" and "considers himself to be a documentary filmmaker" who travels across the country to film events. Allen said that he did not enter the Capitol and that he did not destroy any media equipment, court documents indicate. He also said that he "sometimes does things while filming among groups like those at the U.S. Capitol to fit in and cause those around him to believe that he is one of them." He told police the worst thing he did was "use foul language."
charges: Destruction or Injury to Buildings or Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; Act of Physical Violence on Grounds

summary: Noah Bacon was reported to the FBI after he allegedly appeared in a video published by The New Yorker. In the video, prosecutors say, Bacon can be seen opening a door to the balcony area of the U.S. Senate Chamber inside the Capitol for himself and others. Bacon allegedly spent about 10 minutes in the chamber, sitting in the back row in an "I ♥ Trump" t-shirt, fist-bumping others. Verizon phone records obtained by the FBI also place Bacon in the Capitol that day, as does security camera footage, court documents indicate. On Instagram the day before the riot, Bacon allegedly posted about his plans to go to "Trump's special Jan 6th event" and that "we are on the precipice of something beautiful."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct at the Grounds and in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Bacon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors allege that at least two people called the FBI to report that Timothy Earl O'Malley had been at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and that one of those tipsters said O'Malley has previously identified himself as a Proud Boy. In an interview with the FBI, O'Malley said that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Florida to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to court documents, O'Malley wore a red softball batting helmet with a "Trump is my president" bumper sticker on the side, because he said he had heard that antifa followers had sacks of rocks they were planning to throw. In his interview, O'Malley described the scene at the Capitol as "mayhem" and admitted to entering the building, where he can allegedly also be seen on security camera footage. The FBI also obtained videos from O'Malley's cellphone through a warrant. In one video, O'Malley allegedly yells, "WE FOUGHT OUR WAY, ALL THE WAY IN THERE. AND WE FOUGHT OUR WAY BACK OUT ... WE SWARMED THE CAPITOL, THOUGH. HOT DAMN."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: O'Malley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/12/2022 to 2 years of Probation; 20 hours of community service; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Joshua Haynes, federal prosecutors allege, appears in a black hat and yellow bandanna in images taken in and around the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. He was allegedly part of a group seen in publicly available video attacking members of the media at a staging area outside the Capitol. Haynes is reportedly depicted slamming a video camera on a tripod to the ground and stomping on it. Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."
charges: Obstruction of Proceedings; Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Haynes pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, the FBI received at least seven tips that Jonathan Laurens was inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Federal prosecutors allege he wore a bright orange winter hat, a black face mask and a “Trump 2020: No More Bulls***” flag as a cape. Court documents include a number of images that seem to show Laurens inside the Capitol. Documents also show that Laurens posted to his Facebook page about the riot, saying, “we got into the capitol (sic), walked around, chanted some slogans and stuff. A few bad apples were trying to break windows and kick on doors, but most of us put that s**t to bed real fast. We weren’t there to tear s**t up, just disrupt the system. All in all, I had fun! Lol.” Prosecutors say Laurens’ account was public when they reviewed it in April and posts related to the riot were still visible. The FBI also served Facebook with a search warrant for Laurens’ account. A review of the account turned up a selfie Laurens took with the Lansdowne portrait of George Washington in what appears to be the Rayburn Reception Room inside the Capitol, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Laurens pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/10/2022 to 60 days of home detention, 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $742 fine, $500 in restitution, $10 special assessment

summary: At least three people contacted the FBI after seeing posts on Trevor Brown's Facebook and Instagram accounts indicating he participated in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol, including breaching the building, according to court documents. Brown is allegedly seen in multiple videos from the day, including one where he is yelling through a bullhorn as rioters attempt to breach a tunnel going into the building, court documents indicate. Shortly after that video was taken, police apprehended Brown and placed him in handcuffs, but he was later released without any charges being filed. On Jan. 7, 2021, Brown allegedly posted on Facebook, "People should be storming that Brothel we call the Capitol everyday for what goes on in there. ... Today thise [sic] elitist creeps are getting the same thing we live with everyday, fear for their own safety." In another post, he reportedly wrote, "I made it into the Capitol. I almost died getting in but I made it.” Since at least November, Brown had posted content on social media that questioned the legitimacy of the presidential election, court documents indicate.
charges: Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brown pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: On Dec. 12, 2020, George Amos Tenney III reportedly wrote to another person on Facebook asking about plans for Jan. 6, 2021: "What’s up in DC??? Rally?? Trump??? What’s going on? I wanna be involved!!” Two days later, he reportedly asked the same person: “Where and how do I get involved or a part of one of these patriot revolution groups? Like proud boys, or any of the other American Patriot militias??” The two planned to drive to Washington, D.C., together and split the cost of a hotel room, court documents indicate. On Dec. 28, 2021, Tenney wrote, "We need to talk about the trip to D.C. … It’s starting to look like we may siege the capital building and congress if the electoral votes don’t go right. ... [W]e are forming plans for every scenario.” In an interview with the FBI, Tenney admitted he entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but that as soon as he "realized that something bad was happening," he left, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege Tenney told the FBI he "did not think he was doing anything wrong at the time, but, in hindsight, wishes he had not gone inside the Capitol Building." Videos and security camera footage from that day allegedly show Tenney, and another defendant, Darrell Alan Youngers, entering the building together. In one video, contrary to Tenney's claims, he can reportedly be seen helping rioters inside the building and grabbing and pushing police officers.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tenney pleaded Guilty to two charges: Civil Disorder and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding. Sentencing set for 10/20/2022

summary: “Non violent disobedience is how you take your lives back. You’re [sic] freedom isn’t being taken, it’s being given away," Darrell Alan Youngers reportedly wrote on Facebook above a picture of a toppled fence and sign that read “Area Closed.” "Open your business, go to work, live your life." The photo was posted minutes before Youngers entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents say. According to the FBI, Youngers, who was wearing a jacket with the phrase “Semper Fi," served in the U.S. Marine Corps and the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve. Closed-circuit TV footage reportedly shows Youngers and George Amos Tenney III enter through the Senate Wing Door. Later, both men are seen having an altercation with a U.S. Capitol Police officer as the officer tries to prevent Tenney from opening a door and letting rioters outside the doors into the East Foyer, court documents indicate. Both men reportedly attended the "Save America" rally earlier that day.
charges: Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Youngers pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.  Sentencing set for 8/22/2022

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, David Moerschel and nine other members of the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers moved in a tactical military formation used by infantryman up the stairs to the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. Footage reportedly shows Moerschel wearing a long-sleeved black jacket and backward green baseball cap with Oath Keepers insignia. The group has been known to target and recruit active-duty members of the military and veterans, in part for their specialized skills. According to the FBI, the Oath Keepers believe a cabal of elites has co-opted the federal government by actively trying to strip Americans of their rights. Credit card transactions and intercepted messaging platforms reportedly show group members coordinated their actions ahead of the Jan. 6, 2021 rally, allegedly bringing weapons with them. According to court documents, they stored firearms at a northern Virginia hotel they referred to as “QRF,” or Quick Reaction Force. The FBI says the government obtained surveillance video from the Comfort Inn Ballston on Jan. 7, 2021, showing three individuals wheeling a concierge cart with at least one long gun case onto an elevator. Moerschel reportedly appears to be one of the individuals. The government was able to gain access to a Signal group messaging account used by members of the Oath Keepers, including Moerschel, who wrote under the name "Hatsy."  A search warrant executed on the number used by that user connected the FBI to Moerschel, court documents say.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Moerschel pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Alan William Byerly assaulted a photographer for The Associated Press and also used a Taser or Taser-like device "meant to deliver a debilitating electric shock" to assault police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Byerly, court papers say, charged toward a police line in front of the West Terrace of the Capitol while activating the Taser-type device; police were able to remove the device from Byerly, but he continued to "physically strike, and push against officers," court documents say. At the time, Byerly was allegedly wearing a hat with the logo "Kutztown," which prosecutors believe is a reference to a Pennsylvania town a few miles from where Byerly lives. Separately, around that time, Byerly is accused of joining members of a violent mob that pushed, shoved and dragged the AP photographer outside the Capitol. After the FBI posted photos of the incident and requested tips from the public, a witness reportedly contacted investigators. Byerly was arrested on July 7, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Grounds Using and Carrying a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Grounds Using and Carrying a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Physical Violence in Restricted Grounds Using and Carrying a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds; Striking, Beating or Wounding of Another Person within the Territorial Jurisdiction; Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction
case_updates: Byerly pleaded Guilty to two charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; and Striking, Beating or Wounding of Another Person within the Territorial Jurisdiction. Sentencing is set for 10/21/2022

summary: Less than two weeks after the U.S. Capitol riot, a tipster told the FBI that Kenneth John Reda had posted on the social media platform Parler (under the username "mrjoebidenhead") about breaching the Capitol that day, court papers say. Investigators then served search warrants to Google and Verizon and received location data that allegedly shows Reda was present at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Surveillance footage from inside the Capitol also allegedly shows Reda inside the building. Parler posts from Reda cited by investigators in court documents provide additional information about Reda's possible motivation: He posted in December that "it is IMPERATIVE every single person that VOTED for Trump has to flood DC" on Jan. 6, 2021, and separately, "we need to get together and organize against this KABAL [sic] we need to overthrow it." In one message cited in the court papers, Reda used the hashtag "#WWG1WGA," which refers to a phrase used by supporters of the pro-Trump conspiracy theory QAnon: "Where We Go One, We Go All." Reda was arrested on July 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Reda pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced to 3 years probation; 60 days home detention/location monitoring; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: Reddit users dubbed Edward Francisco Rodriguez “#SUITMACER” based on a video in which he sprays a chemical irritant at law enforcement officers while dressed in a suit, federal prosecutors say. Videos on Reddit and Twitter also showed Rodriguez giving interviews to reporters, according to court documents. In one video, the FBI says Rodriguez said, “Here in America, we fight back. We will never surrender to dictatorship, corruption, communism or socialism. We the people will never put up with their bullshit.” Court documents show that tipsters identified Rodriguez based on his Century 21 Real Estate profile. The FBI says two former co-workers were also able to confirm Rodriguez’s identity in the videos.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Rodriguez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Matthew Thomas Purse wore a tactical vest and helmet emblazoned with the word “PRESS,” according to federal prosecutors, despite no known media employment history. Court documents show the FBI identified Purse by his “PRESS" attire, as well as a long black pole he carried that seemed to have a recording device at the end. Photos seem to show Purse entering the U.S. Capitol, standing in the rotunda and exiting after the “crowd became more volatile,” according to court documents. Federal prosecutors say a confidential source described a Twitch livestream in which Purse said, “Mission accomplished — we broke into the Capitol” and admitted he wasn’t a member of the press. The FBI says that it located a privately owned mail facility where Purse rents a mailbox and that an employee there was able to identify photos of Purse in his “PRESS” helmet.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Purse pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, at approximately 2:04 p.m., footage shows a line of police officers with riot shields trying to guard the west side of the U.S. Capitol from the advancing crowds, according to court documents. Michael Steven Perkins, alongside several other individuals, is allegedly seen engaging in multiple altercations with the police, including thrusting a flagpole into the chest of an officer who is trying to assist other officers. According to the FBI, he is then seen raising the same flagpole over his head and striking the officer in the back or the back of the head. The Justice Department says Perkins was arrested on June 30, 2021, alongside three other individuals.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Perkins pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Joseph Daniel Hutchinson III was identified to the FBI by a witness who was familiar with two other people charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol — Olivia and Jonathan Pollock. Around 2 p.m. on the day of the attack, Hutchinson, along with a group of others with whom he is charged, including the Pollocks, was allegedly located on the west side of the Capitol behind a police barricade. Hutchinson can be seen on police body camera footage grabbing the barricade and pulling it away, "providing rioters with unobstructed access to the line of police officers," according to court records. Later on, Hutchinson can reportedly be seen charging at officers and "directing punches" at their faces. Later still, Jonathan Pollock allegedly seized a police riot shield, and as Hutchinson supported him from behind, Pollock thrust the bottom edge at an officer's throat or face. Hutchinson can also reportedly be seen throwing an officer out of his way in the crowd of rioters. According to the witness who identified Hutchinson to the FBI, Hutchinson works at the Pollock family's gun shop in Lakeland, Fla.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Hutchinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Joshua Christopher Doolin, carrying zip tie handcuffs and an chemical irritant canister, was allegedly seen yelling at police officers, along with a group of others with whom he is charged, on the west side of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. At one point, Doolin charged up the Capitol steps brandishing a flagpole that he pointed at officers, according to court documents. Doolin was reportedly deterred by a chemical spray and dropped the flagpole.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Doolin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Various footage taken in front of the U.S. Capitol reportedly shows Olivia Michele Pollock wearing a green headband and a tan ballistic plate-carrier vest with distinctive patches on the front, according to court documents. A little after 2 p.m., Pollock is seen carrying a flagpole alongside another individual who punches a police officer, court documents indicate. She is then allegedly seen attempting to strip a baton off a different officer. After briefly being knocked back in the altercation, she can reportedly be seen getting up and raising her hands in a fighting position, elbowing the officer in the chest and trying to again strip the baton from the officer. According to the FBI, an hour later she is seen having advanced past the metal barriers and up to the upper west terrace of the building. According to the Justice Department, Pollock, alongside three other individuals, was arrested at the end of June 2021.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Pollock pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, multiple images and police body camera footage taken at the U.S. Capitol show Jonathan Daniel Pollock wearing a ballistic plate-carrier vest, camouflage-patterned shirt and pants, green kneepads and brown tactical gloves, according to court documents. Pollock, alongside another individual, is allegedly seen brandishing flagpoles and charging toward a police line protecting the west side of the building. According to the FBI, after police wrestled the poles away, Pollock fell backward into the crowd. He then reportedly got up, threw his shoulder against the fence separating the police from the crowd and screamed “Let’s go.” Once the fence fell, Pollock can allegedly be seen jumping over the rioters to attack the officers, grabbing one around his waist and pulling the officer down. According to court documents, Pollock is also seen punching two more officers in the face, holding one officer’s neck in a choking action and pulling a riot shield away from another officer and then slamming it into the police line. Later, he is also seen thrusting the bottom edge of a shield into an officer’s throat or face, court documents indicate. In the next two hours, Pollock reportedly moved closer to the building and blocked the entrance to a tunnel leading into the Capitol, not allowing officers to advance out of it. In January of 2021, a co-worker of Pollock called the FBI, identifying him and reporting that he took several weeks off in January to travel to Washington, D.C., with his family. The witness also said immediately once Pollock returned to work, he bragged to his colleagues about his participation on Jan. 6, 2021. On his second day back to work, Pollock called in to report a family emergency and never returned. According to the witness, a separate employee had to go to Pollock’s home address to recover keys and items belonging to the company. Pollock remains at large, according to the Justice Department.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Pollock remains at large. The FBI has offered a $15,000 reward for information on his whereabouts.

summary: Fi Duong was reportedly first identified on the morning of Jan. 6 by an undercover officer with the Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department. Duong asked whether the undercover officer was a "patriot," and he identified himself as an "operator," according to court documents. The undercover officer later saw Duong in a restricted area of the U.S. Capitol but did not engage with him, court documents indicate. After identifying and connecting Duong's email and phone to his whereabouts, the Metropolitan Police Department officer introduced him to an undercover FBI agent. Duong opened up to the agent, reportedly saying he was part of a group he compared to a known militia group in Northern Virginia. According to the FBI, he said he had thought about going to Texas but decided against it, saying: "I grew up here. My blood is Virginia and I’d hate to leave it. ... For me, you can only run for so long, eventually you got to make a stand. I spent, my family spent two generations running from communists. First in China and then in Vietnam, now we’re here. And at a certain point, you just gotta make a stand.” The undercover FBI agent reportedly continued his relationship with Duong, who eventually told the agent he had been at the Capitol and had video of it. The FBI agent also went to Duong's house, where they met with the militia group they had discussed, and preparations for group activities were made, including a plan to get a private chat server to keep communications within the group secure, court documents indicate. The FBI observed firearms and ammunition boxes at Duong's house, and Duong often expressed interest to engage in violence and conflict, and interest in explosive and destructive devices, according to court documents. Duong continued conversations about surveillance of the U.S. Capitol into February, and in March brought into the group a person alleged to be a member of the Three Percenters, a far-right extremist group. Duong also allegedly continued to share information about his activities on the day of the riot, including videos he had taken. By June, the FBI agent was talking with him regularly about testing Molotov cocktails, and Duong reportedly said, "At a certain point, as a man ... you’re gonna have to stand your ground and say no ... and technically, you’re engaging in war or conflict, but again, what is the price we ultimately pay for peace?"
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Duong pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Dawn Munn was allegedly at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with four other members of her family who are also charged in the riot and an unnamed child who is not charged. According to news reports, Dawn Munn is the mother of three of the Munns charged (Joshua, Kristi and Kayli) and partner to Thomas Munn. On Jan. 6, 2021, an additional family member, who appears not to have been at the Capitol and has not been charged, posted photos of some of the Munn family members, including the caption: "The biggest and best female empowerment I have ever seen before in my life!!!! ... These women stormed OUR capital and demanded OUR House and Country back!!!!" Security footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, also indicates that Dawn Munn entered the building with other family members, court documents indicate. Dawn Munn was also identified by an employee at a college in Borger, Texas, who had taught both her and her daughter Kristi Munn. On Jan. 6, 2021, in a Facebook conversation the FBI obtained, Dawn Munn allegedly wrote: “We were in capital!! … I do mean IN the building!!”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Dawn Munn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 8/19/2022

summary: Joshua Munn was allegedly at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with his parents and two sisters, who are all also charged in relation to the riot, and one unnamed child who is not charged. Security footage from inside the building that day indicate that Joshua Munn entered the Capitol with other members of his family, according to court documents, and he also allegedly appeared in a video livestreamed from inside the Capitol by the far-right extremist known as "Baked Alaska." On Jan. 6, 2021, Joshua Munn reportedly posted on Facebook, “Before you hear it on the news ... family marched on DC today it was extremely cool we did enter the Capitol building." Cellphone records that the FBI obtained from Verizon also place Joshua Munn inside the Capitol that day, court documents indicate. According to news reports, Joshua Munn lives in Wisconsin, while the others charged in his family live in Texas.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Joshua Munn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing hearing scheduled for 8/18/2022

summary: Kayli Munn was allegedly at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021,  with her parents and two siblings, who are all also charged in relation to the riot, and an unidentified child who was not charged. Security footage from that day places her inside the building with the other four members of her family, according to court documents. Kayli Munn was also identified, along with some other family members, by two employees at a high school in Borger, Texas, both of whom had taught her and other Munn children. In a Jan. 6, 2021, Facebook conversation obtained by the FBI, Kayli Munn allegedly responded to the question, “How’s the March," by answering, “F***ing great! Holy s*** we were inside the f***ing capital!” Cellphone records obtained by the FBI from Verizon also place Kayli Munn inside the Capitol that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kayli Munn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 8/18/2022

summary: Kristi Munn was allegedly at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with her parents and two siblings, who are also charged in the riot, and one other child who was not charged. A tipster contacted the FBI after seeing posts on Kristi Munn's Facebook and Snapchat accounts that indicated she had been at the rally and later at the riot, including one photo that was captioned, "Washington D.C. here we come… #StopTheSteal #TrumpIsMyPresident.” On Jan. 26, 2021, in an interview with the FBI, Kristi Munn admitted to going to the Capitol but denied going inside, according to court documents. However, videos from that day place her inside the building, the court documents say. On Jan. 7, 2021, in a message on Facebook obtained by the FBI, Kristi Munn allegedly wrote, “We were in the capital !! … Just keep that bit of info on the DL for right now.” Cellphone records obtained by the FBI from AT&T also place Kristi Munn inside the Capitol that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kristi Munn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 8/18/2022

summary: Thomas Munn was allegedly at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with four other members of his family who are also charged in relation to the riot, and a child who is not charged. According to news reports, Thomas Munn is the father of three of the Munn family members charged (Joshua, Kristi and Kayli) and partner to Dawn Munn. On Dec. 28, 2020, Thomas Munn reportedly posted an image on Facebook that indicated that then-President Donald Trump had "requested your attendance" in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6. According to court documents, Thomas Munn captioned the image: “Our President has only asked two things from us, so far... #1 Vote #2 January 6, 2021.” On Jan. 5, 2021, he allegedly wrote on Facebook, “We made it to our hotel just outside DC … 1,600 miles in 24 hrs!” and included a photo of a trailer passed on the highway with a sign that said, "D.C. Bound. We are Q." On the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, he posted a photo of himself with the four other family members charged and the child who has not been identified, court documents indicate. He reportedly wrote: "Made it back to the hotel about an hour ago . . . Have lots of pics and video to follow. ... The only damage to the capital building was several windows and sets of doors. Nothing inside the capital was damaged. I can tell you, patriots NEVER made it to the chamber. There was no violence in the capital building, the crowd was NOT out of control . . . they were ANGRY!!!” Security footage from inside the Capitol that day indicate that Thomas Munn entered the building with his family, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Thomas Munn pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 8/19/2022

summary: In February, Erik Rau’s friend Derek Jancart was arrested in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, court documents show. Jancart told prosecutors he entered the U.S. Capitol with Rau, and the FBI says Jancart identified Rau in photos from the Capitol. On the same day of Jancart's arrest, Rau called the U.S. Marshals Service in Columbus, Ohio, asking to turn himself in, according to court documents. Both Jancart and Rau gave the FBI Rau’s phone number, according to prosecutors. The FBI says that it served a search warrant on Google, and that a mobile device associated with Rau’s number was determined to be in the Capitol for 39 minutes on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rau pleaded Guilty to one count of Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building. The other charges were dismissed. Sentenced 9/29/2021 to 45 days in jail; $10 assessment; and $500 restitution.

summary: Two tipsters who know Joshua Dressel identified him to the FBI, according to court documents. The first one saw video of Dressel inside the U.S. Capitol on MSNBC, prosecutors say. The second reportedly identified Dressel in stills from surveillance footage. The FBI says the first tipster also described a video on Dressel’s Facebook page that seemed to be from inside the Capitol and included chants of “Stop the Steal.” Dressel’s Facebook account seemed to be deleted by the time the FBI interviewed that tipster, but court documents show the FBI got records from Facebook, including a conversation between Dressel and another individual on Jan. 6, 2021. According to the FBI, Dressel wrote, “First 20 people or so to break into the Capitol,” and, “Lol I’m proud to say I was a voice of reason in there trying to stop the crazy s*** and calm things down.” The other individual asked, “Was there antifa f***s in there?” to which Dressel answered, “Yes,” according to the FBI. Prosecutors say the Facebook account shows a login on an IP address near Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The FBI also served a search warrant on Google and said it found a phone believed to be Dressel’s that was in and around the Capitol during the riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Dressel pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/22/2022

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Nathan Wayne Entrekin stood out among the crowd gathered in front of the Capitol. He sported a Roman gladiator costume in the 40-degree weather and waved a huge white flag with black letters that read: “IN MEMORY OF OUR GOD, OUR RELIGION, AND FREEDOM, AND OUR PEACE, OUR WIVES, AND OUR CHILDREN,” according to court documents. Entrekin, however was not dressed as Caesar, as many around him seemed to believe, but as Captain Moroni, a figure from the Book of Mormon, who Mormons believe sought to defend the liberties of his people — the Nephites. According to the FBI, Entrekin drove from Arizona to Washington, D.C., to attend President Trump’s rally, as he believed Trump to be the rightful presidential election winner. Entrekin arrived at the mall too late for the speech but made his way with the crowd to the Capitol and entered the building at least twice.  A video he took of himself shows he recorded everything live for his mother to watch upon his return home. “Wow, Mom. I wish you were here with me. It’s really exciting in here. It’s joyful and it’s sad at the same time. We can’t let Biden ... to be our president. We can’t ... there’s no way,” he can be heard saying on the video. Entrekin could also be seen pushing his way into Oregon Sen. Jeff Merkley’s office and shouting that he wanted ice cream.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Entrekin pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced to 45 days incarceration; 36 months Probation with conditions; $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500; 60 hours community service

summary: Kevin A. Tuck was a police officer with the Windermere Police Department in Windermere, Fla., until federal charges against Tuck and his son, Nathaniel Tuck, were unsealed in July. Both Tucks have been accused by federal authorities of breaching the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Nathaniel Tuck, the son, is also a former police officer and previously served with the Apopka Police Department in Apopka, Fla., though he had left the police department in 2020, prior to the Capitol riot. The chief of the Windermere Police Department told the Orlando Sentinel newspaper that he was "disheartened" by Kevin Tuck's arrest and that the agency would conduct an internal investigation. The Windermere Police Department confirmed to NPR Kevin Tuck's previous employment with the department.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tuck pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Nathaniel A. Tuck has been charged alongside his father, Kevin Tuck, and others with taking part in the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Both Tucks are former police officers. Nathaniel Tuck previously served with the Apopka Police Department in Apopka, Fla, according to a statement released by the department. He had left the police department in 2020, prior to the Capitol riot. "The Apopka Police Department became aware of the FBI’s investigation of Mr. Tuck and cooperated with their investigation," the department's statement states. Kevin Tuck, his father, was a police officer with the Windermere Police Department in Windermere, Fla. He resigned after the federal charges stemming from the Capitol riot were unsealed, according to the Windermere police department. Multiple news outlets have reported that Nathaniel Tuck expressed interest in joining the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys and had participated in online chats with the group. The Tucks are named in the same indictment as Arthur Jackman, a Florida man who has a Proud Boys tattoo on his left wrist, according to court documents.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Civil Disorder
case_updates: Tuck pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A nine-count indictment from early July 2021, names Edward George Jr. alongside four other defendants, two of whom identified themselves as members of the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys. According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, George allegedly assaulted a law enforcement officer and stole an American flag and flagpole. According to the FBI, George was arrested in North Carolina, but resides in Florida.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: George pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew DaSilva was identified to the FBI in February when he was recognized by somone he knows in a photo circulated by the FBI, according to court documents. The photo shows a man in a red hat, a blue and gray camouflage Navy jacket, and a black and gold scarf. The FBI said that DaSilva’s distinctive outfit can be seen in video footage of the front line of rioters and that DaSilva can be seen grabbing, pushing and pulling on shields held by law enforcement officers. Prosecutors say the tipster, as well as a second person who told the FBI about DaSilva, recognized the scarf as one DaSilva wore every day. The second tipster told the FBI that after DaSilva returned from Washington, D.C., he shaved his beard and cut his long hair. Court documents say DaSilva also stopped wearing the black and gold scarf.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: DaSilva pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Devlyn Thompson is charged with using a deadly and dangerous weapon, in his case a baton, and with assaulting a police officer on Jan. 6, 2021, at the U.S. Capitol.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon
