case_updates: Thompson pleaded Guilty to one felony count: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. Sentenced 12/20/2021 to 46 months with credit for time served; 36 months of supervised release; $100 special assessment; and $2,000 in restitution.

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Caleb Berry conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6, 2021. Berry allegedly participated in planning meetings with members of the group via both GoTo Meeting and the encrypted messaging app Signal. Prosecutors say that Berry and "and others known and unknown dropped off firearms at the Comfort Inn Ballston hotel in Arlington, Virginia" on Jan. 5, 2021, prior to the storming of the Capitol. During the storming of the Capitol, Berry allegedly helped form a military-style "stack" formation with other members of the Oath Keepers as they pushed up the stairs outside the Capitol and forced their way into the Rotunda. Later, after exiting the Capitol, Berry and other members of the Oath Keepers met together about 100 feet from the building, according to court papers. Berry agreed to cooperate with federal investigators as part of a plea agreement.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Berry pleaded guilty to one charge of Conspiracy and one charge of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding

summary: Mark Sami Ibrahim worked for the Drug Enforcement Administration as a special agent, and several weeks before Jan. 6, 2021, he had "given notice to the DEA of his intention to resign," according to charging documents. Then, while "on personal leave from the DEA" and not on duty for the government, he took part in the chaos in restricted areas outside the U.S. Capitol that day, prosecutors allege. Ibrahim "posed for several photographs in which he flashed and displayed his DEA badge and firearm" outside of the Capitol and entered into restricted areas outside the building, prosecutors say. He has not been accused of breaching the Capitol building. At one point, Ibrahim allegedly climbed onto the Peace Monument on Capitol grounds and "took a video of himself delivering a monologue." In March 2021, Ibrahim gave a voluntary interview to federal investigators from the Department of Justice alongside his attorney and allegedly denied ever displaying his DEA badge or gun while at the Capitol. Ibrahim told investigators that he went to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with a friend, who had been asked by the FBI to help document the event, the court documents state. The investigators then interviewed that friend, who allegedly said that Ibrahim's story was concocted to "cover his a**," and that Ibrahim actually went to the Capitol that day to try to promote a political podcast and cigar brand. Ibrahim was arrested on July 20, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Injuries to Property; Firearms and Dangerous Weapons on Capitol Grounds; False Statements and Representations
case_updates: Ibrahim pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Michael Brock repeatedly pushed and struck police officers guarding the Capitol with a "four-foot-long rod." Brock was identified after the FBI released a "Be on the Lookout" image, and a confidential witness contacted the agency in June of 2021. Investigators later corroborated that witness's statement, charging documents claim, by obtaining cellphone location data regarding Brock.
charges: Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers (2 counts); Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Brock pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Andrew Taake assaulted law enforcement officers twice -- once with pepper spray and once with a metal whip, according to the FBI. Court documents show that Taake was identified to prosecutors by a match on the dating app Bumble. Those documents include screenshots taken from the app, which the FBI says show Taake being in Alexandria, Va., on Jan. 6, 2021, and admitting to spending half an hour inside the U.S. Capitol. Security camera footage confirms Taake was inside the Capitol carrying the metal whip, prosecutors say. The FBI says it served a search warrant on Verizon, and cellphone records show a phone associated with Taake’s number was likely inside the Capitol. Prosecutors also say they reviewed flight records showing Taake flew from Houston to Baltimore on Jan. 5, 2021, on Spirit Airlines and returned to Texas on Jan. 8, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Taake pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Samuel Lazar sprayed an orange chemical irritant at law enforcement officers while trying to move a barricade on the West Front of the U.S. Capitol, leaving one officer unable to see, according to court documents. Prosecutors say Lazar dressed in a camouflage tactical vest, a black hooded sweatshirt and a patch that read, “Blessed be the Lord, my rock, who trains my hands for war, and my fingers for battle.” He also reportedly carried a bullhorn and a radio and wore camouflage face paint. A tipster turned Lazar in to the FBI, saying they had known him for 28 years. Lazar can be seen spraying law enforcement officers on video, the FBI says. Court documents also reference a video that the FBI says includes Lazar admitting to “macing” the officers. Prosecutors say he also said, “They attacked the people. We have a right to defend ourselves. F*** the tyrants. There’s a time for peace and there’s a time for war.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Lazar pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In March, an anonymous tip submitted to the FBI identified Amy Schubert and her husband to have been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Schubert is seen on footage taken within the building, wearing a black jacket with the text "Plumbers & Pipefitters Local Union 422 Joliet IL" on the back, court documents say. A federal magistrate judge authorized a search warrant for her email account that reportedly showed she was present inside the Capitol on that day. A neighbor told a local CBS station that the Crest Hill, Ill., couple had posted Trump signs on public property multiple times. Schubert was released on bond.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schubert pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/8/2022 to 18 months of probation; $2,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment; and 100 hours of community service

summary: Footage taken inside the U.S. Capitol shows John A. Schubert Jr. and his wife walking around the rotunda on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. In March of 2021, an anonymous tip to the FBI identified the couple, court documents say. A federal magistrate judge authorized a search warrant for the email of Schubert’s wife that reportedly placed them both inside the building. Schubert was released on bond.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schubert pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/8/2022 to 18 months of probation; $1,500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment and 100 hours of community service

summary: An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI saying that three individuals, one of whom was Therese Borgerding, had posted photos on Facebook that indicated they had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Borgerding also made at least two comments on Facebook, admitting she entered the building, court documents say. In one, she reportedly replied, "YES I was inside the Capitol Building for a long time. You don't know The Truth [of] what really happened." Law enforcement also identified Borgerding in surveillance camera footage from inside the building, court documents indicate. In photos and videos from that day, she allegedly is seen carrying a pole with a large "Q" emblem on top, which may indicate an embrace of QAnon. It's a conspiracy theory that claims Satan-worshipping pedophiles are running a global child sex trafficking ring.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Borgerding pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two people contacted the FBI after seeing videos from inside the U.S. Capitol on the Instagram account "dannyforsenate," which is owned by Daniel Christmann, court documents indicate. Christmann is also identified in security camera footage from that day, according to law enforcement. On Jan. 7, 2021, Christmann was asked in an Instagram direct message obtained by the FBI if he had stormed the Capitol. He reportedly replied, "Yeah I'm not going to lie. I wasn't one of the first people in. When realized it was happening I was scaling walls and s***." When asked if he went inside, he reportedly replied, "How could I not?" On Christmann's Instagram account, the bio for his profile also presumably identifies him as a "3%er soldier," court documents indicate. According to news reports, Christmann, a plumber, ran for the New York state Senate in 2020 to represent the 18th District, which includes parts of Brooklyn's Williamsburg, Bushwick and Greenpoint neighborhoods. Christmann ran with the New Moderate Party and lost to the Democratic candidate, garnering 2% of the vote. Christmann also made a bid for U.S. president as a libertarian but lost at the party convention in May 2020.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Christmann pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Walter Messer allegedly posted a selfie from inside the U.S. Capitol onto his Facebook account on Jan. 6, 2021. In the photo, he is seen posing with a statue of former President Ronald Reagan inside the building's rotunda with the caption "little selfie with Ronnie," court documents indicate. Captioning another batch of photos from inside the Capitol, he reportedly wrote he was "inside the capital." Messer also allegedly posted videos from inside the building onto YouTube and is identifiable in surveillance footage from that day. Location records obtained by the FBI from AT&T and Google also show him traveling from Ohio to Washington, D.C., and place him inside the building that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Messer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: James Russell Davis can be seen in police body camera footage among the mob at the U.S. Capitol wearing a U.S. Marine Corps baseball cap and wielding a large stick, court documents indicate. In the footage, he can allegedly be seen charging up the West Front terrace stairs, pushing and screaming at an officer, and charging toward officers with the stick positioned as if he were planning to strike them with it. The officers eventually were able to stop Davis' advances. In the bodycam video, he can reportedly be heard saying, "I fought for this country, I fought for this country, what the f*** are you doing, I fought for this country, I fought for this country, I’m a military f***ing police, I’m a military police." According to court records, Davis served in the Marines from 1994 to 1996 and was a military police officer for one year. Davis was reportedly interviewed in a video titled “Williston Trending Topics News Radio Live." In that Facebook video, Davis identifies as a Virginia Proud Boy, court documents indicate.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Davis pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Donald Smith “says he was in Nancy Pelosi’s office and that it was the best day of his life,” alleged a co-worker of his at a New Jersey UPS facility. Court documents say that the witness told the FBI that Smith took part in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and “gloated” as he showed pictures from the day. A criminal complaint states that a separate tip corroborated that Smith “was bragging about it at work.” Two other co-workers submitted photos of television news coverage appearing to show Smith inside the Capitol.
T-Mobile records show Smith’s cellphone traveled on the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, from the Philadelphia suburb of Lindenwold, N.J., to Washington, where it remained for over eight hours. The criminal complaint includes surveillance footage with time stamps that appear to show Smith remained in the Capitol for at least a half-hour, walking through various parts of the building. Court documents show he was arrested July 29, 2021, in Lindenwold, N.J.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Smith pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
Glenn Brooks “boasted” about his role at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot and sent selfies from inside the U.S. Capitol to members of his church prayer group, according to a criminal complaint. A member of that text message group chat forwarded them to the FBI in January. The FBI says surveillance footage shows Brooks climbing through a broken window near the Senate wing and taking pictures inside, wearing plaid scarf and a hat with the word "Trump" emblazoned on it. Court documents show Brooks was arrested on July 29, 2021.
According to his LinkedIn profile, the 60-year-old Brooks owns a home-remodeling firm called Brooks Works Corp. in Huntington Beach, Calif. Court documents say that surveillance conducted on Brooks by the FBI shows him exiting a vehicle with the name of the company on the side.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brooks pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary:
“Patriots Its [sic] time to come together in DC. And fight for our country. Just like our President Donald Trump has done for us. It’s time we fight for him. See yall in DC Jan 6th,” posted Luke Wessley Bender on TikTok days before the storming of the Capitol, according to court documents. An anonymous tipster who identified themselves as a co-worker wrote to the FBI on Jan 13, 2021: “Luke Bender was bragging about being present during the insurrection at the US Capitol … He has photos of himself and with others inside of the US Capitol Building. Some of the people he has photos with have already been arrested for their participation in this insurrection.”
Images from Jan. 6, 2021, show Bender wearing a black cowboy hat, a camouflage jacket and a big blue Trump flag on the National Mall. Footage also shows him walking around the Capitol Rotunda and, later, entering the Senate chamber, where he appeared to use his phone to photograph documents left on senators’ desks. The court documents also show images of Bender pictured on the dais on the Senate floor.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bender pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Janet Buhler, according to court documents, traveled to Washington, D.C., along with her stepson-in-law, Michael Lee Hardin. Hardin is a former Salt Lake City police officer. Federal prosecutors allege that both Buhler and Hardin breached the U.S. Capitol building during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and can be seen in footage taken from inside the building that day. According to her profile on LinkedIn and a company website, Buhler is the owner of a fashion brand in Salt Lake City.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Buhler pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced 6/1/2022 to 30 days incarceration, 36 months probation, $500 in restitution, $10 special assessment

summary: "It's wartime!... Charge! Charge the motherf***er!....We ride for Trump, we die for Trump!" screams Jacob Kyle Wiedrich on a SnapChat video he posted under the online name “Jacob Weed” on Jan 6, 2021. Court documents say he recorded himself as he made his way from the National Mall to the inside of the Capitol. Wiedrich wore a red "Make America Great Again" hat and a T-shirt with a partial picture of the space shuttle. According to the FBI, footage shows Wiedrich entering the Capitol through a broken window, and once inside, he is seen screaming and taunting a police officer. He was apparently so confrontational that another member of the mob is seen restraining him. He was arrested in Salt Late City.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wiedrich pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/19/2022 to 3 years probation; 90 hours location monitoring/home confinement; special assessment of $10; restitution of $500; 100 hours of community service

summary: In the weeks after the riot at the U.S. Capitol, court documents say, tipsters led the FBI to the Facebook posts and social media accounts of Pam Hemphill, including one posted on Dec. 28, 2020, that reads: "It's not going to be a FUN Trump Rally that is planned for January 6th, its [sic] a WAR!" The criminal complaint also shows a post indicating her plan to travel to Washington, D.C., for the rally, featuring an image of Hemphill holding a firearm that said, "Happy New Year! On my way to Washington DC January 6th!"  The FBI also found videos taken on Jan. 5, 2021, posted to a YouTube channel with Hemphill's name on it. In one, she is heard talking about Ammon Bundy and the occupation of the Idaho State Capitol by protesters of COVID-19 restrictions, saying “Let’s do this; let’s go to the Capitol. We did it in Boise.” Surveillance footage from the Capitol Police shows Hemphill with a selfie stick entering the Capitol and walking through the Rotunda. Later, she can allegedly be seen being escorted out of the building by law enforcement. The criminal complaint also shows a post from another individual identified as a friend of Hemphill's that reads: "Pam is ok!! I am on the phone with her. She was inside the Capitol and they escorted her out in one of the secure tunnels. She got lost and is walking through DC by herself. I will stay on the phone with her until she gets to her hotel. She has some awesome video from inside the capitol to download for us. Wait until you see."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hemphill pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. On 5/24/2022, Hemphill was sentenced to 60 days of incarceration followed by 3 years of supervised release; special assessment of $10; restitution of $500.

summary: Two witnesses tipped off the FBI to an image of Tyler Slaeker in the U.S. Capitol building on social media during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Court documents say that the picture was posted to his mother's Facebook page, along with a comment from her describing the crowd at Trump's speech that morning: "They were very peaceful. But I've seen how this develops, especially after dark. The pictures tyler sent of the crowds show normal, middle class, even older crowds.” CCTV footage from the U.S. Capitol Police allegedly showed Slaeker in a black helmet and gray jacket entering the Capitol building and in the Rotunda wearing an American flag gaiter-type mask.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Slaeker pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds

summary:
Twenty days after the riots at the U.S. Capitol, an anonymous tipster wrote to the FBI: “I was made aware that an individual that works at Yoder locksmith in Nevada, Missouri was involved in the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. I am unsure of the gentleman’s first name but know the day of the event he was inside the Capitol and was dressed as George Washington.” According to the FBI, Isaac Samuel Yoder, the owner of that business, dressed in colonial period attire, attended President Donald Trump’s rally at the mall and later entered the Capitol building, where he walked around the Rotunda taking pictures. 
In a Newsweek article published in March, Yoder stated he wore the George Washington costume as a nod to America’s founders. "Most of us out there are on the side of the aisle who are the gun owners … If we had collectively gone there to cause trouble there would have been piles of bodies. We could have leveled things," he told Newsweek. But Yoder also stated he did not have any altercations with the police and remained in the building for several minutes only, which was confirmed by footage analyzed by the FBI. Yoder also told Newsweek that he believed the election was stolen.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Yoder pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Few details have been released about Nicholas Kennedy's role in the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Kennedy, also known as "Nick," was arrested on July 28, 2021, and made his first appearance in federal court on Aug. 5, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kennedy pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Ulrich conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6, 2021. Ulrich has been indicted along with several members of the group. According to the indictment, Ulrich goes by the moniker "Molon Labe" and allegedly participated in conversations on the encrypted messaging service Signal in a group message labeled "DC OP: Jan 6 21." On Dec. 31, 2020, Ulrich reportedly wrote the following message on the chat: "The more patriots the merrier 'gonna be wild." Later he allegedly wrote, "Someone can tell me if I'm crazy but I'm planning on having a backpack for regular use and then a separate backpack with my ammo load out with some basics that I can [just] switch too is [sic] s**t truly the fan blades. ..." According to court documents, Ulrich also asked another member on Signal: "Hey we told to bring guns and maybe stage them in VA ...?" On Jan. 4, 2021, Ulrich traveled with others to Washington, D.C., from Alabama and Georgia, and stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, court documents say. On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He continued on foot and ultimately pushed his way inside through the Rotunda doors, and then, according to court documents, left the same way he came in.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings
case_updates: Ulrich pleaded Guilty to two charges: Seditious Conspiracy and Obstruction of an Official Proceeding

summary: Cynthia Ballenger didn’t want to share much information regarding her alleged involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol when the FBI interviewed her, court records show. The FBI says Ballenger told investigators they should already know or figure out how she got to Washington, D.C. She reportedly said she planned to meet friends at a cafe but wouldn’t share the names of the friends or the location of the cafe. After an anonymous tip, court documents show the FBI constructed its case against Ballenger through a series of records and video. Ballenger is charged alongside her husband, Christopher Price. Investigators say Facebook records led them to an email and phone number belonging to Ballenger. A search warrant to Google showed a device associated with Ballenger’s email in or near the Capitol, the FBI says. Bank records for Ballenger and Price’s joint credit card show charges the FBI believes to be consistent with the couple traveling by public transit to Union Station in Washington. The FBI also says Ballenger can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol and the restricted grounds outside. According to court documents, Ballenger was likely inside the Capitol building for seven minutes. Price sent photos of Ballenger to a friend and reportedly noted, “Cynthia smiling but she’s freezing.” In her interview with the FBI, Ballenger said there were different categories of people at the Capitol and that she and her husband were on the “low-end of the spectrum,” according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ballenger pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Christopher Price would only discuss his presence at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, in hypothetical terms with the FBI, court documents show. But after an anonymous tip, the FBI was able to construct a trail of records and video that reportedly show Price, along with his wife, Cynthia Ballenger, who is also charged, traveling to Washington, D.C., and entering the Capitol building. Investigators say Facebook records show Price posted about traveling to Union Station in Washington. Someone replied to the post, asking if Price had received “a free tour of the Capitol building today?" Price reportedly replied with a thumbs-up emoji. Facebook records led to an email belonging to Price, which in turn led to a phone number, the FBI says. A search warrant to Google showed a device associated with Price’s email in or near the Capitol, the FBI says. Bank records for Price and Ballenger’s joint credit card show charges the FBI believes to be consistent with the couple traveling by Metro to Union Station. The FBI also says Price can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol and the restricted grounds outside. Price was likely inside the Capitol building for seven minutes, court records indicate. Phone records showed Price receiving a call from a friend with whom he co-owned a business, investigators say. That friend allegedly showed the FBI texts from Price that included “Worth fighting for Trump” and pictures of people inside the Capitol, according to court documents. The FBI says while Price wouldn’t talk about specifics, he said whatever the consequences of Jan. 6, 2021, “it was all in God’s hands now.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Price pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A witness contacted the FBI to report that a publicly available facial recognition software could be used to identify an individual wanted over involvement on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The software reportedly identified a YouTube Channel called “CliffCares,” which was associated with the Facebook business page of Cliff's Mobile Motorcycle Tires. That business page included a photo of one of its clients, a police officer that the FBI subsequently contacted. That officer then helped FBI agents identify the owner of the business as Thomas "Cliff" Ballard, the same man who allegedly showed up via the facial recognition software. Footage from Jan. 6 also allegedly shows Ballard sporting a hat promoting Infowars, a far-right conspiracy news outlet owned by radio host Alex Jones. In the footage, Ballard is allegedly seen confronting and assaulting police officers on multiple occasions. According to the FBI, Ballard can be seen using a black police baton assaulting officers, who are trying to defend the Lower West Terrace archway of the U.S. Capitol. He can also be seen throwing a tabletop at them, court documents indicate.
charges: Civil Disorder (2 counts); Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Ballard pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A day before the riot at the U.S. Capitol, Derek Gunby reportedly posted a photo of himself in a car on Facebook with the caption “Halfway to The Capital.” Later that day, having arrived in Washington, D.C., he took a picture of several bags of bricks, placed by law enforcement, with the caption: “Cops in leftist-controlled areas of the US seem to assist with this type of thing for leftist terrorism. We’re ready. We know you, we know what you are and what you bring to play with. We‘re also smarter and are willing to die for our belief whereas you are not," according to court documents. On Jan. 6, 2021, Gunby also allegedly livestreamed himself riding on the D.C. Metro with another individual heading to then-President Donald Trump's rally. In the video, he is reportedly heard saying: “Your congressional leaders are not afraid of you. …They’re more afraid of left-wing media. And they are more afraid of antifa and Black Lives Matter than they are of the American patriot, the American conservative, the American libertarian.” According to court documents, FBI agents interviewed Gunby, who said he entered the Capitol following the rally and walked around the building with a large group of people and recorded on his cellphone. Gunby served in the U.S. Army as a Satellite Communication Systems Operator from 2002 to 2008 and served in the Army Reserve from 2009 to 2012. He deployed to Iraq in 2004 until 2005 and Afghanistan from 2007 to 2008, the Army confirmed.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gunby pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Clifford Meteer left a stream of public comments on Facebook in the days following the U.S. Capitol riot, along with private messages to at least three people containing photos from inside the building, according to a criminal complaint. “I was one of those idiots scaling the wall,” he reportedly wrote to one friend, describing news coverage of the event as “extremely overblown.” “I saw no violence. I saw no destruction. Are you surprised he media is distorting reality?” he wrote in a public comment on Jan. 7, 2021, the complaint indicates. “I saw 2 kids trying to kick in a door and we told them to stop and they did. As to violence, I was right around the corner from the vet who was murdered.” Meteer’s relative and a former classmate both sent photos to the FBI in January, claiming they showed Meteer at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to the complaint. The classmate told the FBI he’d seen several now-deleted posts of Meteer’s Facebook page, including a photo of Meteer holding up a sign reading “Save the republic.” The complaint alleges that video footage shows Meteer in various parts of the Capitol throughout a half-hour span.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Meteer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/21/2022 to 60 days of Incarceration followed by 36 months of Probation (with conditions); Restitution of $500; Special Assessment of $10

summary: Edward McAlanis shared photographs of his participation in the U.S. Capitol insurrection with friends, according to court documents. The FBI says it learned of McAlanis from a tipster who has mutual friends with him. The tipster shared two photos, which are included in court documents. One of those photos allegedly shows McAlanis posing with a statue of Abraham Lincoln in the Statuary Hall at the Capitol. Prosecutors say the man in the photos can also be seen in CCTV footage from the area of the Rotunda, and that the blue sweatshirt, black vest and black and red backpack match the photos sent by the tipster. The FBI found McAlanis’ phone number and says a search warrant to AT&T led to records that placed him inside the Capitol. Other records confirmed the phone number, along with a Pennsylvania address, prosecutors say. A second tipster confirmed the address in July 2021, according to the FBI, and said McAlanis told friends and family he broke into the Capitol.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McAlanis pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 2/15/2022 to 2 years of probation; $500 in restitution; $10 special assessment; 60 hours community service

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that James Douglas Rahm III breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with his father, James Douglas Rahm Jr. According to charging documents, both men attended the Trump rally that day before heading toward the Capitol building. At one point, the elder Rahm allegedly recorded a video in which he said, “[W]e broke the door down. We’re going in. My eyes hurt like sh** from the pepper spray, but we’re going in.” James Douglas Rahm III was also allegedly recording video on a GoPro camera throughout the day and posted one video to Snapchat in which he reportedly said, "Holy sh**, holy sh***. Oh my f****** god, we just stormed the Capitol. Holy f***.” At one point, prosecutors allege, the elder Rahm received a text message from an unidentified individual, who wrote, "[G]o find Pelosi rip her f****** head off." Rahm allegedly replied, "I pissed in her office. My son's got video." James Douglas Rahm III was arrested on Feb. 5, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rahm pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Esther Schwemmer, federal prosecutors allege, breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and can be seen in video footage from multiple floors inside the building. According to court documents, Schwemmer gave a voluntary interview to federal investigators in which she said she  attended the Trump rally that day before heading toward the Capitol. There, she allegedly climbed a tree to take a photo of the crowd of pro-Trump protesters. She allegedly told investigators she saw the doors to the building open and entered along with a friend, Jennifer Ruth Parks, and encountered no resistance from police. Schwemmer said that when a police officer told her to exit the building, she did so, the charging documents said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schwemmer pleaded Guilty to charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 1/10/2022 to 2 years of probation; $500 restitution; and $10 special assessment; 60 hours of community service

summary: Tanner Bryce Sells wore a black jacket and a hat inside the U.S. Capitol, prosecutors say. Court documents indicate that a witness who has known Sells for more than five years provided the FBI with a photo from Sells’ social media that shows him inside the Capitol. Sells can be seen in the same outfit in closed circuit TV footage, which the FBI says it matched to his Oklahoma driver’s license photo. Prosecutors say the witness also provided them with Sells’ phone number. The FBI says it served a search warrant to AT&T, which provided records demonstrating that Sells’ phone used a cell site that serves an area that includes the inside of the Capitol building.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sells pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/18/2022 to 24 months probation; 90 days location monitoring/home confinement; Special Assessment of $10.00; restitution of $500.00; Fine of $1,500.00; 50 hours of community service

summary: A tipster told the FBI that Jody Tagaris posted pictures on Facebook under the name "Jody Echevarria-Tagaris" showing her posing in the frame of a broken window at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Prosecutors say Tagaris was wearing a unique U.S. Olympics jacket, a MAGA hat and an American flag scarf. Video footage from inside the Capitol allegedly shows Tagaris entering the building through a broken window near the Senate Wing door, taking pictures and engaging with law enforcement. Later, she is reportedly seen going into the Senate Breakout Room, where she sits down at a conference room table until Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police officers arrive and she vacates the room and exits the building. Tagaris was a former Palm Beach County, Fla., Commission candidate and a Republican activist, according to local news reports.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tagaris pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/6/2022 to 24 months probation; 60 hours of community service; $2,000 fine; $500 restitution; special assessment of $10

summary: Antony Vo documented his participation in the U.S. Capitol riot on Facebook and Instagram, according to court documents. Prosecutors say two witnesses shared images with the FBI they say came from Vo’s accounts. One photo, according to the FBI, shows Vo inside the Capitol Rotunda with a woman believed to be his mother. The witnesses both told the FBI Vo engages in conspiracy theories, prosecutors say. One witness said Vo subscribes to libertarian ideologies, court documents show, while the other called Vo “an avid supporter of former President [Donald] Trump.” A search warrant to Facebook yielded conversations Vo had on Facebook and Instagram, the FBI says. Prosecutors say he acknowledged his presence at the Capitol and sent photos as proof. He wrote, “President [Trump] asked me to be here tomorrow so I am with my mom LOL,” and, “My mom and I helped stop the vote count for a bit,” according to court documents. Prosecutors say Vo claimed the results of the 2020 presidential election were fraudulent and that police let rioters into the Capitol; he also reportedly said he and his mother “stormed” the Capitol. The FBI says it also served a search warrant to Verizon. The warrant led to records showing a device with Vo’s number that used a cell site serving an area that includes the inside of the Capitol, court documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A confidential source, who was present at the U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021, provided video to the FBI that allegedly shows Michael Aaron Carico wearing a camouflage shirt and a green hat backward with the word “NAVY” printed on it. According to the FBI, however, Carico did not serve in any of the branches of the U.S. military. According to court documents, a search warrant was issued for Carico’s Gmail account through which the FBI obtained a 30-second video that allegedly shows him singing the last lines of the national anthem and then looking directly into the camera and saying: “Hey Nancy, go f*** yourself,” referring to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Later, additional closed circuit TV footage shows him alongside another individual walking around the Capitol Rotunda, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Carico pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 3/11/2022 to 24 months of Probation; 60 days of location monitoring/home detention; $10 Special Assessment; $500 Fine; Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service

summary: David Mehaffie is charged alongside eight others over his alleged involvement in the assault on officers in a U.S. Capitol tunnel during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. According to HuffPost, Mehaffie was known by the online group Sedition Hunters as the "#TunnelCommander" over his alleged role in giving orders to rioters attacking police officers at one entrance to the Capitol building. The Sedition Hunters group seeks to help federal investigators in identifying the rioters. In the past, Mehaffie has also been a member of an anti-abortion group in Ohio that would protest outside abortion clinics, HuffPost reported.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mehaffie pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Steven Cappuccio is charged with eight others over his alleged actions in the assault on officers in a U.S. Capitol tunnel at the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. According to a reporter at HuffPost, Cappuccio was known by the Sedition Hunters, an online group that aims to help law enforcement identify the rioters, as #stripesguy. Among other more common charges stemming from the riot including assault, Cappuccio is facing one somewhat unusual charge: robbery, over allegedly taking a baton from a police officer, according to a criminal indictment.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Robbery and Aiding and Abetting (baton); Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Cappuccio pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Steven Billingsley may never have made into the U.S. Capitol building, but his words on restricted grounds were violent, prosecutors say. “We do want to hurt [House Speaker Nancy] Pelosi. I do. Yeah, I would hang her from that big -- you see that tree over there? We’d put [up] a rope and hang her. We hang her and [Senate Majority Leader Chuck] Schumer over there, they’ll all go, ‘Oh s***,' ” Billingsley said, according to court documents. Billingsley livestreamed his time on the Capitol grounds via Facebook, a tipster told the FBI. The account where the videos were posted, prosecutors say, was closed in March. Billingsley narrated the first-person videos and turned the camera to show his face at least once, according to prosecutors, who matched the image to the photo of Billingsley’s driver’s license. Those videos, court documents say, show Billingsley undoing a metal barricade and breaching it. The FBI also says Billingsley shouted at police officers saying, “We’re going through. We can do it the nice way or the hard way. … You guys turned on us.” He also repeatedly said, “This is war,” prosecutors say. Court documents include photos from outside the Capitol that the tipster told the FBI resemble Billingsley.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building and Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building and Grounds
case_updates: Billingsley pleaded Guilty to one charge: Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 12/6/2022

summary: Logan James Barnhart is charged along with six others over their alleged actions at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Among other charges, Barnhart -- along with three others -- is charged with assaulting a Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police officer with a baton, flagpole and crutch, though court documents indicate it's unclear who is accused of using which weapon. According to news reports, Barnhart was identified by the Sedition Hunters, a group of online amateur sleuths, as #CatSweat. When then-President Donald Trump tweeted preceding Jan. 6, 2021, that it would be a "historic day," Barnhart, a machine operator who has also modeled for the covers of romance novels, allegedly replied from his own Twitter account, "I'll be there," according to news reports.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Barnhart pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Ronald Colton McAbee is charged along with six others over involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Specifically, McAbee is accused, along with Clayton Ray Mullins, of assaulting an officer with the Washington, D.C. Metropolitan Police. According to the FBI, he was No. 134 on the bureau's seeking information photos, where he can reportedly be seen wearing a red scarf and red baseball cap.
charges: Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: McAbee pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: After Jan. 6, 2021, an anonymous tipster contacted the FBI with a photo showing suspected rioters inside the U.S. Capitol in which a man was circled. According to court documents, the tipster wrote: " “The man in the red circle is Joseph Irwin of the Elizabethtown, KY area. Retired Army and retired Hardin County Police Officer. I [don't] know him well enough to have contact information, but I do recognize him in the photo.” The Hardin County, Ky., Sheriff's Office confirmed to the FBI that Irwin was a former employee, and the sheriff and a lieutenant there also confirmed it was Irwin in the photo, according to court documents. Irwin also allegedly appears in security camera footage from the Capitol that day. NPR could not immediately confirm Irwin's reported Army background.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Irwin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 7, 2021, the Washington, D.C., Metropolitan Police Department received a tip that Deborah Lee, who goes by Debbie, had posted photos on Facebook from inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. Someone responded to one of Lee's posts, saying that she "shouldn't have been there." Lee reportedly responded: "ITS OUR HOUSE. F*** NANCY AND THE DEMOCRATS. WE HAVE EVERY RIGHT TO OCCUPY OUR CAPITAL!!" She allegedly responded to another post that asked if she got into the Capitol, saying "[Y]es we broke in." According to court documents, she claimed that antifa was there and that she and others took weapons from the anti-fascist groups, though there is no evidence that such groups played any major part in the riot. Security camera footage also placed Lee in the Capitol that day, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lee pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Kelsey Wilson's husband, Zachary Wilson, was indicted early on in connection to the riot at the U.S. Capitol. The FBI became aware of him in January after receiving an anonymous tip, according to court documents. The tip pointed to a post on his Facebook account that said he had entered the Capitol and that, while inside, went into House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. In a screenshot of that now-deleted Facebook post, Wilson had tagged his wife, Kelsey Wilson. Initially, both denied they had been inside the Capitol building. Zachary Wilson later admitted to the FBI that he had been inside, but denied his wife had been there. Later, a co-worker of Kelsey Wilson told the FBI that they had been in Washington, D.C., with the couple, and that both had been inside the Capitol for about 30 minutes, court documents indicate. Additionally, the affidavit says that survelliance footage shows both of them inside the building, Kelsey wearing a black and gold hat and a "Make America Great Again" flag wrapped around her body. Wilson is a first-grade teacher at Dayspring Christian School in Springfield, Mo., which has released a statement saying she had been put on administrative leave, according to news reports.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 1/27/2022 to 24 months probation; 30 days home detention; 60 hours community service; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Owen Shroyer is a Texas-based talk-show host for the far-right conspiracy website Infowars. His show, The War Room With Owen Shroyer, streams daily on the Infowars platform banned.video. The criminal complaint indicates that Shroyer was on promotional materials advertising the march on the U.S. Capitol that were circulated by Infowars, reading: "Be a part of history! Fight for Trump." Shroyer also spoke to a crowd the day before the march at a rally at Freedom Plaza, saying: "Americans are ready to fight. We’re not exactly sure what that’s going to look like, perhaps in a couple of weeks if we can’t stop this certification of the fraudulent election ... we are the new revolution!" On the day of the riot, there are multiple images that allegedly show Shroyer inside the restricted area of the Capitol, including a video that reportedly zooms in on him inside the building, while a person can be heard exclaiming, "Well there’s ... Owen Shroyer up there," court documents indicate. Shroyer also allegedly introduced himself in several of the videos. Court documents also note that his involvement in the riot at the Capitol violated the terms of a deferred prosecution agreement entered after he disrupted a House Judiciary Committee meeting in December 2019.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in Capitol Grounds; Obstruct and Impede Passage Through or Within Capitol Grounds
case_updates: Shroyer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Philip Young allegedly pushed a barricade into police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. The criminal complaint says he was identified from videos and photos, one of which showed him letting the air out of the tire of a U.S. government vehicle while wearing a distinctive American flag bandana over his head. Court documents indicate that the jacket he was wearing in that photo bore the unique logo associated with the Boilermakers Union Local 28, located in Eastampton, N.J. When FBI agents later interviewed witnesses who identified Young from the pictures, one witness confirmed that he is a retired member of that union. Footage from officers' body cameras also show Young involved in the violent struggle with police officers and the barricades at the Capitol.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Young pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Benjamen Scott Burlew appeared in at least one video on the U.S. Capitol grounds, where he is allegedly seen assaulting a photographer who works for The Associated Press, according to the Justice Department. As described in the video, Burlew can allegedly be seen wearing camouflage and with a receding hairline, confronting and yelling at the photographer, who had already been dragged down a set of stairs by two unknown people. The FBI says that Burlew, along with others, pushed and shoved the journalist and tried to throw him over the wall of the U.S. Capitol's west lawn. Burlew allegedly disengaged for a while, and then kept shoving the photographer. Eventually, Burlew lunged at the journalist and threw him over the wall, which had a drop of several feet, where he landed on his back, court documents indicate. Burlew reportedly leaned over to watch him fall. The criminal complaint says that Burlew is a former service member in the U.S. Army. Burlew was turned in by a tipster who reportedly overheard Burlew tell a close family member in late December that he planned to "storm the Capitol." Several other people contacted the FBI to identify him as BOLO #195 on one of the FBI's wanted posters.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in Restricted Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Grounds; Physical Violence in Restricted Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds; Striking, Beating, or Wounding of Another Person within the Territorial Jurisdiction; Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction
case_updates: Burlew pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster contacted the FBI after hearing from another person that Blas Santillan had allegedly posted videos on his Snapchat account from inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. That other person confirmed to law enforcement that Santillan had posted up to 15 videos that day, court documents indicate. In one, Santillan reportedly pans around the Capitol Rotunda saying, "Look at this. All this stuff.” In another, he allegedly is seen walking down the street with a chair and a pole strapped to his back and says: “I got a chair, a pole, and a book.” In a cellphone video taken just outside the Capitol doors, Santillan can reportedly be heard shouting at rioters: "It seems like you’re that weak, because I’m the only one that was willing to do something! I’m the only one that was willing to kick that door! Who else is willing to storm in there? ... You are lazy Americans! That is what you are! You are used to sitting on your couch, and watching your Netflix, and listening to your shows, and watching YouTube! You do not know what freedom is. ... Freedom is doing what you want!" Santillan also appears in security camera footage from inside the building, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Santillan pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 8/26/2022

summary: A little after 3 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, Gabriel Burress was allegedly captured on security camera footage from inside the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate that Burress is seen in the footage with his girlfriend, Madison Pettit, who is also charged in the riot. While the pair are walking inside the Capitol, Burress can be seen walking behind Pettit with his hands around her hips, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Burress said he followed the crowd to the Capitol and pushed inside the building.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Burress pleaded Guilty to the charge.  Sentenced to 18 months probation; 45 days location monitoring/home detention; 60 hours community service; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Sometime in January, the FBI received a tip that Madison Pettit had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with her boyfriend, Gabriel Burress, who is also charged in the insurrection. According to court documents, the FBI traced Pettit's cellphone to an area that included the inside of the Capitol that day, and the bureau was also able to locate Pettit and Burress in security camera footage, where they are seen walking closely together. Pettit allegedly admitted to entering the building and said that once inside, she had felt pepper spray in her lungs.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pettit pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced to 18 months probation; 45 days location monitoring/home detention; 60 hours community service; $10 special assessment; $500 restitution

summary: Jeffrey Scott Brown was allegedly part of a group chat on the encrypted messaging service Telegram that the FBI obtained in the aftermath of Jan. 6, 2021. The chat's "about" section reportedly read: “This group will serve as the Comms for able bodied individuals that are going to DC on Jan 6. Many of us have not met before and we are all ready and willing to fight. We will come together for this moment that we are called upon.” According to court documents, Brown posted a selfie to the group on Jan. 5, 2021, with the caption "Boarding LAX," and it was later confirmed he took a flight from Los Angeles that day to Washington, D.C. In security camera footage from a tunnel leading into the U.S. Capitol, Brown can allegedly be seen spraying what the FBI believes to be pepper spray at police officers. In a YouTube video, Brown appears inside the tunnel pushing against officers trying to protect the door to the Capitol's Lower West Terrace, court documents indicate. In the video, one officer has his gas mask ripped off by another person, and blood can be seen in his mouth, according to court documents.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building for Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Brown pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an American flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made  the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Dempsey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Uliyahu Hayah stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege, and soon after spoke about his experience inside the building to a reporter on camera. "We pushed all the way through," Hayah said on the video, according to court documents. "They couldn't stop us." In that video, he said he been "maced," but was wearing a gas mask at the time. Prosecutors allege that Hayah can be seen on police bodycam and surveillance footage pushing an officer inside the building during one confrontation. Court documents said that Hayah is on parole following a criminal conviction for assault in Maryland. Hayah's parole officer helped to identify him to federal investigators, court records said. Hayah was arrested on Aug. 26, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hayah pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Robert Fairchild Jr. was identified after law enforcement posted photos of him on the FBI website, asking tipsters to help find an individual who had allegedly assaulted a federal officer. Law enforcement subsequently asked Fairchild's brother-in-law, who worked at the Troup County, Ga., Sheriff's Office whether he knew the person in the photos, and the brother-in-law identified Fairchild. The FBI alleges that Fairchild is observed on body camera and surveillance footage pushing against security barriers protecting the U.S. Capitol, helping to remove those barriers and walking inside the building. Federal law enforcement said he appeared to be taking a video of himself with his cellphone and at one point seemed to be yelling, "Fight for Trump," while on the Senate side of the building.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fairchild pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. Sentencing set for 8/22/2022

summary: The FBI was alerted to the presence of Jodi Wilson and her son Cole Temple inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot by tips sent to the bureau, court documents indicate. The two allegedly entered the building around 3 p.m. and can be seen in surveillance footage holding up their phones, as if they were documenting the day. An FBI affidavit says that during the investigation into Wilson, agents spoke to a court-appointed guardian who was involved in a custody case with Wilson. The guardian reportedly said that Wilson had said that she had entered the Capitol with her son but claimed she had been invited by someone she assumed was a congressman and was later told by a police officer they were allowed to go in. Later during an interview with the FBI, Wilson again asserted that police officers had “held the door open for [her]” and that an officer had “told me that’s what I could do, and I went in, and that’s all that I did,” according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI identified Cole Temple and his mother, Jodi Wilson, as having gone inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot based on tips sent to the bureau. The pair allegedly can be seen in surveillance footage from the building holding up their phones, documenting the day. Temple can be seen, according to court documents, in a hooded sweatshirt and a dark blue cap with the word "America" across the front. An FBI affidavit says that during the investigation, a witness pointed to Temple's Snapchat account, where he apparently recorded video while in the Capitol. Recordings on his account reportedly show the inside and outside of the building, and one part of the video appears to show Temple filming himself inside and yelling, "[J]ust broke in this b****." Court documents say that when the FBI interviewed Temple, he said that law enforcement allowed him and his mother into the building. He also admitted to posting material on Snapchat when inside the Capitol, court documents say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Temple pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement identified Francis Connor in an Instagram photo posted by another person charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Anton Lunyk. The photo allegedly shows Connor, Lunyk and a third man charged, Antonio Ferrigno Jr., standing inside the U.S. Capitol. The FBI was able to link both Connor and Ferrigno to the photo based on the email addresses used to log into Instagram, court documents indicate. Connor and Ferrigno also reportedly appear in a livestreamed video shot by the far-right media personality known as "Baked Alaska." In a group message on Instagram with Lunyk and Ferrigno, Connor also allegedly wrote, "I was in the Capitol building."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Connor pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI identified Antonio Ferrigno Jr. in an Instagram photo posted by Anton Lunyk, who is also charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. The photo shows Ferrigno posing inside the U.S. Capitol alongside Lunyk and another man charged in the riot, Francis Connor, court documents indicate. In text messages obtained by the FBI and sent by Ferrigno to Lunyk, Ferrigno denied being inside the Capitol. In one message, he claimed an earlier video he sent of Connor climbing out a Senate Wing window, was "air dropped" to him, court documents indicate. In another, he reportedly wrote: "I wasn't in the Capitol so idc." However, the FBI identified him in security camera footage from inside the building and in the background of a video shot by the far-right figure known as "Baked Alaska," according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ferrigno pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In February, a tipster reached out to the FBI with photos that Christopher Cunningham had posted to Facebook that showed him inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Location records obtained by the FBI from Google also reportedly place Cunningham in the Capitol that day, entering on the west side of the building a little after 2:15 p.m. and leaving on the east side. Cunningham also appears in surveillance camera footage that day, court documents indicate. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Cunningham served in the U.S. Navy and was honorably discharged in 2010.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cunningham pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/27/2022 to 12 months of Probation with 3 months on location monitoring/home detention; Special Assessment $10; Fine $1,113; Restitution of $500; 60 hours community service

summary: A witness called the FBI after seeing videos on Kelly McFadden O'Brien's Facebook page reportedly showing her inside and nearby the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In the videos, she narrates her path to the Capitol, reportedly saying: “We’re getting gassed and rubber bullets. We’re under Joe fake Biden Inaugural steps that he was supposed to be the fake president in. we’re probably about 20 feet to 40 feet from the Capitol doors. Some really brave patriots here. I’m right in the thick of it, following them up.” Law enforcement also identified O'Brien in security camera footage from inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. In social media posts leading up to Jan. 6, 2021, O'Brien reportedly posted often about what she believed was a stolen election, a claim for which there is no basis. On Nov. 26, 2020, she allegedly wrote: "We are an Army of Patriots. You will know us when you see us. There will be no ambiguity. Prepare yourself.”  On Dec. 12, 2020, she allegedly posted about being in Washington, D.C., and said she was walked back to her hotel by the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys. A week later, she reportedly posted: "CALLING ALL PATRIOTS! Be in Washington D.C. January 6th. This wasn’t organized by any group. DJT has invited us and it’s going to be 'wild.' " On Jan. 1, 2021, she made reference in a post to the "3 percent," which refers to a far-right extremist group named for the myth that only 3% of Colonists fought against the British during the American Revolution, court documents indicate, and in other posts she reportedly made references to QAnon. In a post on Jan. 7, 2021, O'Brien seemed to distance herself from those videos and posts that placed her among the Jan. 6, 2021, rioters, writing she “had to scrub my page, for obvious reasons,” according to court documents. Later, though, she reportedly wrote again: "No regrets" with a heart emoji.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: O'Brien pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/6/2022 to 90 days incarceration, 12 months Supervised Release, a Fine in the amount of $1000, $500 Restitution, and a $25 Special Assessment

summary: A longtime friend of Marcos Gleffe's contacted the FBI after seeing a Facebook post from Gleffe that indicated he had been at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. The FBI was then able to trace Gleffe's cellphone location that day and confirmed that the device had been inside the building, court documents indicate. Gleffe is also allegedly in security camera footage inside the building, where he can be seen holding a flag that reads, "TRUMP 2020 MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN." In a May 3, 2021, interview with the FBI, Gleffe reportedly admitted to being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and said he decided to do so after he overheard people at the pro-Trump rally saying they were going to storm the building. He told the FBI he had made the "biggest mistake going through the door" and would take it back if he could, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gleffe pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Benjamin Martin, a real estate agent from California, came to the attention of federal prosecutors after a tipster recognized Martin from footage of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, charging papers say. The tipster allegedly told investigators they knew Martin from high school and had seen his political posts and videos on Facebook, including videos saying he was going to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. Before the riot, according to court papers, Martin was part of a group chat on the encrypted messaging platform Telegram, where he discussed plans to go to Washington. He allegedly said in that group chat on Jan. 6, 2021, that “I just spoke to Peggy Hall she said we need to meet." Hall is a far-right activist from California who opposes vaccination and the use of masks to mitigate COVID-19, and who was in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021. Hall is not facing any criminal charges related to the Capitol riot. On Jan. 15, 2021, Martin gave an interview to FBI investigators, court documents say, and claimed that he was at the Capitol attempting to calm demonstrators who had gathered at the doors of the building.
