Subsequently, the FBI allegedly reviewed footage showing Martin inside the Capitol building as well as footage from the Capitol grounds, where Martin told law enforcement officers, "You guys are not doing your job. You swore an oath. You’re bound by your word. Move out of the way and let us in. Move out of the way and let us in.” At one point, officers allegedly deployed chemical spray toward Martin while protecting the building.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Martin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Julia Sizer came to the attention of the FBI via a tip from a person who'd obtained a video allegedly taken by the defendant that showed her "in the [U.S.] capitol building during the insurrection," court documents indicate. The criminal complaint says that after reviewing the video, agents reached out to Sizer, who denied being in the Capitol at the time of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot and subsequently acquired counsel. Sizer's phone was not shown to be among those that showed up in records provided by Google in a search warrant, but after a later interview with the FBI in the presence of her legal counsel, she admitted she was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Sizer also confirmed that she'd taken the video inside the Capitol and described the clothing she was seen wearing that could also be matched to closed circuit TV footage, including a hat with the word "Trump" emblazoned across it. More footage appears to show her entering the Capitol just after the first surge through the door but leaving soon after, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Sizer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced 2/1/2022 to 12 months probation; $2,000 fine; $10 special assessment; and $500 in restitution

summary: The criminal complaint against Cory Brannan, an employee at the Midland County Sheriff's Office in Texas, says he was identified as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by the FBI using cellphone location data. Once agents went through his cellphone records, they found he’d been in touch with many other individuals alleged to have participated in the riot. Photos of Brannan online show him at the Capitol wearing a black hoodie, camouflage pants and a khaki vest with scissors and goggles. The vest had various patches, including one for the Three Percenters, an anti-government extremist group. There are multiple images that appear to show Brannan on the day of the riot, allegedly climbing into the Capitol through a window and walking around inside the building as well. Brannan was identified in photos by a captain of the Midland County Sheriff's Office in Texas where Brannan works as a jailer.
charges: Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brannan pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.  Sentencing set for 9/23/2022

summary: According to a federal affidavit, the FBI was led to James Lollis, Jr. by the individual he went to the U.S. Capitol with on Jan. 6, 2021. Lollis traveled to Washington with Derek Gunby, who had already been charged in connection with the riot. Federal agents identified Lollis from a Facebook video made of the two by Gunby, as they left the Capitol on the Washington Metro. During the video, Gunby introduces his companion by saying, “I went with James here, Jame[s] Lollis,” and turns the camera to a man later identified as Lollis. Later, Gunby says, “We didn’t bring weapons,” while an off-camera voice is heard stating, “we should.” According to court documents, the FBI looked at body camera footage from the day and Lollis can allegedly be seen addressing officers saying, “Y’all on the same team we are, aren't you? You’re not going to respond? You’re not on the same team?" Footage from inside the Capitol also appears to show Lollis’ image, as well as a moment where he appears to be sprayed in the face by officers trying to hold the crowd off.  Later, in Gunby’s video, he says of his companion, “Yeah, yeah. James here took a good bear mace can spray straight to the face.”
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lollis pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced 2/18/2022 to 36 months probation with 90 days of home detention/location monitoring; $10.00 special assessment and $500.00 restitution; 100 hours of community service

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Gary Wilson breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with two other men: Patrick Montgomery and Brady Knowlton. Wilson wore a T-shirt from the far-right conspiratorial news site Infowars depicting a Revolutionary War soldier with an automatic weapon, according to charging documents. Wilson was in close proximity to multiple violent clashes between rioters and police in and around the Capitol, prosecutors say, though they do not accuse Wilson of committing violence himself. During one confrontation with police, Wilson allegedly told officers, "We came all the way from our jobs to do your job and the freaking senators’ job.” Charging documents state that federal investigators confirmed Wilson's presence in the Capitol through flight records, cellphone records, an interview with a family member of Wilson and videos from multiple sources at the Capitol. The FBI arrested Wilson on Sept. 13, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Theft of Government Property
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jean Lavin and her daughter, Carla Krzywicki, breached the U.S. Capitol together on Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege. During the attack, Lavin and Krzywicki allegedly climbed a bike rack that rioters had used as a ladder to reach the building and entered through the Senate wing door. Both women can allegedly be seen on video wearing pro-Trump clothing and walking throughout the Capitol. Lavin allegedly carried a sign with the message "Trump Won." Soon after the attack on the Capitol, the FBI received a tip from a source that Krzywicki had posted images from in and around the Capitol that day to Facebook. The Facebook post, which is cited in the charging documents, states: "we come for the government officials that are ruining our country. we go straight to the source. change needs to happen. that is our house and you work for us." Court documents state that FBI agents later interviewed both Lavin and Krzywicki about the events that day, and both allegedly admitted to the FBI that they had entered the building.
charges: Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lavin pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/22/2022 to 36 months of probation with 10 days intermittent confinement and 60 days home detention; a special assessment of $10, a fine of $2,500, and restitution of $500

summary: Carla Krzywicki and her mother, Jean Lavin, breached the U.S. Capitol together on Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege. During the attack, Krzywicki and Lavin allegedly climbed a bike rack that rioters had used as a ladder to reach the building and entered through the Senate wing door. Both women can allegedly be seen on video wearing pro-Trump clothing and walking throughout the Capitol. Soon after the attack on the Capitol, the FBI received a tip from a source that Krzywicki had posted images from in and around the Capitol that day to Facebook. The Facebook post, which is cited in the charging documents, states: "we come for the government officials that are ruining our country. we go straight to the source. change needs to happen. that is our house and you work for us." Court documents state that FBI agents later interviewed both Krzywicki and Lavin about the events that day, and both allegedly admitted to the FBI that they had entered the building.
charges: Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Krzywicki pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/22/2022 to 36 months of probation with 90 days home detention; a special assessment of $10, and restitution of $500.

summary: “I’m getting ready to storm D.C.,” wrote Marshall Neefe in a message to a friend on Nov. 4, 2020, the day after Election Day 2020, expressing his dissatisfaction with the election results, according to court documents. In the following weeks, Neefe engaged in multiple online conversations organizing travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. He wrote on Facebook in December: “Cause hot damn son I really wanna crack some commie skulls." According to the FBI, Neefe made a wooden club he called “the commie knocker” that he brought to Washington. On the Capitol grounds, footage shows Neefe participating in hoisting and pushing a large metal sign frame into a defensive line of police officers, court documents indicate. He is also allegedly seen entering the building and disregarding commands from law enforcement. “If i had it my way every cop who hurled a baton or maced [one] of us would be lined up and put down," he allegedly wrote later. Neefe faces 10 charges, including seven felonies.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Neefe pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding and a lesser offense as to Count 4s, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting. Sentencing set for 9/23/2022.

summary: “Take off the 6th man! It’s the Big one!!! Trump is literally calling people to DC in a show of force,” Charles Bradford Smith, known as Brad Smith, allegedly wrote on Dec. 31, 2021, urging a friend on Facebook to travel with him to Washington, D.C. According to the FBI, Smith also told a friend, “If it’s big enough we should all just storm the buildings.” Three days before coming to D.C., Smith allegedly purchased a KA-BAR military-style knife. On Jan. 6, 2021, Smith is allegedly seen yelling and encouraging rioters to keep forcing a door to the U.S. Capitol closed so that police officers inside could not respond to the riots outside. “Well we literally chased them out into hiding…Pence cucked like we knew he would but that was an Unbelievable show of force and it did its job,” he allegedly wrote to a friend after the riot. Smith faces seven charges, including four felonies.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Smith pleaded Guilty to two charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding and a lesser offense as to Count 4s, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting. Sentencing set for 9/23/2022

summary: Tara Aileen Stottlemyer, who the FBI allege willfully and knowingly entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was arrested on Sept. 14, 2021. Her partner, Dale Shalvey, has already been indicted in this matter, charged with multiple offenses, including assaulting law enforcement. According to court documents, the couple married and moved to North Carolina after the incident. According to local media, the couple started a small business raising animals in early 2020 in Fredericktown, Pa. Prior to that, Stottlemyer worked as a flight attendant.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Stottlemyer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “They can’t stop millions. … We busted in the Capitol,” Marilyn Fassell allegedly said in a video obtained by the FBI. According to court documents, footage from inside the building depicts Fassell, alongside her husband, walking inside the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol. A blurry selfie allegedly captured her smoking a cigarette in the Capitol, her mask lowered below her chin. “This is my house, we pay taxes for this,” she is later heard saying on a different video, court documents indicate. Fassell was initially flagged to the FBI because her husband reportedly bragged about their actions on Jan. 6, 2021, in front of co-workers, one of whom law enforcement later interviewed. Agents interviewed the Fassells, who allegedly admitted to having entered the Capitol building through a broken door, but they also said they were unaware they were doing anything illegal.
charges: Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fassell pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: A tipster reached out to the FBI, alerting the bureau that Thomas Fassell had reportedly bragged to the tipster's mother, who is Fassell's co-worker, about being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The FBI then interviewed the tipster’s mother, who said Fassell showed her and other co-workers pictures and videos of him and his wife, who is also charged in the riot. The FBI also interviewed the couple, who allegedly said they had traveled from Florida to Washington, D.C., to “participate in a peaceful protest.” The Fassells described entering the Capitol through a broken door and walking around various offices. Both told the FBI they did not know they were doing anything illegal, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Fassell pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Mike Eckerman ⁠— wearing a red hat, neon gloves and a load-bearing tactical vest ⁠— is captured on body camera footage yelling at law enforcement outside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. Once inside the building, he is allegedly seen on surveillance cameras pushing an officer backward several feet. According to court documents, the pushed officer loses his balance and falls down a set of stairs. A different individual then proceeds to spray that officer with a fire extinguisher in the face. As Eckerman makes his way further in, he is seen pushing several other officers, court records indicate. Once back outside, Eckerman is reportedly captured on video discussing his motivation for going inside and also comments on the shooting of Ashli Babbitt. “I don’t know her name, all I know is we went there (Capitol) as patriots. She is dead because we’re here. These mother f***ers are traitors, they are f***ing traitors!” he allegedly says.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Eckerman pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew Buckler was initially flagged to the FBI on Jan. 13, 2021, when a tipster sent agents a screenshot of Buckler's alleged Snapchat account. According to court records, the screenshot captured a video of Buckler inside the U.S. Capitol. The tipster also provided a screenshot that showed a Bitmoji labeled “Matt,” placed on top of a satellite image of the Capitol building and grounds. In May, Buckler’s phone was seized and searched after a federal warrant was issued. According to court records, the phone had at least seven videos taken inside the Capitol. On one of the videos, Buckler is allegedly seen shouting repeatedly: “Stop the Steal” and on another video, which appears to be taken in the Crypt at the Capitol, he can reportedly be heard saying: “We in this b****. We in this b****.”
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Buckler pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.  Sentenced 7/21/2022 to 14 days of home detention, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: “It was all bs. It was staged by ANTIFA, BLM and Capitol police. The police moved barricades and encouraged people to go in. … [I]t was like going to the shopping mall,” David Wiersma allegedly wrote on Facebook late on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021. A co-worker of Wiersma's saw the posts on Facebook and contacted the FBI. Agents then interviewed Wiersma at his home, where he reportedly admitted to going into the U.S. Capitol but refused to provide any information about his social media posts without his attorney present.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Wiersma pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Dawn Frankowski, alongside two others, drove to Washington, D.C., to attend the “Save America” rally, according to court documents. Later on, she allegedly walked with one of her travel companions, who has also been charged, to the U.S. Capitol and entered the building, where they stayed for about half an hour. According to the FBI, Frankowski told agents that she wanted to support then-President Donald Trump. She was released on a $10,000 recognizance bond, according to local media.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Frankowski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI submitted a BOLO, or Be on the Lookout, alert for a man wearing a gray hooded sweatshirt and a black face gaiter with a skull jawbone printed on it. According to the FBI, the man was later identified as Anthony Sargent and can be seen on open-source videos attempting to breach the north entrance of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. On a different video, Sargent can allegedly be seen pushing the crowd to breach the building. According to court documents, Sargent ⁠— who has tattoos on his knuckles and the back side of his right hand ⁠— can be seen repeatedly throwing an unknown object toward the inner doors of the entrance. Based on estimates provided by the office of the Architect of the Capitol, Sargent and others caused over $1,000 in damages to the north doors, court records indicate. After further investigation, the FBI allegedly identified Sargent as a member of the Proud Boys. Open-source searches also reportedly identified some of the Twitter accounts associated with him. Law enforcement was allegedly able to retrieve a now-disabled account that contains an image resembling Sargent and lists his username as Sarge Slaughter alongside the following description: “Ancient City Proud Boy Constitutionalist Unapologetic no mask.” According to court documents, his background picture on Twitter is a recruitment poster for the Proud Boys in the style of the Uncle Sam U.S. Army poster but with the slogan: “We Want You to Be A Proud Boy.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sargent pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “I’m reclaiming Aztlan because I love America. Querer es poder! ... #chicanohistory #mexicanamerican,” Erik Herrera allegedly wrote on Instagram as a caption to a picture of him holding a large stack of papers inside one of the offices in the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Aztlán is the ancestral home of the Aztec people. Querer es poder, translated from Spanish, means “where there’s a will, there’s a way.” The FBI identified Herrera after a tip and later obtained a federal search warrant for his social media accounts. In a personal message to another user, Herrera allegedly wrote he was in Washington, D.C., “for both photojournalism and our people,” and stated his dissatisfaction with the election results. Additionally, when asked on Instagram, “What was going through your mind while holding what appeared to be a stack of government documents?” he allegedly responded: “I wasn’t thinking much, I just wanted a goofy ‘f*** you’ picture.” According to the FBI, Herrera later admitted on social media that the “press patch” he wore was purchased online and was not issued by a media organization. “I don’t have a monopoly on press badges. They’re on Amazon for like $8 … No special permission to buy.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Herrera pleaded Not Guilty to all charges. A jury trial held 8/15/2022-8/19/2022 found him Guilty on all charges. He is to be sentenced on 11/10/2022

summary: On Jan. 7, 2021, a tipster reached out to the FBI to report that a friend had breached the U.S. Capitol with other people, including Mick Chan. That tipster provided a screenshot to the FBI of a Facebook post from a friend in which Chan was tagged, and which seemed to indicate that Chan and the friend had gotten massages after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, court documents indicate. The post reportedly read: "After all the tear gas and rubber bullets shot at us, this massage today was like heaven on earth!" On Jan. 8, 2021, Chan contacted the FBI and allegedly admitted to entering the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, Chan told the FBI that he "broke into, well, air quotes, broke into" the Capitol and clarified that he believed others had breached the building before him. Chan reportedly told the FBI that he did not engage in any confrontations, believed the crowd had been infiltrated by antifa and Black Lives Matter and that he had entered the building with "journalistic intent." Chan also allegedly said he had previously met with members of the Proud Boys. In security camera footage from inside the Capitol, he is seen giving the middle finger to the camera, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chan pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On July 11, 2021, a confidential source identified Brandon Prenzlin in public available video from Jan. 6, 2021, that shows him inside the U.S. Capitol building, court documents indicate. Prenzlin is also allegedly seen in both police body camera footage and security camera footage from inside the building. Prenzlin was a grassroots coordinator for the libertarian group FreedomWorks at the time of the riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Prenzlin pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 6/27/2022 to 10 Months Probation; $10 Special Assessment; $2,500 Fine; Restitution of $500; 120 hours of community service

summary: David Ticas came to the attention of the FBI via a witness who provided a screenshot of him from what appears to be his Instagram account.  According to court documents, Ticas appears in the Crypt of the U.S. Capitol giving a thumbs up, with the caption, "Storm the Capital [sic]! #StopTheSteal #DemocratsAreCriminals..."  The witness identified Ticas as a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps from their prior service together. The day after the riot, Ticas allegedly posted a picture of the outside of the Capitol that was removed as a community guidelines violation. He added later, "I guess only the clowns of BLM & Antifa can post their peaceful protests." Later messages on his Instagram page allegedly record Ticas saying: "These politicians are straight up criminals. There is a reason for this non-pandemic to continue, it’s the nwo trying to get rid of Trump.” Google location data places Ticas at and inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. In addition, surveilliance footage also allegedly shows him entering the building, walking through the Crypt, and exiting the building. Additional body camera footage captures him yelling "God damn politicians, don’t f***ing touch me" on his way out, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ticas pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/15/22 to 14 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 90 days or location monitoring, 60 hours community service,  $500 restitution, $10 special assessment

summary: Richard Watrous was initially identified from surveillance footage of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, according to a criminal complaint. FBI agents say he was wearing a distinctive red "Trump" hat when he entered the Capitol and then could be seen leaving after a few minutes inside. When he was interviewed by law enforcement, Watrous allegedly said his trip to Washington, D.C., was planned as soon as he heard former President Trump urging people to go. He allegedly said he drove to D.C. from his New York home despite the fact that he did not feel he could have any effect on the proceedings in Congress. According to court documents, Watrous attended the rally at the Ellipse the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, and then made his way to the Capitol, where he said there were already people there, and he could hear flashbangs and was aware of tear gas even though he was fairly far away from the building. When he allegedly entered the Capitol building, he told agents, he heard someone yell, "they just killed a girl!"; agents believe that the person was referring to the shooting of Ashli Babbitt. Once inside, Watrous reportedly said that he felt uncomforable and thought,  “This is crazy.  What the hell is going on here?” He went on to say that people around him "seemed like troublemakers and did not seem like peaceful protestors," court documents indicate. He claims he witnessed a man who had said he was going into House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office holding a bottle of wine and saying "I got Nancy Pelosi's wine!"  Watrous told agents that he was inside the Capitol for about five minutes before he left, going back into the Rotunda briefly before returning to his hotel.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
case_updates: Watrous pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/21/2022 to 14 days intermittent  incarceration; 36 months of probation; 60 days home confinement; $2,500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Jeremy Brown is a former Florida Republican congressional candidate who was identified a few weeks after the riot at the U.S. Capitol by a witness who has known him for a number of years, court documents indicate. The criminal complaint states that the witness pointed law enforcement to pictures of Brown in tactical gear the day before the riot -- even though the witness wasn't sure if he'd actually entered the Capitol during the incident itself. The FBI reportedly verified his location by comparing a photo from the day before to video and pictures taken on Jan. 6, 2021, where he appeared to be wearing the same gear, including zip ties attached to his belt. Police body worn camera footage also allegedly showed him near the Capitol where he was one of a group trying to push back against law enforcement attempting to secure the building grounds. According to court documents, Brown has not been placed by the FBI inside the Capitol building that day, but cellphone data shows that a number used by Brown was in a geographic area that includes the inside of the building. According to court documents, another defendant identified him, and said that he'd provided a ride share to Washington, D.C., coordinating on a Signal chat and through posts on Parler. In a Parler post, Brown allegedly identified himself as a "retired Green Beret that ran for Fl-14" under his account, @brownforcongress2020. On Signal, he allegedly wrote: "If you can, come to my house anytime Saturday. You can stop by and drop stuff off, or stay the night. This way we can load plan, route plan, and conduct PCIs (Pre Combat Inspections).  I would LIKE to depart by 0645 on Sunday morning, Jan 3rd. Push through to the NC linkup on the 3rd, RON (Rest Over Night) there, then push to DC on the 4th. This will give us the 4th/5th to set up, conduct route recons, CTR (Close Target Reconnaissance) and any link ups needed with DC elements."  FBI agents also reviewed a video podcast in which Brown said he was in D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021, and left his guns in Virginia with others, picking them up after the riot, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Brown pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster reached out to the FBI to tell it that Maryann Mooney-Rondon was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with her son, Rafael Rondon, who is also charged in the riot, court documents indicate. Cellphone records, surveillance footage and other videos and photographs also allegedly show Mooney-Rondon and her son inside the building that day, including inside the Senate gallery and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's conference room. In a video taken inside Pelosi's conference room, both Mooney-Rondon and her son can be seen standing nearby as the video appears to show a laptop being stolen from the room, court records indicate. In the video, an arm, believed to be Mooney-Rondon's, reaches over toward the laptop and a female voice is heard to say, "Dude, put on gloves," before an unidentified man lifts the computer off the table. In an interview with the FBI, Mooney-Rondon admitted to entering the Capitol that day and said she provided gloves to the man who took the laptop, court documents indicate. In the interview, she reportedly said the man "scared the crap" out of her.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property (2 counts); Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mooney-Rondon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster reached out to the FBI to tell it that Rafael Rondon was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with his mother, Maryann Mooney-Rondon, who is also charged, according to court documents. Surveillance footage, as well as other videos and photographs, allegedly show Rondon and his mother inside the building, including inside the Senate gallery and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's conference room, where they are allegedly seen standing nearby in a video that appears to show a laptop being stolen from the room, court records indicate. In the Senate gallery, Rondon and his mother allegedly appear in photographs carrying protective respiratory hoods, which are stored in the gallery in case of a biological or chemical attack. Later on, Rondon can reportedly be seen wearing the hood in photographs taken on the Capitol steps, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Rondon allegedly admitted to being inside the Capitol that day, telling the agents: "I think everybody was going there for about the same reason I was, just have your voice heard.” He also admitted to helping the man who took the laptop in Pelosi's conference room, saying, "I was honestly a little bit afraid, because I didn’t know if he had anything on him. So I assisted him a little bit, and that was probably stupid of me," according to court documents.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Theft of Government Property (2 counts); Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rondon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In early June, 2021, Anthony Vuksanaj, alongside two others, was arrested and charged with first degree robbery, according to court documents. Detectives from the Westchester County Police Department in New York interviewed him about his alleged involvement in the robbery, but he denied involvement. The officers seized Vuksanaj’s cellphone and issued a search warrant. According to the FBI, Vuksanaj's phone was subsequently identified as being in an area that included the grounds of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. After reviewing video footage from inside the Capitol, the Westchester County detectives were able to confirm that Vuksanaj was in the building, court documents indicate. A video shot by a reporter for National Geographic also allegedly shows Vuksanaj walking around the building, recording on his cellphone.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vuksanaj pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/29/2022 to 42 days incarceration; 36 months probation; three months home detention; $2,000 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Federal authorities charged Aaron James alongside two other men, Isaac Westbury and his father, Robert Westbury, for their alleged actions during the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors allege James and Isaac Westbury engaged in physical violence on the Capitol grounds by wielding a shield taken from law enforcement, and they accuse all three men of disrupting Congress that day. The three men were arrested in Lindstrom, Minn., on Oct. 4, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: James pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal authorities charged Isaac Westbury and his father, Robert Westbury, as well as a man named Aaron James, together for their alleged actions during the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021. James and Isaac Westbury allegedly engaged in physical violence on the grounds of the building using a police shield. Prosecutors also accuse all three men of disrupting Congress on that day. They were arrested in Lindstrom, Minn., in early October.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Westbury pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal authorities charged Robert Westbury, his son, Isaac Westbury, and a man named Aaron James together for their alleged actions during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors accuse all three men of disrupting Congress that day. All three were arrested in Lindstrom, Minn., on Oct. 4, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Westbury pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Lawrence Dropkin Jr. told his father that he’d likely “be spending some time in jail for participating in the protests at the Capitol” and that he entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office, according to a criminal complaint. Dropkin’s father allegedly repeated those statements to a relative, who passed the information to the FBI in January. A second informant, who has known Dropkin since childhood, says Dropkin called on FaceTime from inside the U.S. Capitol. This tipster took screenshots and sent them to the FBI in January, according to the complaint. Surveillance footage also allegedly shows a man the FBI identifies as Dropkin walking through various parts of the Capitol building over a 40-minute period while wearing a red “Make America Great Again” hat. Dropkin was arrested Oct. 1, 2021, in Newark, N.J., and was released on an unsecured bond of $50,000, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Dropkin pleaded Guilty to all charges. Sentencing set for 10/7/2022

summary: Cara Hentschel allegedly wrote to a Facebook friend shortly after the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, saying, “we storm peloskis [sic] office and took her beer. She drinks Corona,” according to messages the FBI obtained through a search warrant. The FBI’s criminal complaint, however, disputes this claim, stating that although surveillance footage shows Hentschel inside the Capitol for about a half-hour, the footage does not show Hentschel or her acquaintance, Mahailya Pryer, who is also charged, entering House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. Hentschel declined to answer the FBI’s questions in March and allegedly told a tipster who traveled to Washington, D.C., with them that “the FBI could not prove she committed any crimes if she refused to speak with them,” according to a criminal complaint. Hentschel was arrested Oct. 4, 2021, in Springfield, Mo.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hentschel pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 8/19/2022

summary: A relative of Mahailya Pryer, also known as Mahailya Williams, told the FBI they traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend then-President Donald Trump’s Jan. 6, 2021, rally with Cara Hentschel, who is also charged in the riot, and another relative. According to a criminal complaint, the two unnamed relatives stopped at a barrier near the U.S. Capitol, separating from Pryer and Hentschel. Surveillance footage shows Pryer and Hentschel entering the Capitol rotunda doors at 2:43 p.m. and exiting at 2:51 p.m., according to the complaint. As the FBI was interviewing Pryer’s relative in June of 2021, the tipster claimed to be angry that Pryer had entered the Capitol. This relative called Pryer in front of the agents, insisting she should cooperate with the FBI. The criminal complaint says Pryer became angry and hung up on her relative. Shortly afterward, the FBI visited Pryer’s home, where she declined to answer questions because “she did not want to incriminate herself, though she did not think that she had done anything wrong," court documents indicate. She also told the FBI that she and Hentschel were no longer friends. Pryer was arrested Oct. 4, 2021, in Springfield, Mo.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pryer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 8/19/2022

summary: Michael Dickinson allegedly lobbed a large coffee tumbler toward police, striking an officer in the face, during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, according to a criminal complaint. He’s also accused of tossing a large bucket filled with liquid at officers trying to clear rioters from the Capitol grounds. Photos in the court documents allegedly show Dickinson being led away from the Capitol, clutching paper towels to his face and with blood stains down his clothing. Medical records from a Washington, D.C., area hospital show that Dickinson suffered injuries to his face and that he believed he was struck by a rubber bullet, according to the complaint. Dickinson was arrested Oct. 6, 2021, in Philadelphia.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Dickinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Edward T. Spain Jr. wrote that he “utilized poor judgement” in entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a signed confession he provided to the FBI in August. “I had no intent on entering the Capitol building but did so after hearing that shots had been fired on the Senate floor,” he wrote, according to a criminal complaint. He also showed agents the distinctive blue and white shirt, U.S. Army cap and black jacket he wore, as seen in surveillance footage from the Capitol and in photos he posted to Facebook that day, court documents indicate. In an earlier interview with the FBI, Spain said he traveled from Oklahoma to Washington, D.C., with two friends “to witness history,” according to the complaint.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Spain pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced on 5/4/2022 to 36 months of probation, 60 hours community service; $500 restitution and $10 special assessment.

summary: A day after the riot at the U.S. Capitol, the FBI received several anonymous tips that Moises Romero had posted videos of himself on Instagram inside the building on Jan 6, 2021, according to court documents. One of the individuals identified him as nurse in Florida and provided his cellphone number. A search warrant served on AT&T showed his number was used in an area that includes the inside of the U.S. Capitol. According to CCTV footage from the Capitol, Romero, wearing a black hoodie, a respirator and fingerless gloves, can allegedly be seen entering through the doors on the Senate side of the building. Footage appears to show him pushing his way in alongside a large crowd, as police officers are trying to hold the group off. Romero is seen near the front of the line of rioters, pressing his gloved right hand to the wall to assist in his efforts to get inside. Later, Romero can be seen walking around the building and recording on his cellphone. According to local media, Romero worked as a nurse at Memorial Regional Hospital in Pembroke Pines.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Romero pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 7/22/2022 to 12 months and 1 day of incarceration; 12 months of supervised release; special assessment of $100; restitution of $2,000; 60 hours of community service

summary: Thomas Harlen Smith has been indicted on 10 federal counts relating to the Jan. 6, 2021, riots, according to court documents. Smith had worked as a foreman at the Oktibbeha County road department in Mississippi, according to local media. In March of 2021, Smith was arrested on embezzlement charges alleging he stole gas from the road department in summer 2019, when he was an employee. According to The Dispatch, a local newspaper, Smith was terminated in August 2019. He later sued the county for wrongful termination, claiming it was retaliation for his being a whistleblower. Both cases are pending. According to HuffPost, Smith was identified alongside his cousin by the group operating under the name Sedition Hunters, because of the flag Smith carried – an old Mississippi flag that featured the Confederate battle flag. According to the FBI, Smith is charged with assaulting law enforcement. “We pretty much got our a**** kicked by the cops then we kick the cops a**** … Patriots stood together and battled the tyrannical cops throughout the entire afternoon and as I sit here now at the footsteps of the Capitol they’re still shooting off flashbangs pepper spray and innocent people,” he wrote on Facebook according to the HuffPost.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Smith pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In February, the independent investigative group operating under the name Sedition Hunters, identified Donnie Duane Wren as having participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riots, based on publicly available information. According to court documents, Wren is charged with multiple counts for his involvement, including acts of physical violence. The Sedition Hunters were able to identify Wren based on his brown jacket, with his company’s logo. According to local media, Wren was at the Capitol alongside his cousin, who carried a Mississippi Confederate flag. According HuffPost, both men were arrested, nine months after the attack.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Wren pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A mobile device recording from Jan. 6, 2021 showed a man trying to wash his eyes after being pepper-sprayed. He identified himself as “Cody from Rochester” and said in the video that he did not want to fight anyone and was pushed, according to court documents. The FBI, with the help of the independent organization of investigators known as Sedition Hunters identified him as Cody Mattice. Mattice was on the FBI's wanted list known as #FenceSnatcher because footage shows him ripping down a barrier that allowed protesters to bypass law enforcement. According to the FBI, Mattice can also be seen using a chemical agent to spray police officers. Mattice was charged alongside James Mault, who also allegedly used pepper spray against Capitol police officers.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mattice pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/15/2022 to 44 months incarceration; 36 months of supervised release; $2,000 in restitution; $100 special assessment

summary: The FBI National Threat Operations Center was contacted by an anonymous complainant who identified James Mault as having been at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Mault was described as wearing a hard hat with stickers, including one of the Ironworkers Local 33, a union in Rochester, N.Y. According to the FBI, on Jan. 18, 2021, special agents interviewed Mault’s mother, who told them that her husband drove maybe five people, including her son, to attend the protests in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. Agents were also able to interview James Mault, who admitted to having attended the rally in D.C. and explained that he was wearing a hard hat from work because he was afraid that Antifa would attack Trump supporters and he needed the hat for protection, court documents indicate. He also allegedly told agents that he was pushed with the crowd toward the building entrance but denied having participated in any acts of violence. However, footage allegedly shows Mault spraying law enforcement with a chemical agent at the entrance to the main tunnel on the Western side of the Capitol, which was the scene of one of the most intense battles between the rioters and law enforcement. Mault was charged alongside his friend Cody Mattice, who also allegedly used pepper spray against Capitol police officers. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Mault was previously in the U.S. Army. After Jan. 6, 2021, Mault reenlisted in the Army, the sentencing memo states, but did not disclose his involvement in the riot. During an interview with the FBI, he told investigators: “Why would they let me join if I was a threat? Why would they let me join the federal government and be a soldier if I was a threat?” According to the memo, Mault is pending discharge from the Army.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers using a Dangerous Weapon; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Mault pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/15/2022 to 44 months incarceration; 36 months of supervised release; $2,000 in restitution

summary: Willard Thomas Bostic Jr. and his daughter, Meghan Rutledge, breached the U.S. Capitol building together on Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege. According to charging documents filed in court, investigators were tipped off to Rutledge's alleged involvement by two people who knew Rutledge and had seen her post photos to Facebook from in and around the Capitol that day. "After miles and miles of walking and climbing and climbing some more we made it inside the capitol building," Rutledge allegedly wrote. "What an experience for the books." Federal investigators also used surveillance footage to identify Rutledge and Bostic among the mob inside the building, according to an FBI agent's statement of facts in the case. Cellphone records cited in that document also allegedly place Bostic inside the Capitol during the riot. Investigators also allegedly found evidence that Bostic had communciated by phone "with an individual who coordinated convoys, communication plans, maps and packing lists for individuals planning to participate in the events on Jan. 6, 2021. On the packing list provided by the protest organizer, the following items were recommended: ASP baton, body armor, helmets and portable chargers." Both Bostic and Rutledge were arrested on Oct. 13, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bostic pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Meghan Rutledge and her father, Willard Thomas Bostic Jr., breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, federal prosecutors allege. According to charging documents filed in court, investigators were tipped off to Rutledge's alleged involvement by two people who knew Rutledge and had seen her post photos to Facebook from in and around the Capitol that day. "After miles and miles of walking and climbing and climbing some more we made it inside the capitol building," Rutledge allegedly wrote. "What an experience for the books." Federal investigators also used surveillance footage to identify Rutledge among the mob inside the building, according to an FBI agent's statement of facts in the case. Those investigators also allegedly found evidence that Bostic, Rutledge's father, had communciated by phone, "with an individual who coordinated convoys, communication plans, maps and packing lists for individuals planning to participate in the events on Jan. 6, 2021. On the packing list provided by the protest organizer, the following items were recommended: ASP baton, body armor, helmets and portable chargers." Both Rutledge and Bostic were arrested on Oct. 13, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rutledge pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Less than a week after the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot, a relative of Jason Comeau contacted the FBI and said that Comeau had admitted to breaching the building, according to charging documents filed in federal court. Comeau later gave a voluntary interview to FBI agents, court papers state, during which he said he had attended the pro-Trump rally earlier in the day and then marched toward the Capitol building. Comeau allegedly told agents that he climbed the stairs heading into the building and that after the crowd repeatedly chanted "Let us in," Capitol police moved aside, allowing the crowd to enter the building. Comeau allegedly told FBI agents that he believed he was allowed to enter the building and that he only progressed as far as a hallway. Prosecutors now allege that surveillance footage and cellphone video show Comeau going as far as the Capitol's Statuary Hall and remaining in the building for approximately 20 minutes. He also allegedly joined chants of "stop the steal," a slogan adopted by President Donald Trump and some of his supporters that falsely asserts that Trump won the 2020 presidential election. From July 2000 to December 2002, Comeau served in the U.S. Army as a combat engineer, an Army spokesperson confirmed to NPR. Comeau did not have any combat deployments and held the rank of private at the end of his service, the spokesperson said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Comeau pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing rescheduled to 9/20/2022

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that around 12:40 p.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, James Grant walked up to a metal barricade outside the U.S. Capitol building, lifted it up and assaulted police officers guarding a restricted area of the Capitol grounds. Together with another Capitol riot defendant, identified in court documents as Ryan Samsel, Grant allegedly pushed the police backwards and forced them to retreat. Pictures included in the court documents indicate Grant was wearing a mask with the image of a skull on it during the attack. About two hours after that incident, prosecutors say, Grant joined the mob of rioters and entered the Capitol building through a broken window. He can then be seen on video inside Senate offices, prosecutors allege, before he exited the building. Court records indicate that a warrant was issued for Grant's arrest on Sept. 29, 2021, and the FBI arrested him about two weeks later, on Oct. 14, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury, and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Grant pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Darrell Neely works for the Global Enlightenment Radio Network, court documents state. The network's website says that it supports "knowledge enhanced by factual truth"  and features shows titled The Martian Revelation and America's Cannabis Conversation. Prosecutors allege that Neely breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and can be seen on video smoking a "marijuana cigarette" inside the building. According to court documents filed in the case, multiple witnesses said they had spoken by phone and video calls with Neely while he was in and around the Capitol, and he allegedly told those witnesses that he had taken items from the building, including China plates as well as a Capitol Police officer's jacket, hat and badge. Prosecutors allege that Neely later uploaded a video to YouTube, in which he discussed the events of Jan. 6, 2021, while wearing a Capitol Police hat. According to court documents, FBI agents interviewed Neely twice, and Neely admitted to entering the Capitol building, because, Neely allegedly said, he felt the events were newsworthy. Neely also allegedly provided photos he took from inside the building to the FBI and showed agents videos he had taken during the riot. Neely served in and exited the U.S. Navy in 1994, according to a Navy spokesperson. He was arrested on Oct. 18, 2021.
charges: Theft of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Neely pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Christian Manley was captured on video approaching the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, while "holding what appears to be a container of pepper spray" and wearing military-style clothing and a backpack. Manley, court documents state, then sprayed pepper spray at a group of police officers guarding an entry by the lower west terrace of the Capitol. After that canister appeared to be empty, Manley allegedly threw it at the officers and discharged a second can of pepper spray at police. Prosecutors allege that Manley then received a metal rod from other rioters and threw it at police. According to an arrest warrant filed in court, the FBI arrested Manley in Anchorage, Alaska, on Oct. 15, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in a Capitol Building or Grounds
case_updates: Manley pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI and said Julio Cesar Chang had posted photos from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot on Facebook, according to a statement of facts filed in federal court. Chang allegedly posted photos of himself wearing a pro-Trump hat by the U.S. Capitol, along with the caption: "The deplorables have taken back our country." In another post cited in court documents, Chang captioned a video from near the Washington Monument, "The beginning of our Second American Revolution." Prosecutors allege that celphone records and surveillance footage show that Chang breached the Capitol building during the riot and made it inside the Rotunda. Chang previously worked for the Broward County Sheriff's Office in Florida, the court documents state, and one of his former co-workers provided information to the FBI during its investigation into Chang. The Broward County Sheriff's Office confirmed to NPR that Chang worked there from 1991 to 2005 and said he retired at the rank of lieutenant. A spokesperson for the U.S. Marine Corps also confirmed that Chang served on active duty for nearly two decades, reaching the rank of gunnery sergeant. In 2003, he deployed to Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chang pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Landon Mitchell told friends on Facebook that he was “one of the very first in” during the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot, adding that he is “invincible” and “not too worried” about getting arrested because he was “masked up the whole time,” according to subpoenaed Facebook messages included in an FBI statement of facts. Mitchell attached photos and videos of himself posing on the dais at the front of the Senate chamber. Additionally, surveillance footage shows Mitchell entering the Senate chamber and leafing through documents left on a desk when senators abandoned the room, according to the statement of facts. The court documents also include posts from Mitchell’s Facebook page including the statements, “If we don’t fight now, there is no point in ever voting again” and “when they invalidated my vote with all their chasing, they invalidated my consent to be governed by them!” Luke Bender, a man arrested in July on charges stemming from the riot at the Capitol, also told FBI agents that he and Mitchell, his former co-worker, remained inside the Senate chamber for about five minutes, according to the statement of facts. Mitchell was arrested Oct. 20, 2021, in Arlington, Va., and ordered to wear a GPS monitor upon his release.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
case_updates: Mitchell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Unlike many of the defendants charged in the U.S. Capitol riot, Robert Wayne Dennis was identified during the course of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack when police requested and obtained his ID, Social Security number, name and address, according to court records filed by federal prosecutors. Dennis allegedly assaulted multiple police officers outside the Capitol building and can be seen on police body-camera footage pushing at least one officer to the ground and punching the officer. That same afternoon, prosecutors say, a police officer spoke to Dennis and informed him that a warrant would later be issued for his arrest but that he would be released to seek medical treatment. Court documents show that the warrant was issued on Oct. 14, 2021, and Dennis was arrested on Oct. 20, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
case_updates: Dennis pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two people reached out to the FBI to tell the bureau that Philip Weisbecker had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. Law enforcement was then able to find records indicating that Weisbecker had taken a Frontier Airlines flight to the Washington, D.C., area on Jan. 4, 2021 and left on Jan. 7, 2021. Weisbecker also posted to Facebook a screenshot of the TV show Tucker Carlson Tonight, in which Weisbecker can allegedly be seen inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. He allegedly captioned the screenshot: "if you would like to know the truth....just ask." In early February 2021, Weisbecker, who lives in San Diego, was stopped at the U.S.-Mexico border, trying to enter the U.S. During that stop, he allegedly acknowledged that he was at the "Stop The Steal" rally and claimed he had been there as a "citizen journalist." According to court records, Weisbecker admitted to entering the Capitol and also said he was in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office. He allegedly claimed that rioters were "let in the U.S. Capitol building by DC Police." A few days later, he was stopped at the border again. This time, he was "verbally abusive and uncooperative," according to Border Patrol agents. He allegedly told them that he "does not believe President Biden is the legitimate president" and that he "feels that he is freer in Mexico than in the U.S."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Weisbecker pleaded Guilty to charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 6/27/2022 to 24 Months of Probation; 30 days intermittent confinement; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500; Fine of $2,000

summary: Kim Michael Sorgente is allegedly seen in video footage, police body camera footage and photographs among the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, he was wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat and a shirt that read "Deus Vult," a Latin phrase used as a rallying cry during the Crusades that roughly translates to "God's Will" and that has now gained popularity among far-right extremists. Sorgente was also identified, prosecutors say, through his cellphone number. That number had been obtained when he was arrested for an incident in December 2020, and on Jan. 6, 2021, location records allegedly show it near and/or inside the Capitol building. In police body camera footage from that day, Sorgente can allegedly be seen yelling into a megaphone: “How dare you? How dare you, traitors? How dare you traitors?” from behind a line of rioters who were pushing a police barricade into officers. Sorgente continued to yell into the microphone as other rioters assaulted police, court documents indicate, including: “Why don’t you let us in? Let us in. It’s our house. It’s our house. You let us in, we’ll behave. If you keep fighting us and pepper-spraying us, we’re gonna get upset.”  Sorgente is allegedly later seen on surveillance footage entering a tunnel that led into the Capitol, where a violent standoff between rioters and police occurred. At one point in the late afternoon, court documents indicate, Sorgente was pushing directly against law enforcement as they tried to expel rioters from the archway to the tunnel.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
case_updates: Sorgente pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Gilbert Fonticoba was arrested on Oct. 26, 2021, in Miami and charged in a felony indictment with six counts, including obstructing an official proceeding and civil disorder. According to his LinkedIn page and multiple news outlets, Fonticoba has appeared at rallies for Trump in Florida and supports the Proud Boys.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in Capitol Building
case_updates: Fonticoba pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI began investigating Paul Colbath in January after receiving a tip that Colbath had been "bragging" about his involvement in the U.S. Capitol riot, according to documents filed in federal court. FBI agents then interviewed Colbath, who said voluntarily that he had breached the Capitol building through an open door and saw shattered glass and plumes of chemical smoke from tear gas, federal prosecutors say. Colbath allegedly told the FBI that he had made "a big mistake" and said he did not bring weapons inside the Capitol or promote the overthrow of the U.S. government. Agents subsequently found video that appeared to show Colbath inside the Capitol during the riot, prosecutors allege, and Colbath confirmed to agents that it was indeed him on the footage. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Colbath served in the U.S. Army.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Colbath pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 4/6/2022 to 36 Months of Probation; 30 days location monitoring/home detention; 60 hours of community service; $10 Special Assessment; Restitution of $500

summary: Jia Liu enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserves in 2014 and is currently listed as an E-4 (corporal) cyber network operator, according to an FBI affidavit. He’s also the sole member of Memelope LLC, a business registered with the state of New York, according to the court documents. The affidavit notes that records from New York Police license plate readers show a Jeep Wrangler registered to Liu’s stepfather leaving New York City around 5:30 a.m. on Jan. 6, 2021, and returning toward Queens around midnight that evening. FBI agents allege that Liu entered the U.S. Capitol twice on Jan. 6, 2021. First, surveillance footage allegedly shows Liu standing inside and snapping cellphone photos for about seven minutes before exiting through a broken window. About 25 minutes later, Liu reentered the Capitol and remained inside for almost a half-hour, according to the court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Liu pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Wearing a black beanie stitched with a yellow wreath commonly associated with the Proud Boys and a white cowboy hat that referenced the Stop the Steal slogan, Joshua John Portlock allegedly shrugged when officers ordered him out of a tunnel into the U.S. Capitol building. In reply, Portlock allegedly gestured to the crowd surrounding him and said “I can’t with this." He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3, 2021, in Smyrna, Tenn.
charges: Civil Disorder (3 counts); Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Portlock pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal investigators first learned of Daniel Michael Morrissey's involvement in the U.S. Capitol riot from Morrissey's coworkers, charging documents state. Morrissey allegedly shared photos and videos from inside the Capitol with his coworkers, and the coworkers then shared those photos and videos with the FBI. In addition, prosecutors say, surveillance and police body camera footage both show Morrissey inside the building during the riot. Morrissey was arrested in Denvert  on Nov. 4, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Morrissey pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced  8/16/2022 to 45 days of incarceration, three years of probation, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution; $10 special assessment
