summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Thomas Patrick Hamner fought with police outside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Pictures cited in court documents allegedly depict Hamner wearing a sweater with the logo "Guns Don’t Kill People, Clintons Do" and a black helmet. Both open-source and police body camera video show Hamner pushing against the police line protecting the Capitol and pulling bike racks that police were using to hold back the rioters, according to charging documents. Hamner was arrested in Colorado Springs, Colo., on Nov. 9, 2021.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Hamner pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. Sentencing is set for 9/8/2022

summary: Julio Baquero came to the attention of law enforcement through a tip to the FBI about a week after the events of Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. Baquero allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Louis Valentin, and allegedly told law enforcment in an interview that he had entered the U.S. Capitol building during the insurrection. According to a federal filing, video footage from inside the Capitol shows Baquero entering the Capitol Rotunda and, in one instance, grabbing the hand of a police officer as law enforcement attempted to clear the building. At another point, Baquero is allegedly seen on camera shouding at officers, "You're a traitor!"
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baquero pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement was first alerted about Louis Valentin approximately one week after Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Prosecutors say he had gone to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Julio Baquero, and in a March 2021 interview, he allegedly acknowledged being inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the insurrection. According to a federal filing, Valentin can be observed on camera footage entering the Capitol wearing a red hat and flag mask. While law enforcement asserts that Baquero physically and verbally confronted officers attempting to clear the Capitol, they make no similar claim about Valentin.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Valentin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: David Rhine came to the attention of the FBI just days after the riot at the U.S. Capitol, and court documents point to two tipsters who said they knew that he had been in the Capitol during the riot. The FBI identified him from information provided by the tipsters, and a review of records obtained by search warrant indicate that a cellphone number Rhine subscribed to was associated with location data in and around the Capitol on Jan 6, 2021. The first tipster allegedly saw a screenshot of a post by Rhine's wife. That post stated that Rhine had been at the rally that day and entered the Capitol, and went on to say she was proud of her husband's actions, according to charging documents. When the tipster texted both Rhine and his wife to encourage him to share information he had, presumably with law enfrorcement, Rhine allegedly replied "I witenessd ZERO violence.  I saw no 'proud boys'.  Capitol police removed barriers and let people in." Later the tipster identified an image from inside the Capitol building as David Rhine, and more images of that day indicate that the man identified as Rhine was detained by an officer who searched him and found two knives and pepper spray, court documents state. Rhine appears to have been escorted down to the Rotunda, where he left the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rhine pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Gregory Nix is accused of assaulting a police officer during the events of Jan. 6, 2021. Video footage allegedly showed Nix banging a giant white flagpole into the doors of the East House, trying to get into the U.S. Capitol on the day of the riot. Not long afterwards, Nix allegedly struck a Capitol Police officer with the flagpole, and then thrust and threw it at him. Later, court documents state, he tried to smash the glass panes of the East House doors with a black baton before finally entering the building.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property;  Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
case_updates: Nix pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jeremy Baouche first came to the attention of federal law enforcement in a case of mistaken identity. A number of tipsters identified him in a photograph put out by the FBI, but that individual was later determined to be someone else: Elliot Bishai, who was arrested in March 2021. However, Baouche's employer — Electric Boat, a Pentagon contractor — voluntarily provided law enforcement with Baouche's work computer's search history, which included searches about the U.S. Capitol's layout, Trump protests, and "FBI Capitol," court documents indicate. A Google search warrant also allegedly yielded information that showed a phone associated with Baouche was inside the U.S. Capitol during the time of the Jan. 6 insurrection. Upon reviewing video from inside the Capitol, the FBI found video in which Baouche is allegedly seen entering the building while carrying a megaphone. Baouche declined to speak with the FBI without a lawyer.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Baouche pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 1/10/2023

summary: Rafael Valadez Jr. is accused by federal law enforcement of livestreaming his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on Jan. 6, 2021. The video, which the FBI alleges was taken by Valadez, allegedly shows him entering the U.S. Capitol. Further review of surveillance camera footage from inside the Capitol shows a man that the FBI identifies as Valadez, and video from Facebook obtained through a search warrant shows the videos that were apparently livestreamed, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Valadez pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/16/2022

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Gregory Purdy took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged; a man identified as his brother, Matthew Purdy; and another a man identified as his uncle, Robert Turner. Gregory Purdy allegedly documented many of his actions that day on Instagram. Purdy allegedly recorded a video from the chaos outside the Capitol, in which he said, "Right now, we're on the top of the Capitol. Everybody stormed through. We're the second wave coming in." Gregory Purdy can allegedly be heard on police body camera footage telling officers, "Are you guys going to let us in, or are we gonna have to push in?" He later pushed through a police line outside the building before being restrained by officers, charging documents state. In another post, he allegedly stated, "Peep my war cry at the end as we push through this riot team." Purdy then breached the Capitol building and continued to record videos and post them to social media, court documents state. In one social media post, Purdy allegedly added a caption about how he "got out of it with NO CHARGES and nothing on my record" along with an emoji of applying nail polish. Purdy also allegedly recorded videos after the riot, in which he described how "I bumrushed" police officers and said, "It's our job to uphold the constitution and do a f***ing rebellion." Gregory Purdy surrendered to the FBI on Nov. 10, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Purdy pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Matthew Purdy took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged; a man identified as his brother, Gregory Purdy; and another a man identified as his uncle, Robert Turner. Police body camera footage allegedly shows Matthew Purdy with a crowd of people pushing against police officers guarding the outside of the Capitol building. Gregory Purdy also allegedly documented their actions that day on his phone and uploaded more than a dozen videos to Instagram. Prosecutors allege that Matthew Purdy could be seen in footage breaching the inside of the Capitol building. Matthew Purdy surrendered to the FBI on Nov. 10, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Purdy pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Robert Turner took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his nephews, Gregory and Matthew Purdy, as well as their father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged. Gregory Purdy allegedly documented their actions that day on his phone and uploaded more than a dozen videos to Instagram describing or depicting the men pushing against police on guard at the Capitol and actually breaching the building. Police body camera footage also allegedly shows Turner yelling at police. At another point, Turner allegedly told officers, "Stop taking orders. We're not here - we're not here to kill or hurt anybody, we're making our voice heard."
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Turner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A revolver loaded with both live shotgun shells and hollow-point rounds fell from an unknown suspect’s waistband as he scuffled with a police sergeant on Jan. 6, 2021, near the U.S. Capitol steps, according to court documents. Two days later, Mark Mazza reported to local police in Indiana that his gun, matching the serial number of the one dropped, had been stolen from a car while he spent hours inside a Cincinnati casino. When confronted during a police interview in March, Mazza claimed he reported it stolen because, “if Antifa found it, someone might get killed and my name is all over it.” Mazza then claimed the gun slipped from his holster in a tunnel entrance to the Capitol just after 3 p.m. Jan. 6, 2021, according to the court documents, but the police sergeant reported picking it up on the Capitol’s steps a half-hour before that. During the interview, Mazza denied assaulting any police officers during the riot, replying, “In fact … I helped two of them” and “I can barely make a fist because of my arthritis.” However, the court documents allege surveillance footage shows Mazza swinging a baton at officers in the tunnel just after he yelled, “This is our f**king house! We own this house!” According to the court documents, Mazza ended his interview by claiming he “may go down as a hero,” adding “if you do have to come back and take me, put me in a fed … I just want three squares and a nice clean room, someone takes care of my health care and I’m good.” Mazza was arrested Nov. 17, 2021, in Shelbyville, Ind.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Carrying a Pistol Without a License (DC); Possession of Unregistered Firearm (DC); Unlawful Possession of Ammunition (DC); Second Degree Theft (DC)
case_updates: Mazza pleaded Guilty to two charges: Counts 4, and 10 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; and Carrying a Pistol Without a License (D.C. Code). Sentencing set for 9/30/2022

summary: Court documents say that Aiden Bilyard helped break one of the windows through which many people, including Bilyard, breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Bilyard can allegedly be seen in multiple images from that day — some of them show a young man with long, dirty-blond hair, wearing a black jacket over a gray hoodie that appears to read “Harvard.” Later, Bilyard was dubbed #HarvardSweats by the online group Sedition Hunters, which sought to identify some of the people who breached the Capitol that day. According to the charging documents, Bilyard was among the throng of rioters clutching a large gold canister of what is believed to be “bear spray,” which he sprayed at a group of police officers trying to secure the building. An officer who was on the receiving end of that spray found himself incapacitated by it. Later in the afternoon, Bilyard is allegedly seen in video footage egging on another rioter who's trying to break a window of the Capitol. According to court documents, Bilyard was handed a bat, shattered the window and entered a Senate room through the broken window. Bilyard was reportedly identified from a previous booking photo and a Facebook profile associated with him in which he can be seen wearing the Harvard sweatshirt. Later, Bilyard’s mother reportedly retrieved the hoodie and gave it to the FBI. Agents followed up with Bilyard later when he was in basic training for the U.S. Air Force, where he allegedly admitted that he was on the Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021, but said he did not break any laws. When he was shown videos of his apparent participation in unlawful activities, he ended his conversation with the FBI, saying, “I think this is where I take my leave.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bilyard pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Edward Badalian conspired over the encrypted chat-app Telegram to travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying "weapons and tactical gear" such as a "taser, pepper spray, a baseball bat, gas masks, and walkie talkies" to ultimately disrupt the certification of the 2020 presidential election. In December 2020, after then-President Donald Trump called for a rally on Jan. 6, 2021, Badalian allegedly messaged a Telegram group called PATRIOTS 45 MAGA Gang and said, "we need to violently remove traitors and if they are in key positions rapidly replace them with able bodied Patriots." Prosecutors allege that Badalian was traveling with another defendant, Daniel Rodriguez, and that Rodriguez wrote to the chat on Jan. 5, 2021: "There will be blood. Welcome to the revolution." On the day of the riot, Badalian, Rodriguez and others gathered by the western side of the U.S. Capitol, court documents state. Rodriguez has been accused of using an "electroshock weapon" to attack an officer with the Metropolitan Police Department, identified by various news sources to be Mike Fanone. Rodriguez is also accused of using a flagpole as a weapon and breaking into the Capitol building. Badalian also allegedly breached the Capitol through a broken window. Two days after the riot, prosecutors allege, Badalian called into an Infowars show under the pseudonym "Turbo" and claimed he fought off a man from the anti-fascist movement antifa who was breaking windows at the Capitol. (There is no evidence that antifa supporters participated in the Capitol riot.) Though Badalian allegedly used the name "Turbo" to conceal his identity, a subsequent caller referred to him as "Ed" on the Infowars broadcast.
charges: Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings; Restricted Building or Grounds;
case_updates: Badalian pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: James Beeks was allegedly part of a group of Oath Keepers members and affiliates that marched on the U.S Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors say that he was already on the radar of law enforcement after a rioter who pleaded guilty identified him as one of the people who lined up with the Oath Keepers the day of the riot. The criminal complaint alleges that he was part of the group that entered into a formation — called a “stack” — in order to force its way into the Capitol. Court documents enumerate many records obtained that show Beeks traveled to Washington, D.C., on the day of the riot, including records from a personal finance app and a rental car agency, as well as cellphone records. Beeks was not wearing the typical camouflage favored by the far-right extremist group, according to court documents, but instead appears in images from that day in a black jacket with the word “Bad” on it in red letters, from Michael Jackson's 1987 world tour. It is that jacket that helped lead law enforcement to him; agents found photographs on Instagram of a person who appears to be Beeks wearing the jacket while posing in front of a sign for the musical play Jesus Christ Superstar. Beeks is an actor who performs as Judas — under the stage name James T. Justis — in the traveling production of the play, and the criminal complaint notes he was observed performing the role in both San Francisco and Los Angeles. In addition, he has also performed as a Michael Jackson impersonator. Prosecutors claim that Beeks changed his phone and phone number the day after an indictment naming co-conspirators was filed and registered his new phone under his stage name. After Beeks was charged, he appeared in court and claimed that the U.S. government had no authority over him — which a U.S. District judge called “gobbledygook.” The production of Jesus Christ Superstar has since replaced him in the role of Judas.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting

summary: Alexis Ivan Bustos was identified by the FBI from Instagram pictures posted by his relative, Bryan Emmanuel Bustos, that appear to show Alexis Bustos inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The two men allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., from California. According to the FBI, both men share the same last name, address and cellphone plan. Alexis Bustos allegedly entered the building through the Columbus doors at the building's eastern side while sporting a blue “Trump” beanie and a black jacket. Both men entered the building at different times, court documents state, but left shortly before 3 p.m.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bustos pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Sometime around Jan. 10, 2021, the FBI received an online tip with an Instagram picture of a man inside the U.S. Capitol. The Instagram account name on the photo was Bryan Emmanuel Bustos, according to court documents. Security footage reviewed by the FBI confirmed that the picture was indeed taken inside the building on Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say. The FBI also reviewed Bustos’ Instagram account, which allegedly had images of another individual, Alexis Ivan Bustos, outside and inside the Capitol building. According to the FBI, the two men traveled together to Washington, D.C., from California, where they share the same address and a cellphone plan. Both men are charged in the riot. Bryan Bustos allegedly entered the Capitol through the Columbus doors at the building's eastern side while carrying a large U.S. flag. On June 17, 2021, the FBI interviewed a restaurant co-worker of Bryan Bustos who reportedly confirmed his identity.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bustos pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: When a Proud Boys’ leader asked the crowd, “Do you want your house back?” on Jan. 6, 2021, near the U.S. Capitol, video footage allegedly shows Lisa Anne Homer standing next to him yelling, “Yes!” and then "taunting" police at the front of the protest lines, according to an FBI statement of facts. Homer added a camouflage helmet and googles to her tactical vest before entering the Capitol, where subpoenaed phone records indicate she remained for over an hour. Homer has posted a Proud Boys emblem to her social media, as well as photos taken at the Proud Boys’ Million MAGA March in Washington, D.C., in November 2020, according to the statement of facts. She was arrested on Nov. 26, 2021, in Colorado Springs, Colo.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Homer pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 8/9/2022 to 36 Months Probation; $10 Special Assessment; $5,000 Fine; Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service

summary: Phone records show Michael G. McCormick’s mobile phone remained within the restricted zone around the U.S. Capitol for nearly three hours on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Surveillance footage allegedly shows McCormick entering the Senate wing at about 2:55 p.m., hand held aloft filming a video on his cellphone. The FBI obtained photos and videos from McCormick’s phone that appear to have been taken inside the Capitol, including an 11-minute clip of his alleged entry into the building and his walk through the Crypt and Hall of Columns. Court records show McCormick was arrested Nov. 18, 2021, in Orange, Calif., and he was ordered to remove firearms from his home by Nov. 20, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: McCormick pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors allege that Timothy Desjardins arrived at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a backpack with three axes in it, assaulted police with a broken table leg, and later tried to breach chains near FBI headquarters. Desjardins' alleged assault of law enforcement took place during the infamous struggle in the tunnel of the lower west terrace, where he was allegedly seen in YouTube videos striking officers over and over again with “a significant amount of force.” Another tip from an FBI officer reported that Desjardins was caught the day after the riot in the early morning hours at FBI headquarters, trying to go over chains behind the building. When he was approached by officers, he reportedly showed his driver’s license, and officers noticed he had a couple of hatchets on the side of his backpack, which he claimed he was “good with." Desjardins was allowed to leave after it was determined there were no outstanding warrants for him.  Court records state that Desjardins was later confirmed to be at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by agents who compared the video from that day with both his driver’s license and mugshots from an arrest months earlier in which he allegedly fired a shot in a Providence Walgreens parking lot. Two weeks before his arrest on charges related to the Capitol riot, Desjardins was arrested in an armed standoff with police in Providence on unrelated charges.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Howard Charles Richardson is alleged to have assaulted a law enforcment officer with a flagpole during the U.S. Capitol insurrection, which was captured on police body cameras. Cameras worn by at least four police officers captured Richardson taking a metal flagpole with a blue Trump flag on it and attacking the officers "unprovoked," a federal filing claimed. "Here it comes," Richardson is allegedly heard yelling before striking an officer three times. The FBI said that Richardson "only stopped swinging after the flagpole broke in his hands." Photos and videos of that act were later used to identify Richardson as the assailant. Richardson was also known to local police in his community due to a separate act in which he allegedly assaulted a motorcyclist outside his residence. In an interview with FBI agents after his arrest for that unrelated act, he acknowledged that he was at the Capitol on the day of the insurrection. He allegedly told the FBI that he had been tear gassed as rioters attempted to breach the perimeter of the Capitol and acknowledged that he was the individual in the body camera videos. "I'm not saying this is the best behavior I could have done here," he said.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Richardson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon. Sentenced on 8/26/2022 to 46 months incarceration; three years of probation, $2,000 restitution

summary: Shortly after the U.S. Capitol riot, a tipster approached the FBI with the information that Tyler Tew had posted on Facebook that he was at the Capitol during the insurrection, court documents indicate. A search warrant served on Google showed that a mobile device associated with Tew was at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and surveillance camera footage inside the Capitol shows an individual that the bureau has identified as Tew entering the building through the Senate parliamentarian's door, according to court documents. Shortly after this footage, pepper balls were fired in his direction. Messages from his cellphone, obtained through a search warrant, reportedly showed Tew bragging that he "was inside" the Capitol and got "pepper sprayed in the face for my country." Two days after the riot, Tew allegedly wrote his spouse, "I stormed the capital [sic] building FOR YOU!!!!" In the days following, Tew messaged multiple individuals and seemingly acknowledged that he had been inside the Capitol during the riot, according to a federal filing.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Tew pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement was tipped off to Lawrence Ligas’ alleged involvement in the riot at the U.S. Capitol by a tip from someone who said they’d seen him quoted by name in an NPR story about Jan. 6, 2021. In the story, Ligas is quoted as saying, "We're not moving on ... We are not Republicans. We are the MAGA party. We are patriots.” The tipster identified Ligas from a driver’s license photo but hadn’t seen him in a decade, court documents indicate. The day before the riot, Ligas can allegedly be seen in a YouTube livestream in downtown Washington, D.C., wearing a blue scarf with white stars. In video footage from inside the Capitol during the next day's riot, prosecutors allege that he can be seen again, wearing the same scarf, walking in and out of the rotunda. Prosecutors say photographs associated with Ligas and obtained from Google also show him in and around the Capitol on the day of the riot, and Southwest Airlines records trace his apparent trip to and from Washington. The criminal complaint also indicates that Ligas had called the FBI's National Threat Operations Center to report voter fraud in March and April of 2019.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ligas pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Mark Kulas Jr. was charged alongside his younger brother, Christian Kulas, for his alleged involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. The brothers are reportedly from the Chicago area and are sons to the owner of a maid service, Kulas Maids, according to the *Chicago Tribune*. Prosecutors say the two flew from Illinois to Washington, D.C., the day before the riot, according to the *Chicago Sun-Times*. Both men have pleaded guilty.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kulas pleaded Guilty to the charge. Sentenced on 4/26/2022 to 6 months of Probation; 60 days home detention; Special Assessment of $10; Restitution of $500

summary: Danean Kimberly MacAndrew was identified by the FBI as a person inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, based on a review of cell tower data, court records indicate. FBI agents then traveled to MacAndrew's house in late September to interview her, where she allegedly admitted to entering the Capitol building that day, though she claimed she was let in by police. MacAndrew also had posted content on the social media platform Gab that indicated she was at the Capitol that day, court records state. In one comment, she allegedly wrote of expecting to be arrested: "I was scared of it for weeks, so I didn't post my videos. I finally stood up for truth. When I did, I wasn't scared anymore."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
case_updates: MacAndrew pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Daniel Shaw was identified by law enforcement as having been involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot when another person charged, Kenneth Reda, allegedly mentioned that he had stayed in Shaw's hotel room while in Washington, D.C., and identified Shaw in security camera footage from inside the building. Law enforcement also obtained a search warrant from Verizon and allegedly confirmed that Shaw's cellphone pinged on a cell site that serves the area inside the Capitol on the day of the riot. According to court records, security camera footage from inside the building also appear to show Shaw's son, whose name has been redacted, with him.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Shaw pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “Stormed Nancy[’s] office,” Michael Gianos wrote to a friend on Facebook on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. “I watched them take her laptop … Video I have are inside. Just don’t wanna send them … cause their gonna arrest people.” Surveillance footage allegedly shows Gianos and two co-defendants entering an office within House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s suite, where the statement of facts claims they remained for less than a minute. For weeks leading up to the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, Gianos exchanged messages with co-defendants Rachel Myers and Lawrence Stackhouse and also forwarded tweets from President Donald Trump and Rudy Giuliani, which reflected his belief that the 2020 election had been “stolen,” according to the statement of facts. Gianos was arrested on Dec. 1, 2021, in Marlton, N.J.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gianos pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “I am totally fine with a civil war at this point. It’s beyond time,” Rachel Myers replied to a Facebook post in December 2020, according to screenshots that a tipster sent to the FBI. A few days later, according to an FBI statement of facts, Myers expressed hopes of getting into a fight with counterprotesters at the Jan. 6, 2021, rally, writing to her co-defendant Lawrence Stackhouse: “I’m not scared of those little f****** … those twerps love weapons cuz they can’t fight … I’ll be marching with the P[roud ]B[oy]s so they stay away from me." Surveillance footage allegedly shows Myers entering an office in House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office suite and walking through the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In the days following, prosecutors say, Myers commented on a Facebook post: “Girl I was there Wednesday, and NO RIOT ever happened. The media are absolute liars. The cops opened those doors for everyone to walk right into the Capitol.” Myers also allegedly texted Stackhouse, writing: “Don’t tell anyone you were there. Just move forward and we will deal with whatever comes our way if it happens!” She was arrested on Dec. 1, 2021, in Philadelphia.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Myers pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that James Haffner took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named Ronald Loehrke. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Haffner and Loehrke marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building, and, at one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Haffner was arrested in Rapid City, S.D., on Dec. 1, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of Law Enforcement During a Civil Disorder; Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Ronald Loehrke took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named James Haffner. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Loehrke and Haffner marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building. When a line of police protecting the outside of the Capitol stopped people from advancing farther, Loehrke allegedly said, "Don't back down, patriots! The whole f****** world is watching. Stand the f*** up today!" At one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Ronald Loehrke was arrested in Cumming, Ga., on Dec. 3, 2021.
charges: Obstruction of Law Enforcement During a Civil Disorder; Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: Before the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, Brent Holdridge was wanted by law enforcement for failing to report to jail in Humboldt County, Calif., to begin serving a four-month sentence for possession of a controlled substance, according to an FBI statement of facts. Holdridge was arrested in February for that offense and, according to the statement of facts, he later showed photos from his trip to Washington, D.C., to his probation officer, although he claimed he stayed outside the Capitol on the day of the riot. However, the probation officer reportedly identified Holdridge in surveillance footage as a man carrying a rolled-up flag through the Capitol, appearing to record video on a cellphone. Additionally, cellphone records appear to show Holdridge's mobile device as having been present in the building during the riot, according to the statement of facts. When interviewed by FBI agents in September, Holdridge allegedly confirmed his presence at the “Stop the Steal” rally, but he refused to answer whether he entered the Capitol, adding that he “did not steal anything, touch or assault anyone, or damage any property.” He surrendered on Dec. 2, 2021, at the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin, Calif.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Holdridge pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 12/2/2022

summary: The FBI had sought information on a man wearing a hooded sweatshirt with a logo from the University of Michigan who they suspected of assaulting police during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. An online group of civilians investigating the Capitol riot dubbed that man "fingerman," because he was seen on video footage waving his middle finger at police. Federal agents subsequently identified "fingerman" as Justin Jersey. An indictment filed in federal court accuses Jersey of assaulting a police officer with the Metropolitan Police Department and then using a baton to attack other police officers guarding the Capitol. Jersey was arrested on Dec. 2, 2021.
charges: Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Jersey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Josiah Kenyon allegedly stormed the U.S. Capitol building in costume. The criminal complaint details images of him dressed as Jack Skellington, from the film *The Nightmare before Christmas* -- with the addition of a red Make America Great Again hat. Court documents allege that Kenyon attempted to break a Capitol window with a flagstaff and assaulted law enforcement officers with several objects, including a broken table leg with a nail protruding from it. The FBI had asked for help identifying Kenyon from footage of the riot, and ultimately, it was the Jack Skellington costume that led several witnesses to say that they had seen him on the grounds of the Capitol; on the Washington, D.C., Metro; and at a motel in Springfield, Va., on or around Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. According to court records, two more witnesses, including one relative, positively identified Kenyon from a photograph, and the criminal complaint alleges that FBI agents ultimately confirmed that his bank records and fare purchases at the Metro were consistent with his travel to the site of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Kenyon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to charging documents, Marcos Panayiotou is a reservist in the U.S. Marine Corps and wore a Camp Pendleton sweatshirt with the name and logo of his former battalion into the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Panayiotou can allegedly be seen in various images in the sweatshirt and also wearing a red hat which read: MAKE POLITICIANS AFRAID AGAIN. Days after the riot, the FBI received a report from someone whose friend watched a video that allegedly showed Panayiotou inside the Capitol building and also alerted agents to Panayiotou’s military background. Court documents say that agents confirmed with the Defense Department that he is a Marine reservist. Agents spoke to multiple people who identified Panayiotou, including a close family member who described him as very patriotic but added he “does stupid things sometimes," court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Panayiotou pleaded Guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Federal prosecutors say that Roy Franklin was one of the rioters that made his way to the Senate floor on the day of the riot at the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate that Franklin traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend Thomas Adams Jr., who was charged in April of 2021. The criminal complaint references an article from *Insider,* published the day after the riot, that says Franklin tripped while at the bottom of the Capitol steps and fell onto an officer who he says “barely reacted.” The article reported that Franklin followed a group of people who were climbing scaffolding and entering the building through a window that was smashed. Once inside, Franklin allegedly followed people onto the floor of the Senate and observed “a shirtless man with an animal skin headdress and his face painted red, white, and blue stood at the speaker's chair, wielding a bullhorn, and flexing his biceps” who was presumably Jacob Chansley, also known as the QAnon Shaman. Months after the riot, agents say they tracked Franklin down at his house, executed a search warrant and seized gear that they claim can be seen in images of that day and in particular the footage from the Senate floor: a Trump 2020 Keep America Great flag, a plaid patterned shirt, a pair of Nike shoes and a baseball cap emblazoned with “United States of America” and a flag in the center. During the execution of the search warrant, an FBI agent alleges that he overheard a conversation between Franklin and his significant other.  In the conversation, Franklin allegedly admitted that he was in the Capitol building. He also allegedly said, “You had to be there, the whole thing was fun.”
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parade, Demonstrate, Or Picket in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Franklin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Thomas Paul Conover spent much of the day on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a can of Coors Light beer, which he brought with him as he breached the U.S. Capitol building, federal prosecutors allege. During that time, court documents state, Conover also filmed videos of himself, including one in which he said, "I don't always storm the Capitol of the United States of America. But when I do, I prefer Coors Light." Prosecutors allege that Conover posted on Facebook about his activity on Jan. 6, stating, "GREETINGS FROM WASHINGTON DC" and "WE TOOK THE CAPITAL [sic]." Surveillance and police bodycam footage also allegedly shows Conover inside the building during the riot. Later, court documents state, the FBI received a tip from someone who saw Conover's Facebook posts and turned over screenshots to law enforcement.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Conover pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed.  Sentenced on 4/22/2022 to 36 months probation with 30 days confinement in a residential re-entry facility; $2500 fine; $500 restitution; $10 special assessment

summary: Charging documents for Luke Faulkner and Jared Kastner say that a photo of Faulkner in front of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appears in Google records belonging to Kastner. Agents believe Faulkner to be a frequent contact of Kastner and ran a search warrant on Faulkner's cellphone account, which showed the phone had pinged a cell site that includes the inside of the Capitol building during the riot. Surveillance footage also allegedly shows Kastner and Faulkner in the Crypt of the Capitol, among a crowd pushing through officers that were attempting to hold them back. In addition to the footage, multiple records obtained by law enforcement show that Kastner traveled to an apartment in North Beach, Md., in the first week of January 2021 from his home in Ohio and then back to Ohio, where he arrived at an address belonging to Faulkner, on Jan. 7, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Faulkner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Court documents say that in the course of the FBI's investigation into the riot at the U.S. Capitol, investigators found information that a device linked with a Google account allegedly owned by Jared Kastner was inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Agents then compared his driver's license photo to the images and videos from the riot, and allegedly found a match. They also looked at photos in his Google account, including one that shows him three days before Jan. 6, 2021, with the same "distinctive" facial hair shown in images of the riot: thick sideburns connected to a mustache and a clean-shaven chin. Kastner has been charged along with Luke Faulkner, and they apparently entered the building together, according to the criminal complaint. Surveillance footage allegedly shows Kastner and Faulkner in the Crypt of the Capitol, among a crowd pushing through officers that were attempting to hold them back. In addition to the footage, multiple records obtained by law enforcement show that Kastner traveled to an apartment in North Beach, Md., in the first week of January 2021 from his home in Ohio. Agents spoke with a person who lived in that apartment who said that Kastner and another person stayed there the night before the riot and said they were going into Washington, D.C., to attend the Trump rally the next day.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kastner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal law enforcement identified Jeffrey Hubbard among the rioters inside the U.S. Capitol building, in part, through what court documents describe as his "distinct bald head." At one point, prosecutors say, footage shows Hubbard chanting "break it down" inside the Capitol. Local law enforcement allegedly spoke to Hubbard's mother around the time of the riot, and court documents state that she told officers that Hubbard was in Washington, D.C., for the pro-Trump rally. Subsequent searches of cellphone records allegedly corroborate the video footage and other evidence suggesting Hubbard breached the Capitol. Hubbard was arrested Dec. 8, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hubbard pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two days after the U.S. Capitol riot, at least three people contacted the FBI to alert them to a concerning Parler user operating under the account @Craftmetal. One wrote: "This individual has been talking about overthrowing the government for weeks in public chat rooms pushing disinformation and talking about hanging and executing people repetitively ... He claims to have been in the Capitol Building on the 6th of January and has posted multiple disturbing videos which would seem to substantiate this statement." The tipster including a screenshot of the Parler account, which appeared to show Michael Oliveras' name and phone number, which the FBI then verified and located as having been near the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court records indicate. The FBI then reviewed Oliveras' Parler account, where they allegedly found video taken inside and around the Capitol on the day of the riot. In one video, Oliveras allegedly shows a pile of news media equipment strewn on the ground outside and says "“That’s what happens when the f***ing fake news shows up at a Patriot rally." In another video showing a mob of people inside the building, Oliveras allegedly says: “Where are the f***ing traitors? Drag them out by the f***ing hair!"
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Oliveras pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI received two tips that Jonas Buxton was at the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. The first, according to charging documents, came from a person married to one of Buxton's family members, who said that they had been told Buxton participated in the riot and may have been carrying an AR-15 rifle. A second tipster reportedly said that Buxton quit his store job after arrests related to Jan. 6, 2021, were announced and "went into hiding." The FBI continued to investigate Buxton's involvement, identifying a cellphone number associated with Buxton, according to court records. Google data obtained by the FBI showed that that cell number was inside the Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, and court documents show a map of the phone's movements on that day. In April of 2021, Buxton flew into Miami from Panama City and was flagged by a Customs and Border Protection officer for secondary search, during which the officer was able to look at Buxton's phone. The customs officer allegedly found several photos of Buxton wearing a tactical vest with a "Trump" patch in the center, including one showing him holding a large gun in front of a Christmas tree and another in a red gaiter and red hat worn backwards. The officer also allegedly discovered a letter from the "Three Percenters," a far-right extremist group, with a "call to action" to go to Washington, D.C., on the day of the riot, saying that the president had called them there that day. Federal prosecutors say that surveillance footage from inside the Capitol that day show someone who appears to be Buxton -- wearing the vest with the "Trump" patch and a red gaiter around his neck.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Buxton pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: Law enforcement allegedly identified Isaiah Giddings as a person who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after searching the phone records of another person charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Giddings is charged with two other men, Brian Healion and Freedom Vy, who were allegedly part of a Telegram message group with Rehl and another person who was not in Washington, D.C., on the day of the insurrection. The group coordinated travel from Philadelphia to D.C. ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on the night before the riot, according to court records. On the day of the riot, Giddings allegedly appeared in a photograph outside the U.S. Capitol with Rehl and others, all flashing the "OK" hand symbol, a gesture associated with the Proud Boys. The four men then allegedly entered the Capitol building, where the four of them appear in several photos and videos. In a reply to a text the next day asking how they were doing, Giddings allegedly wrote: “Yes we have everything and everyone all accounted for ... none of our Philly guys had any PB gear the entire event just plain trump supporters from beginning to end." According to news reports, the Proud Boys were directed not to wear their signature black and yellow on the day of the riot, aiming to blend in with other Trump supporters.
charges: Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: The FBI zeroed in on Brian Healion as a person who entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after the bureau obtained the phone records of another man charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the far-right group the Proud Boys, court documents indicate. Healion is charged alongside two others, Isaiah Giddings and Freedom Vy. They were allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person, who does not appear to be charged. The group members planned their travel together from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, on the day before the riot. Giddings, Healion and Vy then stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C., court records say, on the night before the riot. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument, each flashing the "OK" hand gesture, which is associated with the Proud Boys, court records indicate. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, where they can be seen in various photos and videos.
charges: Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: Court documents indicate that Freedom Vy was identified as a person involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after law enforcement obtained and searched the phone records of Zachary Rehl, who is also charged and is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Vy is charged with Brian Healion and Isaiah Giddings, who were all allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person who was not in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The group members coordinated their travel from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021, according to court records. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument. They both flashed the "OK" hand sign, which is associated with the Proud Boys, according to court documents. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, and appear there in photos and videos.
charges: Unlawful Entry on Restricted Buildings or Grounds; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds

summary: “I’m on my way to Washington DC. To make sure Biden’s doesn’t become president,” Tim Levon Boughner allegedly posted on social media on Jan. 5, 2021, the day that phone records reportedly indicate he traveled from Michigan to Washington, D.C. For weeks prior, Boughner wrote multiple social media entries questioning the legitimacy of the presidential election and calling Joe Biden “stupid,” according to court records. Boughner first came to the attention of the FBI in the spring of 2021 when FBI agents reviewed police body-worn camera footage that allegedly shows Boughner assaulting an officer with a chemical spray. Subsequently, the FBI issued a BOLO alert for the then-unidentified Boughner. In addition, the volunteer group Sedition Hunters assigned a moniker to the person who federal prosecutors say is Boughner: “#blackpufferwhitescarf." According to the FBI, Boughner was identified by a tattoo of a five-point star below a dragon on the inside of his left wrist. At the end of July 2021, a search warrant was issued to a Facebook account that matched Boughner. The subscriber data provided by Facebook allegedly confirmed he was indeed at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. On the day of the riot, he allegedly posted: “I grabbed a can from them and started spraying. I got it on video lol …That was wild. We made it to the senate floor till National guard started fight back.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
case_updates: Boughner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Mason Joel Courson has been charged with eight federal offenses, according to court documents, including participating in an assault of a police officer who was beaten with a baton, flagpole and crutch by a group of armed men. According to federal prosecutors, Courson also participated in a “heave-ho” effort to advance into the U.S. Capitol from the lower west terrace tunnel.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Courson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In December 2020, Lucas Denney allegedly used social media and other means to recruit members to join his self-proclaimed militia group, the Patriot Boys of North Texas, as well as encourage them to travel to Washington, D.C. Court records indicate that Denney engaged in physical violence at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Denney can allegedly be seen wearing a mask with a Joker grin printed on it, as well as a hat with the Three Percenters symbol on it. According to the FBI, he grabbed and shoved a police officer, then attempted to grab a canister of crowd-control spray from a different officer. Denney was also allegedly seen later picking up a long metal pole from the ground and swinging it at an officer. Approximately 10 minutes later, he was seen grabbing a large tube and launching it toward a line of law enforcement officers, court records indicate. As the afternoon progressed, Denney was also allegedly seen carrying a baton and swinging his arm and fist at an officer. Denney has been detained, pending further proceedings.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon
case_updates: Denney pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentencing is reset for 9/28/2022

summary: Donald Hazard has been charged with engaging in physical violence and assaulting police officers on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. On the day of the riot, Hazard allegedly wore a tan tactical vest, as well as a black helmet with the Confederate flag printed on it. Footage reportedly depicts Hazard grappling with officers as he fell down a set of stairs under a scaffolding erected on the west side of the U.S. Capitol. According to the FBI, Hazard fought with an officer, which resulted in both of them falling. The officer was knocked unconscious and sustained multiple injuries, court records indicate. Prior to Jan. 6, 2021, Hazard allegedly helped recruit members to a self-proclaimed militia group called the Patriot Boys of North Texas, where he served as sergeant of arms. Hazard has been detained, pending further proceedings.
charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, Impeding and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Hazard pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that  Avery MacCracken assaulted police officers guarding the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. MacCracken allegedly punched one officer "with his closed fist in the right cheek, causing a cut to the face under his right eye" and pushed and shoved another officer. Both incidents were allegedly captured by police body cameras. Court documents state that MacCracken is "considered a transient with no permanent place of residence" but is generally known in the Telluride, Colo., area. A tipster from Colorado recognized MacCracken in photos of the Capitol siege circulated by the online open-source investigative community known as the Sedition Hunters, prosecutors now allege. That tipster then contacted local law enforcement -- namely, San Miguel County Sheriff Bill Masters -- who reportedly recognized MacCracken as well as the outfit he wore on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents state. MacCracken was arrested on Dec. 11, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence on Capitol Grounds
case_updates: MacCracken pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew Jay Webler posted multiple videos to Facebook in which he showed footage from inside the U.S. Capitol during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and also discussed breaching the building himself, federal prosecutors allege. In one video taken from inside the building, Webler allegedly shouted "1776!" Surveillance footage cited by prosecutors allegedly shows Webler entering the Capitol through a broken window, while wearing a large flag with the letter "Q" on it -- a popular piece of imagery with the the pro-Trump conspiracy theory known as QAnon. Webler also posted to Facebook that he believed the crowd inside the Capitol was peaceful and that he was "proud of myself for not getting caught up to [sic] much and having the sense to stand up to someone trying to vandalize the place," according to court documents. Webler was arrested on Dec. 3, 2021, in Decatur, Ga.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Picketing or Demonstrating in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Webler pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Picketing or Demonstrating in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 5/3/2022 to 45 days incarceration; $500 Restitution; $10 special assessment.

summary: James Robert Elliott, also known as Jim Bob Elliott, is accused of using a flagpole to assault police officers while on the U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a federal indictment, and is also accused of entering the building that day. According to the Chicago Sun-Times, Elliott is reportedly a member of the far-right Proud Boys, and could be heard at the riot shouting “patriots, what is your occupation” — apparently a reference to the movie 300 — before allegedly thrusting the flagpole toward officers. Elliott was arrested on Dec. 20, 2021, in Batavia, Ill.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly and Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Elliott pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Robert Thomas Snow was identified by the FBI as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court records. Law enforcment obtained phone records from Verizon, which allegedly showed that his cell phone pinged a cell site that provided service to an area that included the inside of the Capitol building. According to court documents, FBI agents later interviewed Snow, who reportedly confirmed that he did enter the building that day. Snow told the FBI that he recalled being searched by law enforcement inside the building and that he was given directions to exit. Snow also said he later re-entered the Capitol and urinated on a column inside an area that looked like a cafeteria, then exited the building for the second and final time. According to a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Snow served in the armed forces from 1962 until 1968, including service in Vietnam.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Snow pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 7/7/2022 to 12 months of Probation; $10 Special Assessment and Restitution of $500; 60 hours of community service. During the sentencing hearing, the Court advised Mr. Snow that if he made his required payments and met his community service obligations, the Court would entertain a motion for early termination of probation. Having completed the above, the court granted his request and his sentence of probation was terminated on 8/15/2022.

summary: James Wayne Brooks was identified by the FBI to have been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, through video footage from that day, as well as Brooks’ Facebook posts, Verizon cellphone records and credit card information, according to court documents. According to the FBI, Brooks can be seen in footage inside the Capitol wearing a distinctive black hoodie with a red-lined hood and gray sleeves that matches other pictures he had posted on Facebook. On Jan. 6, 2021, Brooks can also allegedly be seen in footage waving a large South Carolina state flag with a red U.S. Marine Corps logo attached to it. He can allegedly also be seen wearing a camouflage vest and a backward-turned dark cap with yellow lettering that reads “Iraqi Freedom Veteran.” In addition, the footage allegedly shows him carrying a communications radio with an antenna attached to his tactical vest. FBI agents interviewed Brooks’ sister, who confirmed that the pictures match those of her brother and told the FBI that Brooks told their other brother that he was indeed in Washington, D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. The sister also told the FBI that Brooks had served two tours of military duty in Iraq, court documents indicate. Brooks served with the Tennessee Army National Guard from 1995 to 2007, a spokesperson confirmed.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Brooks pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentencing set for 11/3/2022

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, John M. Cameron allegedly posted a video of himself in what appeared to be a Washington, D.C., metro train station, describing his experience at the U.S. Capitol: "Was it pretty? No. Did it make a statement? Yes." According to court documents, he also posted: “The least safe I felt was when walking back to catch train I was told to FU by a little anti fa BLMer on a Vespa who was traveling the opposite direction.” Cameron first came to the attention of the FBI when a tipster provided a link of Cameron’s Facebook account, which allegedly showed him attending President’s Trump “Stop the Steal” rally and his participation in the riot. According to court records, surveillance footage shows him wearing a baseball cap with white "Make America Great Again" lettering and a black hooded sweatshirt covered by a white T-shirt bearing the words "COUNT ALL LEGAL VOTES.”  Cameron was also allegedly seen entering the Capitol through the Senate wing door and exiting 22 minutes later through a broken window.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cameron pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced on 8/15/2022 to 36 months of Probation; 30 days intermittent confinement; Special Assessment of $10; Fine of $1,000; Restitution of $500

summary: In early January of 2021, an anonymous complainant contacted the FBI to report that Paul Lee Seymour Jr. and his girlfriend attended the riot at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The complainant said the girlfriend posted videos allegedly showing Seymour Jr. and her inside the building, but the FBI confirmed she only uploaded the videos and did not attend. The videos have since been deleted, but the FBI interviewed Seymour Jr., who allegedly admitted having been inside the Capitol alongside his father, Paul Lee Seymour Sr., who is also charged. The younger Seymour told the FBI he spent approximately an hour inside the building before he and his father were asked by police to exit, according to court records.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Seymour pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/4/2022

summary: Paul Lee Seymour Sr. first came to the attention of the FBI because two complainants contacted the agency to report that his son — Paul Lee Seymour Jr., who is also charged — had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Later, court records indicate that the FBI managed to get hold of images showing both men exiting the U.S. Capitol via the Chestnut-Gibson Memorial doors. On June 2, 2021, the FBI interviewed Seymour Sr. at his workplace and he allegedly confirmed having gone inside the building with his son. His son, who also allegedly admitted having been inside, told the FBI the two of them walked down a hallway with statues before entering into a “museum room,” where they spent about an hour, before being asked to leave, court records indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Seymour pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 10/28/2022

summary: Thomas Uberto, wearing what appeared to be a “Stop the Steal" T-shirt, can be seen on surveillance footage entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, through the Senate wing door, court records indicate. The FBI was also allegedly able to verify through a search warrant served on Google that an account associated with Uberto was present inside the building that day. According to the FBI, Uberto can be seen walking through the Capitol's Small House Rotunda and the Hall of Columns before exiting the building in under 10 minutes.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Uberto pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “Yeah, that was us today; no that wasn’t Antifa,” Andrew James Galloway allegedly said on a TikTok video that was submitted to the FBI as a tip concerning his alleged participation in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. The FBI later confirmed using cellphone records and footage take inside the building that Galloway entered the Capitol through a breached window and after about 10 minutes exited through another breached window, court documents indicate. According to court documents, the FBI interviewed Galloway at his home in Wyoming, where he allegedly confirmed the TikTok video but denied having entered the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
