case_updates: Galloway pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentencing reset for 10/7/2022

summary: “Shooting tear gas at us at the Capital (sic). Real nice civil servants,” wrote Long Island-based massage therapist Frank Giustino. He allegedly posted that message to Facebook on Jan. 6, 2021, according to screenshots his former high school classmate sent to the FBI. An FBI affidavit claims Giustino also posted to the group-chatting platform Discord under the handle “President-Elect Frankie G” throughout the day, reiterating: “They’re firing tear gas at us.” The FBI claims surveillance footage shows Giustino passing through the U.S. Capitol’s crypt, rotunda and other areas throughout a 20-minute period on Jan. 6, 2021. He was arrested on Jan. 11, 2022, in Kings Park, N.Y.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: The FBI has been monitoring Nicholas Lattanzi since he reportedly asked his TikTok followers: “Who wants to commit war crimes in Bosnia with me?” in December 2020, according to an FBI affidavit. On the day of the U.S. Capitol riot, an FBI agent spotted photos on Lattanzi’s TikTok account showing him near the U.S. Capitol wearing a paper Burger King crown, cowboy hat and a white flag wrapped around his shoulders as a cape, court documents indicate. Lattanzi originally denied entering the Capitol, according to the affidavit, telling agents he came to Washington, D.C., to “support my President.” Two weeks later, Lattanzi allegedly told agents he did, in fact, go inside the building and provided photos from the incident. The FBI claims he walked through the Capitol for about five minutes.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lattanzi pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A confidential source contacted the FBI to tell the bureau that Billy Knutson had posted that he was at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate Knutson posted on the social media platform Parler under the username @playboythebeast. A second source also told the FBI that Knutson had entered the building through a window and provided a video. Knutson can also allegedly be seen inside the building from surveillance footage that day. In a post uploaded to a YouTube channel with the same username as Knutson's Parler account, Knutson allegedly wrote: "D.C., it was real. Until next time."
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Knutson pleaded Guilty to one charge: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Sentenced  on 8/26/2022 to 6 months of incarceration; 12 months of Supervised Release; Special Assessment of $25; Restitution of $500

summary: Elmer Stewart Rhodes III, who goes by his middle name, is a former Army paratrooper, a graduate of Yale Law School and the founder and leader of the far-right, anti-government group the Oath Keepers. Federal prosecutors allege that Rhodes and other members of the Oath Keepers committed seditious conspiracy by plotting to “oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power,” which culminated in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. That conspiracy, the indictment against Rhodes states, began shortly after the November 2020 presidential election. On Nov. 7, 2020, Rhodes allegedly sent a message to other Oath Keepers in which he said, “We must now do what the people of Serbia did when [President Slobodan] Milosevic stole their election - Refuse to accept it and march en-mass [sic] to the nation’s Capitol.” Later, Rhodes allegedly messaged other Oath Keepers that if Joe Biden assumed office, “it will be a bloody and desperate fight. We are going to have a fight. It can’t be avoided.” Throughout this period, the Justice Department alleges, members of the Oath Keepers communicated over encrypted channels and conducted training in techniques such as “unconventional warfare.” In the lead-up to Jan. 6, 2021, Rhodes allegedly purchased thousands of dollars' worth of firearms and other military-style equipment, such as night-vision goggles and ammunition, and the Oath Keepers discussed plans to have an armed “quick reaction force” available just outside Washington, D.C., prepared to bring “heavy weapons” to the city at a moment’s notice. On the day of the Capitol attack, Rhodes allegedly entered restricted Capitol grounds and was in communication with members of the Oath Keepers who formed military-style stack formations as they breached the Capitol building. There is no evidence that Rhodes entered the building himself. The Justice Department alleges that later that evening, Rhodes had dinner with members of the Oath Keepers “to celebrate their attack on the Capitol and discuss next steps.” In the days after, Rhodes allegedly purchased thousands of dollars of additional weapons and other military-style equipment and encouraged people to form militias to oppose the Biden administration. Rhodes has publicly denied any wrongdoing and defended members of the group who breached the Capitol building. “I don't think they did anything wrong. I don't think they committed any crimes," Rhodes said in July. “Do I think it was stupid? Yeah. Because it left our enemies a chance to demonize and persecute them. But I do not disavow them.” Rhodes was arrested on Jan. 13, 2022.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Tampering with Documents or Proceedings and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Rhodes pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Edward Vallejo, along with other members of the anti-government group the Oath Keepers, committed seditious conspiracy by plotting to “oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power.” In December 2020, Vallejo was allegedly invited by Oath Keeper leader Stewart Rhodes to a Signal group chat titled “DC OP: Jan 6 21." Later that month, Vallejo allegedly wrote to Rhodes on Signal saying that he and others were coming to Washington, D.C., and that “everyone coming has their own technical equipment and knows how to use it,” with a winking emoji. In addition, court documents say, he said that the group would have both “rifles” and “man power.” Federal prosecutors claim that Vallejo was designated as part of an armed “quick reaction force” (QRF) stationed outside Washington but prepared to bring “heavy weapons” to the city. Two days before the riot, Vallejo messaged alleged co-conspirator Kelly Meggs saying that he was with the “cadre” in Tennessee and “requesting coordinates,” signing off, “For the Republic,” court documents indicate. He arrived in Virginia on Jan. 5, 2021, and was provided the address of the Comfort Inn in Ballston, where he and the rest of the QRF were given firearms and ammunition, according to court documents. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vallejo and others were reportedly waiting at the hotel for information from alleged co-conspirators on the ground. Court documents point to a podcast that Vallejo and another Arizona team member appeared on, where they talked about the possibility of “armed conflict” and “guerrilla war” and said, “there are people who are prepared, have the will, have the facilities to do more than taunt.” Later in the day, members of the Oath Keepers allegedly formed military-style stack formations as they breached the U.S. Capitol building. Prosecutors say Vallejo messaged the Signal chat more than once to assert his readiness to step in. Later that night, he was part of a group that included Rhodes that celebrated the attack at a restaurant and talked about how to continue fighting the presidential transition of power, according to court records. The next morning at 5:46 a.m., Vallejo allegedly told the Signal chat that he would “probe their defense line right now,” stating, “Departing for Recon now.” A few days later, an alleged co-conspirator from the Arizona QRF team reportedly wrote to Rhodes as they drove back to Arizona, “wanted to let you know that [Vallejo] and I are here. We are excited to learn next steps and would like to know what we should be doing right now.” Vallejo's attorney stated in federal court that he served in the U.S. Army in the 1970s and was stationed at Ft. Polk in Louisiana.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties
case_updates: Vallejo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The government's indictment against Zachary Johnson alleges he entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying both pepper spray and a sledgehammer. Johnson is accused of assault with a deadly weapon and engaging in physical violence, and he is accused of spraying a law enforcement officer with the pepper spray during the riot. He was indicted alongside Dion Rajewski.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Johnson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Dion Rajewski is alleged to have entered the U.S. Capitol with Zachary Johnson on Jan. 6, 2021, and a federal indictment names them both. The two men allegedly went to the Capitol carrying pepper spray, with Johnson allegedly carrying a sledgehammer as well. Rajewski is accused of an act of physical violence while at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Building or Grounds
case_updates: Rajewski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Law enforcement claimed in a court filing that Jeffrey Schaefer was first brought to their attention by a tipster who took screenshots of his social media accounts. In one alleged post by Schaefer, he posted an image of what appears to be the inside of the U.S. Capitol, with the caption, "THE CAPITAL HAS BEEN BREACHED... IT IS FILLING UP... THEY CAN'T STOP US." The FBI was able to link a Facebook photo of Schaefer, obtained through a search warrant, with an image from a body camera worn by a police officer at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. In both photos, the person the FBI identifies as Schaefer is seen wearing the same green baseball hat with the word "REALTREE" on the front. The FBI also obtained video from inside the Capitol in which Schaefer is allegedly seen entering the building through a broken window on the Senate side. This video suggests that he was inside the Capitol for approximately 28 minutes, the FBI said.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Schaefer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Alan Fischer III, also known as "AJ," is known to associate with the extremist group the Proud Boys. He allegedly appeared with members of the group near the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and flashed the "OK" hand signal, which was popular with the group during the attack. Prosecutors allege that Fischer joined with the mob trying to enter the Capitol through a tunnel by the Lower West Terrace and yelled, "push!" as the crowd pushed against police officers. Later, prosecutors allege, Fischer threw an orange traffic cone, a pole and a chair at a line of police officers guarding the Capitol. According to HuffPost, civilians helped identify Fischer by comparing photos of the Capitol riot to photos of Fischer from his work as a fashion model. A spokesperson for the U.S. Air Force confirmed that Fischer served in the Air Force from 2013 to 2017 and reached the rank of senior airman.
charges: Civil Disorder (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Fischer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “The whole nation will watch it happen,” Kirstyn Niemela told a witness and former friend, according to court documents. That witness told the FBI that Niemela claimed to be a member of the Proud Boys and that she had allegedly shown the witness a video of her breaking a window in the U.S. Capitol building. A second witness, who said they were related to Niemela, as well as an anonymous text tipster, told the FBI that Niemela had also posted to Facebook near the Capitol, court documents state. Prosecutors allege that other Facebook posts show “a woman believed to be Niemela” dressed in a sweatshirt reading “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” as well as wearing sunglasses and an American flag cape. The FBI says a woman wearing the same outfit can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol. Court documents also allege that data from search warrants to Google and Facebook back up the assertion that Niemela entered the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Niemela pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Stefanie Nicole Chiguer came to the attention of the FBI when a witness identified her as the girlfriend of Kirstyn Niemela, who is also alleged to have entered the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and is charged in relation to the riot. The witness identified Chiguer only as “Stefanie” but told the FBI she lived in Dracut, Mass. A driver’s license photo for Chiguer matches Facebook photos from Jan. 6, court documents say. Those photos allegedly show Chiguer wearing a sweatshirt that says “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” which matched a sweatshirt worn by Niemela. Prosecutors claim Chiguer can also be seen in surveillance photos from inside the Capitol, and data from Verizon is allegedly consistent with Chiguer’s phone being inside the Capitol as well.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Chiguer pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: The FBI alleges that Juliano Gross documented his own participation in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection on TikTok. Court documents show Gross first came to the attention of investigators via two online tips from people who shared screenshots of the TikTok account @julianospiano. The tipsters didn’t know Gross but wanted to help with the investigation, prosecutors say. The FBI later interviewed Gross twice, and according to investigators, Gross admitted to going into the U.S. Capitol, hoping to livestream the day’s events to secure donations. Gross allegedly told the FBI he received $150 to $200 but was not able to retrieve the money after his account was “banned.” Court documents state that Gross also confirmed his clothing on Jan. 6, 2021: a red Trump hat and an American flag mask. Prosecutors say that a person matching that description can be seen in surveillance footage from that day as well. They also say that a TikTok video purportedly from Gross’ account includes Gross saying: “We are in the Capitol Building. The Capitol Building has been overthrown.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gross pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 12/9/2022

summary: Geolocation data from a search warrant served on Google showed that Anthony Carollo’s mobile phone was likely inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Investigators compared his Illinois driver’s license photo to surveillance footage filmed inside the Capitol, and they found people they believed to be Carollo, his brother Jeremiah Carollo and their cousin Cody Vollan. In October 2021, Carollo allegedly admitted to FBI agents that he entered the Capitol and identified himself in the surveillance footage. His brother and cousin have also been charged.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Carollo pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/13/2022

summary: A search warrant served on Google produced geolocation data showing that Jeremiah Carollo’s mobile phone was likely within a restricted area of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. When FBI agents interviewed Carollo in November 2021 at his home in Illinois, he allegedly admitted entering the Capitol building and identified himself, his brother Anthony Carollo and his cousin Cody Vollan in surveillance footage. Those two men have also been charged.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Carollo pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/13/2022

summary: According to court documents, Cody Vollan admitted to entering the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, after traveling to Washington, D.C., with his cousins Anthony Carollo and Jeremiah Carollo, who also have been charged in relation to the riot. The three identified one another in stills from videos taken inside the Capitol, prosecutors say. A witness who told the FBI they are related to Vollan also allegedly identified him and confirmed his presence at the insurrection with his cousins. A search warrant to Google also allegedly showed a device for Vollan’s email address was likely in or around the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vollan pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: Kenneth Armstrong III first came to the attention of the FBI after a tipster contacted the agency, saying Armstrong had entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The tipster also provided Armstrong’s business address. On March 11, 2021, the FBI interviewed Armstrong at his business. He told the agents that he traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend President Donald Trump’s rally on the day of the riot and that he later walked with the crowd to the Capitol and entered the building, court documents indicate. Armstrong also allegedly sent the FBI a video he took while inside the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Armstrong pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Christopher Logsdon and Tina Logsdon are jointly charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Logsdon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Tina Logsdon and Christopher Logsdon are jointly charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Logsdon pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: On Jan. 8, 2021, a tipster contacted the FBI with the following message: “My radicalized [family member] Kenneth Bruce Rader Jr. from Sioux City, IA has been sharing videos of himself on Capital [sic] grounds and inside the building and has verbally articulated a full rage [sic] of threats against VP Mike Pence,” according to court documents. According to the FBI, Rader updated his profile picture on Nov. 7, 2020, which was the day Joe Biden was declared the winner of the presidential election, to show a burning American flag. In February 2021, he updated his profile again with a picture that included a large Q, referring to QAnon, the far-right conspiracy theory. In September, the FBI interviewed Rader who said he attended a rally on Jan. 6, 2021, in Washington, D.C., and stated he looked into the U.S. Capitol through an open door but never entered. According to the FBI, however, surveillance video shows Rader entering the building through the Senate wing door and exiting three minutes later.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rader pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/9/2022

summary: Prosecutors say Jason Blythe was part of a group of people charged with injuring officers during the riot at the U.S. Capitol. Named in a superseding indictment along with five others, Blythe is accused of participating in the attacks against two Capitol police officers, in which a metal crowd control barrier was used against the officers. One of the officers was injured in the attack.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Resulting in Significant Bodily Injury, and Aiding and Abetting; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
case_updates: Blythe pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Like many of the people charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S Capitol, Markus Maly allegedly bragged in numerous posts on social media about his participation in the riot. Prosecutors say he wrote to his girlfriend as the attack was taking place, saying: “We took the f***** Capital.” Later, when she expressed concern, he allegedly replied, “I know…I’ve got stories though,” and “I was so fun…”  Later he reportedly corrected himself: “It.” Prosecutors say Maly posted multiple pictures of himself that appear to be from the day of the riot, including a selfie that helped investigators match his clothing on the day to photographs of a suspect posted by the FBI. Maly was eventually identified through pictures and videos matched to booking photos of him in Virginia and his driver’s license and, additionally, through cellphone data showing the phone registered to him pinged cellphone sites consistent with those providing service to the Capitol building, court records indicate. Maly allegedly was spotted wearing a cowboy hat branded with “Trump 2020” and “Team Trump” and carrying a black canister which court records indicate he sprayed toward police officers. In other social media communications, Maly allegedly responded to a contact of his who suggested he should have “stood his ground:” “I stood my ground and went back for seconds and thirds even.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
case_updates: Maly pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Kenneth Duncan Massie entered the U.S. Capitol building through the Senate Wing door, according to court documents. Surveillance footage allegedly shows him wearing a white cowboy hat, with the American flag under the rim. Massie was allegedly accompanied by two men -- Luke Faulkner and Jared Kastner, who are both also charged in relation to the riot. The three men moved through the Capitol's Crypt in a row, each with a hand on the shoulder of the person in front of them, court records say. The FBI arrested Faulkner and Kastner on Dec. 8, 2021. According to court documents, both men identified Massie as the third person with them. On Dec. 9, 2021, the FBI then interviewed Massie, who allegedly admitted to having entered the Capitol. He also provided the FBI with a black jacket that he said he wore that day, as well as the cellphone he used, but said he had deleted the images taken while at the Capitol building, court records indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Massie pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, witnesses who said they were a former high school classmate and a former coworker identified Jolene Eicher to the FBI. Both recognized Eicher in a photo from inside the U.S. Capitol, which prosecutors say shows Eicher in a purple shirt, tan jacket and necklace. The FBI say they traced a woman in the same outfit on Capitol surveillance footage and in social media videos, including one that appears to show Eicher climbing through a broken window. Witnesses told the FBI that Eicher did not show remorse for her involvement and lost or resigned her job on a Virginia rescue squad when her involvement became public. A search warrant to Facebook led investigators to conversations Eicher had in which she allegedly shared photos from in and around the Capitol, including one in which she holds a sign reading “Trump 2020.” Court documents show that the FBI also received Eicher’s cellphone records through a search warrant to AT&T and that those records are consistent with Eicher being in or near the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Eicher pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: When Matthew Jason Beddingfield allegedly stormed the U.S. Capitol, he was in the midst of legal proceedings on an attempted murder charge. He later pled guilty to a lesser charge. Prosecutors investigating the Capitol insurrection say online sleuths referred to Beddingfield as #soggykidinsider and #nazigrayhat because he appeared wet in some photographs and could apparently be seen performing a Nazi salute. Court documents say private citizens used facial recognition software to connect images of Beddingfield on Jan. 6, 2021, to his mugshot from the attempted murder case. Beddingfield was also the subject of a HuffPost article on the use of facial recognition software by citizen sleuths. The FBI says that while Beddingfield’s father told HuffPost his son was not at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and had never been there before, public Facebook posts show Beddingfield and his father at the Capitol in November of 2020. The bureau also alleges that Beddingfield’s father wrote in a Facebook post: “WE ARE HERE TO TAKE THIS COUNTRY BACK FROM THOSE COMMIE BASTARDS” and confirmed to a commenter that he was in Washington, D.C. According to court documents, surveillance footage from the Capitol shows Beddingfield jumping a barricade on Capitol grounds and jabbing at law enforcement officers with a flagpole he carried. Prosecutors also allege that after Beddingfield entered the Capitol, he tried to strike police officers with the flagpole.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Beddingfield pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Eric Gerwatowski opened the upper House doors of the U.S. Capitol Building, yelled "Let's Go!" and directed rioters inside before entering, according to an FBI statement of facts. Moments before, two officers had unsuccessfully tried to secure those doors. Court records indicate that in order to identify Gerwatowski, the FBI reviewed crowdsourced information shared on Twitter by the account @SeditionHunters and media organized by Twitter users using the hashtag #lordlonghair. Tipsters who knew Gerwatowski also contacted the FBI, according to court documents. Those tipsters identified Gerwatowski in social media photos and video that allegedly showed him both outside and inside the Capitol. The tipsters, who alleged that Gerwatowski had admitted to entering the Capitol, also gave law enforcement agents Gerwatowski's phone number, which subpoena results confirmed. Additionally, a search warrant served on Google produced geolocation data showing that Gerwatowski's phone was present at the Capitol on Jan 6, 2021, according to court documents.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gerwatowski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jake Maxwell was arrested on Feb. 10, 2022 in Athens, Ga., and charged with six counts related to the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, including assault. In October 2021, the FBI received a tip from a confidential source that Maxwell had engaged in a physical confrontation with law enforcement at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. In a previous phone interview with the FBI, a family member of Maxwell stated that he attended the Pro-Trump rally that day with Maxwell and another person and then they made their way to the Capitol. The FBI also reviewed police body camera footage from two Metropolitan Police Department officers. Those videos allegedly show a person physically struggling with a police officer and grabbing his baton. Court documents indicate that images of the attacker in the video match social media photos of Maxwell, as well as his driver's license photo. Court documents also state that in an interview with the FBI on Dec. 9, 2021, Maxwell confirmed that he was the person in the video. Maxwell allegedly said that he has no memory of those actions and had been sprayed with an irritant.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (two counts); Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Maxwell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Shelly Stallings was arrested in February 2022 after being charged in a federal indictment that also included her husband, Peter Schwartz, as well as Markus Mally and Jeffrey Brown. A press release from the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the District of Columbia alleged that Stallings pepper-sprayed law enforcement officers. She is also charged with civil disorder related to allegedly entering and committing physical violence inside the U.S. Capitol building.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Stallings pleaded Guilty to all charges. Sentencing set for 1/13/2023

summary: Leticia Ferreira shared a video depicting the scene inside of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with a person who then stepped forward as a witness, according to an FBI statement of facts. FBI agents interviewed Ferreira at her home in Illinois on April 2, 2021. Ferreira, who told the FBI she is a Brazilian citizen living in the U.S. on a work visa, allegedly stated that she flew to Washington, D.C., on the day before the riot and returned home the day after. Cellphone location data obtained by the FBI match Ferreira's travel description, court documents indicate. During the FBI interview, Ferreira also allegedly shared photos and videos she had taken inside the Capitol, according to court documents. Security footage from inside the Capitol, along with video taken by others present, allegedly show Ferreira inside the Crypt of the building, wearing a red beanie with the word "Trump" and a camouflage Michael Kors jacket.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ferreira pleaded Guilty to the single charge

summary: Reva Vincent is charged with having willfully and knowingly paraded, demonstrated and picketed in the U.S. Capitol building at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to court documents. A plea agreement hearing for Vincent is scheduled for March 23
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Vincent pleaded Guilty to the single charge.

summary: Katharine Hallock Morrison was arrested in Dansville, N.Y., on Feb. 10. Morrison was added to an existing indictment, in which she is charged along with two others for alleged actions during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Morrison pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jerry McKane Waynick allegedly rushed a police line outside the U.S. Capitol, attempted to grab an officer’s baton and threw a barrier or cone at officers. Prosecutors say Jerry Waynick and his father, Mark Waynick, who is also charged, wore black tactical helmets and vests at the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Both are alleged to have entered the Capitol through the Senate wing doors, spending about half an hour inside. The FBI says it used Jerry Waynick’s Instagram account to isolate a phone number that cellphone data shows was inside or near the Capitol on the day of the attack. Court records also indicate that a local sheriff’s deputy was able to positively identify both Waynick men. Jerry Waynick's Instagram indicates he attended Nashville State Community College, court records say.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, and Act of Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Utter Loud, Threatening, or Abusive Language, Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct, and Acts of Physical Violence in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers

summary: Mark Waynick rushed a police line outside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. While allegedly attempting to push and reach for law enforcement officers, prosecutors say, Mark Waynick wore a red, white and blue bandana and tactical gear, including a helmet, vest, gloves and knuckle protectors. The FBI alleges that Mark Waynick was part of the Capitol riot alongside his son Jerry McKane Waynick, who is also charged. Both men are alleged to have entered the Capitol through the Senate wing doors and spent about half an hour inside. Court documents show Mark Waynick owns a property in Charlotte, Tenn. Investigators conducted surveillance there, where Waynick was seen in a truck registered under "Mark Waynick dba Waynick Plumbing." The FBI says they were able to match Waynick’s driver’s license photo to surveillance footage from the Capitol on the day of the riot. Both Waynick men were arrested in February 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, and Act of Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Utter Loud, Threatening, or Abusive Language, Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct, and Acts of Physical Violence in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers

summary: Prosecutors say Vincent J. Gillespie made his way to the Lower West Terrace tunnel of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and fought with law enforcement officers defending the exterior door. Body camera footage from a Metropolitan Police Department officer allegedly shows Gillespie grabbing a police shield and ramming officers with it while shouting "traitor" and "treason." When FBI agents created a media campaign to ask the public for help identifying rioters from open-source video and security footage, six people reportedly identified Gillespie from images taken from the footage, according to an FBI statement of facts. The witnesses allegedly included Gillespie's past neighbor and others who worked at businesses that Gillespie frequented.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Gillespie pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that on Jan. 5, 2021, the day before the attack on the U.S. Capitol, Athanasios Zoyganeles posted comments on Facebook saying: “We need to take over the capital [sic] building tomorrow." The following day, prosecutors say, Zoyganeles joined the mob that breached the Capitol and can be seen on video smoking a cigarette and filming inside the building during the attack. Federal investigators corroborated Zoyganeles' presence in the building by obtaining records from telecommunications providers and asking Zoyganeles' family members to identify him in photographs from in and around the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court records state. Those records also allege that Zoyganeles posted on Facebook that he "was teargassed maced and they were throwing flash bangs at me but I still stayed on the front lines. It wasn’t easy but we did it.” Zoyganeles was arrested on Feb. 22 in Chicago.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Zoyganeles pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: Matthew Krol, federal prosecutors allege, repeatedly attacked law enforcement guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. An FBI affidavit filed in the case against Krol states that he "pushed forward through the crowd, threw a water bottle at police officers, pulled other civilians out of his way, and attacked Metro Police Department Officer D.P., grabbing him and his police baton." Krol then allegedly used that baton to attack other police officers. Court documents describe Krol as "the self-professed executive officer of the Genesee County Volunteer Militia." Krol was arrested on Feb. 23, in Linden, Mich. After his arrest, the website for the Genesee County Volunteer Militia stated that Krol had left the group in 2017.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon (2 counts); Robbery; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Krol pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Carol Kicinski breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with fellow Floridian Jon Heneghan, who is also charged, and can be seen on video in the Capitol Rotunda. Prosecutors say they examined user location data obtained from Google and cellphone providers to help identify Kicinski and Heneghan and confirm their presence in the Capitol that day. On her website, Kicinski describes herself as "America's Gluten Free Voice," and she has made appearances on local TV in her capacity as a chef. Kicinski was arrested in Dunedin, Fla., on Feb. 23, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Kicinski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jon Heneghan breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with fellow Floridian Carol Kicinski, who is also charged, and can be seen on video in the Capitol Rotunda, court documents indicate. Prosecutors say they examined user location data obtained from Google and cellphone providers to help identify Heneghan and Kicinski's presence in the Capitol that day. Investigators also contacted Heneghan's ex-wife to assist in identifying him in photographs and videos from the Capitol, court documents state. Heneghan was arrested in Dunedin, Fla., on Feb. 23, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Heneghan pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani attended then-President Trump's “Stop the Steal” rally with her brother Elijah Yazdani and her sister Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani, who are both also charged in relation to the riot, according to court documents. After the rally, the three siblings walked to the U.S. Capitol and allegedly walked into the building shortly before 3 p.m. According to the FBI, Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani wore a “Make America Great Again” baseball cap with a red band underneath the baseball cap that day.  The three siblings allegedly walked through the rotunda and Statuary Hall and exited the building after a little less than 40 minutes. Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani is reportedly a student at Shawnee State University in Portsmouth, Ohio, and has been a member of the women’s soccer team there.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend then-President Trump's “Stop the Steal” rally alongside her sister Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani and brother Elijah Yazdani, who are both also charged in relation to the riot, according to court documents. On Jan. 6, 2021, Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani walked alongside her two siblings after the rally and allegedly entered the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors say the three siblings walked through the rotunda and Statuary Hall and exited the building after a little less than 40 minutes. Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani’s brother was arrested first after a witness contacted the FBI. According to the FBI, Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani was present at his arrest, voluntarily spoke to the agents and admitted entering the building alongside her siblings.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Loruhamah Yazdani-Isfehani pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: Joshua Lee Hernandez, also known as “Ace Hernandez,” has been charged with nine counts for his involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, Hernandez is accused of assaulting law enforcement officers that day. He was arrested in Memphis, Tenn.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hernandez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges.

summary: On Jan. 3, 2021, Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr. drove with friends to Washington, D.C., to attend then-President Trump's rally three days later, according to court documents. On Jan. 6, Cruz watched Trump’s speech and then marched with the crowd to the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate. He allegedly told the FBI, who interviewed him several months later, that he observed Capitol personnel remove the lower barriers so that people could walk closer to the building. He also allegedly told agents that he saw people dressed in “dark clothing,” who he assumed were antifa, pushing and removing barriers on the upper level of the Capitol. (There is no evidence that antifa played any major role in the attack on the Capitol.) Cruz told investigators that he then went to get food from a food truck and saw gas and rubber bullets being deployed on people at the upper barriers. According to court documents, Cruz's further stated that he went back onto the Capitol grounds to help anyone who might be injured, but did not enter the building. In June, the FBI interviewed Cruz voluntarily again. He allegedly stated that he recorded footage on his GoPro camera and gave the content to the FBI. The contents of the camera, in addition to security camera footage, allegedly show Cruz inside the building. The FBI interviewed Cruz three additional times and during the final interview he did confirm he was inside the building, court documents indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cruz pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Geoffrey Shough is one of many suspects who appeared on one of the open source platforms trying to identify people who might have committed crimes on Jan. 6, 2021. Shough was given the hashtag name of #TexasPleather. He wore a cognac-colored jacket that looked like leather and carried a Texas flag in images that prosecutors allege he appears in. On the day of the riot, court documents claim that Shough can be seen “forcibly” entering the U.S. Capitol and that he was one of the first people to breach a line of law enforcement officers trying to prevent the group from getting inside. On cellphone footage obtained by the FBI, agents claim that he can be heard saying he’s from Austin, Texas. Court documents indicate that Shough was ultimately identified by the FBI through two tipsters who led them to his ex-girlfriend: When agents interviewed her, she said they’d broken up the week before. She allegedly told the FBI that Shough owned a cognac-colored jacket, had said he was interested in attending the “Stop the Steal” rally while in Washington, D.C., and later said she was “fairly certain” that images shown to her were of him. In those images, Shough can allegedly be seen with a decal on his helmet that matches the logo of the Oath Keepers, a far-right extremist organization.  Prosecutors also say that financial records show a payment to “Oath Keepers” in December of 2020.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Shough pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. Sentencing set for 12/8/2022

summary: Narayana Rheiner told officers inside the U.S. Capitol to “stand down and go home,” according to court documents. Prosecutors allege he also tried to pull away an officer’s riot shield at the police line outside the Capitol. One officer allegedly told the FBI he remembered Rheiner as someone who was “trying to hurt officers” and “get past the police line.” The FBI listed photos of a man they say is Rheiner online in May of 2021. Prosecutors also say they compared the photos to Rheiner’s driver's license photo and received an online tip connecting the photos to a YouTube video of “Ryan from Baltimore.” According to court documents, a close personal and professional contact of Rheiner positively identified him in still images from surveillance and body worn camera footage from Jan. 6, 2021. Online sleuths referred to Rheiner as “Lynyrd Sinner," court documents indicate.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rheiner pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Iraj Javid allegedly appears on the “Sedition Hunters” website – an open source platform of people identifying Jan. 6, 2021, rioters who may have committed crimes that day. He was identified to the FBI by a cooperating individual using photos from the website, images that allegedly show Javid near the Speaker’s Lobby in the U.S. Capitol right after Ashli Babbitt was shot. He also appears to be in several other locations inside the building that day, including the rotunda. Once the FBI concluded that the images seem to depict Javid, a search turned up his Virginia driver’s license and his name on LinkedIn, which indicated he is an employee at WMATA, the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority. Court documents indicate that others employed at WMATA also identified him, and agents were also able to use cellphone data to confirm that a phone number associated with Javid was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Javid pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 11/4/2022

summary: As his fellow Proud Boys allegedly entered the Senate chamber of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Enrique Tarrio posted to social media that he was “Proud of My Boys and my country,” court records indicate. According to the FBI, Tarrio served as the national chair of the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group, and allegedly helped plan the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. Tarrio is charged in an eight-count superseding indictment alongside five other members of Proud Boys leadership. Court documents reportedly show Jan. 6 as the culmination of months of planning by Tarrio and his associates, including the creation of a chapter of the Proud Boys called the “Ministry of Self Defense,” which allegedly existed to make plans for the insurrection. In November 2020, prosecutors say Tarrio posted to social media: “The media constantly accuses us of wanting to start a civil war. Careful what the f*** you ask for we don’t want to start one… but we will sure as f*** finish one.” In December 2020, Tarrio traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend a “Million MAGA” rally and prosecutors say he stole and burned a “Black Lives Matter” banner from a local church. Later in December 2020, Tarrio and other members of Proud Boys leadership allegedly founded the “Ministry of Self Defense” chapter, court documents show. The FBI says that Tarrio emphasized a top-down structure for the group and directed potential members to “fit in... or f*** off.” Prosecutors allege leadership of the “Ministry of Self Defense” group raised money for paramilitary supplies, planned for Proud Boys not to dress in their traditional yellow and black colors, and encouraged members to travel to D.C. for the “Stop the Steal” rally on Jan. 6, 2021. An encrypted chat for members of the “Ministry of Self Defense” is alleged to have included at least 65 members. According to the indictment, during this time another individual sent Tarrio plans to occupy several buildings around Washington, writing “the revolution is more important than anything,” to which Tarrio responded: “That’s what every waking moment consists of… I’m not playing games.” Court documents show Tarrio was arrested on a destruction of property charge related to the December flag-burning incident on Jan. 4, 2021. He was released and ordered to leave Washington on Jan. 5, 2021, but met with the founder of the Oath Keepers, as well as others, in an underground parking garage before leaving for Baltimore, Md. He was not physically present during the riot on Jan. 6, prosecutors say. After Tarrio’s arrest, court documents show leadership of the “Ministry of Self Defense” group created a new encrypted chat group that did not include Tarrio, as well as a new membership chat that included about 90 people. After Tarrio’s release, his compatriots allegedly added him to the new chats. During the riot itself, prosecutors allege that while other Proud Boys stole a police officer’s riot shield, broke a window at the Capitol and entered the Capitol itself, Tarrio engaged on social media and by a short phone call to another Proud Boy. Tarrio was indicted on seven charges. Though he was not alongside his fellow Proud Boys on Jan. 6, prosecutors say Tarrio wrote on social media that he was “enjoying the show.”
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts);
case_updates: Tarrio pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Ralph Joseph Celentano III was identified by law enforcement after his image appeared on an FBI "Be On The Lookout" page following the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate. After that photograph was posted, someone contacted the FBI to provide them with another photograph of Celentano, which was posted to social media by the Jenny Albert Sea Turtle Foundation. The FBI was then able to find witnesses who know Celentano and could identify him in photographs from the insurrection, according to court documents. Additionally, data from EZ Pass and the New York License Plate Reader capture a car owned by a person law enforcement believes to be Celentano's significant other leaving New York early the morning of Jan. 6 and returning the next day. Prosecutors say police body camera footage from the riot depicts Celentano "engaging in several physical altercations" with officers. Additionally, other open source video allegedly shows Celentano pushing a police officer over a ledge on the West Terrace of the Capitol. The officer, an Iraq War veteran, suffered minor injuries, but reportedly later stated that he was frightened and thought at the time: "I didn't survive a war to go out like this.”
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Celentano pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI identified Raul Eduardo Jarrin as having been present at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after a search warrant served to Google showed a cellphone associated with his email address was there that day, court documents indicate. The FBI then interviewed Jarrin in July 2021, and Jarrin allegedly admitted to having been there that day but denied that he entered the Capitol. However, prosecutors allege Jarrin can be seen inside the building on security camera footage, and a photo taken inside the building was allegedly recovered from his phone.
charges: Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds, Parading in a Capitol Building.
case_updates: Jarrin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Closed circuit television from inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, captured Quentin G. Cantrell entering the building, alongside his cousins, according to court documents. He first came to the attention of the FBI when multiple tipsters reached out to the agency after seeing social media posts by one of his cousins who was with him. According to the FBI, Cantrell attended then-President Trump's “Stop the Steal Rally” and then walked to the Capitol. He entered the building through the Upper West Terrace Door, but exited two minutes later.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cantrell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, Eric Andrew Cantrell, wearing a plaid jacket, backpack, Carhart hat and a gray hoodie, attended then-President Trump's “Stop the Steal Rally” alongside his two cousins, according to court records. Later, the three of them walked to the Capitol and entered the building through the Upper West Terrace Door. Cantrell remained in the building for only two minutes, according to the FBI. Cantrell first came to the attention of the FBI when multiple tipsters contacted the agency after seeing his cousin’s social media posts.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cantrell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “I was one of the first 50 in,” Jared Paul Cantrell wrote on Facebook, according to court documents. On Jan. 6, 2021, alongside his two cousins, Cantrell attended then-President Trump's “Stop the Steal Rally” and then walked to the Capitol, wearing a dark Carhart coat and a Goruck hydration system tube over his right shoulder, according to the FBI. The following day, Cantrell wrote on Facebook: “I do not think I broke any laws. I have not been to the Capitol before and was a big reason I went in the first place. I didn’t go over any barricades or push through any police. They were letting folks in and at no point was there any verbal Indication from any authority to not go in.” CCTV footage shows Cantrell walked inside the Capitol and through the building, unlike his cousins who left only two minutes after entering the building. Cantrell first came to the attention of the FBI when multiple tipsters contacted the agency after seeing Cantrell’s social media posts, according to court documents.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cantrell pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Charles Hand III attended the Jan. 6, 2021, rally to “protest and stop the certification of what I personally believe to be an election stolen from the American people,” according to screenshots of his Facebook page included in an FBI statement of facts. His post also included the accusation that “Antifa sporting Trump gear were the ones who caused the chaos and who vandalized and attacked the Capitol Police," though there is no evidence suggesting antifa played any major role in the attack. According to court documents, video footage shows Hand breaking off a piece of metal fencing outside the U.S. Capitol and pocketing it in the early afternoon. More than an hour later, surveillance footage from inside the building allegedly captured Hand and his wife, Mandy Robinson-Hand, who is also charged in relation to the riot. Court documents indicate that surveillance footage shows Robinson-Hand restraining Hand at one point as he allegedly tried to move toward a scuffle between police and protesters. Hand and his wife were arrested March 11 in Butler, Ga.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hand pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “We’re in the capital (sic). Taking our house back … we’ve Been tear gassed etc.,” Mandy Robinson-Hand allegedly wrote in Facebook posts, which a tipster then submitted to the FBI. The FBI claims surveillance footage from the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appears to show Robinson-Hand, formerly known as Mandy Robinson-Lanning, entering the building through the Senate wing door just before 2:30 p.m., holding her cellphone aloft. She and her husband, Charles Hand III, who is also charged, were then filmed walking hand in hand through the Capitol Visitors Center and the Crypt, court documents allege. According to an FBI statement, the video footage shows Robinson-Hand appearing to restrain her husband from advancing toward a scuffle involving police and protesters. Robinson-Hand and her husband were arrested March 11 in Butler, Ga.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Hand pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jacob Garcia of Burleson, Texas, allegedly posted to Facebook on Jan. 7, 2021, writing “MY ONLY REGRET IS NOT GETTING SOME SOUVENIRS,” and “THERE’S NO WAY IN HELL THEY WILL ASCEND BACK TO POWER AS THEY WISH IF THEY DON’T GET RID OF US ALL. SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST." The day before those posts went up, prosecutors say, the Burleson Police Department reported that Garcia indicated on Facebook he’d entered the U.S. Capitol. The FBI says they also found posts from before the Capitol riot that included comments such as “Get ready DC” and “IT’S TIME TO RISE THE F*** UP.” Investigators examining Garcia’s Facebook page also allegedly found GoPro style video footage that they were able to match with CCTV footage from inside the Capitol. The FBI also says Garcia’s childhood friend positively identified him in photos, including from inside the Capitol. The same friend told the FBI that Garcia’s belief in QAnon and other conspiracy theories “changed his behavior.” Through Facebook, investigators say they found a phone number for Garcia that had used cell sites in an area that includes the Capitol and that Garcia called a cannabis delivery service in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 5, 2021. That phone number is registered to Garcia’s mother, who said that she told investigators she did not travel to Washington and that the number belongs to one of her children.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building

summary: While examining the cellphone of another defendant, Jonathan Laurens, FBI agents found a photo depicting a man’s reflection in a mirror in a U.S. Capitol reception room. FBI agents claim that the image depicts Laurens’ co-worker, John Gould, and that Gould texted the message “Can you see me in the mirror?” when he sent the photo to Laurens on Jan. 6, 2021. According to an FBI statement of facts, surveillance footage also shows Gould entering the Senate wing doors at about 2:15 p.m., wearing a distinctive white cowboy hat labeled “Team Trump.” The FBI claims Gould was filmed across various parts of the building over a 40-minute period. Gould was arrested March 15, 2022, in Norcross, Ga.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Entering or Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary:
Jacob L. Zerkle allegedly told FBI agents that he drove from Arizona to Washington, D.C., with a family member “to protest about election integrity … not to listen to speeches." Police body camera footage shows a man with large mutton chops, whom police claim to be Zerkle, as he grabbed at officers and threw a punch on the U.S. Capitol’s West Lawn on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts.
FBI agents claim Zerkle says he “probably did something dumb” when they interviewed him in October of 2021, according to the statement of facts. That court document adds that Zerkle says he was shoved into police while trying to protect himself and that he didn’t intend to assault a police officer. He was arrested March 15, 2022, in Tucson, Ariz.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
case_updates: Zerkle pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Nancy Barron turned herself in one day after the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, prosecutors say. The FBI interviewed Barron in person and allegedly matched her appearance to videos from inside and outside the Capitol. Court documents indicate Barron wore a “MAGA” beanie, a gray sweatshirt and a green coat, and investigators say Barron can be seen in images from the riot near the front of a group of rioters pushing up the stairs, then waving a flag before entering the Capitol. In her interview with the FBI, Barron told investigators she was pushed into the Capitol and immediately looked for an exit, which prosecutors say does not line up with video showing Barron walking through different areas of the building. The FBI says it served a search warrant to Facebook, which yielded Barron’s page, including a video where she can be heard saying she “made it in” to the Capitol and later “F*** Nancy Pelosi and f*** Chuck Schumer. Got to drag those c***s***ers down.”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Barron pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors allege that Riley Kasper sprayed an aerosol, which they allege was pepper spray, toward law enforcement officers at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. A confidential source sent the FBI screenshots from Kasper’s Facebook on Jan. 7, 2021, in which Kasper allegedly captioned a photo: “Trump rally Washington, D.C.!” According to court documents, a judge later authorized a search warrant to Facebook for Kasper’s account, which yielded several private messages. Prosecutors say Kasper wrote: “I pepper sprayed 3 cops so bad they got undressed and went home” and also “there is definitely something satisfying about pepper spraying cops in riot gear and watching them run from you like a b****.” Kasper’s Facebook also allegedly included a video that shows him wearing a gray patterned jacket, a camouflage face mask and head covering, and a tan camouflage backpack. These clothes are consistent, the FBI says, with YouTube videos and body-worn camera footage from the pepper spray incident. Prosecutors say they compared images from YouTube to booking photos from Kasper’s previous arrests, as well as to his driver’s license photo. The confidential source and a family member of Kasper’s each positively identified him in photos from the Capitol. Kasper was arrested in March of 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Kasper pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Details are limited as to Carson Lucard's case related to the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. He was charged on March 16, 2022, with one count: parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. A plea agreement hearing was then scheduled for March 25, 2022, before Chief Judge Beryl A. Howell.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Lucard pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentenced 6/24/2022 to 36 months Probation; 21 days of intermittent confinement; 60 days home detention; $10 special assessment, and restitution of $500

summary: Using police body camera and surveillance camera footage, FBI agents allegedly identified Jordan Bonenberger and Melanie Archer, who are both charged, as having been present during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. Multiple tipsters were also able to identity Bonenberger in images taken outside the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate, and one tipster noted that the person the FBI identified as Bonenberger outside the Capitol was wearing the same clothes as a person captured by surveillance footage inside the building. Bonenberger initially agreed to an interview with the FBI, but declined in person. After seeing Bonenberger in person, FBI agents say they were able to confirm a match between him and images from the riot. In court, attorneys refer to Bonenberger as a member of the military, which the U.S. Marine Corps confirmed to NPR. According to a USMC spokesperson: “The Marine Corps is aware of the situation, and we will fully cooperate with federal authorities as appropriate." The spokesperson added that Bonenberger is "pending administrative separation from the Marine Corps for unrelated misconduct" and that the "administrative separation process was started prior to the indictment.” Bonenberger is a corporal and has no service deployments, according to the Marines.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bonenberger pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Melanie Archer and Jordan Bonenberger, who are both charged, were allegedly seen together on police body and surveillance camera footage during the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol insurrection, court records indicate. FBI agents contacted a person who had known Archer for a long time and casually knew of Bonenberger. That person was allegedly able to identify some photos of the pair outside the Capitol, but was less sure about images from inside the building. Prosecutors say the clothing and likeness of the images that allegedly show Archer and Bonenberger outside the Capitol match with images from inside the Capitol. In addition to the previously mentioned tipster, FBI agents also received information from other tipsters who knew Archer. According to those people, Archer allegedly told them she was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Archer declined an interview with the FBI.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Archer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Jeffrey Munger admitted traveling to Washington, D.C., and entering the Capitol through a broken window, prosecutors say. In an interview at his home in Goshen, Ind., Munger allegedly confirmed what the FBI says it found through cellphone records. Those records, which court documents indicate came through a search warrant to Google, reportedly showed Munger’s device in the area of the U.S. Capitol for about an hour on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021. They also allegedly included selfies of Munger, which prosecutors matched to surveillance footage from inside the building. The FBI alleges that Munger was inside the Capitol for about 14 minutes. According to court documents, Munger claimed he only climbed through the broken window because he was being pushed and left the building after seeing people smoking pot.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Munger pleaded Guilty to the single charge. Sentencing is set for 9/20/2022

summary: John Lammons traveled with a female friend to Washington, D.C., from Galveston, Texas, according to court documents. The FBI said they received a tip, including screenshots of a Whatsapp chat where Lammons allegedly sent videos from the U.S. Capitol and wrote “we honestly wanted to just get inside and see what they were saying" and "after we left some idiots came in and did some stupid things but the first group was totally professional.” Lammons reportedly runs a business called “Anaconda Jiu-Jitsu” where, according to court documents, the FBI interviewed him in January 2021. Lammons allegedly described entering the Capitol after someone opened the doors and said “come in.” Court documents indicate that Lammons told investigators he got between law enforcement officers and people yelling at them, and helped an older man who didn’t look well move to a safer area. The FBI said Lammons shared videos he claimed to have recorded, including one that shows him at the front of a crowd facing police officers at an interior door. Lammons allegedly told agents he said “hold your ground” to the crowd. Court documents say Lammons left by climbing out a window.
