Lammons reportedly told investigators he wore green cargo pants, a gray hoodie and a black coat. The FBI matched that description and Lammons’ appearance in his own videos to Capitol security footage, which allegedly showed Lammons inside the Capitol. Lammons was arrested in March of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Twitter users dubbed a man in images from the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as “#Metrojack." Later, the FBI says it used booking photos to identify that man as Joshua Johnson. The photos from the Capitol allegedly show Johnson wearing a red plaid shirt, brown overalls, a dark jacket and a beanie, and he appears to be carrying a gas mask. The Social Security number associated with the booking photos led investigators to an apartment Johnson had left a few months earlier, but where his former neighbors positively identified him in the “Metrojack” photos, according to court records. The manager of the apartment complex gave investigators Johnson’s phone number, which AT&T records allegedly showed had used a cell site consistent with an area including the Capitol on the day of the riot. That phone number was also associated with Expedia records showing Johnson booked a one-way ticket to Washington, D.C., prosecutors say. Two of Johnson’s family members also spoke with the FBI, and both reportedly confirmed Johnson’s identity in photos from the Capitol. Court documents show investigators had a search warrant for Johnson’s residence, where they allegedly found the clothes he wore on Jan. 6, as well as the gas mask and ticket stubs for his travel. In July of 2021, court records indicate that Johnson was arrested on a domestic assault charge, after which investigators say they interviewed him in custody. Prosecutors say Johnson admitted entering the Capitol because he wanted to “stop the steal” and hoped to convince then-Vice President Mike Pence to “do the right thing.” Johnson was arrested in connection with the Capitol riot in March of 2022.
charges: Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Brian Raymond Jones researched the marijuana laws in Washington, D.C., before traveling there to attend the pro-Trump rally on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. After the rally, he allegedly marched to the U.S. Capitol and, with co-defendant Patrick King, then smoked marijuana inside the building, according to their middle school classmate who claimed to have seen photos on Facebook and tipped off the FBI in February of 2021. Investigators say surveillance footage shows Jones passing through the Senate Wing doors shortly after 2 p.m. and then walking through the rotunda. According to the FBI, Google records allegedly show Jones spent the evening of Jan. 6 searching phrases such as “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. Court documents also allege that Facebook records show Jones told Facebook friends he deleted anything “political” from his account and was creating a second account for only close friends and family, as he grew anxious about getting arrested for allegedly entering the Capitol. He was arrested March 23, 2022, in Seattle.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Jones pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Patrick John King told friends on Facebook that he “smoked weed n s***” while in the U.S. Capitol and “was part of rushing the riot police,” according to an FBI statement of facts. King also allegedly wrote to friends on Facebook that he “went to punk congress… let them know we ain’t f***ing around no more." Google records allegedly show King, similar to his co-defendant Brian Raymond Jones, spent the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, searching phrases like “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol,” “US Capitol facial recognition” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. A business owner near King’s home tipped off the FBI after one of King’s family members came into his business, in which a television was tuned to news coverage of the Jan. 6 riot. King’s relative allegedly told the business owner that King was “involved in that” and that he “went inside” the Capitol that day. King was arrested March 23, 2022, in Mount Vernon, Wash.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: King pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: “Your f***ing president told us to be here. You should be on this side, right here, going with us,” Cale Clayton allegedly shouted at police officers on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. The FBI claims Clayton was filmed by an officer’s bodyworn camera for several minutes that afternoon, calling police “brainwashed” and claiming 84 million “pissed-off” voters backed the rioters. About an hour later, the FBI alleges that Clayton picked up a police baton from the ground and used his hand to strike an officer trying to strip away the baton. He was taken into custody and released without charges that day, according to the FBI statement. When interviewed in March 2021, Clayton told FBI agents he was attempting to return the baton to police and that he “did not riot, engage in violence or commit any acts of vandalism,” according to the FBI statement. He was arrested on March 31, 2022, in Drexel, Mo.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Theft of Property Within Special and Maritime Jurisdiction; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Clayton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: "We all know they changed the rules mid-game and they are not being held accountable and that’s a shame," Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr. allegedly said to a camera crew inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, according to a statement of facts. Cellphone data obtained through the legal process also allegedly shows a phone, connected to a Google account matching Mazzio's name, that was in the Capitol during the riot. Additionally, Capitol security camera footage shows Mazzio entering through the Senate Wing door at 2:15 p.m., according to court records. Mazzio is allegedly seen in that footage wearing a camouflage jacket and pants, a tactical vest, and holding a Trump flag. FBI special agents interviewed Mazzio's neighbor, who knew him well. The neighbor confirmed that the person shown in images inside the Capitol was Mazzio, according to court documents. The FBI agents also talked with Mazzio at his house and confirmed a visual match between him and the photos collected. Mazzio was arrested on April 4, 2022, in Dothan, Ala.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mazzio pleaded Guilty to the single charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 9/22/2022

summary: Matthew LeBrun went to the U.S. Capitol with Steven Miles, with whom he is charged, and two other men previously charged in relation to the attack, prosecutors say. Court documents indicate that LeBrun wore a dark gaiter face mask with stars on it that day, along with a dark headband with stars, a black tactical vest, and what appeared to be a body camera. According to the FBI, the tactical vest also included an American flag patch with the logo of the far-right militia group the Three Percenters, though NPR has not confirmed whether LeBrun is a member. LeBrun allegedly marched to the Capitol and climbed the stairs onto the West Terrace. Prosecutors say Miles, LeBrun's alleged companion that day, broke a window that he and LeBrun then climbed through into the building. LeBrun was arrested in April of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: LeBrun pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Steven Miles allegedly shoved police officers outside the U.S. Capitol before breaking a window of the building and climbing inside on Jan. 6, 2021. According to court documents, Miles went to the Capitol with Matthew LeBrun, with whom he is charged, as well as two other men previously indicted in connection with the riot. The FBI says Miles can be seen in video and photos from that day wearing a black shirt that read “Trump 2020 F*** Your Feelings," camouflage pants and jacket, fingerless gloves, and a red “Make America Great Again” baseball cap. Prosecutors say AT&T records place Miles’ cellphone near the Capitol on the day of the riot. He was arrested in April of 2022.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Mile pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI was tipped off to defendant Jerry Braun’s alleged actions at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by an Uber driver who had been on duty that day.  According to the driver, one of his passengers, who he identified as “Jerry Last Name Unknown,” entered his vehicle with an injury on his face and said that he “tore down the barricades,” court records indicate. The driver replied, “Well, how’d that work out for ya?” and the man alleged to be Braun responded “Well, it looks like, uh, Biden’s gonna be our president." After matching a photograph of Braun in the Uber car to a driver's license photo, FBI agents found additional images they allege are of him on Jan. 6, including some from police body worn camera, which allegedly show him struggling with law enforcement at a barricade. Some images in the affidavit also allegedly show Braun fighting with a photographer and brandishing an 8-foot-long wooden plank with which he struck him. Prosecutors say he was wearing a black face mask covering his nose and chin with a long white beard poking out. When federal agents executed a search warrant at Braun’s house in California, he allegedly told them he had been analyzing politics his whole life and went to Washington, D.C., to hear then-President Trump. Court records indicate that when the federal agents seized Braun’s cellphone, they found a selfie of his eye injury, which he allegedly called his “Souvenir from DC," and a text that said he “tried to stop the steal but they wouldn’t let us in.” According to court documents, agents asked him if he wanted to tell them anything before they left the house, to which Braun responded, “Guilty.” When asked of what, he allegedly replied, “everything.”
charges: Obstruction during Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Building; Violent Entry or Disorderly Conduct

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Barry Bennett Ramey can be seen on video spraying police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol with an "unkown orange substance that is consistent with pepper spray." Federal investigators say they obtained cellphone records that corroborate Ramey's presence in and around the Capitol during the attack on Jan. 6, 2021. Ramey is also tied to the far-right extremist group the Proud Boys, according to court documents, and his name was listed on a "master list of Proud Boys members in Southern Florida," which was obtained "from multiple confidential human sources." In the course of the investigation, court records state, a person believed to be Ramey anonymously contacted an FBI agent by phone and asked if the agent still lived at his home address before hanging up. Later, that person allegedly texted the agent the vehicle identification number (VIN) for the agent's previous vehicle with the message "Check that VIN number." The FBI arrested Ramey on April 21, 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Ramey pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Matthew Montalvo is a real estate broker specializing in vacation home sales near Florida’s Disney World resort, according to his business website HomeSalesNearDisney.com, of which screenshots were included in an FBI statement of facts. On Jan. 6, 2021, Montalvo allegedly spent about 25 minutes walking around the U.S. Capitol’s second floor, according to the FBI statement, which includes photos from video surveillance footage that appear to show Montalvo carrying a tan backpack through the building. The FBI statement also alleges that Montalvo admitted to an FBI agent in December of 2021 that he went inside the Capitol that day. He was arrested April 26, 2022, in Kissimmee, Fla.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Montalvo pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In January of 2021, the FBI says it received a tip about a Facebook post in which an unnamed person claimed to be a friend writing on behalf of Joshua Colgan. In that post, Colgan allegedly said he was present for the death of Ashli Babbitt and that he’d also seen the Washington, D.C., police and National Guard escorting “hundreds of antifa." Prosecutors say Colgan also posted to his own Facebook page, writing that “several million Brothers and Sisters united at our nation’s capitol to overthrow this corrupt government and to form a new brotherhood of Patriots that will be permanently carved into our history books to never be forgotten.” The FBI then interviewed Colgan in August of 2021, during which he admitted being near the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but not to going inside. The FBI says Google records show a phone associated with Colgan in areas in and around the Capitol that day, and stills from security footage allegedly show Colgan inside the building, wearing a dark sweatshirt and a blue “Trump” baseball cap.
charges:
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Colgan pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: The FBI was tipped off to Chad Heathcote's alleged involvement in the riot at the U.S. Capitol by a witness who said they had heard about it from Heathcote's wife. Agents were then able to connect movement on Jan. 6, 2021, in the U.S. Capitol from a mobile device associated with Heathcote's email address and identified him from video footage as well. In the footage, according to law enforcement, Heathcote can be seen approaching a door of the Capitol and going around two officers guarding the door to enter. The FBI also interviewed other witnesses, who identified Heathcote by the nickname "D-Love" and also identified him from footage they were shown from the riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Heathcote pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A confidential source who did not know Justin Michael Smith sent screenshots from surveillance footage, social media videos and Smith's Facebook to the Cleveland FBI, court records indicate. FBI agents used these videos and screenshots to identify surveillance footage of Smith allegedly entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. That footage allegedly shows Smith inside the building, wearing a dark hoodie and carrying a flag with the words "Trump 2020 The Sequel, Make The Liberals Cry Again" printed on it. The FBI also says Google records show a device associated with an account in Smith's name appearing in and around the Capitol for more than an hour that day. Smith was arrested on May 4, 2022, in Cleveland.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Smith pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Surveillance footage allegedly shows Colton Wargo and his mother, Kimberly Wargo, walking through the U.S. Capitol rotunda, Statuary Hall and other parts of the building during a half-hour span on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. The FBI photos show Colton wearing a T-shirt depicting a version of the character Calvin, from the comic strip Calvin and Hobbes, modified to look like former President Donald Trump urinating on the CNN logo. Colton Wargo allegedly admitted to an FBI agent in May 2021 that he and his mother traveled to Washington, D.C., to attend Trump’s rally and “took advantage of the opportunity” to follow the crowd into the Capitol. Colton Wargo said they left “after they were yelled at by an armed tactical police team,” according to the FBI statement. The statement also claims Google records show Colton Wargo’s phone was on Capitol grounds from about 2 to 3:30 p.m. on the day of the Capitol riot.

Kimberly Wargo told FBI agents in May 2021 that she and her son Colton Wargo traveled from Ohio to Washington, D.C., to attend former President Donald Trump’s rally on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. After the rally, they allegedly followed the crowd into the U.S. Capitol, but she said they left when police officers yelled at them, according to the statement. The FBI alleges that surveillance footage shows the pair spent about 30 minutes walking through various parts of the Capitol, with Kimberly Wargo appearing to lead Colton by the hand at times.

William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean.
charges: Seditious Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding
case_updates: Wilson pleaded Guilty to both charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Jennifer Horvath breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with her boyfriend Glenn Wes Lee Croy, who is also charged. On that day, Horvath was allegedly wearing a pro-Trump hat and sweatshirt. Horvath and Croy allegedly entered the Capitol twice during the riot and can be seen on video chanting "our house" while marching inside. In one video cited in court documents, Horvath placed a pro-Trump hat and a pair of sunglasses on a bust of Winston Churchill displayed inside the Capitol. Croy, who pleaded guilty, also told the FBI in an interview that he entered the building along with Horvath. Horvath was arrested on May 3, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Horvath pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing Hearing scheduled for 11/4/2022

summary: According to court documents, a witness told the FBI they drove a man named Ed from Tennessee to Washington, D.C., on the day before the riot at the request of their pastor. The pair allegedly stayed in separate rooms of a hotel and then drove back to Tennessee on the day after the riot. Hotel and financial records belonging to Edward Kelley allegedly support that witness's claim. The FBI interviewed Kelley in June of 2021, during which he said he was near the Capitol but did not go inside. But prosecutors say video from the riot and other evidence allegedly show Kelley helping to throw a U.S. Capitol Police officer to the ground, pushing on a metal barricade against law enforcement, breaching a window with a piece of wood, and being confronted by Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman. Prosecutors estimate Kelley spent about 40 minutes inside the Capitol, including in the Senate gallery and the rotunda. He was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Knowingly Engage in any Act of Physical Violence Against Person or Property in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Destruction of Government Property
case_updates: Kelley pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: FBI investigators identified John George Todd III after a tipster said they met him in March 2021 in a Missouri bar, where Todd allegedly claimed he was inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. In the interaction, Todd allegedly showed video of himself on that day smoking marijuana in the building and said he had been asked to “wreak havoc” at the Capitol by someone who paid his airfare to Washington, D.C. Agents identified a mobile device associated with Todd's email accounts, and a search warrant for Google data showed the phone inside the building and on Capitol grounds on the day of the riot, court records indicate. In police body camera footage, Todd can also allegedly be seen yelling at officers: “I swear to God, I’ll hip toss your a** into the f***in’ crowd, mother f***er!”
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Todd pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors say David Joseph Gietzen can be seen on video assaulting police officers guarding the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, while wearing a helmet and protective goggles. At one point, Gietzen allegedly pushed police officers and later grabbed an officer by the throat or mask. Later, Gietzen allegedly took a long pole and used it to attack police. Video evidence cited in court documents also allegedly shows Gietzen joining with rioters by the tunnel on the Capitol's lower west terrace, an area that saw some of the most intense violence during the attack. Tipsters first identified Gietzen to the FBI as a participant in the Capitol riot in early 2021, court documents state, but Gietzen was not arrested until May 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2 counts); Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: A Facebook friend reported Doug Macrae to the FBI on Jan. 7, 2021, court documents show. Macrae allegedly posted three photos on Jan. 6, 2021: a selfie from outside the U.S. Capitol, a photo of a staircase and large painting, and a photo of what seems to be a hallway inside the Capitol. The FBI says that in two in-person interviews, Macrae confirmed he entered the Capitol and took the photos found on his Facebook account. According to court documents, a person believed to be Macrae can be seen wearing a dark jacket and a blue and brown beanie in surveillance footage from the attack on the Capitol. Macrae also allegedly confirmed his cellphone number in interviews, and investigators say the phone associated with that number used cell towers consistent with an area that includes the U.S. Capitol on the day of the riot. Macrae was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Macrae pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Devin Rossman allegedly recorded his participation in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol on Facebook, posting pictures and sending private messages about entering House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. An anonymous tip brought Rossman to the attention of the FBI, court documents show. Rossman allegedly wore a tan jacket, jeans, a baseball cap and sunglasses to the Capitol, an outfit prosecutors say can be seen on surveillance footage from inside the building. The FBI says it also has data from Google to show Rossman’s phone inside the Capitol. Rossman was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings

summary: The Air Force’s Office of Special Investigations reported Jamie Lynn Ferguson, who court documents say is a member of the West Virginia National Guard, to the FBI in January of 2021. The Air Force report, court documents show, included social media, photos and screenshots of a video that allegedly showed Ferguson inside the U.S. Capitol rotunda on Jan. 6, 2021. Ferguson also allegedly requested leave from Jan. 5 through Jan. 7 of 2021, and noted that she was going to Washington, D.C. Based on that information, the FBI reviewed surveillance footage from the Capitol rotunda, where they say Ferguson can be seen in a dark hoodie with the words “Trump Girl” on it. According to court documents, Ferguson confirmed this outfit in an interview, as well as her presence in the Capitol on the day of the riot for around 40 minutes. Prosecutors say Ferguson described attending a rally for then-President Donald Trump with her parents and then continuing to the Capitol without them in hopes of seeing Trump again. Investigators also found Ferguson’s Facebook account, where they say comments show her intent to travel to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. NPR was not able to independently confirm Ferguson's membership in the West Virginia National Guard.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Ferguson pleaded Guilty to one charge:  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/18/2022

summary: Benjamin Scott Robinson was identified by the FBI after footage inside the U.S. Capitol showed him and his family members walking inside the building for half an hour on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Court documents indicate that the FBI first identified Robinson's father from a 2019 arrest picture that matched the images taken inside the Capitol. Robinson and members of his family allegedly entered through the Senate-wing doors and were among the people closest to the internal doorway to the House. According to the FBI, the rioters in the front of the crowd broke the glass windows leading to the House. Several warnings — “he’s got a gun” or simply “gun” — were heard, referring to the officers on the other side of the glass-paned door. Just after that warning, Robinson allegedly used his body and foot to pound the door. According to court documents, Robinson exited the building after hearing the shot that killed Ashli Babbitt.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Robinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Linwood Alan Robinson II was identified by the FBI after footage inside the U.S. Capitol showed him and his family members walking inside the building for half an hour on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The FBI first identified his father, Linwood Alan Robinson, from an arrest picture taken a couple of years earlier that matched images from inside the Capitol. Robinson II allegedly entered the Senate-wing doors with four other family members, including his father. According to the FBI, the family walked through several parts of the Capitol, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Robinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: According to court documents, Brittany Nicole Robinson entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with four other family members. She first came to the FBI's attention after agents managed to match an old booking image of her father-in-law with footage from the Capitol, court documents indicate. Court documents describe the family walking through several parts of the Capitol, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office. They exited the building after hearing the shot that killed Ashli Babbitt.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Robinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Linwood Alan Robinson first came to the FBI's attention after publicly available video footage taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appeared to match images of him taken from a 2019 arrest, according to court documents. The FBI called Robinson, who allegedly confirmed to the agents that it was indeed him. According to court documents, Robinson entered the building alongside his two sons, his daughter-in-law and his grandson — a minor at the time. A witness who has known the family for years confirmed the identity of all the individuals alongside him, according to court records.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Robinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two tipsters and five witnesses help make up the FBI’s case against Chadwick Clifton, court documents show. Clifton, prosecutors say, traveled to Washington, D.C., with his neighbor David Johnston, who is also charged in the riot. Clifton bragged to co-workers about his involvement in the attack on the Capitol, court records indicate, including posting pictures and videos to Facebook and TikTok. In one video, showing Clifton in a gray jacket, red baseball cap and jeans, the caption says Clifton is picking up trash inside the Capitol, court documents show. A search warrant for Clifton’s Facebook account gave prosecutors access to his messages, including one that allegedly read, “When I went to DC that was an experience of a lifetime. I’m sorry that I went inside a broken door where we could have potential he got in trouble but I was a patriot and I made sure that people didn’t destroy things and picked up trash and we respectful.” Clifton was arrested in May 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Clifton pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Prosecutors say David Johnston traveled to Washington, D.C., with his neighbor Chadwick Clifton, who is also charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. In a social media video of Clifton, the FBI says, he identifies the person with him as Dave, and a witness reportedly confirmed that the person was Johnston. He wore metal-rimmed glasses, a dark North Face jacket, yellow gloves and a winter hat with “Trump” and “45” on it, court documents show. Cellphone records, prosecutors say, show Johnston’s phone used a cell site consistent with an area including the Capitol. The FBI says Johnston can also be seen on surveillance footage from inside the building. Johnston was arrested in May 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Johnston pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Michael Pomeroy is one of several alleged members of the Pennsylvania-based political group "Free PA" who have been accused of entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Free PA’s mission, according to its website, is to organize “physical meetings for like-minded patriots to gather, communicate and strategize.” The FBI claims surveillance video footage shows Pomeroy entering the Capitol’s second floor, along with other Free PA members, before walking through various areas of the building. Pomeroy was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted  Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Pomeroy pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A tipster who met Lynnwood Nester at a small gathering in December of 2020 told the FBI they’d spotted Nester in since-deleted Facebook videos filmed during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. The tipster “specifically remembered Nester due to some concerning comments Nester made at the event,” according to an FBI statement of facts. Surveillance footage shows Nester and several other alleged members of the Pennsylvania-based political group “Free PA” walking through the Capitol over a span of about 10 minutes, according to the FBI. Free PA’s website describes the group as “Pennsylvania Patriots volunteering together to restore and protect our rights and freedoms by using ​ACTION, ACTION, ACTION!” Nester was arrested May 20, 2022, in Dillsburg, Pa.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted  Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Nester pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Brian Korte, along with other alleged members of a Pennsylvania based political group called "Free PA," were seen on surveillance footage unlawfully entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. Another member of the group, arrested in May of 2021, identified Korte in a photo the group took outside the Capitol on the day of the riot, court records say. On June 16, 2021, the FBI executed a search warrant on Korte's home. Korte allegedly admitted being inside the Capitol but said he drove his car to Washington, D.C., that day with no expectation of entering the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted  Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Korte pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that, in the days after the 2020 election, Rodney Milstreed messaged a friend on Facebook warning that things could get "ugly" in the country, along with a photo of multiple military-style rifles, ammunition and a medical kit. On Nov. 25, 2020, court documents state, he posted on Facebook, "I pray every night. I hope we dont have to hurt anyone. THESE JUDGES BETTER DO THE RIGHT THING." On Jan. 6, 2021, Milstreed allegedly threw a flagpole "javelin-style" at a group of Capitol Police officers guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol. Later that day, Milstreed can allegedly be seen on video trying to move bike racks that police had set up as a barricade around the building and taking a smoke grenade that was on the ground on the side of the rioters and throwing it toward police. Milstreed then allegedly pulled and shoved a photographer working for The Associated Press, who was covering that day's events. That evening, prosecutors say, he messaged a Facebook friend, "We f***** them federal cops up." Milstreed was arrested on May 24, 2022, in Brighton, Colo.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Assault by Striking, Beating, or Wounding; Simple Assault; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: Matthew Bokoski and his father, Bradley, who is also charged, were inside the U.S. Capitol for about five minutes, but their time there was well-documented, court documents show. Prosecutors say Bokoski took photos and videos, including one showing his outfit, which included a red and blue “Trump 2020” flag on his back and a red and blue hat with a pompom on top. One of Bokoski’s Facebook posts, which the FBI says it uncovered through a search warrant, allegedly read “...only thing I’m guilty of is trespassing on federal property if you want to get down to it. I kept my distance from police and even thanked them for being out and making sure things don’t get insane.” Prosecutors say Bokoski confirmed his presence in the Capitol in an interview and shared photos with investigators. Bokoski also said in the interview that the rally was effective because it shut down government, court documents show. Bokoski was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Bokoski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Bradley Bokoski and his son Matthew, who is also charged, were inside the U.S. Capitol for just five minutes, court records indicate, but in that time, Matthew Bokoski took numerous photos and videos, including at least one that showed his father. In an interview in June of 2021, investigators say Bokoski confirmed that he went inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Surveillance cameras also allegedly captured Bokoski entering through the Senate parliamentarian's door. Bokoski was arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
case_updates: Bokoski pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: In the lead-up to Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say Paula Conlon posted to Facebook about the idea that the 2020 election was stolen and said the upcoming rally on Jan. 6 “should be epic.” While court documents show Conlon’s account was deactivated around the time of the attack on the Capitol, prosecutors say a witness who knows Conlon personally confirmed her identity in a video from the Upper West Terrace in which Conlon tells police to “back off.” The FBI says Conlon and fellow defendant Stacy Bond can be seen in surveillance footage from the Capitol. Conlon and Bond were inside the Capitol for around three minutes, the prosecutors say. They were both arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Conlon pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 6, 2021, prosecutors say Stacy Bond wrote in a Facebook message, “I got there right after they broke in, I was pretty pissed, but I went in there just to go in and out the front door and got maced.” The message was found via a search warrant, which court documents show also revealed Bond’s photos from outside the Capitol. A second search warrant to Google revealed interior photos as well, according to the FBI. Prosecutors say Bond can be seen in body-worn camera footage from law enforcement and with fellow defendant Paula Conlon in surveillance footage from the Capitol. Bond and Conlon were inside the Capitol for around three minutes, the FBI says. They were both arrested in May of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Bond pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Karegan Bostic’s father and sister, Willard Bostic and Meghan Rutledge, were both arrested for their involvement on Jan. 6, 2021, in the riot at the U.S. Capitol.  In the course of the FBI’s investigation of the two of them, a woman – alleged to be Karegan Bostic – can be seen on CCTV footage with a blond ponytail, tan baseball hat, and blue face mask, and the three can be seen entering the Capitol together.  A search of Willard Bostic and Meghan Rutledge’s phones revealed pictures of Karegan Bostic on Jan. 6, including one that appears to be of the two sisters in front of the Washington Monument.  After the FBI interviewed Karegan Bostic at work, she said that, along with her father and sister, she walked into the Capitol, walked around, and left.  She also said that she did not see any violence that day and felt they had been “set-up" when they heard of the violence afterward.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Levi Gable first came to the attention of the FBI after a witness, who identified himself as his college fraternity brother, contacted the agency, according to court documents. The witness told the FBI that Gable posted videos on social media of himself being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. “I was among the first people to make our way into the U.S. Capitol Building,” Gable allegedly wrote on Facebook. “Those in the building first were there in protest of Vice President Mike Pence’s statement that he would not stand with the American people and challenge the results of 2020’s stolen presidential election. The proof is undeniable for anyone who takes an objective look at the accusations of election fraud, provided you are looking somewhere other than the fake news and social media.” The FBI interviewed Gable in person, but he denied having entered the building. Footage taken inside the building was also used to confirm he entered the Capitol and walked through Statuary Hall while filming and taking pictures on his cellphone, court records indicate.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted  Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Gable pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: On Jan. 8, 2021, the FBI obtained information that Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr. was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, according to court records. The FBI interviewed Johnson shortly after, but he told the FBI he traveled to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6 at “the request of United States President Donald Trump,” but did not enter the Capitol. In September of 2021, however, a confidential human source provided open-source video that showed Johnson near a door of the building, wearing a red “Keep America Great” hat. In addition, CCTV footage showed Johnson enter the building through the Northwest Side door and walk through the Capitol, including the Senate parliamentarian’s office. In May of 2022, the FBI interviewed Johnson again, who this time admitted entering the building and confirmed that he was indeed the man depicted in the photos taken from inside the building.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds;  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Johnson, Jr. pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Video Sentencing set for 11/10/2022

summary: “A huge group of us stormed inside … we were basically shouting at the cops,” says Josiah Hueso in CNN footage shot outside the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. A tipster who’d known Hueso for some time sent a link of the video to the FBI, adding that they’d heard Hueso “brag” about his involvement at the Capitol, according to the statement. The FBI claims surveillance footage shows Hueso entering the Senate side of the Capitol and heading into the parliamentarian office at one point. People were picking up items inside the office, Hueso later told the FBI, but he says he told them not to steal anything. He was arrested May 25, 2022, in San Diego.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: Prosecutors allege that Adam Miller breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with his brother-in-law, a man named Devin Steiner. According to court documents, both men can be seen on video entering the Capitol through a door on the Senate side of the building around 2:19 p.m., where they remained for more than 30 minutes. An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI in February of 2021 and told investigators that Miller had openly discussed breaching the Capitol. Another tipster allegedly told the FBI that Miller was a follower of the conspiracy theory QAnon. FBI agents later obtained a search warrant for Steiner's phone, which allegedly contained a text message from Steiner sent during the riot stating, "Storming the capitol building with hundreds of thousands !" Miller was arrested on May 31, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: Prosecutors allege that Devin Steiner breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, along with his brother-in-law, a man named Adam Miller. According to court documents, both men can be seen on video entering the Capitol through a door on the Senate side of the building around 2:19 p.m., where they remained for more than 30 minutes. An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI in February of 2021 and told investigators that Miller had openly discussed breaching the Capitol building. FBI agents later obtained a search warrant for Steiner's phone, which allegedly contained a text message from Steiner sent during the riot stating, "Storming the capitol building with hundreds of thousands !" Steiner was arrested on May 26, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.

summary: AT&T phone records show Conlin Weyer remained inside the U.S. Capitol for about 45 minutes on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Surveillance footage shows him entering the Upper West Terrace door and later passing through Statuary Hall and the rotunda, according to the document. In April of 2022, the FBI interviewed one of Weyer’s former high school classmates, who positively identified Weyer in the surveillance footage and provided FBI agents with Weyer’s high school yearbook photo for comparison. He was arrested May 13, 2022, in Plover, Wis.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Weyer pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Trudy Castle came to the attention of the FBI because fellow defendant Kimberly DiFrancesco contacted her phone on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents show. Cell records, prosecutors say, showed Castle’s phone used cell sites consistent with the inside of the U.S. Capitol. Castle spent about 30 minutes inside the Capitol with DiFrancesco, according to court documents.The FBI says Castle and DiFrancesco can be seen on surveillance footage entering through the Senate Wing door and walking through the Capitol, including going up and down to the lower level visitor’s center more than once. Castle wore a white jacket, dark pants and a red, white and blue knit “Trump” hat with a pompom, according to the FBI. After leaving the interior of the Capitol, prosecutors say, Castle and DiFrancesco met up with Castle’s adult son. Castle and DiFrancesco were both arrested in Chicago.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Castle pleaded guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/22/2022

summary: Kimberly DiFrancesco sent three pictures from inside the U.S. Capitol to a friend, whose spouse then reported DiFrancesco to the FBI, court documents show. The pictures represent a small part of the approximately 30 minutes prosecutors say DiFrancesco spent inside the Capitol with fellow defendant Trudy Castle. The FBI says DiFrancesco and Castle can be seen on surveillance footage entering through the Senate Wing door and walking through the Capitol, including going up and down to the lower level visitor’s center more than once. DiFrancesco wore a red hooded sweatshirt, green pants, gray gym shoes, black jacket, black backpack and something black on her head, according to court documents. Cell records show DiFrancesco’s phone traveled from the Chicago area to Washington and used cell sites consistent with an area that includes the Capitol, prosecutors say. Those records also allowed investigators to identify Castle, according to the FBI. DiFrancesco and Castle were both arrested in Chicago.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: DiFrancesco pleaded guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing set for 11/22/2022

summary: Brian Boele was arrested on June 3, 2022, in Lakeland, Fla. He is charged in an indictment dated May 25, 2022, with four other defendants.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Boele pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: James Brett was arrested on June 3, 2022, in Clearwater, Fla. He is charged in an indictment dated May 25, 2022, with four other defendants.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: A witness reached out to the FBI saying his distant relatives Brian Scott Jackson and Jackson's brother Adam Lejay Jackson, who is also charged, posted on Facebook that they were at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The Facebook posts were removed, but the FBI was able to track the brothers using cellular data and found records of them flying to Washington, D.C., on Southwest Airlines the day before the riot, court records indicate. Video obtained from the U.S. Capitol Police and from open sources allegedly shows Brian Jackson hurling a flag on a pole at police officers. His brother is also allegedly seen throwing a large object at the police. According to the FBI, Brian Jackson attempted to delete evidence by sending multiple messages asking others to delete videos and messages he had sent to them. "Aint nothing but n****** there even all the cops are black f***ing crazy I will never take my a** back to DC, !!!” he allegedly wrote to one of them.
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Jackson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: A witness reached out to the FBI saying his distant relatives Adam Lejay Jackson and Jackson's brother Brian Scott Jackson, who is also charged, posted on Facebook that they were at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. The Facebook posts were removed, but the FBI was able to track the brothers using cellular data and found records of them flying to Washington, D.C., on the day before the attack, according to court records. Video obtained from U.S. Capitol Police and from open sources allegedly show Adam Lejay Jackson hurling a large orange object at a line of law enforcement officers at the tunnel outside of the Lower West Terrace. His brother is also allegedly seen throwing a flag on a pole at the police. After throwing the orange object, Adam Jackson can be seen charging at the line of officers with riot shields, court records indicate. On Jan. 10, 2021, Adam Jackson exchanged messages with another person, indicating that he wanted to return to Washington, D.C., for the Inauguration: “I’m f***ing pissed at what is happening and the things that are being covered up.” He added: “I’m gonna do my best to get there. Working on it.”
charges: Civil Disorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Jackson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Two tips and a confidential source led the FBI to Ryan Kelley’s alleged involvement in the attack on the Capitol, court documents show. Kelley is a candidate in the Republican primary for governor. At a “Stop the Steal” rally in Michigan, prosecutors say Kelley told the crowd, “Covid-19 was made so that they can use the propaganda to control your minds so that you think, if you watch the media, that Joe Biden won this election. We’re not going to buy it. We’re going to stand and fight for America, for Donald Trump. We’re not going to let the Democrats steal this election.” Investigators tracked Kelley’s movements on Capitol grounds through news and online videos, reconstructing a timeline they say includes him waving other people towards the stairs to the Capitol. In many images, prosecutors say Kelley wore aviator sunglasses, a black baseball cap with an American flag, a black coat and a red watch strap. Witnesses who know Kelley positively identified him in photos from Jan. 6, 2021. Kelley was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Knowingly Engage in any Act of Physical Violence Against Person or Property in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Willfully Injure or Commit any Depredation Against any Property of the United States

summary: David Walls-Kaufman came to the attention of the FBI after he was named in a civil lawsuit related to the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol, court documents show. Screenshots used to identify Walls-Kaufman in that suit, found by the Sedition Hunters, showed Walls-Kaufman in what the FBI calls a “scuffle” with law enforcement. Prosecutors say he wore a red, white and black motorcycle jacket, which they say can also be seen in a youtube screenshot of Walls-Kaufman discussing his work as a chiropractor. Court documents say Walls-Kaufman appeared on body-worn camera footage and surveillance video, which show him inside the Capitol. Prosecutors say they were also able to confirm Walls-Kaufman’s phone number and that his cell phone used cell sites inside the Capitol. Walls-Kaufman was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Walls-Kaufman pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Dylan R. Cronin took part in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot in the U.S. Capitol along with his father, Kevin Cronin, Sr., and his older brother, Kevin M. Cronin, Jr. Kevin Cronin, Jr. serves with the Washington Army National Guard, Dylan Cronin serves in the U.S. Army Reserves, and Kevin Cronin, Sr. works with the U.S. Postal Service, court documents state. Those court filings indicate that Dylan Cronin can be seen on video kicking an exterior door to the Senate side of the U.S. Capitol, then using a "piece of lumber" to break a windowpane and enter the building. Kevin Cronin, Jr. and Kevin Cronin, Sr. then allegedly entered the building through a nearby door, which had been breached. The elder Cronin, prosecutors state, soon left the building, but his sons later made their way to different parts of the Capitol building, including the statuary hall and crypt. The three men allegedly remained on Capitol grounds for at least two hours after the building was breached.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Damaging Property of the United States
case_updates: Cronin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Kevin Cronin, Sr. took part in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot in the U.S. Capitol along with his sons, Kevin M. Cronin, Jr. and Dylan R. Cronin. Kevin Cronin, Jr. serves with the Washington Army National Guard, Dylan Cronin serves in the U.S. Army Reserves, and Kevin Cronin, Sr. works with the U.S. Postal Service, court documents state. Those court filings indicate that Dylan Cronin can be seen on video kicking an exterior door to the Senate side of the U.S. Capitol, then using a "piece of lumber" to break a windowpane and enter the building. Kevin Cronin, Jr. and Kevin Cronin, Sr. then allegedly entered the building through a nearby door, which had been breached. The elder Cronin, prosecutors state, soon left the building, but his sons later made their way to different parts of the Capitol building, including the statuary hall and crypt. The three men allegedly remained on Capitol grounds for at least two hours after the building was breached.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cronin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Kevin M. Cronin, Jr. took part in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot in the U.S. Capitol along with his father, Kevin Cronin, Sr., and his younger brother, Dylan R. Cronin. Kevin Cronin, Jr. serves with the Washington Army National Guard, Dylan Cronin serves in the U.S. Army Reserves, and Kevin Cronin, Sr. works with the U.S. Postal Service, court documents state. Those court filings indicate that Dylan Cronin can be seen on video kicking an exterior door to the Senate side of the U.S. Capitol, then using a "piece of lumber" to break a windowpane and enter the building. Kevin Cronin, Jr. and Kevin Cronin, Sr. then allegedly entered the building through a nearby door, which had been breached. The elder Cronin, prosecutors state, soon left the building, but his sons later made their way to different parts of the Capitol building, including the statuary hall and crypt. The three men allegedly remained on Capitol grounds for at least two hours after the building was breached.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Cronin pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Leslie Gray allegedly took part in the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021 along with two friends from Florida named Luis Hallon and Traci Isaacs. Federal prosecutors state in court documents that Isaacs said Gray had applied for membership with the far-right extremist group known as the Oath Keepers in the days before the riot. Gray ultimately breached the Capitol separately from Hallon and Isaacs, the documents state. In one video taken inside the Capitol rotunda, Gray allegedly said, "I am in Congress. This is our house. This is our house!...I don’t know what we are doing now but we are in here. We’ve taken it." Prosecutors say she can also be heard yelling "traitor" at officers protecting the Capitol building. At one point, a police officer tried to stop Gray from moving further into the Capitol, and, prosecutors state, she pushed past the officer. In another video from after the riot, described in court documents, Gray allegedly said, "this revolution that in earnest began today. We will take back our country from the communists...American patriots stormed the Capitol today. I am an American patriot. I stormed the Capitol today." Gray, Hallon and Isaacs were arrested on June 15, 2022.
charges: Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds; Parading in a Capitol Building; Obstruct, Impede, or Interfere with Law Enforcement Officer; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding.

summary: Traci Isaacs allegedly took part in the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021 along with two other people from Florida - her husband, Luis Hallon, and her friend, Leslie Gray. Federal prosecutors allege that Isaacs had first joined the far-right extremist group known as the Oath Keepers in 2016, but she stopped paying for an annual membership after one year. In the days prior to the Capitol riot, Isaacs allegedly paid for a new membership with the group. Prosecutors allege that "she wanted access to the Oath Keepers forums in order to determine if others would be traveling from Florida to Washington, D.C." During the riot, Isaacs and Hallon allegedly went to the east side of the Capitol grounds, because Isaacs had heard the Oath Keepers were gathered there. Isaacs and Hallon then entered the Capitol and remained inside for almost 15 minutes. Later, prosecutors say, Isaacs described her actions that day in text messages, many of which were later deleted. "It was glorious but kinda f***** up. We should have done this differently. We should have occupied the Capitol with demands," Isaacs wrote in one text message, according to prosecutors. "Delete anything I sent you please. Feds are going after people hard," she allegedly wrote in another message. Isaacs, Hallon and Gray were arrested on June 15, 2022.
charges: Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds; Parading in a Capitol Building; Impair a Record or Document for use in an Official Proceeding

summary: Luis Hallon allegedly took part in the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021 along with two other people from Florida - his wife, Traci Isaacs, and his friend, Leslie Gray. Federal prosecutors allege that Isaacs had first joined the far-right extremist group known as the Oath Keepers in 2016, but she stopped paying for an annual membership after one year. In the days prior to the Capitol riot, Isaacs allegedly paid for a new membership with the group. Prosecutors allege that "she wanted access to the Oath Keepers forums in order to determine if others would be traveling from Florida to Washington, D.C." During the riot, Isaacs and Hallon allegedly went to the east side of the Capitol grounds, because Isaacs had heard the Oath Keepers were gathered there. Isaacs and Hallon then entered the Capitol and remained inside for almost 15 minutes. Later, prosecutors say, Isaacs described her actions that day in text messages, many of which were later deleted. "It was glorious but kinda f***** up. We should have done this differently. We should have occupied the Capitol with demands," Isaacs wrote in one text message, according to prosecutors. According to prosecutors, Hallon retained an attorney who told investigators that Hallon "and his wife never had any intention to inflict harm on anyone or take over the Capitol. They only intended to peacefully exercise their rights, or alternatively, to engage in a peaceful protest and eventually visit the Capitol building which appeared to be opened to them at the time of their entrance." Hallon, Isaacs and Gray were arrested on June 15, 2022.
charges: Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds; Parading in a Capitol Building.

summary: Frank Joseph “Joe” Bratjan, Jr. worked to hide his involvement in the attack on the Capitol, court documents say, with tipsters pointing to deleted social media posts, and moved from New York to Minnesota. The FBI says Bratjan, Jr. was reported by at least four people, three in 2021 and one in 2022. The 2022 tipster pointed investigators to Minnesota, where they said Bratjan, Jr. lived with his mother and worked at a post office. Prosecutors say other tipsters talked about Bratjan’s photos from the Capitol, which they claimed had been deleted. One such tipster gave the FBI a screenshot of an Instagram post, court documents show, in which Bratjan wrote, “we stormed up those steps and into the halls,” of the Capitol. The FBI says they tracked Bratjan through the Capitol via surveillance footage and open source video, looking for a "boxed beard" and red hat. Prosecutors also found an incident that they allege matches up with Bratjan’s mention to a tipster of being tear gassed. Bratjan was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;  Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Todd Tilley’s brother confirmed Tilley’s identity after the FBI showed the brother a screenshot of Tilley inside the U.S. Capitol building, court documents show. Tilley and his brother messaged on Jan. 6, 2021, the FBI says, and Tilley wrote “Pence screwed us over.” Tilley dressed that day in a red hoodie and glasses, an outfit that prosecutors say they tracked through the Capitol building on surveillance footage and public videos. The FBI alleges Tilley was inside the Capitol for approximately half an hour. Court documents show Tilley’s phone records were consistent with this claim. TIlley was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Hatchet M. Speed told his story of the U.S. Capitol insurrection to an undercover FBI employee, court documents show. Prosecutors say Speed admitted to going to the Capitol with friends who are members of the Proud Boys and eventually entering, though he said that wasn’t the plan – he said he simply wanted to listen to speeches. “What the FBI did in advance is they arrested or threatened all the people they knew were going to be the speakers so that there would be no leadership. They wanted to make sure there was no one there … they wanted to maximize the possibility of violence,” Speed said, according to prosecutors. Court documents show when Speed did decide to go into the Capitol, he blamed what he saw as a betrayal by Mike Pence, saying: “I have no respect for people in this building. They have no respect for me.” When he left, the FBI says, Speed claims it was because he thought House Speaker Nancy Pelosi had agreed to a 10-day delay of the vote and an investigation of the election, which was not the case. “It should have gotten to the point where Nancy Pelosi should have resigned out of fear for her life. That’s what should have happened," Speed allegedly said. Court records show investigators used cell records, surveillance footage and publicly available video to track Speed’s time inside the building, which lasted approximately 40 minutes.  According to the FBI, Speed is currently in the Naval Reserves and was recently employed as a software developer at a contractor with the Department of Defense.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Bernard Sirr engaged in an assault on law enforcement in a tunnel at the Capitol, prosecutors say. Court documents show screenshots from a YouTube video in which, investigators say, Sirr can be seen pushing against people assaulting police officers and pressing his hand against a police shield. Sirr left the tunnel, returned, and was then ejected with other rioters, according to the FBI. Prosecutors say they compared photos of Sirr from the Capitol, where he wore a baseball hat with a snake on it, a blue gaiter, glasses, and a coat, to his passport application and a picture from social media. Sirr was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Sirr pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Luke Lints’ mother told FBI agents she was hospitalized after a medical incident while walking to the Capitol and doesn’t know what her son did while she was gone, court documents show. Prosecutors say he was in a tunnel at the Capitol assaulting law enforcement. Court documents include photos of Lints allegedly “holding a police shield and pushing back against police officers.” The FBI referred to Lints, of Traverse City, Michigan, as #GreyBlackFlannel when trying to identify him online, court documents show. Prosecutors say Lints wore a shirt of that description, as well as a knit hat with the letters “PV” on it at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. A confidential human source pointed the FBI toward online videos of Lints at the Capitol, as well as his social media. Court documents show investigators compared Lints’ driver’s license to photos from the Capitol to help confirm the identification. Lints was arrested in June of 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
case_updates: Lints pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Paul Kovacik breached the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, through the Senate wing doors and filmed several YouTube videos over the course of the roughly 25 minutes that he remained in the building. According to the government's court filings, investigators obtained data from Google indicating that Kovacik's phone was inside the Capitol and Kovacik acknowledged breaching the building in a phone conversation with investigators. Prosecutors say they further confirmed Kovacik's presence in the building through surveillance camera footage and police body-worn camera footage. Kovacik was arrested on June 19, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Ahead of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Michael Greene was named an "Operations Leader" for the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers, according to federal prosecutors. He allegedly uses the moniker "whip" and "whiplash." Along with the leader of the Oath Keepers, Stewart Rhodes, Greene allegedly made plans to bring firearms and ammunition to an area of Virginia just outside Washington, D.C., in preparation for the events that day. Prosecutors allege that the Oath Keepers had planned a "Quick Reaction Force," based outside of D.C., which had access to extensive firearms and ammunition. Greene, court documents state, entered Capitol grounds on Jan. 6 and texted an acquaintance just before the first breach of the building: "Storming the capital [sic]." Prosecutors do not allege that Greene entered the Capitol building, but state that he communicated and coordinated closely with Rhodes and other members of the Oath Keepers during the attack. "The [sic] have taken ground at the capital[.] We need to regroup any members who are not on mission,” Greene allegedly messaged other members of the Oath Keepers around 2:14 p.m., shortly after the first breach of the building. At 3:05 p.m., Greene allegedly messaged an acquantance, "Were [sic] storming the Capitol," and "Congress evacuated." Greene was arrested on June 23, 2022.
