charges: Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Tampering with Documents of Proceedings
case_updates: Greene pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Lilith Anton Saer, also known as Drakken Saer, is a computer programmer from Portland, Ore., according to LinkedIn. Several tipsters told the FBI they spotted Saer in open-source videos posted online a day before the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a statement of facts. The videos depict Saer with distinctive blue hair and facial piercings, wearing gloves emblazoned with a large “Q,” which the FBI claims to refer to the QAnon conspiracy theories. On Jan. 6, surveillance footage shows Saer entering the Senate wing of the U.S. Capitol at about 3 p.m. before walking through the Hall of Columns, according to the FBI. Saer was arrested on July 7, 2022, in Portland, Ore.
charges:
Enter and Remain with Intent to Impede or Disrupt an Official
Proceeding in a Restricted Building; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Buildings or Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings

summary: Photos from an FBI statement of facts allegedly show Country Cramer wearing a mohawked helmet and carrying a bullhorn and small baseball bat as he and his brother, Eric Cramer, who is also charged in relation to the riot, approached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021. Country Cramer later told FBI agents they’d seen other rallies turn violent on television and they wanted to protect themselves. Two weeks after the riot, during a phone interview with FBI agents, Country said he waited outside near the Reflecting Pool while his brother Eric went inside. When interviewed again seven months later, Country clarified that he did enter the Capitol to find his brother Eric just inside the doorway. Surveillance footage shows the pair remained inside for a few minutes before exiting to an upper terrace to take photos of the crowd. Country was arrested July 8, 2022, in Martinsburg, W.Va.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: “I guess that’s my trophy,” Eric Cramer replied on Twitter after his daughter posted a picture of a police baton on Jan. 6, 2021, also claiming he “took it from the cop that hit me with it,” according to an FBI statement of facts. Police body-worn camera footage shows Cramer “catching the baton, grasping it, and refusing to relinquish his grip,” according to the FBI statement. The video allegedly depicts Cramer wearing a gas mask and carrying a blue baseball bat in the crowd outside the U.S. Capitol. Two weeks after the riot, Cramer told officers he drove from West Virginia to Washington with his brother “to witness the election-related events.” Cramer also said the crowd of protesters pushed him inside the Capitol, according to the court documents, but he left “after an opportunity to exit the U.S. Capitol building presented itself” and then reunited with his brother near the Reflecting Pool. Seven months later, in August 2021, he told officers that his brother had, in fact, entered the Capitol as well. Surveillance footage shows the pair inside for a few minutes before exiting. He was arrested July 8, 2022, in Martinsburg, W.Va.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Tyler Earl Ethridge posted a video of himself inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents, saying: “Christians, we need to infiltrate every area of society like this. Every area of society like this. Peacefully. But if it takes a little bit of aggression to barge through the walls that Satan separates us from the culture, it’s time for the body of Christ to infiltrate the culture.” Ethridge also sat for an interview with the FBI, in which he described traveling from Colorado to Philadelphia with two other people and meeting a fourth person in Washington, D.C. Ethridge told agents he did not participate in the destruction of barriers outside the Capitol, but investigators say they have video that contradicts that statement. Ethridge was pepper sprayed twice at the Capitol, court documents show, as well as hit in the knee with a rubber bullet. Still, Ethridge spent about half an hour inside the Capitol, prosecutors say, including being pushed back with other rioters out of a hallway between the Capitol rotunda and the Senate chamber. Ethridge also continued to post about his involvement at the Capitol in the months following Jan. 6, 2021, court documents show. He was arrested in July of 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: The FBI found their first trace of John Thomas Gordon because of his head tattoos, court documents show. Investigators say they matched pictures of an individual at the U.S. Capitol to social media images from a tattoo shop in West Virginia. Then in March of 2021, prosecutors say a tipster identified Gordon and said he lives in Davis, W.Va. Court documents indicate Gordon has prior felony convictions related to drugs and firearms. An ex-romantic partner and the local county sheriff both confirmed to investigators that Gordon is pictured in photos from the Capitol on the day of the riot. Gordon allegedly told his former partner that he kicked the doors of the Capitol and threw a weighted ball at the doors - actions the FBI says they matched to videos found online. Gordon was arrested in July of 2022.
charges: Civil Disorder; Destruction of Government Property; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: The FBI alleges that images from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show William Hendry Mellors firing a canister of bear spray toward police officers on a staircase leading into the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. “Took a nice beat down from Washington DC police tonight. Some tear gas and a riot baton. Broken ribs and some stitches needed,” Mellors later wrote on Parler as a caption for a close-up photo of what appears to be his own bloody ear, according to an FBI statement of facts. Mellors told FBI agents in April 2022 that he’d joined some “rabid” protesters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, also mentioning that a group of Proud Boys had asked him to “walk some ladies back to their hotel to protect them from Antifa” during the Trump rally in November 2020. He added that the Proud Boys “seemed like nice people.” When FBI agents interviewed Mellors a second time in May, he said he expected to be arrested and confirmed he brought two canisters of bear spray to Washington. He was arrested on July 18, 2022, in Houston.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Dova Winegeart wielded a "long wooden pole with what appears to be pointed metal attachments," which she swung at an outside door to the House of Representatives. The architect of the Capitol estimated that rioters caused more than $1,000 in damage to the door. The day after the riot, according to court documents, Winegeart texted a friend, "Had to stay in hotel after storm of capital. It got crazy. I did s***," and "Yes we are mad. Yes we want to go inside Capital. It’s our building. Not the governments. We are their bosses but get treated like dogs. I’m done with this government. It’s fight time non stop now. They asked for it.” Winegeart was arrested on July 19, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;  Destruction of Government Property.

summary: According to federal prosecutors, William Stephon Kit recorded a video of himself inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, in which he said, “Where are those goddman [sic] politicians at? [We’re] taking over the goddman [sic] Capitol." At another point, Kit can allegedly be seen on video outside the Capitol saying, "There is a f***ing price to pay for freedom" and "We are here to die for this s*** today." Law enforcement identified Kit as using the name "Semore Views" online, and he allegedly posted videos from the Capitol on his YouTube channel. On that channel, Kit, who is Black, has described himself as representing the "smallest demographic of Trump supporters." Court documents indicate that law enforcement first contacted Kit about his alleged participation in the Capitol riot on Jan. 8, 2021, and Kit acknowledged breaching the Capitol building. He was arrested more than a year later, on Aug. 1, 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Samuel Fontanez Rodriguez of Emmaus, Penn., noticed the media coverage of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. According to court documents, he texted a link to a New York Times article about the attack, which included a photo of people in clothes resembling his and a friend’s, with the text “Flower got CNN. We got NYT.” Rodriguez also shared his involvement with the FBI, prosecutors say, calling in January of 2021 to say he’d been at the Capitol and entered the building for a “short period of time.” Investigators spoke with a friend of Rodriguez who also went to the Capitol, and they say the friend shared a picture that showed the clothes Rodriguez wore: a red beanie and a black hoodie. In other photographs, court documents show, Rodriguez wore a red baseball cap and a black backpack. The FBI executed a search warrant on Rodriguez’s home and took a hat, a black hoodie, and a pair of tan boots Rodriguez said he wore on the day. He told prosecutors he lost the red beanie and his black face mask. Prosecutors say phone records show Rodriguez’s phone using a cell site that covers the area including the inside of the Capitol. Rodriguez was arrested in July of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Rodriguez pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Jerod Bargar illegally brought a 9 millimeter handgun in an American flag holster to Washington, D.C., which he then dropped outside the U.S. Capitol on Capitol grounds during the rioting. Police officers recovered the gun from the ground around 2:30 p.m. and, according to court papers, managed to later trace the gun to Bargar. During an interview with law enforcement, Bargar allegedly admitted that he brought the gun with him - despite not having a license to carry in Washington, D.C. - for “self-protection" while going to the “belly of the beast." Court papers indicate that the gun had a cartridge in the chamber, and a magazine that held more than 10 rounds, which is illegal in the District of Columbia.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Unlawful possession a pistol, firearm, or ammunition outside their home or place of business, in the District of Columbia, without a valid license and registration certificate issued by the District of Columbia; Unlawful possession, sell, or transfer any large capacity ammunition feeding device, in the District of Columbia

summary: Kasey Von Owen Hopkins answered questions from the FBI when they visited his home in Kansas City, Kan., court documents show. He described going to Washington, D.C., for the Stop the Steal rally, prosecutors say, and then walking to the U.S. Capitol building. He also showed investigators a picture of his clothes from Jan. 6, 2021, which included a red baseball cap with the words “Trump Train,” a gray hoodie, a black vest, and blue jeans. Investigators then tracked a person wearing those clothes through Capitol surveillance footage, court documents show. Prosecutors allege that Hopkins entered first through a fire door and later went into a senator’s office, walked through the crypt, and used his phone to record. The FBI says they served search warrants to AT&T and Apple, which produced phone records showing Hopkins’ phone in an area that includes the inside of the Capitol, and photos from D.C. on Jan. 6, 2021. Hopkins was arrested in August of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Derek Sulenta was brought to the attention of the FBI by a relative who sent the bureau pictures from Sulenta’s Facebook page, court documents show. After getting a search warrant for Sulenta’s account, investigators say they found a picture captioned “Took this from inside the capital building” and posts reading “I’ll be there Jan 6th to support the president no matter what happens.” Prosecutors say a later post read “Dude we breached the capital building.” Court documents allege that Sulenta spent about 47 minutes inside the Capitol, during which time he talked on the phone and took photos. Prosecutors say this can be seen in surveillance footage and a Youtube video. Sulenta was arrested in August of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: James Robinson told FBI agents his martial arts instincts to help people kicked in on Jan. 6, 2021, when he heard screams and cries for help near the U.S. Capitol. According to an FBI statement of facts, Robinson caught a ride with friends from the Philadelphia area that morning “to listen to speeches,” but he got separated from them and was then “sucked into a large group of people who were trying to gain access into the Capitol.” Surveillance footage shows Robinson carrying a velvet rope around the Capitol Rotunda for several minutes “enthusiastically pumping his fists into the air while appearing to yell out,” according to the FBI statement. He was arrested on Aug. 5, 2022, in Fort Washington, Pa.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Robinson pleaded Not Guilty to all charges

summary: Shawndale Chilcoat came under investigation after the FBI received “numerous” tips about her and her husband Donald’s involvement on Jan. 6, 2021, according to the bureau. Court documents state that tipsters said Chilcoat posted messages, videos and photos on Facebook, including: “OK so antifa is being blamed for breaking windows and storming congress. Um no, it was us I was with them and couldn't be more proud. Please stop giving them credit and realize trumps side has crazies too and they should stew on that for awhile." Investigators compared Chilcoat’s Ohio driver’s license photo to surveillance footage from the U.S. Capitol, and say she can be seen in the footage wearing jeans, a black jacket and a navy beanie with white and red stitching. According to court documents, the FBI served a search warrant to Facebook and found a video of Chilcoat that she sent eleven times to other people, in which she says: “I'm right at the top of the congress . . . we're going to show them how they need to vote today.” Chilcoat and her husband were both arrested in August of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings; Obstruction or Impeding Any Official Proceeding

summary: Donald Chilcoat came under investigation after the FBI received “numerous” tips about him and his wife Shawndale, according to the bureau. Court documents show the FBI served a search warrant to Google, which led them to records showing a device associated with Chilcoat’s email as being inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Investigators also served a search warrant to Facebook, and found a video Chilcoat allegedly narrated at the Capitol, saying, “we’re getting ready to go up that scaffolding into the capitol building here. People climbing everywhere. Crazy s*** man. Crazy s*** here... we’re going into the capitol building now.” Prosecutors say they compared Chilcoat’s Ohio driver’s license to images from Capitol surveillance footage and that Chilcoat can be seen in that footage wearing jeans, a black jacket, and a red “Trump” beanie. A tipster who knows Chilcoat and his wife personally positively identified them in images from the Capitol, court records state. Chilcoat was arrested in August of 2022.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings; Obstruction or Impeding Any Official Proceeding

summary: Surveillance footage from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show Antonio Lamotta entering the U.S. Capitol through the east Rotunda doors, prosecutors allege. Police body camera footage allegedly captured an image of Lamotta's face as law enforcement attempted to push rioters out of the building. Lamotta was arrested in Chesapeake, Va., on August 16, 2022, in connection to the Capitol riot. But this wasn't his first time being arrested: Two days after the 2020 presidential election, Lamotta was arrested for carrying a firearm without a license, court records state. The FBI agent that interviewed Lamotta after that arrest positively identified him in the images and videos captured by cameras in the Capitol.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: According to court documents, Landon Manwaring is charged in relation to the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021. He is accused of having "willfully and knowingly paraded, demonstrated, and picketed" in the Capitol.
charges: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
case_updates: Manwaring pleaded Guilty to the charge

summary: A neighbor identified Joseph Leyden in photos from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, according to an FBI statement of facts. After the crowd knocked over metal barriers, police body-worn camera footage allegedly shows Leyden lunging and pushing a police officer before retreating into the crowd. Court documents say Leyden was dressed in a sweatshirt embroidered with the words “Trump 2020” and that he wore a blue flag draped around his neck as a cape. Leyden was arrested Aug. 23, 2022, in La Grange, Ill. His brother Daniel Leyden was also arrested on Aug. 23 in Chicago.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Aiding and Abetting;  Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: A witness identified Daniel Leyden among photos of the crowd at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Court records indicate Leyden helped push metal bike racks being used as barricades into two Capitol Police officers, pinning one underneath and knocking another officer unconscious. The FBI also says records from the Illinois Tollway, Chase Bank and Verizon appear to show that Leyden traveled from the Chicago area to Washington, D.C., between Jan. 5 and 7, 2021. Leyden was arrested Aug. 23, 2022, in Chicago. His brother Joseph Leyden was also arrested on Aug. 23 in La Grange, Ill.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Aiding and Abetting; Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: Kaleb Dillard went to the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, “to strike fear into the politicians,” according to an FBI tipster who claims they spoke with Dillard the day after the riot. Security footage shows Dillard grabbing a police officer from behind and throwing him to the ground before pushing a second officer in the chest near the East Rotunda doors at about 2:30 p.m. that day, according to an FBI statement of facts. Court records indicate that the second officer later told the FBI that Dillard began yelling at him when he tried to secure the Rotunda doors, claiming that he’d been in the military. Images from the Department of Defense’s media repository, DVIDS, identify Dillard as a combat videographer with the U.S. Marine Corps, with the most recent photos taken in 2019. He was arrested Aug. 23, 2022, in Columbiana, Ala.
charges: Assaulting Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;  Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Bobby Wayne Russell, of Falkville, Alabama, went to the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, with his wife Deborah, prosecutors say. Russell wore a red “Alabama Crimson Tide” hoodie, a brown coat, a red and white hat, and jeans, court documents show – an outfit that investigators say can be seen in body worn camera footage from law enforcement. Prosecutors allege that Russell pushed against a bike barricade with his back, was pepper sprayed by law enforcement, and grabbed onto the barrier. Court documents show that when the barriers broke apart, Russell held on to the barrier while grabbing an officer’s jacket, causing them both to fall. According to the FBI, Russell and his wife later stood near the Senate wing doors until police formed a line to clear the area. Prosecutors say Russell once again pushed against law enforcement, this time against their shields. Court documents show Russell told officers, “I’m not scared of you and I’m not weak” as well as, “there’s more of us than you guys, you’re gonna lose.” Investigators say Russell posted pictures of himself in D.C. on Facebook and that records from a search warrant to Google were consistent with Russell’s phone being within the restricted grounds of the Capitol. Russell was arrested in August of 2022.
charges: Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Preller is a “self-described” member of a Florida-based militia group known as the “B Squad” - an apparent reference to an “alternate plan” in the case that former President Donald Trump could not remain in power. The “B Squad,” court documents state, adheres to the anti-government pro-militia ideology of the Three Percenters. In December 2020, members of the “B Squad” allegedly distributed a message about the upcoming protest on Jan. 6, 2021  stating that a Three Percenter group was “responding to the call from President Donald J. Trump to assist in the security, protection, and support of the people as we all protest the fraudulent election and re-establish liberty for our nation.” A leader of the “B Squad,” identified in court documents only as “B Leader,” then coordinated travel and booked a block of rooms at a hotel in Washington, D.C, and encouraged group members to bring “defensive tools” including knives, a taser, pepper spray, and a metal baton. On Jan. 6, 2021, Preller allegedly wore a blue shirt with the words “WATERBOARDING INSTRUCTOR,” goggles, a helmet, and a “green tactical vest with a chemical spray irritant attached to the front.” Prosecutors say that Preller and other members of the “B Squad” confronted police guarding the tunnel on the west side of the U.S. Capitol and joined with the mob as they pushed police in a “heave-ho” effort to try to force their way into the building. Police then allegedly repelled Preller and others, and Preller picked up a police shield belonging to the U.S. Capitol Police. Later that year, Preller told a female acquaintance that he was getting a divorce, and added, “that tends to happen when the FBI shows up at your door,” court documents state. Other messages from Preller described in court documents referred to the pro-Trump conspiracy theory known as QAnon, and stated “continuing to build my 3% army so I can overthrow the federal government."
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Benjamin Cole is part of a Florida-based militia group known as the “B Squad” - an apparent reference to an “alternate plan” in the case that former President Donald Trump could not remain in power. The “B Squad,” court documents state, adheres to the anti-government pro-militia ideology of the Three Percenters. In December 2020, members of the “B Squad” allegedly distributed a message about the upcoming protest on Jan. 6, 2021 stating that a Three Percenter group was “responding to the call from President Donald J. Trump to assist in the security, protection, and support of the people as we all protest the fraudulent election and re-establish liberty for our nation.” A leader of the “B Squad,” identified in court documents only as “B Leader,” then coordinated travel and booked a block of rooms at a hotel in Washington, D.C, and encouraged group members to bring “defensive tools” including knives, a taser, pepper spray, and a metal baton. On Jan. 6, 2021, Cole allegedly joined with other members of the “B Squad” in confronting police guarding the tunnel on the western side of the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors say the group tried to push the police line with a “heave-ho” effort that successfully allowed rioters deeper into the tunnel before they were eventually repelled.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds

The “B Squad,” court documents state, adheres to the anti-government pro-militia ideology of the Three Percenters. In December 2020, members of the “B Squad” allegedly distributed a message about the upcoming protest on Jan. 6, 2021 stating that a Three Percenter group was “responding to the call from President Donald J. Trump to assist in the security, protection, and support of the people as we all protest the fraudulent election and re-establish liberty for our nation.” A leader of the “B Squad,” identified in court documents only as “B Leader,” then coordinated travel and booked a block of rooms at a hotel in Washington, D.C, and encouraged group members to bring “defensive tools,” including knives, a taser, pepper spray, and a metal baton. On Jan. 6, 2021, Crowley allegedly joined with other members of the “B Squad” in confronting police guarding the tunnel on the western side of the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors say the group tried to push the police line with a “heave-ho” effort that allowed rioters deeper into the tunnel before they were eventually repelled.

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Jonathan Rockholt is part of a Florida-based militia group known as the “B Squad” - an apparent reference to an “alternate plan” in the case that former President Donald Trump could not remain in power. The “B Squad,” court documents state, adheres to the anti-government pro-militia ideology of the Three Percenters. In December 2020, members of the “B Squad” allegedly distributed a message about the upcoming protest on Jan. 6, 2021 stating that a Three Percenter group was “responding to the call from President Donald J. Trump to assist in the security, protection, and support of the people as we all protest the fraudulent election and re-establish liberty for our nation.” A leader of the “B Squad,” identified in court documents only as “B Leader,” then coordinated travel and booked a block of rooms at a hotel in Washington, D.C, and encouraged group members to bring “defensive tools,” including knives, a taser, pepper spray, and a metal baton.The Justice Department says that on Jan. 6, 2021, Rockholt wore a “tactical vest,” a baseball helmet, and carried “what appeared to be a knife in his front right pocket.” Rockholt allegedly joined with other members of the “B Squad” in confronting police guarding the tunnel on the western side of the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors say the group tried to push the police line with a “heave-ho” effort that allowed rioters deeper into the tunnel before they were eventually repelled.
charges: Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds

summary: Federal prosecutors allege that Tyler Bensch is part of a Florida-based militia group known as the “B Squad” - an apparent reference to an “alternate plan” in the case that former President Donald Trump could not remain in power. The “B Squad,” court documents state, adheres to the anti-government pro-militia ideology of the Three Percenters. In December 2020, members of the “B Squad” allegedly distributed a message about the upcoming protest on Jan. 6, 2021 stating that a Three Percenter group was “responding to the call from President Donald J. Trump to assist in the security, protection, and support of the people as we all protest the fraudulent election and re-establish liberty for our nation.” A leader of the “B Squad,” identified in court documents only as “B Leader,” then coordinated travel and booked a block of rooms at a hotel in Washington, D.C, and encouraged group members to bring “defensive tools,” including knives, a taser, pepper spray, and a metal baton. On Jan. 6, 2021, “Bensch wore a tactical vest, as well as a military-style helmet with goggles and a black gas mask,” along with “a chemical irritant in front of the vest,” the Justice Department said. While other members of the “B Squad” allegedly pushed on the police line guarding the tunnel on the west side of the Capitol, Bensch “remained just outside.” After police successfully repelled the group, Bensch “used one of his chemical irritants to spray the face of an individual who was an unknown member of the crowd, even though that person posed no threat to him,” the Justice Department stated.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds

summary: Weston Sobotka was brought to the attention of the FBI by two colleagues, court documents show. The first tipster sent a screenshot of a text exchange that included a selfie of a person they alleged was Sobotka inside the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. The second tipster alerted the FBI that Sobotka had shown photos to others from when he was inside the Capitol during the riot, court documents indicate. Sobotka's drivers license photo was run through a government database containing digital multimedia from the riot. According to court records, a match was returned showing an individual outside the East Front of the Capitol. Further analysis of U.S. Capitol Police CCTV footage allegedly showed a person inside the Capitol that matched the clothes and appearance of Sobotka from the selfie sent in by the first tipster. A search of Sobotka's social media accounts also allegedly returned a positive match between him and footage from the Capitol riot.
charges: Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

summary: Jonathan Copeland was identified to the FBI in the days after the riot at the U.S. Capitol by a witness who said they'd seen him in footage of the day shot by CBS news, court documents indicate. A second witness months later also contacted law enforcement about him. The FBI interviewed Copeland, who said he'd traveled to Washington, D.C., that day with another person he'd met online and went to the rally early in the morning. Court documents indicate he left the speech early and walked with others to the Capitol, where he followed a group of people climbing the scaffolding and went through an open door into the building where he witnessed a standoff between police and rioters. While he was inside, Copeland said he received a phone call from the person he'd traveled with that day, who told him, "Son, you know what you're doing is a crime," according to court records. After that, he said he retraced his steps and a police officer directed him to exit thorugh a window. An open source search of images from Jan. 6, 2021, by law enforcement appear to show Copeland in a variety of places during the day. Videos and photos allegedly show Copeland advancing past barricades, ignoring commands from law enforcement, and joining other rioters in pushing a large, metal "Trump" sign into a line of police. Copeland told law enforcement officers during the interview with them that he felt remorse for his actions, which is why he deleted his accounts and disposed of his cellphone.
charges:
Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; Civil Disorder
Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Buildin
